title: Underground Toronto
shortdescription: Toronto has one of the most extensive underground walkway systems in the world. Roughly 30km of pathways connect over 50 buildings within the downtown core! Come explore how it all started and how to orient yourself in this maze.
longdescription:
Toronto has one of the most extensive underground walkway systems in the world. Roughly 30km of pathways connect over 50 buildings within the downtown core. We will talk about the historic origins of the walkways, how to orient yourself in this maze, the public vs. private space issues that we will encounter down here – and why there are so many health food stores and barber shops! 

Disclaimer: This walk is on private property. Filming is not permitted. Photography may not be permitted in all areas. 

Tipp: A printable map of the underground walkways available HERE

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Outside BCE place, in the garden court facing Front street (with the brown lights that look like mushrooms), just outside the Allan Lambert Galleria

team.bio: Lisa Dietrich is an intern architect from Hamburg, Germany, presently living in Toronto. She designs and manages projects for PLANT Architect, and has published articles and illustrations in Spacing, On Site and Stadtaspekte magazines. Lisa dealt with the challenges and opportunities of Toronto's underground walkways as part of her architecture thesis.

accessible-info: Officially, the walkways are fully accessible. In practice, it will prove difficult.
accessible-transit: Take the subway to Union Station, follow the PATH to BCE place / Brookfield place, take the escalator up into the Galleria and exit facing Front street.
accessible-parking: Valet parking at the Royal York Hotel and other paid parking lots nearby
accessible-find: The tour guide will be wearing a signal colour construction vest.

title: Landscape Archaeology of Garrison Creek
shortdescription: The walk will focus on finding clues that reveal the original, pre-urban, landscape of Garrison Creek!
longdescription: This Jane's Walk will focus on finding clues in the urban fabric (such as changes in finish floor levels,  subsidence, sewer access points etc.) that reveal the original typography - recognizing that much of the recoverable landscape is a human artifact and that the extraction/brick making industry significantly altered the original landscape of Garrison Greek.  The walk applies the techniques used by British landscape archaeologists to an urban environment.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: North West Corner of Bloor St. West & Christie St. at Christie Pits Park.

team.bio: Jon Harstone is an author and local historian who lives in the west end of Toronto. With a background in architectural history and archaeology, Jon is a former board member of Heritage Toronto (formerly the Toronto Historical Board) and the former Chair of the Toronto Local Architectural Conservation Advisory Committee (LACAC).  His understanding of urban evolution and landscape transformation comes from his experience developing affordable housing.

accessible-transit: Exit at Christie Subway Station.
accessible-parking: Limited free parking on side streets.
accessible-find: To be determined.

title: Long Branch: Etobicoke Creek to the Lakeshore Hospital Grounds
shortdescription: "We can think of Long Branch as a lost beach resort area, with turrets, verandas, and porches," says local resident David Switzer. "Here you still have buildings that look like there’s sand in front of them, not lawns."
longdescription:
Long Branch is located on the shores of Lake Ontario. The shoreline has in the past wandered north of the current location during the Glacial Lake Iroquois phase when Lake Ontario expanded, and south of it during the Admiralty Lake phase when the lake contracted.

Long Branch once served as a resort area for summer cottagers and weekend visitors, beginning with the founding of the Long Branch Resort.

"We can think of Long Branch as a lost beach resort area, with turrets, verandas, and porches,’" says local resident David Switzer. "Here you still have buildings that look like there’s sand in front of them, not lawns."

 

 

The photo that we’ve chosen to publicize the May 4 walk shows Harold Snelgrove, age 2, enjoying a summer’s day in Long Branch in July 1915. Photo credit: W.J. Snelgrove family. We're trying to figure out the location of the photo based on the cottage in the background. If you have any information, please let us know! Click on the photo to enlarge it. Click again to enlarge it further. Use the "Back" button on your browser to return to the page you are now reading.

A current topic of conversation in Long Branch concerns the severances of building lots and the building of large houses on the subdivided lots. On our walk we’ll also discuss the fire that destroyed the Long Branch Hotel in 1958. The fire began when a blowtorch was used to warm up frozen water pipes underneath the building.

The walk begins at Marie Curtis Park at the mouth of Etobicoke Creek, proceeds along Lake Promenade by Lake Ontario and concludes in New Toronto at the Lakeshore Hospital Grounds.

The hospital was known as Lakeshore Psychiatric Hospital when it closed down in 1979. Erving Goffman’s Asylums (1961) provides an overview of the circumstances that would have led people to be incarcerated in such a total institution and what daily life would have been like for inmates and staff.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: East Parking Lot at Marie Curtis Park.

team.bio:
Jaan Pill is a documentary maker and writer with a website called Preserved Stories, which includes a category devoted to Jane's Walk.  Mike James is a retired school principal with fond memories of growing up in the area in the 1960s. 
Mike James and Jaan Pill began publicizing their Long Branch walks with a Jane's Walk table at the Government and Community Services Fair on Sat., Feb. 23, 2013 at Cloverdale Mall. They had several historic maps and photos on display -- openings for great conversations about Long Branch!

accessible-info: Wheelchair accessible
accessible-transit: From Long Branch GO station or Long Branch TTC Loop walk south on Forty Second Street to Marie Curtis Park.
accessible-parking: Free parking is available!

title: Along the Front ROMwalk
shortdescription: "Along the Front" is a panoramic stroll from the site of the crossroads of the early Town of York, at Front and Jarvis St. We walk along Front St., as it became the southern edge of the metropolis that Toronto is to-day. The history of the buildings that we pass is indeed the history of the commerce of Toronto from its earliest days.
longdescription:
Along the Front is a panoramic stroll from the site of the crossroads of the early Town of York, at Front and Jarvis St. We walk along Front St., as it became the southern edge of the metropolis that Toronto is to-day. The history of the buildings that we pass is indeed the history of the commerce of Toronto from its earliest days.

  

The former Bank of Montreal now the Hockey Hall of Fame.

 

Along the Front is one of  many ROMwalks which is an ongoing  free volunteer program of the Department of Museum Volunteers of the Royal Ontario Museum that began in 1980.  Our present walk program runs May to October, Sundays at 2:00 pm and Wednesdays art 6:00 pm. We put out handy schedules of the various walks which are also on the ROM website .

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: In front of the St Lawrence Market, SW corner Front & Jarvis.

team.bio: The Along the Front ROMwalk will be led by members of the ROMwalk team.

title: Long Branch: Etobicoke Creek to the Colonel's homestead site
shortdescription: We begin at Marie Curtis Park and proceed to the Mississauga-Toronto border located some ways to the west of the current channelized version of Etobicoke Creek. a large number of cottages were removed from the flood plain at the mouth of the creek following Hurricane Hazel in 1954.
longdescription:
This walk explores the prehistory and history of Long Branch, on the shores of Lake Ontario, starting with the arrival of Palaeo-Indian nomadic hunters in the area about 10,000 years ago at the end of the last Ice Age. 

The flood plain at the mouth of Etobicoke Creek at Marie Curtis Park, where the walk begins, was once a major wildlife habitat and a scenic beauty location. A cottage community was located in the area until the 1950s 

Hurricane Hazel in 1954 resulted in the loss of seven lives and destruction of many houses on the flood plain. The remaining houses were expropriated and the area was re-purposed as Marie Curtis Park, which is currently undergoing major capital improvements. The bridge over Etobicoke Creek at Lake Shore Blvd. West is also being rebuilt.

The first European settler in the area was Colonel Samuel Smith, a veteran of the American Revolutionary War, who in 1797 built a log cabin where the school grounds of Parkview School are now located. The school, now known as St. Josaphat Catholic School, is at 85 Forty First Street. 

  

The photo, from about 1927, that we've chosen to publicize our walk  shows the radial bridge over Highway 2 (now Lake Shore Blvd. West) at Etobicoke Creek. Photo credit: Durance family. Click on the image to enlarge it. Click again to enlarge it further. Use the "Back" button on your browser to return to the page you are now reading.

The circa 1927 photo (above) features an early version of a Henderson motorcycle, an American make built from 1912 to 1930. Hendersons were popular with police forces. With a top speed of 97 km/hr, they were faster than anything else on the roads.

The walk begins at Marie Curtis Park at the mouth of Etobicoke Creek and proceeds to the Mississauga-Toronto border, located to the west of the current channelized version of the creek. 

South of Lake Shore Blvd. West, the municipal boundary is located where the western branch of Etobicoke Creek used to run in the past, when the creek had two branches, flowing around an island

Before the creek was channelized, the outlet into Lake Ontario was located a considerable distance to the west of its current location. Cottages were located on the island and on a split of land that extended to the Mississauga border.

Many people have stories to share about Long Branch. At the Feb. 26, 2013 meeting of the Etobicoke York Community Council, by way of example, Deputy Mayor Doug Holyday briefly shared some great stories related to the house in Long Branch that his grandfather purchased in 1919.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Marie Curtis Park at Lake Promenade and Forty Second Street

team.bio:
Jaan Pill is a documentary maker and writer with a website called Preserved Stories, which includes a category devoted to Jane's Walk.  Mike James is a retired school principal with fond memories of growing up in the area in the 1960s. 
Mike James and Jaan Pill had a Jane's Walk table at the Government and Community Services Fair on Sat., Feb. 23, 2013 at Cloverdale Mall. The Fair offered a great opportunity for conversations about how Jane's Walks serve as walking conversations, whereby residents can share what they know about their communities.

accessible-info: Wheelchair accessible
accessible-transit: From Long Branch GO station or Long Branch TTC Loop walk south on Forty Second Street to Marie Curtis Park.
accessible-parking: Free parking

title: Fish and Storms and Energy Fields
shortdescription: An amble through the Portlands to Cherry Beach to recount the landscape and development history of Fisherman's Island and a sacred energy centre for the Ojibwe.
longdescription: I want to take you on a stroll along Cherry St in the Portlands, ending up on Cherry Beach.  We will recount the history of this urban geography from the marshes of Ashbridges Bay, to Fisherman's Island, to the development of the Portlands, and the long sacred spiritual and energy centre for First Nations people.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Cherry Street Restaurant, 275 Cherry St, Toronto

team.bio: Todd Smith is a landscape architect and arborist working in Toronto.  He thinks trees are very cool and seeks to balance the needs of human and non-human systems in his design practice.

accessible-transit: 72 Pape bus

title: Down the Lower Don Trail
shortdescription: Evergreen Brick Works to Chinatown East-Riverdale Park to 107 Villiers Street via the Lower Don Trail
longdescription:
This walk will also occur on the same day as the TRCA’s Paddle the Don, and hikers will get to cheer the paddlers on down the river!

 

 

Walk proceeds down the Lower Don Trail from Pottery Road, past Todmorden Mills, Helliwell’s Hill wetland, Chester Springs March, Riverdale Park and the new Bridgepoint Health building and ends at the new 170 Villiers Street, a parkette found at the northwest corner of Villiers Street and Don Roadway. Hikers will have a chance to join the Manulife Paddle the Don Take-out Party, where lunch and refreshments will be available for purchase.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Evergreen Brick Works

team.bio: The walk will be lead by Evergreen staff. Evergreen is a national charity whose mission is to inspire and enable action to green cities. As one of our newest initiative, Evergreen, along with the City of Toronto, the TRCA and many other diverse partners, is working to transform the Lower Don into an innovative green space for Torontonians. Fore more about this project: http://info.evergreen.ca/en/ecw

accessible-info: Some stairs and slopes, woodland path which may be rough or muddy.
accessible-transit: Take the shuttle bus from Broadview Station. Map and times: http://ebw.evergreen.ca/visit/getting-here/bus/shuttle-bus-schedule
accessible-parking: Paid parking at Evergreen Brick Works available

title: Returning to Nature in Your City
shortdescription: Explore nature nestled in the heart of Toronto with a Jane's Walk through the Evergreen Brick Works, Moore Park Ravine, and Rosedale.
longdescription: This walk starts at Evergreen Brick Works then proceeds up the Mud Creek section of the Beltline Trail to Moore Avenue, then circles back through historic North Rosedale to Chorley Park and back to Evergreen Brick Works.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Evergreen Brick Works, Watershed Wall

team.bio: The walk will be lead by Evergreen staff. Evergreen is a national charity whose mission is to inspire and enable action to green cities. Find out more about us and Evergreen Brick Works here: http://ebw.evergreen.ca

accessible-info: rough terrain, slopes and hills, sidewalks
accessible-transit: Take the shuttle bus from Broadview Station. Map and times: http://ebw.evergreen.ca/visit/getting-here/bus/shuttle-bus-schedule
accessible-parking: Paid parking available on site.

title: Walking the Don: 200 years of change along the river
shortdescription: In the 1790s, the Don Valley was wild and unspoiled. Over the next two centuries, the river was harnessed, channeled, polluted, moved, and ignored. Join us for a walk through the Lower Don trail system from Riverdale Park to Todmorden Mills and see how humans have impacted the valley – and how it is being reclaimed as a vital green space at the heart of the city.
longdescription: In the 1790s, the Don Valley was wild and unspoiled. Over the next two centuries, the river was harnessed, channeled, polluted, moved, and ignored. Join us for a walk through the Lower Don trail system from Riverdale Park to Todmorden Mills and see how humans have impacted the Don Valley – and how it is being reclaimed as a vital green space at the heart of the City.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: South end of Riverdale Park East, by St Matthews Clubhouse

team.name-first: Lori Zuppinger, Todmorden Mills Heritage Site
team.bio: Lori Zuppinger is a historic interpreter based at Todmorden Mills Heritage Site. As a historian, she's interested in the evolution of Toronto; as a walker and runner, she's always looking for interesting ways to navigate the city. Jane's Walk is a chance to bring the two together.

accessible-info: Flight of stairs descending from Riverdale Park pedestrian bridge to trail
accessible-transit: 504 King or 505 Dundas streetcar to Broadview & Langley Ave.
accessible-parking: Limited street parking near start; free parking at end location
accessible-find: A rainbow umbrella.

title: The Literary Don: From Todmorden to the Rosedale Ravine
shortdescription: For generations of Toronto writers and painters, the Don River Valley has served as a metaphor for the City's development as well as its more undesirable underbelly.  Join us for a walking tour through the heart of the ravine, and explore the Valley's place in Toronto's literary landscape from the early 20th century to the present.
longdescription: For generations of Toronto writers and painters, the Don River Valley has served as a metaphor for the City's development as well as its more undesirable underbelly.  Join us for a walking tour through the heart of the ravine, and explore the Valley's place in Toronto's literary landscape from the early 20th century to the present.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Todmorden Mills Heritage Site, 67 Pottery Road

team.name-first: Evan McMurtry, Todmorden Mills Heritage Site
team.bio: Evan McMurtry is a Historical Interpreter for Todmorden Mills Heritage Site who seeks to interpret Toronto's rich urban fabric in ways that shed new light on old features.

accessible-info: Stairs ascending to pedestrian bridge to exit trail.
accessible-transit: From Broadview Subway Station, take any northbound bus to the corner of Broadview and Mortimer, and walk down Pottery Road.
accessible-parking: Free parking at Todmorden Mills.

title: Printers Row and the South Loop
shortdescription: Tour of South Loop extends south from Congress to Polk; Dearborn Park; Film Row @ 14th and Wabash; ending at Roosevelt/State.
longdescription: The old printing houses and railyards of the South Loop have become one of the city's most walkable and urbane neighborhoods over the last 30 years.  Your tour guide has been in the middle of it.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Harold Washington Library, center door on Congress Parkway

team.name-first: Dennis McClendon, Chicago geographer and historian
team.bio: Dennis McClendon is a Chicago geographer and historian, and a certified Chicago tour guide.  He has been involved with South Loop neighborhood issues since 1983.

accessible-transit: CTA: Red or Blue Line Jackson; Green, Brown, Orange or Pink Line Harold Washington Library; buses 29, 36, 62, or 146.

title: Hope Street a Great Street, Liverpool UK
shortdescription: At the heart of the cultural quarter of Liverpool, Hope Street has long been recognised as a 'Great Street' with the breathtaking architecture of the Anglican and Metropolitan Cathedrals and the iconic performance spaces of the Philharmonic Hall and the Everyman and Unity Theatres.  Not the mention the Philharmonic Pub with its listed toilets! This street has real charm and historic character.  Join us on our walking tour and find out what all the buzz is about!
longdescription:
At the heart of the cultural quarter of Liverpool, Hope Street has long been recognised as a 'Great Street' with the breathtaking architecture of the Anglican and Metropolitan Cathedrals and the iconic performance spaces of the Philharmonic Hall and the Everyman and Unity Theatres.  Not the mention the Philharmonic Pub with its listed toilets! This street has real charm and historic character and lends itself so well to supporting modern lifestyles.

Recently awarded a Great Street award by the Academy of Urbanism for the improvements to public realm, the Hope Street Feast festival, the development of new retail and hotels and its Community Interest Company to name just a few changes, this street is well worth a visit!

 With recent planning approval to develop student accommodation on the street the street is facing fresh challenges of supporting the needs of the future whilst retaining and enhancing the areas charm and character.

 This tour is being organised by the Royal Town Planning Institutes' North West Young Planners (NWYP) Please join us on our walking tour of Hope Street and see why this street has everyone talking.

Meeting at 6pm on the steps of the Anglican Cathedral, with the tour taking us down the street to the Anglican Cathedral, with a few stops in between. 

You are invited to walk, listen, and tell your own story. At the conclusion of the walk, all are invited to the Philharmonic Pub, to share stories and simply chat over a drink.

Further information on the NWYP here: http://www.rtpi.org.uk/the-rtpi-near-you/rtpi-north-west/young-planners-in-the-north-west/ 

Please email Kim from the NWYP's (kim_cooper@hotmail.co.uk) if you are intersted in attending the tour.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Liverpool Anglican Cathedral

team.bio: Matt Biagetti is as a Chartered Town Planner who has worked in a variety of planning roles for a local authority including development control, planning policy, local plan-making and the management of major development projects.  Matt has worked for Liverpool Vision, the city’s economic development company, since 2004, creating the conditions to attract investment into the city centre.  Matt works closely with key stakeholders in the city centre including businesses, property owners, developers, residents, educational institutions and public sector organisations to support sustainable economic growth, the development of communities and the creation of attractive places.

title: Harbord Village East
shortdescription: Explore Harbord Village East in this two-part series on Jane's Walk and Doors Open!
longdescription:
Harbord Village, enclosed by Bloor, Spadina, College, Bathurst, is a neighbourhood of late 19C and early 20C homes (about one quarter of which are members of Harbord Village Heritage Conservation District.) It is bounded by a diversity of retail, dining and entertainment venues and is close to the University of Toronto, Queens Park, Kensington Market, Little Italy and Chinatown.

The 2:00pm walk explores the eastern half of Harbord Village, south to College then north-east to finish at Trinity-St Paul's United Church at Bloor St W and Robert St at 4:00pm.

This is a Doors Open Toronto Jane's Walk, with a reprise of the tour on May 25th or 26th!

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: We'll meet in front of the Brunswick House. (South side of Bloor St W, midway between Spadina and Bathurst)

team.bio:
Tim Grant is the Chair of the Harbord Village Residents' Association.
Richard Longley is a Member of the Harbord Village Heritage Conservation District Directory Committee.

accessible-transit: Bathurst Subway Station

title: The Beltline and Beyond: The Midtown Trail Loop
shortdescription: A BIKE RIDE through 16 km of off-road trails in the heart of Toronto.
longdescription: Did you know that you can cycle a loop that is almost entirely off road right in the middle of Toronto? The trail and ravine systems consisting of the Kay Gardner Beltline Trail, Park Reservation Trail, David Balfour Park, Yellow Creek, Nordheimer Ravine and Cedarvale Park together form a 16 kilometer loop separated by only 1 km of city side streets. These trails story some of Toronto’s most important urban history, as well as reveal our rich natural history and watersheds.  We'll also be riding on top of three of Toronto's 'lost rivers'. Join us as we ride and explore this unique Toronto treasure.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Ben Nobleman Park, across the road from Eglinton West Subway Station

team.name-first: Cycle Toronto Midtown - ride facilitator is Burns Wattie
team.bio: This walk is a collaboration between Cycle Toronto Midtown and Cycle Toronto Ward 21.  We are passionate about cycling, our city, and our trails. Burns Wattie is the facilitator of the walk and is a member of Cycle Toronto Midtown. Catch us at http://cycleto.ca/ward/22 or on Twitter @CycleTOMidtown.

accessible-info: Accessibility and conditions: This is a cycling, not a walking tour - approximately 16km of light riding. You do need a bicycle in reasonable shape. Although the ride is almost entirely on trails, they are generally smooth and rideable  by most bikes. The most challenging part will be the hill leading out of the Yellow Creek trail up to Avoca. The section between Avoca and Russell Hill Road is the only section on city side streets, and riders are expected to follow the rules of the road.
accessible-transit: Across the road (south side) from Eglinton West Station
accessible-parking: Nearby on street parking and municipal lot on northeast corner of Eglinton West and the Allen Road
accessible-find: We will meet at the enormous picnic table in the middle of Ben Nobelman park.

title: NOT the history of Liberty Village - digging under the skin and behind the curtain.
shortdescription: This Jane's Walk will explore the contrast between Big Data - the things we know, see and experience about a place vs. the Small Data - the questions, insight and yes, history  that we don't know, can't see, never stop to question or couldn't readily find out about our community.
longdescription:
This Jane's Walk will explore the contrast between Big Data - the things we know, see and experience about a place vs the Small Data - the questions, insight and yes history that we don't know, can't see, never stop to question or couldn't readily find out about our community.

As we circumnavigate Liberty Village, we will be exploring this concept in a different way - through narrative and with immersive technology - a smart phone app.

You'll be given a chance to download the app for this walk on lovewhereyouliveToronto.com, one week before the event.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Starbucks in Liberty Village (85 Hanna Avenue)

team.bio:
Lori Hoinkes is interested in the social, environmental and economic sustainability of the communities she lives, works and plays in. As a real estate sales representative and through her involvement in Liberty Village she has uncovered a number of  little known facts about this growning and evolving community.
Rodney Hoinkes is a new media visionary, with a background in landscape architecture and urban design. He is also the creator of some really cool web-based stuff. Although not the walk leader - he created the interactive geo-locating app for the walk - so he deserves props.
Together they will take you on an immersive and interactive tour of Liberty Village like you have never seen it before.

accessible-transit: King Streetcar
accessible-parking: Pay parking lots in the area.
accessible-find: There will be a sign posted at the meeting area.

title: Pioneers, Fox Farms & Buffalo Jumps
shortdescription: Wander through the neighbourhoods of Pumphill, Bayview and Palliser with 82-year-old life-long resident Clancy Patton and friends from the local community association. Our walk was such fun last year, we decided to host it again. Clancy has so many stories, he won't have to repeat himself!
longdescription: From our start at Good Earth Cafe at the Glenmore Landing Shopping Centre, we will walk up to the bike path bordering the Glenmore Reservoir. We'll share stories of how the early settlers used the riverstones to build their farms. Then south on 19th Street to talk about the pioneers who settled the Palliser area and for whom the two schools are named. Then east through Pumphill for a look at the 100+ year old house and  stories about the early residents who built and entertained there. Clancy Patton, a lifelong resident of Pumphill, will share his knowledge and memories of people and places. You'll enjoy his stories; he's as comfortable talking about the paperboy getting stiffed on his Chrismas tip as he is about Calgary's Who's Who using an area residence for their weekend parties.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Good Earth Cafe, Glenmore Landing (corner 90th Ave & approximately 16 St SW)

team.bio:
Clarence (Clancy) Patton was born and raised on a market garden property in what is now Pumphill. At 82 years of age and a lifelong resident, he is the neighbourhoods' local historian, well known and appreciated for his articles in the community newsletter (Deer Neighbour) and his website  http://calgarymemories.com/
Gerrie is on the Board of the Palliser Bayview Pumphill Community Association and volunteered last year to organize the area's first Jane's Walk. It was such a success, she's hosting it again.

accessible-info: Some of the route is a bit hilly but we'll use 96 Ave SW going downhill only
accessible-transit: Bus #80 from Heritage C Train Station; Bus #79 to return. It's also a great bike ride along the pathways
accessible-parking: Glenmore Landing Shopping Centre

title: Humboldt Park
shortdescription: Humboldt Park is one of Chicago's loveliest and most significant parks.  It served as a living laboratory for renowned Prairie style designer Jens Jensen.
longdescription: Humboldt Park is like a tapestry reflecting many interesting and beautiful layers of history.  Architect and engineer William Le Baron Jenney designed the park in 1870.  The northeast corner of the lagoon and its small island's are remnants of his original design.  The park continued to evolve in the late nineteenth century, and there are monuments representing the various immigrant groups that had settled nearby.  The park's most compelling period occurred in the early twentieth century, when the site became a living laboratory for Prairie style landscape architect Jens  Jensen.   A Danish immigrant who lived accross the street from the park, Jensen served as the park’s superintendent in the 1890s.  After he rose to the position of General Supt. and Chief Landscape Architect for the West Park System in 1905, redesigning and completing Humboldt Park provided him with an exciting opportunity.  Inspired by natural Midwestern scenery, Jensen created the park’s prairie river, edging it with native plants, rocky cascades, and stepping stone paths.  He also incorporated Prairie style architecture in to the park, most notably the Boat House and Refectory designed by Schmidt, Garden and Martin.  Ms. Bachrach will bring to life Jensen's contributions and highlight restoration projects throughout the walk.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Humboldt Park Boat House, 1400 N. Sacramento

team.bio: Julia S. Bachrach is the historian and preservationist for the Chicago Park District.  She is the author of The City in a Garden: A History of Chicago’s Parks which was recently published in a second edition.  She is co-author of Inspired by Nature: The Garfield Park Conservatory and Chicago’s West Side and Sounds of Chicago’s Lakefront: A Celebration of the Grant Park Music Festival.  Ms. Bachrach also contributed to other publications such as the Oxford Companion to the Garden and the AIA Guide to Chicago Architecture.   She has curated a number of exhibits including “A Force of Nature: The Life and Work of Jens Jensen” held at the Chicago Cultural Center in 2001-2002.  Since 2010, she has served on the board of trustees to the Illinois Historic Preservation Agency.

accessible-transit: CTA Buses #70, #72, or #52
accessible-parking: Yes

title: Bikes and Boulevards
shortdescription: Meet your City on a bike as you explore the 23rd St. boulevard. Hear about the politics of cycling infrastructure in a city that could be the best year round cycling city in the world!
longdescription: bikes and boulevards

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: 23rd St and Ave. C.

team.bio: Led by Saskatoon Cycles

accessible-info: must ride 5 km on flat with one gentle Saskatoon hill
accessible-parking: on the street

title: Walkable Westmount
shortdescription: Join us for a walk around one of Edmonton's most walkable and historic communities - Westmount
longdescription:
Join us for an afternoon stroll around the community of Westmount.  We will wander the historic streets, check out our interesting parks and poke along 124th Street, learning and sharing some history along the way.

We will start at Westglen Elementary School and wind our way through the community on both sides of 124th Street.

You are invited to walk, listen, and tell your own story. At the conclusion of the walk, all are invited to join us for a coffee or latte at Cafe Tiramisu.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Westglen Elementary School - 10950-127 Street

team.bio: Ian Hosler is a Westmount Resident and as part of his day job with the City of Edmonton, coordinates the Jane's Walks in Edmonton with friends and colleagues.

accessible-parking: Lots of on-street parking available
accessible-find: We'll meet on the front steps of the school, look for our walk leader wearing this lovely orange Jane's Walk T-Shirt

title: Inglewood Urban Village Narratives
shortdescription: What if we told stories about building community and everybody came? Join us for a Jane’s Walk in Inglewood.
longdescription: Inglewood is famous for its historic architecture and arts scene but it’s the people who really make the community. Join us for a walk through the places in Inglewood where history on the urban design front is being made by ordinary citizens doing extraordinary things to protect and preserve the diverse socio-economic character, history and environmental well-being of the ‘hood. Expect to hear some stories!

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Esker Foundation, Art Block, 1011 9th Ave. SE

team.name-first: Andrée Iffrig and neighbours: Rhonda Barber, Pat Abbott, Ed Top, Corinne Dickson, Rebecca Walsh, Madeleine Wakefield and Shirley-anne Reuben
team.bio: Andrée Iffrig is an ambassador for sustainable design and development. She is the author of the Inglewood Design Initiative, Calgary’s first sustainable community plan. She loves celebrating people who make a difference and working with fellow community activists on the greening of Calgary.

accessible-info: We'll be at grade level.
accessible-transit: Buses #1 and #302

title: Beasley Alley Way Walk: Behind the Scenes
shortdescription: You will never know what you will find.
longdescription:
The Beasley Neighbourhood Association will be undertaking a green alley way project. We need your help to develop an alley way inventory of the neighbourhood and characterize according to key elements such safety, green sustainablity, walkabilty , cleanliness etc.

You will never know what you will find.

title: Putting the "Loop" in Marda Loop
shortdescription: Have you ever wondered where the "Loop" is in Marda Loop? On Sunday, May 5th at 2:30 pm join me for a short walk around Calgary's loopiest neighbourhood.
longdescription:
Have you ever wondered where the "Loop" is in Marda Loop? On Sunday, May 5th at 2:30 pm join me for a short walk around Calgary's loopiest neighbourhood. Learn about some awesome Marda Loopers from times past, the people who make it so awesome and loopy today and some of the many cool projects underway for Calgary's coolest 'hood. While there (probably) won't be balloon animals, this tour is certainly family and dog-friendly. 

We will start in front of the Alexander Calhoun Library, stopping along the way at the community association, new fire hall and cSpace (formerly the King Edward School). Then we'll stop by some of Marda Loop's best attractions, learn about the history of the area as well as plans for future development, take a group photo at River Park and make our way back to the library.

Sign up on Facebook for more details.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: In front of the Alexander Calhoun Library (3223 14 St SW)

team.bio:
Julie Phillips is a communications and community engagement professional in Calgary, Alberta. She is passionate about her city and loves taking walks and doing creative things like filming Harlem Shakes. In fact, she will jump on just about any internet meme and try to put a unique Calgary spin on it. This will be Julie's first time hosting a Jane's Walk - and hopefully not the last. 
Connect with Julie:

accessible-info: We will try to stay on sidewalks.

title: From Landfill to Parkland: Exploring the Leslie Spit
shortdescription: A 3 hour walk to explore the Leslie spit, including its history, wildlife and plants.
longdescription:
For both Nature lovers and those interested in exploring Toronto’s unusual “beauty spots”, Leslie Spit (aka Tommy Thompson Park) has a lot to offer; beautiful views of the lake, interesting plants, birds and an ever-changing landscape. Join guides Felicia Cohen and Charles Bruce Thompson for a leisurely 3 hour walk  through the spit, exploring how Nature has colonized a landfill site, and discussing its future. 

 We will meet at 8AM  at the entrance of the park, at the southernmost end of Leslie street, below Lakeshore and Commissioners at Unwin. Please wear comfortable walking shoes, and sun protection, if it is a sunny day. Binoculars are suggested.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Entrance to Tommy Thomson Park is at Leslie St at Unwin Ave.

team.bio:
Felicia Cohen is an experienced tour guide, presenting art tours at the Art Gallery of Ontario. She has a background in Photography, and loves Toronto for its hidden gems for walkers and cyclists; Leslie Spit is one of those gems, and she hopes to share her love of  the place .
Charles Bruce Thompson is a member and outings leader for Toronto Field Naturalists, a with a special affinity for Leslie Spit. He is a bird watcher, bee-keeper, and nutritionist.

accessible-info: Pets are not allowed.
accessible-transit: Queen street car (Queen & Leslie), 83 Jones bus (Commissioners & Leslie)
accessible-parking: Yes, there is on street parking available.
accessible-find: We (Felicia + Bruce) will be wearing red T shirts

title: No Casino: Rethinking Ontario Place
shortdescription: Please join us Saturday, May 4, for a walk to Ontario Place.  The walk will commence at the last stop of the 509 and 511 streetcar routes at Exhibition Place.  The walk is to highlight the historical iconic structures at Exhibition and Ontario Place, accessibility issues to the park, and the importance of public spaces.
longdescription:
The sudden announcement that Ontario Place would close was one of the top local news stories in early 2012.  As the year wore on the discussion has ranged  from Rethinking Ontario Place  to No Casino at Ontario Place.

Please join us Saturday, May 4, for a walk around Ontario Place.  The walk will commence at the last stop of the 509 and 511 streetcar routes atExhibition Place.  The walk is to highlight the historical iconic structures at Exhibition and Ontario Place, accessibility issues to the park, and the importance of public spaces.

Along the route we will discuss not only why a casino at this location would be detrimental to the surrounding community, but also what kind of public space this important area should and could be.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: The last transit stop at the Exhibition Place

team.name-first: Rosario Marchese, Laurie Miller and Peggy Calvert and Special guest appearance: Eberhard Zeidler, Original Architect, Ontario Place
team.bio:
Rosario Marchese is the Member of Provincial Parliament for Trinity-Spadina.
Laurie Miller is the Campaign's Officer for the Ontario Public Service Employees Union (OPSEU).
Peggy Calvert is one of the founders of No Casino Toronto, an independent organization of concerned citizens.

accessible-info: This event is open and accessible to Wheelchairs, Bicycles, Seniors, Children.
accessible-parking: Parking is available at Ontario Place. Please walk north and meet at the loop

title: The Ave We Had: An Alberta Avenue Exploration
shortdescription: Join us for an interactive exploration of the history of one of Edmonton's oldest neighbourhoods.
longdescription:
Have you ever heard of Alberta Avenue? What did you hear? Was it good? or was it something else?

To observe buildings is not to be solely concerned with architecture. Embodied in any given structure are the multiple layers of meaning that stretch through history and tell the story of who we are as a community and as individuals.

Alberta Avenue is an incredibly unique neighbourhood in Edmonton. One of the city's oldest, it has changed in dramatic ways over the years. Today, as the area once again begins to thrive, we are pleased to be able to look back and uncover the layers of experience that make up its character. 

Join us for a walk through the neighbourhood where we will explore the history of the area, but in an attempt to understand the places as they are now.

*If you have a smartphone make sure to bring it as there is opportunity to listen to stories from residents themselves. If not, options will be avalible. 

For More Information: www.theavewehad.org

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Alberta Avenue Community League 9210 118 Avenue

team.bio: Jon Weller is the producer of The Ave We Had history project, a unique community history project that has sought to bring the history of the Alberta Avenue neighbourhood to life through theatre, writing, podcast, oral history and more. Most recently Jon has been developing a multimedia historical walking tour for the area and is looking forward to finally getting to share what he has learned.

accessible-parking: Free parking in community league lot

title: Kitsilano Bee-Line Walk
shortdescription: See Kits neighbourhood from a bee's perspective. Find bee homes and hives; herbs and pollen; and honey!
longdescription:
Kitsilano Bee-Line Walk – Jane’s Walk – May 4, 2013

2pm – Meet at Wired Monk, 4th & Trafalgar

Mary will share her enthusiasm for art, bees and community.

From the Wired Monk, we’ll walk together to Mary’s traffic circle garden at 6th & Trafalgar, which won the most bee and butterfly friendly garden at last year’s Green Streets celebration. If you’d like to pick some herbs, bring along a little bag to put them in. Picking is encouraged.

The walk will include other bee-friendly highlights in the neighbourhood.

In the meantime, do visit my traffic circle garden at 6th & Trafalgar.

I have lots of herbs – feel free to pinch a bit – mason bee houses and a bird art installation made for last year’s Worldwide Bird Art Installation day in the Fall.  And did I mention the solar lights put up for Christmas, but staying as year-round decor.

Mary Bennett

maryinvancouver@gmail.com

RSVP appreciated.   http://kits-bee-line-2013.eventbrite.com/

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Wired Monk Coffee Shop, 4th & Trafalgar

team.bio:
Mary Bennett is a mixed-media artist and community catalyst.
She got interested in bees from a gardener's standpoint and has become quite an afficionado.
Mary has a B.Ed. in Art Education, is involved in many community and creative endeavours.
She only ever intended to do one Bee Walk event, but it's become a "thing". Join her for Walk #7.
Lots more about Mary at www.marybennett.wordpress.com
Mary blogs on eco-arts in Kits at kitsilano.ca

accessible-info: We'll be walking along city sidewalks
accessible-transit: Take #7 or #4 to Trafalgar and 4th.
accessible-parking: on-street parking available

title: Making Riverside: a behind the scenes of Queen East
shortdescription: Take a walk down Riverside’s Historic Queen Street East and have a walking conversation on how things are made in Toronto's Riverside District. Although known for its heritage buildings, award-winning restaurants, and the street that inspired the cult classic Degrassi TV series, Riverside’s secret also lies in its artisans and community builders of many sorts.  Get a behind the scenes view of where and how everything from fashion and furniture designs, to streetscaping and community parks are made in Riverside.
longdescription:
Take a walk down Riverside’s Historic Queen Street East and have a walking conversation on how things are made in Toronto's Riverside District. Although known for its heritage buildings, award-winning restaurants, and the street that inspired the cult classic Degrassi TV series, Riverside’s secret also lies in its artisans and community builders of many sorts.  Get a behind the scenes view of where and how everything from fashion and furniture designs, to streetscaping and community parks are made in Riverside.

Made in Riverside

1. (start) The Ralph Thornton Centre - making community,
2. Bergstrom Originals - making Fashion,
3. Olive & Olives - making olive oil
4. Mac Fab workroom - re-making furniture and home furnishings
5. Hangman Gallery and Studio - making art
6. Quince Flowers - making flower arrangements
7. Streetcar – making homes
8. Joel Weeks Park and TCHC - a community making parks
9. (end) Matt Durant’s Studio -   remaking & reclaiming

Along the way we will explore making streetscapes and what makes a neighbourhood distinctive and inspiring to be in - you'll never look at a street the same way!

 

 Let us know you’re coming: RiversideJanesWalk.eventbrite.com

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Ralph Thornton Centre 765 Queen St E

team.name-first: Morgan Peers, Rachel Conduit & Anjuli Solanki
team.bio:
Morgen Peers, maps and plans neighbourhoods and builds outdoor furniture for the greater good. He is based in the Greater Toronto area, where he works with communities, institutions and governments to create better, more profitable places.
Rachel Conduit, is a local personality instrumental in reviving Toronto’s East End. Among her many initiatives, she has spearheaded local community garden projects, the East End Icon calendar - highlighting the area’s unsung heroes, has organized “The Little Art Show”, and a community East End Bike Ride. She is the owner of the “The Avro” in Riverside and “The Handlebar” in Kensington Market. 
Anjuli Solanki, is the Director of Marketing and Events at the Riverside BIA and has a background in community engagement, public programming and urban research. She has a passion for public spaces and public art.

accessible-transit: You can take the 501 Streetcar to the Saulter St Stop on Queen Street East. You can also take the 504 Streetcar which stops at Queen and Broadview - and walk 2 minutes east
accessible-find: Look out for the red umbrella to find us along the way

title: An Oasis in the City: Glenbrook Ravine Walk
shortdescription: New West's coolest and newest nature path- an oasis in the city!
longdescription:
Ever wanted to take a long walk in a forest inNew Westminsterwhere the pedestrian rules, no cars, no noise- just peace and quiet!  Well, the newly updatedGlenbrookRavineParkoffers this opportunity.  It is located between the old B.C. Pen and the Victoria Hill development.

We will start our walk at the Canada Games Pool and make our way down toRichmond Street.  The Onni Group have done an excellent job of providing a sloping packed pathway at the top end and a stairway up intoBlackberry Lane.

The ravine itself is pretty wild, with ivy and ferns climbing the steep sides, and blackberry bushes cut right up close to the path. It's especially nice in the springtime when the trees are all budding out.

The pathway ends at the bottom at the lovely gardens and pond of the Glenbrook amenities centre. There are side trails that lead up into Victoria Hill and into the BC Pen areas.

Walk time is estimated at one hour round trip. Alternative end points are Queen’s Park via the overpass, Downtown viaColumbia Streetor the Dublin Castle Neighbourhood Pub at the Old Pen site.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Canada Games Pool Entrance

accessible-parking: Lots
accessible-find: I will be holding a red balloon.

title: A Sense of Spadina
shortdescription: An historic walking tour of the former Jewish neighbourhood.
longdescription: Did you know that Kensington Market, the epicenter of Toronto hipsterdom, was once a thriving Jewish village teeming with kosher bakeries, synagogues, and social clubs? Through the OJA’s “Sense of Spadina” Walking Tour, the Jewish life of the past—biographies of its former inhabitants;  the sounds;  the smells;  Yiddish language;  religious, social, and political attitudes—is brought to life.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Anshei Minsk Synagogue, 10 St. Andrew Street

team.bio:
Founded in 1973, UJA Federation’s Ontario Jewish Archives (OJA) acquires, preserves and makes accessible the photographs, films and records that chronicle our province’s Jewish history. The collection documents organizations, individuals, synagogues, schools, summer camps, leisure, athletes, and businesses. As a first-class research institution, the OJA provides researchers with the opportunity to explore the richness of Jewish history found in the records of our holdings. Through exhibitions, programs, and walking tours, the OJA tells the stories of Ontario’s Jewish community.
To see regularly posted photos from the collection, like us on Facebook.

accessible-info: There are steps at the entrance to the Anshei Minsk Synagogue.
accessible-transit: Spadina Streetcar south to Dundas Street. A short walk north to St. Andrew Street.
accessible-parking: Green P parking next to the Synagogue on St. Andrew Street.

title: Historical Walking Tour of Yorkville (Part 2): The Parks of Yorkville
shortdescription: Led by President of The Cultural Landscape Foundation Charles A. Birnbaum and Architect Michael McClelland, this walk will explore three public spaces that have played an important role in the transformation of Yorkville from a one-time bohemian village to the bustling commercial and residential district it is today. This walk will coincide with Doors Open Toronto.
longdescription:
Half a century ago, the village of  Yorkville was a bohemian neighbourhood frequented by artists, poets and musicians. In more recent years, this neighbourhood has transformed into a bustling commercial and residential district. Meandering through a series of parks, laneways and squares, this walk will explore Yorkville's public realm and the impact urban revitalization and landscape architecture projects have had on the evolution of this dynamic neighbourhood.  The stops on this tour will include the Village of Yorkville Park, the Four Seasons Hotel arrival court and garden and Town Hall Square. This walk will coincide with Doors Open Toronto.

 

Image source: land8.com

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: The base of the giant granite rock in Village of Yorkville Park (south side of Cumberland St, between Bellair St and Avenue Rd).

team.bio:
CHARLES A. BIRNBAUM
Charles A. Birnbaum, FASLA, FAAR, is the Founder and President of The Cultural Landscape Foundation (TCLF). Prior to joining TCLF, Birnbaum spent fifteen years as the coordinator of the National Park Service Historic Landscape Initiative (HLI) and a decade in private practice in New York City with a focus on landscape preservation and urban design. His recent projects include two web-based initiatives: What’s Out There (a searchable database of the nation’s designed landscape heritage) and Cultural Landscapes as Classrooms. He has authored and edited numerous publications including the Modern Landscapes: Transition and Transformation series (Princeton Architectural Press, 2012), Shaping the American Landscape (UVA Press, 2009), Design with Culture: Claiming America’s Landscape Heritage (UVA Press 2005), Preserving Modern Landscape Architecture(1999) and its follow-up publication, Making Post-War Landscapes Visible (2004, both for Spacemaker Press), Pioneers of American Landscape Design (McGraw Hill 2000) and The Guidelines for the Treatment of Cultural Landscapes (National Park Service, 1996).
 In 1995, the ASLA awarded the HLI the President's Award of Excellence and in 1996 inducted Birnbaum as a Fellow of the Society. He served as a Loeb Fellow at Harvard’s Graduate School of Design during which time he founded TCLF. In 2004, Birnbaum was awarded the Rome Prize in Historic Preservation and Conservation and spent spring/summer of that year at the American Academy in Rome. In 2008, he was the visiting Glimcher Distinguished Professor at Ohio State’s Austin E. Knowlton School of Architecture. That same year the ASLA awarded him the Alfred B. LaGasse Medal and in 2009 the President’s Medal. Birnbaum is currently a Visiting Professor at the Columbia University Graduate School of Architecture Planning + Preservation and a frequent blogger for The Huffington Post.
 
MICHAEL McCLELLAND
Michael McClelland, OAA CAPHC FRAIC, is a founding partner of E.R.A Architects Inc.  He is a registered architect specializing in heritage architectural conservation, and in particular in heritage planning and urban design.  After graduating from the University of Toronto, Michael worked in the municipal government most notably for the Toronto Historical Board, advising on municipal planning, permit and development applications, and on the preservation of City-owned museums and monuments. 
Well known for his promotion and advocacy for heritage architecture in Canada, Michael was awarded a certificate of recognition from the Ontario Association of Architects and the Toronto Society of Architects in 1999 for his contribution to the built environment and to the profession of architecture.  He has taught at the University of Toronto and Ryerson University, and is the editor of a number of publications including Concrete Toronto (2007).
Michael is the coordinating architect for the Distillery District and the heritage architect for a number of significant Toronto projects including the ROM Renaissance with Daniel Libeskind Studio, the Art Gallery of Ontario Transformation with Frank Gehry, Bridgepoint Health’s conversion of the historic Don Jail, and Evergreen Foundation’s adaptive reuse of the Don Valley Brickworks.

accessible-info: The terrain is generally flat and accessible. Some steps may be encountered during the laneway portion of the walk.
accessible-transit: Bay TTC station. Cumberland St exit (or Bellair St exit and walk half a block west along Cumberland).
accessible-parking: There are two "Green P" lots in the vicinity. One is located at the intersection of Bellair St and Yorkville Ave. The other is accessible from both Cumberland and Yorkville, and is located between Bay and Yonge.
accessible-find: Image Source:  asla.org

title: War, Invasion & Occupation: Fort York and Toronto  during the American Invasions and War of 1812
shortdescription: Some of the most dramatic events in Toronto’s (formerly known as York) history occurred during the War of 1812 - especially during the American invasion and subsequent occupationof April 1813. This Jane's Walk, in and around the Fort York Historic District, will examine some of the main events that took place during this time and the impact  these dramatic events had on the development of our  modern city.
longdescription:
Starting at the canteen at Fort York National Historic Site, this special walking tour explores  some of the most dramatic events in Toronto’s (York’s) history.  During the War of 1812  American forces occupied Toronto on two separate occasions - with the most dramatic occurrence unfolding  in April of 1813  when a bloody battle took place. After this battle  the Americans  occupied  the  town  for over a week.

This tour, in and around the Fort York Historic District, will examine some of themain events that took place during this invasion and occupation  and the  impact  this  had on the development of our city.

You may discover a surprising blend of past and present in the historic landscapes surrounding the Fort. Free admission to Fort York following tour.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: The group will meet next to the canteen/admissions office by the main (west) entrance at Fort York ( off Garrison Rd.).

team.bio: René Malagón has lived and worked in Toronto for the past 25 years, previous to this he worked in Ottawa with National Museums of Canada. In Toronto he has worked in the Museum Section   with the City of Toronto at Historic Fort York and other city run museums.  He has given walking tours  of the areas in and aroundFort York for many years and has  witnessed  the huge changes that have occurred in this historic part of the city.

accessible-info: Aprox. 60% on sidewalks & pavement, 40% on grass including  a couple small hills.
accessible-transit: The BATHURST 511 “Exhibition” streetcar stops at Fort York Boulevard and Bathurst St. Walk west on Fort York Blvd., following the footpath under the Gardiner up to the west gate of the fort. The 509 “Exhibition” streetcar/bus from Union Station stops at Fort York Boulevard and Fleet Street. Walk north on Fort York Boulevard, following the footpath under the Gardiner up to the west gate of the fort. Please proceed to the Canteen to sign in.
accessible-parking: Take the Jameson exit off the Gardiner Expressway and continue east on Lakeshore Boulevard. Continue past Strachan Avenue and turn left at Fort York Boulevard. Take an immediate left at Fleet Street and then an immediate right at Garrison Road. Continue all the way to the parking lot at the end.
accessible-find: Ask for tour leader René  Malagón  at admissions desk.

title: Earth to Sky: Greenglade Area, Sidney, BC
shortdescription: On our walk we will amble between Weiler West and Ocean Drive West, in the Greenglade area of Sidney. We will walk through the light industrial area near the Victoria Airport control tower, visit the graveyard of one of Sidney's pioneer families, the Brethours, as well as a trail through a small urban forest.
longdescription:
This part of Sidney West has a wonderful mix of history and modern innovation. Our tour starts at the 676 Kittyhawk Air Cadet Squadron and then loops past Viking Air Ltd., the Victoria Airport control tower, Dakota Cafe and the Victoria Flying Club as well as the Shell Aerocentre (that's where the rich and famous land their private jets!). We will visit the Brethour family graveyard, established in 1875 and then walk through a small urban forest - and each pull a strand of ivy on the way through.  We will finish the walk with a restorative  lemonade and some cookies, back at my house, near the Squadron hall. The walk will take about 1.5 hours and we'll go rain or shine. The forest path is OK for baby strollers but  not suitable for wheelchairs. There are no stairs on the walk.

Itinerary: 

- Meet 2 pm at 676 Sidney Kittyhawk Air Cadet Squadron at the corner of Dehavilland Way and Canora Rd. We may meet with a representative of the squadron to hear about what the Air Cadets do for young people. 

- Walk past Viking Air Ltd, which may also have a representative give us a quick talk about the company.

- Walk to the control tower and Dakota Cafe, where the Victoria Flying Club will give us a few words. 

- Next to the Shell Aerocentre, where we will stop in, use the washrooms if necessary, and see where John Travolta and the elite land their private jets.

- Walk to Brethour Family Graveyard, where we will ask everyoen to try to find the oldest gravestone. A Brethour family member will be invited to meet us there and say a few words. 

- Walk down to the pocket forest and go through the path to the southeast corner, then trek across the back (south) edge of the play field.

- Take the path over to Redwing and the road out to Brethour Park way, walk down to Epco; Epco to Weiler; weiler to Canora and back to the Squadron. 

- Walkers are invited to end the tour at my house for cookie, lemonade, and discussions!

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: 676 Sidney Kittyhawk Air Cadet Squadron; at the corner of Canora Road and Dehavilland Way (also marked as Anson Drive on Google maps)

team.bio: Hello - Jane Wynne here. I led the first Jane's Walk in Sidney last year and we had a good time. I am a recently retired geologist (Geological Survey of Canada), a runner and a pickleball player. I am also a member of Peninsula Singers and St.  John's United Church.

accessible-info: The forest path is not suitable for wheelchairs.
accessible-transit: There is limited Sunday service on routes 81, 83 and 88 that will get you within a block of the starting location.
accessible-parking: There is ample free parking beside the road.

title: Transit in Nature in Transition
shortdescription: We will be walking through a South Richmond neighborhood originally organized around the transit of the day - trolleys - and designed to bring people's domestic lives out of the city, closer to nature.  How'd that go - and what happened after the tracks were pulled up and the cars started zipping through from further out?  And where is the neighborhood headed now?  Come find out with us on May 4th!
longdescription:
The 5th District Community Action Team would love for you to join us on a walk!

 

We will set out from the new community garden at 34th Street and Forest Hill Ave and proceed through Woodland Heights past old homes and civic buildings to Carter Jones/Fonticello Park, where we may be treated to some virtuoso skateboarding. 

We will head south to Semmes Ave – formerly the trolley line that gave rise to the neighborhood as an early example of transit oriented development.  The bus still runs down Semmes, but the bulk of the traffic now is cars travelling downtown from points further west.

Crossing Semmes we will walk through some of the neighborhood's distinctive alleys - seeing the variety of outbuildings that inspired a book.  We will see a contemporary, “green” house, nestled among the trees, and learn how it relates to its 1920s era neighbors.

We will end close to where we started – at the small commercial node where Semmes, Forest Hill and Dundee meet – right across from Richmond’s first charter school.  Afterwards, come continue the discussion and have a bite at Crossroads Coffee or the Parkside Grill.

.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: McDonough Community Garden

team.bio:
Although I grew up across the River, I have been living in Woodland Heights for the last 15 years.  A recent graduate from NC State's School of Architecture, I went to NYU for undergraduate and got to spend time in Jane Jacobs' part of town, although I didn't know it at the time.  I am currently an intern at Glavé & Holmes Architecture down town.
I've always loved cities, and my homecity Richmond in particular.  Something about the mix, the big picture and the small, random encounter: a diminutive man with an African accent telling a story about lions eating children at 2am at the corner of 12th and Broadway.
I'm looking forward to seeing who shows up, and spending some time walking and thinking about what it means to be in Woodland Heights.

title: The Return of Randolph
shortdescription: We will be walking through the historic, and storied Randolph neighborhood.   This neighborhood was sliced apart when the RMA was built to speed commuters from the suburbs to the city center, just the sort of project that got Jane Jacobs fired up about neighborhoods in the first place.  Since then, with a lot of perseverance by the people, Randolph has been rebuilt.  Come join us May 5th to find out what's going there now.
longdescription:
The 5th District Community Action Team would love for you to join us for a walk!

We will meet at the Joseph Jenkins Jr Funeral Home and make our way through the Randolph neighborhood, which borders on Byrd Park and Oregon Hill, to learn the story of this residential neighborhood where “the People Perservered before the Expressway Came through,” in the words of former City Councilman Marty Jewell.

We will see what remains of the old Civic institutions which nurtured the neighborhood, and see how it has been, and continues to be, rebuilt over the last 50 years.  We will hear from people involved in that struggle, and from people who live there now, what they think of their neighborhood.

Meet us at the Joseph Jenkins Jr Funeral Home (2011 Grayland Ave) at 2pm on Sunday, May 5th and spend an hour or so getting to know this storied part of the 5th District. 

Parking will be available on the street and in the parking lot.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Joseph Jenkins Funeral Home

team.bio:
The Honorable E. Martin (Marty) Jewell has been a lifelong advocate for human rights and civil rights. Marty earned a bachelor's degree in sociology from Virginia Union University, before becoming an  entrepreneur, founding the household cleaning industry in Richmond, and consulting in management and political affairs.  He has been active with the Crusade for Voters, as well as chairman and CEO of a non-profit, VITAL.
 
Marty has lived in the Randolph Neighborhood for the last 20 years.  He has served the 5th District as City Councilman for 3 terms, from 2005 to 2012.  He is committed to fighting for the rights and interests of the elderly, the disadvantaged and the young who often are forgotten people.

title: Heading UpTown!
shortdescription: What's so interesting about a Saturday morning trip to the library?  Walk there with me, and you might be surprised.
longdescription: What's so interesting about a Saturday morning trip to the library?  Walk there with me, and you might be surprised.  We'll start - and finish - in the West End, travelling from Thirteenth Street and Edinburgh to the library and back again.  Along the way we'll snoop through back lanes, wander past the ball park, check out playgrounds, admire public art, and traverse Moody Park (twice).  Our route will utilize a variety of pathways available to pedestrians, and will include stories, details, and diversions.  New Westminster's library is one of my favourite destinations; getting there is part of the pleasure.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Beside the fire hall at 13th Street and Edinburgh

accessible-transit: 112 runs on 12th Street, 101 runs on Eighth Avenue, both one block away.
accessible-parking: On Thirteenth Street

title: Our Past is Our Future
shortdescription: There will be 10 stops along the way with different speakers describing each location and its importance to the history of Carthage.  Refreshments will be servered in the Chamber of Commerce Center.  A special focus this year will be on transportation namely the defunct Canton Carthage Railroad.
longdescription: There will be 10 stops along the way with different speakers describing each location and its importance to the history of Carthage.  Refreshments will be servered in the Chamber of Commerce Center.  A special focus this year will be on transportation namely the defunct Canton Carthage Railroad.
