markers.description: The Breezeway on Courthouse Square

title: Jane's Transit Ride
shortdescription: Take a ride with planners from Calgary Transit and Land Use Planning and Policy to learn about the City's long-term plan for investing in transit services and transit-oriented development to deliver a more liveable and sustainable city.
longdescription:
Interested in talking about transit, planning, sustainability, and the future of Calgary?  Jane's Transit Ride is a tour with staff from Calgary Transit and Land Use Planning and Policy that will explore the future of transit and redevelopment in this city.  Share your thoughts about how new approaches to urban design, transit investments, and real estate can help make Calgary more liveable, vibrant, and sustainable.

While we're on the bus, participate in the conversation about Calgary's new strategy for transit investment, RouteAhead and learn what the future holds for new lines, new technologies, and a new approach to thinking about how we move around Calgary.  When the bus stops, we'll get out and explore past, present, and future transit-oriented development, and talk with the people involved, including planners, developers, and community advocates.

At Westbrook, learn about how the City assembled land and created an area redevelopment plan ahead of the West LRT opening up.  At Brentwood, meet with planners and developers and learn about  the successful creation of a major activity centre focused on transit.  At Bridgeland, visit the completed portion of the Bridges redevelopment and talk about how transit oriented development can be designed to fit into an established neighbourhood.  Finally, in Inglewood, we'll talk about plans for the Southeast Transitway and future transit investments.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Westbrook LRT Station, mezzanine/lobby level.

team.bio:
Jonathan Lea is a planner with Calgary Transit.  His fascination with transit began many years ago while riding electric trolley buses as a youngster.  He believes that transit plays an important role in making communities efficient and enjoyable places to live.  Jon has recently finished working with a team to craft ‘RouteAhead: A Strategic Plan for Transit in Calgary’, which will guide decision-making and capital infrastructure investments in the city for the next 30 years.  More information on RouteAhead can be found at www.routeahead.ca.  Jon’s next projects include updating transit service in the Centre City and analyzing options for new transit vehicle technologies in Calgary.
Desmond Bliek is a planner with the City's Land Use Planning and Policy business unit.  A Calgary native, Des brings perspective from time spent in Montréal and Vancouver to bear on the challenge of attracting more residents, employees, and visitors to the areas within walking distance of Calgary's transit hubs.  As part of a team that creates policy for transit oriented development, Des is working on updating the City's overall strategy for encouraging high quality urban design and transit supportive land uses close to transit, transforming stations into places.  More information on transit oriented development can be found at www.calgary.ca/todplanning.

accessible-info: Tour will be a combination of bus rides and walking.
accessible-transit: Take the West LRT to Westbrook Station
accessible-parking: Parking at the Westbrook Mall is for mall patrons only; limited on-street parking may be available nearby.
accessible-find: We will be meeting at Westbrook Station (inside, ground level), spending some time at Westbrook, and then proceeding by bus for short visits at Brentwood, Bridgeland, and finally Inglewood, where the tour will end with a short walk to the Hose and Hound neighbourhood pub for optional, post-tour conversation.

title: Homer Watson, Scottish Industrialists and Mennonite Farmers -- The Stuff of Lower Doon
shortdescription: Discovering how a neighbourhood changes in 200 years.... Come explore the natural and social history of Lower Doon, a south Kitchener neighbourhood that has been a landing place for immigrants for 200 years!
longdescription:
Explore the neighbourhood at the mouth of Schneider Creek and along the Grand River where settlement began in the early 1800's, forming the basis of a rich social history in south Kitchener.  

On our cultural walkabout we see, discuss and learn stories of some of the foundations of this community, including early train service and the station, the Red Lion Inn, the Doon School of Fine Arts and Willow Lake and Resort. 

We will also learn about how Homer Watson, born in Doon, makes it as a landscape artist. Watson lived and worked in the Watson House Gallery. 

The walk will be a 4km loop.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Public Parking Lot at Homer Watson Blvd/Doon South Drive - Grand River Trail Entrance

team.bio: Janice is an amateur historian and is well-travelled to historic and natural history destinations.  She often leads hikes with local hiking groups to destinations in Southern Ontario and elsewhere.  She is excited to share nuggets of this fascinating neighbourhood of Kitchener-Waterloo.

accessible-info: Not recommended for accessibility devices like wheelchairs & walkers.
accessible-transit: GRT Route #16
accessible-parking: Yes - Homer Watson Blvd at Doon South Drive
accessible-find: Look for the group of people near the trail at the side of the parking lot.

title: Anatomy of a Street Festival: The Birth of Dundas West Fest
shortdescription:
Have you ever wondered what exactly it takes to organize a huge street festival? 

Get an exclusive glimpse at just what it takes to build one from scratch.

Anatomy of a Street Festival will definitely change the way you think about these important, community-building events!
longdescription:
On June 8, 2013, Toronto's hottest neighbourhood will host Toronto's newest street festival for the first time!  

12 city blocks, from the Village of Brockton to Little Portugal, will be closed to vehicular traffic and public transit and the community has been invited to take to the street for the inaugural Dundas West Fest (www.dundaswestfest.ca)

Get an exclusive, insider, once in a (festival's) lifetime glimpse at just what it takes to build one of these behemoths from scratch.

Led by the festival's organizer, Anatomy of a Street Festival: The Birth of the Dundas West Fest will surely change the way you think about street festivals.

A joint project of the Dundas West BIA and the Little Portugal BIA.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Southwest Corner of Dundas Street West and Lansdowne Avenue

team.name-first: Helder Ramos, Coordinator, Dundas West BIA
team.bio: Helder Ramos is the Coordinator of the Dundas West BIA.

accessible-info: Urban sidewalks throughout
accessible-transit: 504 Dundas Street West streetcar or 47 bus from Lansdowne Subway Station
accessible-parking: Some on-street parking and some in the lot at Peter's No Frills, southwest corner of Dundas Street West and Lansdowne Avenue

title: A Poor People's History of East Downtown Toronto
shortdescription: The House of Industry was Toronto's first "poor house," which dominated the lives of the poor people in East Downtown Toronto for over a century. This Jane's Walk will explore the history of the poor in this area, including the relationships between the poor and the wealthy, what happened to the slums of Cabbagetown, and more!
longdescription: The walk will explore the history of poor people in East Downtown Toronto going back to Toronto's first poor house, the House of Industry. How did this poor house come to dominate the lives of Toronto's poor for over a century? What was the relationship of Toronto's wealthy residents to the unemployed who relied on the House of Industry? What happened to the slums of Cabbagetown? How did Toronto's 'skid row' come to be established in East Downtown Toronto? These are just some of the questions that we will explore during the walk.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: 51 Division (Front St. and Parliament St.)

team.bio: Gaetan Heroux is a long time anti-poverty activist with the Ontario Coalition Against Poverty who has worked in East Downtown Toronto for 25 years.

accessible-transit: Take King St. Street car to Parliament St. ( 51 Division is just south of King St. E. on the south side of Parliament)
accessible-parking: Meter Parking on King St. East.

title: Alternative Campus Tour
shortdescription: The Alternative Campus Tour uncovers and unpacks compelling stories shaping tomorrow’s post secondary institutions and the wider community. As a tourist you will get an insider perspective behind the highly publicized “Middle East War” which took place in Vari Hall, learn about how Stong Pond was connected to the flash flood that washed out a section of Finch Avenue in 2005, hear the concerns of women studying on a campus originally built for men and cars and discover how the 2015 Pan American Games may be a threat to the Michael Boyer Woodlot.
longdescription:
Are you interested in uncovering alternative campus narratives?

Post secondary institutions are oftentimes viewed as “ivory towers”, distinct from the larger community and overall human experience. For many people, Universities and Colleges are the backdrop of their fondest memories, critical social debates, thought experiments, character development and community building. Besides being halls of higher learning on scholarship, campuses are also important cultural sites. The Alternative Campus Tour uncovers un- and under-told stories delivered by poets, students and writers.

As a tourist you will get an insider perspective behind the highly publicized “Middle East War” which took place in Vari Hall, learn about how Stong Pond was connected to the flash flood that washed out a section of Finch Avenue in 2005, hear the concerns of women studying on a campus originally built for men and cars and discover how the 2015 Pan American Games may be a threat to the Michael Boyer Woodlot. Be sure to bring along your cell phone as this tour has an augmented reality component, which will allow tourists to experience a special digital storytelling component.

The tour will begin at 2:00p.m. at  York University. We'll be meeting  at the water fountain in front of Vari Hall (close to the bus depot) on York Boulevard. We will tour various sites on campus and then close the tour with participant stories and observations. Light refreshments will be served.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: We will be meeting at the water fountain in front of Vari Hall (close to the bus depot) on York Boulevard

team.name-first: Professor L. Anders Sandberg, Jay Pitter & Adrina Bardekjian
team.bio:
L. Anders Sandberg is a Professor in the Faculty of Environmental Studies at York University. He likes to think critically about the everyday and seemingly mundane. He has led many tours across the campus. One of his recent books, Urban Explorations: Environmental Histories of the Toronto Region (2013), is a collection of essays that combines writing and field trips in the Toronto region, from downtown Toronto to Niagara Falls, Indigenous Toronto to queer Toronto, and Hamilton Harbour to the Oak Ridges Moraine.
 
Jay Pitter is a senior communications specialist, writer and narratologist. She has worked in numerous leadership roles such as Arts Curriculum Writer with the Toronto District School Board, Arts Education Grants Officer with the Ontario Arts Council, Director of Communications with DIALOG - a premier national architectural firm and a Columnist with CBC Radio Canada. Her writing credits include the Walrus, Toronto Star, Fireweed, Spacing Magazine and the book Climate Change; Who’s Carrying the Burden.  Jay recently completed graduate research in Narrative Theory and Methodology; the Alternative Campus Tour provides an excellent opportunity for her to continue working with her advisor and mentor Professor Anders Sandberg to explore the impact of narrative.                          

Adrina Bardekjian is a PhD Candidate at the Faculty of Environmental Studies at York University examining urban forestry through a political ecology lens. She has been involved with the Alternative Campus Tour for the past five years engaging with students to expand their perspectives about their physical surroundings. Adrina's main site of interest is the Michael Boyer woodlot and its significance as a place-maker in social and ecological narratives. Adrina works as an Urban Forestry Researcher and Consultant, with a number of urban greening organizations, on a diversity of projects

accessible-transit: There are many buses connecting the York University Keele Campus to Finch, Downsview, and Sheppard stations. For more info: http://www.yorku.ca/trnsprt/publictransit/ttc.htm
accessible-parking: Pay parking is available on campus.

title: PARC and Peggy Nash MP Present – Belly Full
shortdescription: A history of hunger resistance in west end Toronto and finding community through food security will be explored on this Jane's Walk.
longdescription:
Hunger and food insecurity create serious health risks for low income people living in Toronto and across Canada.  The widening gap between the rich and the poor is a reality, made more visible by the large numbers of vulnerable people  using  various types of food relief programs to feed themselves on a daily basis.  Their struggle underpins the need for a national food security strategy and the political will to move this forward.

A community’s response to hunger is often aligned with the quality and measure of its other interdependent activities to understand, confront and change the conditions that trap people in poverty.    

Some of these conditions include:  creating a shared understanding and resolve to address citizen income disparities, increasing the supply of affordable and supportive housing resources, creating education, employment and support options to alter the poverty equation and improve community food health.   

The Belly Full Walk will share stories about the struggle to support food security in west end Toronto over the last 30 years; how food insecurity has been personally experienced, how marginalized communities (and organizations working with them) have responded, the need for legislative change at all levels of government to eliminate food insecurity and the importance of citizen action in creating change.

The Belly Full Walk will journey through the heart of Parkdale between Queen West and Sorauren Ave.  and Queen West / Duffern Ave.  Belly Full stories will share information about:    

  • Hunger and Food Insecurity:  A lived experience perspective
  • Supporting Food Relief Programs (from food bank to daily meal services):  What they do and what they do not do / The struggle for sustainability, nutrition standards and dignity / funding and support needs
  • Meeting the Challenges of a Changing Local Food Economy:  access for some / exclusion for others  / food safety regulations and their  tie in to food security / the importance of supporting local producers
  • Promoting  Food Economy Equity and Food Security:  the issues / the partners and players (The Parkdale Food Network)  / collaborative action directions promoted by the West End Food Co-op, PARC and Greenest City /  the benefits of community engagement

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Parkdale Activity-Recreation Centre (PARC) / Queen and Sorauren

team.name-first: Bob Rose (PARC Ambassadors Program) / Peggy Nash MP
team.bio:
Peggy Nash - MP Parkdale-High Park 
Peggy Nash is the Member of Parliament for Parkdale-High Park. She was first elected to Parliament in 2006. Since the May 2011 election, Peggy has served as Opposition finance critic and she also sits as Vice Chair of the Standing Committee on Finance.
She served on the board of Invest Toronto, promoting investment in Canada’s largest city. As Industry Critic she worked to protect highly skilled Canadian jobs and successfully pressed the government to reject – for the first time in more than 20 years – the foreign takeover of a major Canadian company.  
Peggy served as a Canadian election observer in South Africa’s first post-apartheid elections in 1994, and in Ukraine in 2004 and 2007. She has spoken internationally in defense of human rights and democracy
Peggy has been the recipient of numerous awards, including: two awards from the Sierra Club of Canada for her leadership on sustainable transportation; the YWCA Woman of Distinction Award; and a certificate of honour for contributing to women's equality from the City of Toronto in recognition of her work to end violence against women.

PARC AMBASSADORS
 
Glen Pappin has been a member of PARC for 15 years and a PARC Ambassador since 2009.  He currently volunteers weekly at the West End Food Co-op in his role as a Food Security Ambassador. Glen works part-time at PARC in weekend reception, volunteers in the PARC kitchen and with Peers About community, a member leadership group supporting PARC programming. He also serves as a peer representative with the St. Joseph's Health Centre Panel on Mental Health Issues and Addictions.
 
Jack MacDonald has been a PARC member for many years.  Jack volunteers weekly at the West End Food Co-op in his new role as a PARC Food Security Ambassador.  He has previously worked on a variety of peer driven initiatives including:  Green Thumb Enterprises / The PARC Heat Registry and Heat Response Project / Knowledge is Power and as peer facilitator at Camp Kandalore, an annual wilderness program offered to our member community.
 
Eugene has been a PARC member since September 2011.  He is a new PARC Ambassador working to support member involvement in urban agriculture and gardening activities.  Eugene lives in a local rooming house and is a regular consumer of local food bank / food service support programs due to income assistance barriers.  
 
Robert was born and raised in Cape Breton Nova Scotia.  After 3 years in the Canadian Armed forces he moved to Toronto where he worked steadily as a licensed exterminator, then as an iron worker for almost 30 years.  A job injury ended his employment. He fell into homelessness and eventually found his way to PARC in 2012. Robert is a new PARC Ambassador working to support member involvement in urban agriculture / gardening activities.   He is also a regular volunteer in the PARC food service.
 
Terence Williams has been very involved with PARC since 2002 and a PARC Ambassador since 2008. He has also been a PARC Board Director for over 5 years, serving on a number of committees. He is Co-President on the Board of Directors at the Consumer Survivor Information and Resource Centre (CSIRC) with one year left to serve in his third term, and is involved with the Ontario Recovery Campaign, which deals with recovery in relation to mental health.  Terence is on the Executive of the Parkdale Residents Association and is now completing his 4th year as a Parkdale Community Health Centre Board Director.  Terence has been employed by the Maytree Foundation Building Blocks program as a community leader for the last year and a half.
 
Bob Rose is a senior PARC manager and the current coordinator of the PARC Ambassadors program.
PARC ambassadors are member leaders who engage in community development and public education activities.  Bob has more than 30 years of community work experience focused on social justice / access to housing / the development of the drop-in model of mental health support and improving the quality and range of services / recovery activities provided for psychiatric survivors. 
 
WEST END FOOD CO-OP 
Ayal Dinner is the Kitchen and Retail Coordinator of the West End Food Co-op.  Ayal has been a founding member of the Co-op / Sorauren Farmers market for the last 7 years.  He has a background in community work, food security and food production activism.  Prior to coming to the WEFC he worked as a community food animator with Food Share.  He lives in Parkdale with his wife and two children.

title: Old Glenora: Now and Then
shortdescription: Join us for an early morning walk through one of Edmonton's most stately historic neighbourhoods.
longdescription: Join us for an early morning walk through one of Edmonton's most stately historic neighbourhoods. Discover the diverse urban pattern and architecture of Glenora, new and old. The community's evolving urban story  will be traced back to its early planning at the beginning of the early 1900's.  We will conclude at Government House, Edmonton's newest National Historic Site to learn more about its 100 year history.  After a short break to refresh and if your time permits take an half hour guided tour of Alberta's vice-regal mansion.  Public tours are offered Saturday, Sunday and holiday Mondays from 11:00 am to 4:30 p.m.. See www.governmenthousefoundation.ca

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Glenora Elementary School 13520 102 Avenue

team.bio: Marianne Fedori is an urban historian and architecture enthusiast  who has lived in the community of Glenora for almost two decades in a well loved designated municipal heritage resource.

accessible-transit: Routes 2, 112 & 111 along Stony Plain Road
accessible-parking: Free on Street
accessible-find: We will meet at  the front doors of the school facing 102 Avenue.

title: Birch Cliff: Scarborough Old and New
shortdescription: Several community touchstones anchor our leisurely walk along Kingston Road east from Warden, ending at Harrison Gardens at the Bluffs.  Our stops provide a framework to allow the walk to come alive through the memories of residents.  Come and share with your neighbours!
longdescription:
Are you now or have you ever been a resident of Birch Cliff?  This century-old southwest Scarborough neighbourhood is rich in history, heritage and stories.  Nestled just above the western bluffs, Birch Cliff's legacies include a radial streetcar line, Scarborough's first Canadian Tire store, and Scarborough Township's (almost) first council chambers.

We'll stroll eastward along Kingston Road from Warden to Birchmount, with lots of stops and opportunities for memories and chatting along the way. The walk will end in the Harrison Gardens land above the bluffs at the eastern end of Springbank, just south of the Scarborough Arts house.

Our walk highlights traditional and new community landmarks including the Royal Canadian Legion and new public murals.  The best part of the walk will be stories we share with each other about Birch Cliff.

Birch Cliff retains its history as it remains a vital neighbourhood of retail shops, public services and community gathering spaces.  We're just the skeleton of the walk.  What are your stories of Birch Cliff? Bring your memories and your stories to share and make this a wonderful community event!

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Northwest corner, Kingston Rd & Warden.

team.bio:
Marie Belanger is a resident of southwest Scarborough. She has worked at libraries in Scarborough for over 20 years.
 Karin Eaton is Executive Director, Mural Routes and a Birch Cliff  resident.

title: Creative with Nature - Nordheimer Ravine
shortdescription:
Nature is found and designed in a city - but it is also the very basis of our lived locale. Come out to the Nordheimer Ravine, at Spadina W Subway and below the St. Clair Reservoir.

We will walk through a naturalized forest and consider how a forest and its water system have been constructed over the years. We will look at how we can use our sensuality to create new nature in a city. Along the way we will use historical imagery,  reference existent designed city and nature and meet professionals and artists to engage our sensory creativity.
longdescription:
Nature is found and designed in a city - but it is also the very basis of our lived locale. Come out to the Nordheimer Ravine, at Spadina W Subway and below the St. Clair Reservoir
We will walk through a naturalized forest and consider how a forest and its water system have been constructed over the years. We will look at how we can use our sensuality to create new nature in a city. Along the way we will use historical imagery,  reference existent designed city and nature and meet professionals and artists to engage our sensory creativity.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: St. Clair W subway entrance, south side of St. Clair Ave.

team.bio: Susan Aaron has been the city's natural environment volunteer steward in the Nordheimer ravine for close to 15 years. She also has an academic interest in natural environment and creativity, often working with arts based research and artists.

accessible-info: the ravine can be accessed through a slope/but it is a city maintained walking path not concrete  - scooters are possible, wheelchairs with aid, and hand held walkers would be slow going,
accessible-transit: St. Clair W subway or the streetcar to the same stop.
accessible-parking: There is parking in the adjacent Wells Hill neighborhood

title: The Stairs of Lake Iroquois
shortdescription: 9 staircases - 356 stairs - amazing views of the city plus Casa Loma, Tollkeeper's Cottage, Wychwood Park, Artscape Wychwood Barns and more!
longdescription:
Glacial Lake Iroquois was a prehistoric lake that existed at the end of the last ice age approximately 13,000 years ago. The lake was essentially an enlargement of the present Lake Ontario, which formed because the St. Lawrence River was blocked by an ice sheet. The level of the lake was approximately 30 m  above the present level of Lake Ontario. The ridge that runs just above Davenport Road is the former edge of Lake Iroquois. Over the years, several sets of stairs have been built to assist residents with getting up and down the hill that is the former edge of Lake Iroquois. 

We will start at the bottom of historic Baldwin Steps at the corner of Davenport and Spadina (below Casa Loma). From there, we will make our way across the ridge up and down nine sets of stairs covering 366 steps. The walk will end at Davenport & Glenholme.

We will pass by the historic Tollkeepers cottage at Bathurst and St. Clair. We will wind our way through famous Wychwood Park. From there we will make a 15 minute pit stop at the exciting Wychwood Barns while the Farmer's Market is in full-swing. There will be amazing views all along the way. 

This walk is a combination fitness walk with some tales about historical and current land use. It is not wheelchair accessible. 

You can sign up on Facebook but that's not mandatory. Just show up if you want. 

Note:  We did a dry run yesterday and all the stairs are in good shape. However, decent footware is recommended. 


 

Perhaps the only Jane's Walk with bonafide Jane Jacobs graffiti

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: The steps on the corner of Davenport & Spadina.

team.bio: Gary Shaul designed and has led this walk on three previous occasions. He has been living in the Bathurst and St. Clair area for the past 17 years. This year, he is pleased to be co-leading with Heather Robertson with assistance from Jane's Walk volunteer Anna Chiaramonte.

title: Not a Boring Walk
shortdescription: This walk, led by Mount Dennis Community Association members, Metrolinx staff, and technical experts,  will visit and discuss the Crosstown LRT’s boring machine launch site,  the Black Creek valley in transition, a new Community Recreation Centre site, the historic Kodak building (planned to become a major transit hub), and the newly renovated Mount Dennis library.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Meet near the Chris Tonks Arena in Keelesdale Park  (south side of Eglinton Ave., between Keele Street and Black Creek Drive)

team.name-first: Mount Dennis Community Association members and technical specialists from Metrolinx, TPL, TRCA and others, TPL, Toronto Parks and Rec
team.bio: The Mount Dennis Community Association has been working for the betterment of Toronto’s greenest neighbourhood since 1975, and has organized several previous local Jane’s Walks. MDCA works with politicians and agencies at all levels to advocate on behalf of the community, monitoring developments and proposals. It also engages in community-building activities such as litter clean-ups, safety audits, celebratory events and operating a natural ice rink. MDCA’s motto is “working together to strengthen Mount Dennis”.

accessible-info: Most of the walk is accessible.  Dogs not allowed inside library.

accessible-parking: Park at the York Civic Centre, Municipal Drive at Eglinton

title: The "West" West End
shortdescription: Join Gordon Price has he takes you on a walk of the “West” West End, that is the neighbourhood west of Denman.
longdescription: The walk will explore the urban fabric of this vibrant community from Coal Harbour to English Bay.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Alberni and Chilco (A block south of Georgia St and two blocks west of Demman.)

team.bio:
Gordon is the Director of the City Program at Simon Fraser University and author of the popular ‘Price Tags’ blog focusing on urban development and planning.
He served six terms as Councillor for the City of Vancouver, from 1986 to 2002, as well as on the board of the Greater Vancouver Regional District (now Metro) and TransLink, the regional transportation authority.

title: A Creative Tour of the Baltic Triangle, Liverpool
shortdescription: Come and join Jane’s Walks in the Baltic Triangle. Starting at the Baltic Fleet pub and brewery and walking through this often overlooked part of the city that is now a flourishing place for creative and digital companies.
longdescription:
Come and join Jane’s Walks in the Baltic Triangle. Starting at the Baltic Fleet pub and brewery and walking through this often overlooked part of the city that is now a flourishing place for creative and digital companies. Learn something about the history of the area, discover it’s incredible buildings and meet some of their occupants. Step inside the quirky events space of Camp and Furnace and see the latest education centre being built in a huge Victorian warehouse. Discover an art gallery you never knew existed and try a beer from our most famous local brewery – Cains.

 

If you are interseted in attending please contact Kim Cooper, Vice Chair of the Royal Town Planning Institutes' North West Young Planners on: kim_cooper@hotmail.co.uk

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Baltic Fleet Pub, L1 8DQ

team.bio: GERRY PROCTOR is born and bred in Liverpool and now lives in one of the Waterfront’s largest apartment complexes. He has always worked with local communities and has recently completed a Masters in Philosophy thesis at Hope University entitled A Commitment to Neighbourhood. Gerry is Chair of a social enterprise company called Engage Liverpool that works with everyone who lives in apartments in the city centre and waterfront.  He is also a member of the Baltic Stakeholder Group. Gerry is passionate about city living and will share this enthusiasm with Jane’s Walks participants

title: Stanley Street Quarter, the LGBT area of Liverpool
shortdescription:
Liverpool’s Stanley Street Quarter nestled in the Historic Downtown area of the city and sandwiched between the bustling retail and commercial districts has developed into the city’s defacto gay quarter. It’s quirky but cultured, diverse yet inclusive and vibrant in a uniquely Liverpool way. 

This walk explores the challenges, achievements and history of a developing historical area of the city; It will highlight aspirations of the area from a city council, stakeholder and passer-by perspective as well as look into the histories of the Gay Scene from it’s roots in Queens Square and the early footprints of the now established Quarter.
longdescription:
Liverpool’s Stanley Street Quarter nestled in the Historic Downtown area of the city and sandwiched between the bustling retail and commercial districts has developed into the city’s defacto gay quarter. It’s quirky but cultured, diverse yet inclusive and vibrant in a uniquely Liverpool way. 

This walk explores the challenges, achievements and history of a developing historical area of the city; It will highlight aspirations of the area from a city council, stakeholder and passer-by perspective as well as look into the histories of the Gay Scene from it’s roots in Queens Square and the early footprints of the now established Quarter.

You will join the quarter in the run up to marking International Day Against Homophobia and get a sneak peek at plans and things to come, You will be welcomed by the City Council who (in a first for the UK) officially endorsed the area in 2011 which was referred to at the time as a ‘Gaybourhood’ and has now today established it’s name as ‘The Stanley Street Quarter’.

As part of this walk you will experience workshops, first hand accounts and interviews of people from the area, past and present and have the chance to be a part of the development of one of Liverpool’s most cultural centres.

This tour is being ran in partnership with the RTPI's North West Young Planners and part of a city wide programme of walking tours.

For more information contact Andi Herring – andi.herring@liverpool.gov.uk

If you are interested in coming on the tour you are more than welcome, but please email Andi so we have an idea of numbers!

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Queens Square Bus Station

team.bio: Andi has been the project officer within Liverpool City Council for the last 6months, and was heavily involved in the developments and events taking place in the Quarter before this. He has a background in human geographies and is currently applying to University Of Liverpool to study Town and Regional Planning.  Andi chairs the steering group for the area and leads on the implementation of the strategic plans for the Quarter.

accessible-info: Unfortunately, Due to the nature of the buildings in the area and the uneven surfaces this walk is not suitable for wheelchair users.

title: A Radical History of Allan Gardens
shortdescription: Allan Gardens was a playground for some of Toronto's most affluent residents in its early history. Come find out about its hidden history.
longdescription:
In the 1880s and 1890s, Allan Gardens served as a playground for some of Toronto’s wealthiest residents. Many historians have written about this grand era. However, the radical history of Allan Gardens following the turn of the 20th century has largely been ignored. This walk will look at this radical history -- the battle for free speech during the Great Depression, the protests against the nuclear bomb and the fight to read poetry in the park in the early 1960s, the anti-Nazi riots in the mid-1960s, and the large anti-poverty demonstrations of the 1990s.


 Pictured above: Unveiling of the Robert Burns Statue in Allan Gardens, 1902.

markers.title: Meeting Place

team.bio: Gaetan Heroux is a long time anti-poverty activist with the Ontario Coalotion Against Poverty and has worked in East Downtown Toronto for 25 years.

title: The Walls Are Alive With The Sounds of Mad People
shortdescription: A lively theatrical walk around the historic patient-built wall on the grounds of the Centre for Addiction and Mental Health (CAMH), led by the Friendly Spike Theatre Band.
longdescription:
A lively theatrical walk around the historic patient-built wall on the grounds of the Centre for Addiction and Mental Health (CAMH), led by the Friendly Spike Theatre Band.

These walls are a testiment to people whose unpaid labor was central to the operation of asylums throughout the province of Ontario during the 19th and 20th century. By learning from their individual stories we can ground our own continuing struggle.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: South-west corner of Queen St West and Shaw St.

team.bio: The Friendly Spike Theatre Band is an award-winning community theatre group composed of psychiatric survivors and disabled people. Our mission is to include our personal stories and link them with the larger historical struggle in mental healthcare.

accessible-info: Accessible for people with mobility challenges
accessible-transit: Via the 501 Queen St streetcar or the 63 Ossington bus, get off at Queen St West at Shaw St!
accessible-parking: There is on-street parking nearby.
accessible-find: We will be located at Plaque #1, the historical marker just at the corner of Queen St West and Shaw St.

title: London Road, 1885-Present
shortdescription: We will explore the history and stories that shape one of Lethbridge’s most established neighbourhoods, the London Road. The walk will include a mix of historic homes, modern buildings, parks, re-used buildings and a lost landmark.
longdescription:
A walking exploration of a mix of historic homes/modern buildings/parks/ re-used buildings and a lost landmark building.

Route Information

1)       The walk will begin at the NE corner of the Civic Field (500 - 11th Street South) - with a short talk on the wonders of green spaces in our area.

2)       Old Spudnut shop (Crazy Cakes) –with a brief history of the building and cupcakes all round.

3)       Continue along 5th Ave S - to first take a look at one of the beautiful historic (brick) homes between 12 & 13 St

4)       Edith Cavell Nursing home - a 'battle' that saw the LRNA successfully get the designs radically changed to fit in better with the neighbourhood - and to be a more pleasant institution for residents and staff.

5)       Down 13th St (our eastern boundary), then west along 7th Ave. to firstly look at the sad sight of the razed Van Haarlem, talk about its history, the community who lived in it so recently and lost their homes, with discussion about the vital importance of social housing, and speculation about what might happen on that site.

6)       Along 7th, we'll take a look at the new condos/single apartments in the old Red Cross building- a fine example of re-use (with preservation of a unique exterior).

7)       Next block west is the Hill House - a beautiful old mansion that had fallen on hard times - but which is now being energetically renovated by a young professional couple for use as a family home once more - a very 'good news' story!

8)       Next, south to 8th Ave - looking at one of the lovely art deco/art modern homes, then walking across our beautiful Kinsman Park.

9)       Final stop - 'Urban Grocer' where a long time convenience store has been given new life as a neghbourhood grocery specializing in local and organic products.

title: Antiguo Neighborhood Views
shortdescription: We invite you to walk with us along the streets of Antiguo district, and to discover the local face of San Sebastian. Basque sports, local shops, bars with Pintxos... everything is mixed in the everyday life of the Basques.
longdescription:
Have you ever considered visiting San Sebastian from another perspective? Have you ever thought about how it looks like the local life of this beautiful city? We invite you to walk with us along the streets of Antiguo district, and to discover the local face of San Sebastian. Basque sports, local shops, bars with Pintxos... everything is mixed in the everyday life of the Basques. Join us and discover it! We will be waiting for you on May 5th at 11:30 am for a  walk around Antiguo. Learn about its people, the history, and the rich tradition of this neighbourhood.

We will start in the park where is located the Miramar Palace, at the main entrance, stopping along the most characteristic places of Antiguo and going up the hill to the seminary to view the beautiful San Sebastian from another perspective. Then we'll go down again to explore some more.

You are invited to walk, listen, and tell your own story. At the conclusion of the walk, you may join us for a pintxo and drink.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Miramar Palace, in front of the big tower.

team.bio:
I have been a tour leader for 6 years, and I have run trips in the most important cities of central Europe. I have taken visitors to explore places such as Viena, Prague, Krakow, Munich, Salzburg, but for the past two years I have been working in the Basque Country. I have led Intrepid Travel groups around Spain, Portugal, France and Morocco, but my passion is San Sebastian!
I am in love with this Basque city and with the secrets it hides, and that is why I am specialising in guiding urban tours in this city because I plan to become an Urban Adventures Partner. I studied History and I like to discuss the origins and roots of things we see and experience at the present.

accessible-info: This walk includes walking up and down many small hills. It may not be appropriate for people who require the use of mobility devices.

title: Jack's Walk:  Stories about Jack Layton's life & work from those who knew him best
shortdescription: Jack Layton's friends and family will lead a walk through Toronto, telling stories about his life and his work as a city Councillor, MP and leader of the NDP.
longdescription:
Jack Layton's friends and family will lead a walk through Toronto, telling stories about his life and his work as a City Councillor, MP and leader of the NDP.

The walk will start at the University of Toronto where Jack was a professor who taught courses in urban environmental issues.  The walk will travel down to City Hall past Jack's house as well as affordable housing projects Jack helped develop. 

At City Hall Jacks family will discuss the memorial at Nathan Phillips Square and his former City Hall colleagues will discuss some of Jack's city wide work as a councillor.

The walk will proceed up to Ryerson University where Jack was a professor of political science in his early years as an activist, before it travels east towards Cabbagetown, an area he represented.  The walk will end at a pub in the area, as would have no doubt been Jack's suggestion.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Lilliam Smith Library, 239 College St (College and Huron)

title: Revitalization or displacement? A critical look  at the idea of mixed neighbourhoods.
shortdescription: The walk will explore the effects of the  Regent Park redevelopment  project on homeless and low income people living East Downtown Toronto. We will look at the early history of the gentrification of the neighbourhood dating back to 1965, along witth the more recent redevlopment of Regent Park, and offer a critical look at the concept mixed neighbourhoods. Do revitalization projects like the Regent Park redevelopment contribute to a healthy neighbourhood or do they contribute to the further displacement of poor people in East Downtown Toronto? These are some of the questions that we will explore during the walk.
longdescription: The walk will explore the effects of the  Regent Park redevelopment  project on homeless and low income people living East Downtown Toronto. We will look at the early history of the gentrification of the neighbourhood dating back to 1965, along witth the more recent redevlopment of Regent Park, and offer a critical look at the concept mixed neighbourhoods. Do revitalization projects like the Regent Park redevelopment contribute to a healthy neighbourhood or do they contribute to the further displacement of poor people in East Downtown Toronto? These are some of the questions that we will explore during the walk.

title: Ward Healing: How "The Ward" Transformed Modern Toronto
shortdescription: This Jane's Walk will travel across the ghost paths of Toronto's first priority neighbourhood -- an area that extends from Nathan Philips Square and up Elizabeth Street -- in an attempt to discover how The Ward shaped modern Toronto.
longdescription: Efforts in the 1910s and 1920s to clean up Toronto's Ward -- a so-called slum that extended between Queen and College, and Yonge to University, and focused on Elizabeth Street -- had a far-reaching effect on local government as well as Toronto's attitude towards recent immigrants and the poor.  In an attempt to confront contagious disease epidemics, fetid housing conditions and the social crises associated with extreme poverty, the City launched a range of health and works reforms aimed at cleaning up The Ward. But by the 1920s, the area had slated for redevelopment as the site of a major civic square, part of a high-minded planning campaign for Toronto's downtown. Yet 21st century Toronto barely knows the history of Canada's original priority neighbourhood. This walk will explore The Ward and chart its remarkable yet barely acknowledged impact on the contemporary city.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Winston Churchill Statue, north side of Queen Street near City Hall

team.bio: John Lorinc is a Toronto journalist and frequent contributor to Spacing, The Globe and Mail and other publications. He led last year's #stclairdisaster Jane's Walk (which turned out not to be...a disaster.) He has written frequently about Toronto in the 1920s.

title: Challenges and Promises of Change
shortdescription: While exploring the Hastings-Sunrise area of east Vancouver we will discuss the pressures that exist in this era of gentrification and upward mobile status.
longdescription:
How, if at all, may the poor hang on, if still here? What measures exist to supplement one's income, in order to hang on? How do some cope, using the "necessity is the mother of invention" axiom? Housing, food, recreation, modes of transportation, and spiritual resources will be noted and discussion/reflection invited.

The walk will also include some historical reminscences which illustrate a loss of heritage character (e.g. diversity, age, uniqueness).

We will begin at the Longhouse Church and end at Laughin' Bean, with glimpses of diverse life in the 'hood.

title: Successful Garden Alternatives
shortdescription: A walk through 15 blocks of alternative approaches to gardening in the urban environment.
longdescription: A walk through 15 blocks of alternative approaches to gardening in the urban environment. If you think lawn is the only way to go, you will see a dozen very successful gardens that are operated by people who challenge the Joneses to keep up with them.

title: Activism is the Rent I Pay for Living on this Planet
shortdescription: Join us for an insider's backyard tour of Hillhurst Sunnyside, a community packed with history, creativity, and eco-enthusiasm.
longdescription:
Activism is the Rent I Pay for Living on this Planet.  Inspired by this Alice Walker quote, this year's Jane's Walk begins at the Higher Ground in Kensington and takes you on an insider's backyard tour of a community packed with history, creativity, and eco-enthusiasm.

You'll see green projects including a community garden, a shared garden, a community orchard, businesses accepting Calgary Dollars complementary currency, Calgary Carshare and Car2Go vehicles, a locally-run egg cooperative, bee hive, coyote and owl homes, and low-impact homes.

To learn about the area's history and character, you'll visit cooperative and progressive housing locations, see the former Calgary streetcar route, an ancient buffalo butchery location, a laneway house that was floated across the Bow River, and the Donegal Mansion, home to John Brownlee, Alberta Premiere from 1925-1934, until forced to resign due to seduction charges. These historic and modern assets have helped create the Bow to Bluff community engagement initiative and the 9A St. Transit Oriented Development Zone and you'll see numerous current developments underway.

You'll tour public art and activism including a visit to Calgary's first pesticide-free park, past climate change protest sites, and the locations of numerous street events. Community art projects include the Hillhurst Hardware display case, graffiti showcase alley, the Urban Bird Time Share, and the newest installation, the Little Free Library.

After the tour ends, you are welcome to join us at a Kensington pub to keep talking.

Bring a go-cup, weather clothes, and comfy footwear.

Details: duration 2.5 hrs, 3 km. Washroom access at beginning and end. Child-friendly but some indoor locations are not pet-friendly.


Watch a video of the points of interest on the walk

title: Central Salford Regeneration
shortdescription: The North-West Young Planners with Salford City Council lead a walking tour exploring the regeneration of central Salford.
longdescription:
The regeneration of central Salford is a central concern of the social and economic future of Greater Manchester. Salford City Council's regeneration strategy is a long-term plan to reverse decades of economic and physical decline and restore the former commercial and civic heart of Salford as a major centre for the region. The plan involves a variety of interventions with different private and public bodies taking responsibility for delivery. This walk will explain Salford's objectives and strategies by visiting the urban interventions completed so far, as well as future development sites, exploring the opportunities and challenges facing all involved.

Places are limited so please register for further details, by emailing thomashiles@gmail.com or phoning 07958 679329.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Chapel Street, Salford

team.bio: The North-West Young Planners are part of the Royal Town Planning Institute and we are the professional network for early-career planners in North-West England. We organise training and professional development events and networking opportunities for young planners and other built environment professionals. David Greenfield is Principal Planner for Physical Regeneration in the Office of the Chief Executive of Salford City Council.

accessible-info: The route will cross a derelict development site which might not be suited to those with limited mobility. There is a paved route around this section.

title: Historic Newton
shortdescription: Tour the historic Newton Community with Ryan Catena.
longdescription: Take a walk with us, tour historic Newton Community, connect with your neighbours and enjoy a beautiful spring morning. The tour will start at our first officially designated historical site. We will be viewing homes built as early as 1910 in this century old neighborhood. Newton is participating in Jane's Walk this year with a tour through its historic section recognizing some of its preserved heritage homes and embracing its safe walkable community."

title: New Westminster All Candidates Walk
shortdescription: NEXT NewWest, New Westminster Environmental Partners, and 10th to the Fraser bring you another unique All Candidates Event! An hour or so walking with 5 local candidates for the upcoming Provincial Election!
longdescription:
In what is becoming a New Westminster election tradition, Tenth to the Fraser, NEXT NewWest, and the New Westminster Environmental Partners are organizing a unique event to bring voters and candidates together. Far from the traditional “All Candidates Debate”, this will be an inviting, social, and fun event. The goal is to give everyone a chance to meet, greet and get to know the candidates seeking your vote on May 14th.

All New Westminster residents are invited to gather at SappertonPark (at the corner of East Columbia Street and Sherbrooke Street) at 5:30pm (sharp!). The five candidates will be introduced, and the group will walk along Columbia Street and the Central Valley Greenway to Downtown New Westminster and the River Market (a distance of about 3.5 km, so about an hour walking at a leisurely pace).

Along the way, each of the candidates will be given an opportunity for their 3-4 minutes “on the soapbox” to address the crowd. We promise to keep the speeched short, as the emphasis will be on face-to-face and small group conversations during the walk. Participants will be encouraged to chat with the candidates and ask their own questions. There may be a few surprises along the way to encourage a meaningful dialogue!

At the end of the walk, participants and candidates will be encouraged to gather at the Paddlewheeler Pub to continue the conversation, socialize and network  in the NEXT NewWest tradition!

title: Calgary Gay History Walk
shortdescription: Where did Calgary's fledgling gay community meet in the 1960s and 1970s?  Come on this walk to learn and share stories about Calgary's gay history.
longdescription:
Calgary is a relatively young city, which from the 1950s on has become a key metropolitan centre and regional powerhouse. Throughout the exponential population growth over the next 60 years, the city’s gay community has existed as a distinct undercurrent. 

However, not too much is known about it…

Through a Calgary 2012 Artist in Residence grant I have been exploring what life was like for gay people in Calgary in the middle of the last century.   Most of my research has taken place at the Old Y Centre for Community Organizations, now called CommunityWise.  Not only is it a historical institution itself, but it also has been a focal point for queer community organizations since the 1970s. Perhaps most significantly the Old Y Centre was the home of the Gay & Lesbian Community Services Association (GLCSA) [now called Calgary OutLink], which has been a hub, resource, and saving grace to thousands of Calgarians.

I have been publishing research findings on my website at Calgarygayhistory.ca.  It is from these articles, plus new discoveries, that this walk is sourced.  On the Calgary Gay History Jane's Walk, we will be visiting historic locations of significance to the city's fledgling gay community.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: 223 12 Ave. SW

team.bio: Kevin Allen biography.

accessible-parking: Street Pay Parking Available
accessible-find: We will be meeting at CommunityWise, formerly known as the Old Y Centre,  just in front of the building.

title: Public Art in Kingston: Past, Present and Future
shortdescription: This walk will engage participants in an active discussion about the importance, value and function of art in the public realm. Street art, sculpture, and installation in alleys and walkways will form the tactile substance of the walk, but discussions about the impact of past performances, ephemeral installations, and future projects will be touchstones for more macro-level discussions about what public art in downtown Kingston has been, is, and could be.
longdescription: Have you ever wondered what the motivation was behind the large public works along the waterfront in front of the hospital? What about that weird metal clothesline thing that is in the alley behind the Toucan? This walk will trace the steps of artists who visited Kingston or lived in Kingston and will discuss some of the ways in which they wanted to aesthetically and physically make their mark in this city. Public art changes urban space, but it can be too often overlooked. The names of artists are sometimes forgotten, and their reasons for choosing certain locations often provide a kind of aide-mémoire  for stories and histories about a community. This springtime walk is intended to inspire you to think about how public art effects a city, whether or not it should be "beautiful", whether or not it is necessary, and what the future holds for artists in Kingston who wish to engage with the city this way.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Stuart St at University St, Queen's Main Campus

team.bio: Claire Grady-Smith has lived in or near Kingston for several periods throughout her life. She recently returned to Kingston to complete an MA in Cultural Studies from Queen's. Claire reads and writes about culture and the city, and is a practicing artist who focuses on space and place-making often in her visual work. She has founded a collective called Stage K, which is an informal arts group that thinks through the city and public engagement with the arts. She animates the streets, galleries, pubs, and newspapers of Kingston as much as possible.

accessible-transit: Take Number 2 bus from downtown and get off just past the Hospital.
accessible-parking: Weekend parking on Queen's Campus is free, or park halfway between Princess Street and campus.

title: Ghost Tour of the University of Toronto
shortdescription: A 75-minute walk featuring mysterious urban legends throughout Toronto's central, downtown university campus.
longdescription:
Tour Date : Saturday, May 4th,  7 p.m.

Tour  Time : 7 p.m.

Tour Duration : about 75 minutes

Tour Meeting Point : Eastern (former) entrance, Royal Ontario Museum.

 

Ghost tours the world over have thrilled audience members for years.  Whether you're an enthusiast about the paranormal, or just looking for a good story, this tour will introduce you to some of the more uncommon stories found throughout Toronto's landscape.

 

Although having little more than two centuries of thoroughly documented history, Toronto still has an assortment of strange tales that will fascinate both visitors and residents.  On this tour, we'll explore the grounds of the University of Toronto, where the traditional architecture and tree lined paths lend themselves to sharing some of our city's spookier stories.

 

Our tour starts on the stairs leading up to the east side of the Royal Ontario Museum.  The contemporary entrance is located on Bloor Street, on the north side of the building, but we meet at the site of the former entrance, facing Queen's Park Circle.  For a map of where we meet, visit : http://www.muddyyorktours.com/popup_rom.html

 

The tour is an easy walk of about 75-minutes and concludes in Queen's Park, a short walk back to the Royal Ontario Museum.  “Museum” subway station and “Queen's Park” subway station are less than five minutes away from our ending point, and “St. George” subway station is about ten minute walk away.

 

The tour takes place over easy terrain. It's mostly conducted on sidewalks but there are some unpavesd park spaces that we cover.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Royal Ontario Museum, east (former) entrance, Queen's Park Crescent

team.bio: Richard Fiennes-Clinton began Muddy York Walking Tours fifteen years ago, and has been leading walks around Toronto ever since.  Known to many in the local heritage community, his involvement in local history predates his launch of his own tour company.  Regularly scheduled weekly walks include ghost tours, as well as tours on a variety of other subjects, including neighbourhood history, crime, theatre history and many other subjects.  Visit him online at www.muddyyorktours.com or search for the Muddy York Walking Tour Group on facebook for special upcoming events.

accessible-info: Mostly accessible but some unpaved park space.
accessible-transit: Closest subway station is "Museum".  St. George Subway Station is a walk of about 10 minutes.
accessible-parking: Some side street parking and nearby lots.
accessible-find:
Our tour begins by the old entrance to the Royal Ontario Museum, facing Queen 's Park Crescent, on the east side of the building (so, not at the crystalline addition on the north Bloor Street side of the building).
 
Please arrive for 7 p.m. on Saturday, May 4th, 2013 at the stairs as pictured in this photograph.

title: Hastings Park History Tour
shortdescription: Hastings Park is Vancouver's second oldest and second largest park. This Jane's Walk will redisocver about 150 years of Vancouver history.
longdescription: Hastings Park is Vancouver's second oldest and second largest park. This Jane's Walk will redisocver about 150 years of Vancouver history. We will also talk about the future of the park.   We will discuss how Hastings Park( HP) and the Vancouver Exhibition Association, which later became The Pacific National Exhibition (PNE) helped shape the surrounding community and Hastings Park as it is today. We will examine how Hastings Park transformed from a 160-acre expanse of thick forest, gullies and marsh in 1889 to what it is today, a mixed use urban park at the north east entrance of Vancouver.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: The corner of Hastings Street and Renfrew Street at the Miracle Mile monument

team.bio: My name is Armin Strohschein. I have lived in Vancouver since 1972 and in Hastings Sunrise since 1979. I find the history of or region, province and city a captivating subject and the history of Hastings Park is most intriguing. I hope you enjoy this look at the past, present and future of Hastings Park and as it relates to this part of the lower mainland.

accessible-parking: Parking in HP is free for park users also there are lots of bike racks.

title: En Masse: Conflict and Change in 19th Century Toronto
shortdescription: This walk explores the theme of conflict and change in 19th century Toronto. We will discuss the various peaceful movements and violent clashes that have led Toronto to become the city it is today.
longdescription: This walk explores the theme of conflict and change in 19th century Toronto. We will discuss the various peaceful movements and violent clashes that have led us to become the city we are today.

markers.description: Queen's Park subway station, northwest entrance.

team.bio:
This Jane's Walk will be led by Mackenzie House Museum staff.
The Mackenzie House Museum is the restored home of William Lyon Mackenzie, Toronto's first Mayor, a radical journalist and publisher, and leader of the Rebellion of 1837 in Upper Canada.

title: The Dog's Leg of Dundas West
shortdescription: The Dog's Leg of Dundas West tells the colourful stories of the denizens and burghers who lived in the Village of Brockton along Ontario's 2nd oldest thoroughfare.
longdescription:
The Dog's Leg of Dundas West tells the colourful stories of the denizens and burghers who lived in the Village of Brockton along Ontario's 2nd Oldest thoroughfare.

This walk will explore how the interaction of commerce and architecture has shaped the development of our unique community.

Sponsored by the Dundas West BIA
