team.name-first: Alec Keefer, Past President of Toronto Architectural Conservancy
team.bio: Alec Keefer has been a resident of West End Toronto for over 30 years. He has an extensive background in studying the urban form; researching, writing and publishing. Alec is Past President of the Toronto Architectural Conservancy and has led numerous, highly entertaining walks all over our city.

accessible-info: municipal sidewalks
accessible-transit: 504 Dundas Street West Streetcar or 47 bus from Lansdowne Subway Station

title: תחבורה בת קיימא: הליכוּת, נגישות וניידות בעיר
shortdescription: סיור המתמקד בתנועה בעיר במהלכו נתבונן ונחווה את ההליכה ואת הנסיעה בתור התרחשויות עירוניות מתוכננות ומכוונות. ההליכה לא תשמש רק כאמצעי להגיע ממקום למקום ולהתבונן על הבינוי או הנוף העירוני, אלא בכדי להבין את פעולת ההליכה עצמה: מהם התנאים בהם היא מתאפשרת, מהן ההזדמנויות שהיא יוצרת; מהי עירוניות הליכה (ניתנת להליכה), איזה קנה מידה עירוני יוצר אותה, אילו סוגים של עירוניות מזמינים הליכה ואילו מאתגרים אותה, מהם מרכיבי ההליכוּת וכיצד ניתן לקדם ולעודד אותה, וגם: מהם המחירים שהיא גובה והאם ניתן להימנע מהם.
longdescription:
״ההליכות של ג׳יין״ היא תנועה עירונית בינלאומית המבקשת להחזיר למרכז הבמה את הפעולה הפשוטה שנדמה היה שהולכת ונשכחת: ההליכה. ההליכה ברגל, השיטוט העירוני, עשויה להיראות מובנת מאליה, אולם סופרים, סוציולוגים ואמנים רבים הרבו להתייחס אליה במשך עשורים. מאז אמצע המאה ה20, נדמה שהנסיעה, ובמיוחד הנסיעה במכונית הפרטית, תפסה את מקומה של ההליכה והיא עתה אמצעי התנועה האנושי המרכזי. נדמה כי בעשורים האחרונים,  יותר מבניינים ורחובות, עיר היא בעיקר כבישים. 

האם מצב זב הוא טבעי? האם הוא טוב? האם אפשר אחרת?

התנועה בעיר היא שעומדת במוקד סיור זה. בסיור נתבונן ונחווה את ההליכה ואת הנסיעה בתור התרחשויות עירוניות. ההליכה לא תשמש רק כאמצעי כדי להגיע ממקום למקום ולהתבונן על הבינוי או הנוף העירוני, אלא בכדי להבין את ההליכה עצמה. מהם התנאים בהם היא מתאפשרת, מהן ההזדמנויות שהיא יוצרת; גם הנסיעה במכונית תובן לא בתור הכרח או טבע שני, אלא בתור פעילות עירונית מתוכננת ומכוונת. במהלך הסיור נתהה על יתרונותיה וחסרונותיה. 

נדבר על המושג הליכוּת (walkability), ועל ניידות ונגישות. נבין מה ההבדלים ביניהם וכיצד הם באים לידי ביטוי בנוף העירוני. מהי עירוניות הליכה (ניתנת להליכה), איזה קנה מידה עירוני יוצר אותה, אילו סוגים של עירוניות מזמינים הליכה ואילו מאתגרים אותה, מהם מרכיבי ההליכות וכיצד ניתן לקדם ולעודד אותה, וגם: מהם המחירים שהיא גובה והאם ניתן להימנע מהם.

ההליכה תעבור בין מרחבים עירוניים שונים ונראה כיצד העיר משתנה על פי אפשרויות ההליכה או הנסיעה בה. מהו רחוב עירוני? אילו אפשרויות נגישות הוא מאפשר? האם ניידות שווה לנגישות? במה ניידות בהליכה משתנה לעומת ניידות בנסיעה? איזה מרקם עירוני יוצר אפשרויות הליכה ואילו נסיעה? ואיזו חוויה עירונית עירונית יוצרת נגישות? ואיך נחווים כל אלה עבור האזרח והאזרחית העירוניים, תושבי העיר הזאת.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: שינקין פינת מלצ'ט

accessible-find: תמר זנדברג היא חברת כנסת (מרצ), יו"ר שותפה של השדולה לתחבורה בת קיימא בכנסת. לשעבר חברת מועצת עיריית תל אביב יפו

title: New Ideas in Old Buildings
shortdescription: Take to the sidewalk in search of new ideas coming out of old(er) buildings in the Beltline
longdescription:
"Old ideas can sometimes use new buildings," noted Jane Jacobs. "New ideas must use old buildings."

This tour will take to the sidewalks in search of new ideas coming out of a few old(er) buildings in the Beltline. Hear first hand stories from local entrepreneurs. Identify with the risks they confront but also the connections they forge with the community. A bonus treat: Experience art, design objects, books, and the smell of fresh bread.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Avalanche Gallery, 1235 Macleod Trail SE at the corner of 13th avenue SE

team.bio: Amery Calvelli is a regular walker who believes the habitual stroll cultivates a deeper understanding of place, and who has discovered new things that were missed before on exactly the same path. She is a proponent of good design and hosts a small radio show called space+place on CJSW.

accessible-transit: LRT stations: LRT Victoria Park/Stampede stop
accessible-parking: Parking lots - Saturday rates - google to find near start or end of walk

title: Early Toronto : Heroes and Rogues in the Old Town of York
shortdescription: On this tour, you'll wander the streets of the Old Town of York, and find out where some of the most bizarre people in the town lived and worked.  You'll learn about Toronto's earliest history, but also have the chance to transport yourself back into the past, to become a resident of the old Town of York for an hour or two, and spy on your neighbours!
longdescription:
For forty years, what we know today as Toronto existed as a small little Georgian community called the Town of York.  Then, on March 6th, 1834, the old Town of York was incorporated into the City of Toronto.  Fifteen years later, in 1849, a fire swept through Toronto's Old Town District and consigned most of whatever was left of the Georgian Town of York to flames.

 

On this tour, we'll wander the ten square blocks of the main downtown Old Town of York.  Those early community leaders – politicians, merchants, heroes and rogues – were mostly brought over from England or Scotland, or were from Loyalist families who had fled the horrors of American republicanism. They weren't always the quiet and sober historical characters that most of us seem to remember from our history books.  They were often here because they were escaping some scandal in their past, or they were just generally eccentric.

 

On this tour, you'll wander the streets of the old Town of York, and find out where some of the most bizarre people in the town lived and worked.  You'll learn about Toronto's earliest history, but also have the chance to transport yourself back in to the past, to become a resident of the old Town of York for an hour or two, and spy on your neighbours!

 

This tour is a fairly easy walk of two hours.  It mostly takes place on sidewalks.  There are some stairs involved, and there will most likely be crowds through the St. Lawrence Market area.

 

The tour starts at the Market Gallery, located on the second floor of the south St. Lawrence Market Building, at 95 Front Street East.  Enter the main lobby of the south St. Lawrence Market building, and use either the stairs or the elevator, both located on the right hand side of the lobby, to go up to the second floor.

 

The tour concludes in the Distillery District by about 3:00 p.m.

 

TOUR START LOCATION : The Market Gallery, south St. Lawrence Market building, 95 Front Street East, second floor

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: The Market Gallery, south St. Lawrence Market building, 95 Front Street East, second floor.

team.bio: Richard Fiennes-Clinton began Muddy York Walking Tours fifteen years ago, and has been leading walks around Toronto ever since.  Known to many in the local heritage community, his involvement in local history predates his launch of his own tour company.  Regularly scheduled weekly walks include ghost tours, as well as tours on a variety of other subjects, including neighbourhood history, crime, theatre history and many other subjects.  Visit him online at www.muddyyorktours.com or search for the Muddy York Walking Tour Group on facebook for special upcoming events.

accessible-info: Easy walk, but some stairs and uneven sidewalks or cobblestone.
accessible-transit: To reach the starting point, disembark at King Street Subway and walk east for about 10 minutes, to Jarvis Street.  Walk south on Jarvis Street for one block to Front Street.
accessible-parking: Local public lots, with parking at the Distillery District, where the tour ends.
accessible-find: Our tour starts upstairs, on the second floor of the south St. Lawrence Market, in the Market Gallery, located at 95 Front Street East.  This is a photograph of the exterior of the Market Gallery.

title: A Walk Through Time: Bridgeland-Riverside
shortdescription: Let's talk about 50 key years in the life of this great neighbourhood
longdescription: We will stroll through time ... from 1910, the 1920s, and all the way up into the 1950s... as we look at the historical factors that have shaped the community of Bridgeland-Riverside.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Bridgeland Riverside Community Association, 917 Centre Avenue NE

team.bio:
Sharon has lived in Bridgeland for 40 years. She spent 22 years working at the former Calgary General Hospital as a medical laboratory technologist and is now on staff at Heritage Park. She's served a volunteer for many groups, inside and outside the neighbourhood, and is a long-term member of the High Riser Toastmasters which has been meeting in Bridgeland since 1979. She is also a volunteer reader with Accessible Media. Sharon has an interest in preserving and retelling history, believing it is important to know your history.
Christine works in the community of Bridgeland-Riverside and became fascinated with its history a few years ago on another Jane's Walk.

accessible-info: We will be on sidewalks and paved roads; no stairs.
accessible-transit: Take the C-train stop Bridgeland-Memorial & then head North along 9 St NE to its intersection with Centre Ave NE. Or take Bus #9, exit at 1 Ave & 10 St NE, then follow 1 Ave West, turn South on 9 St and meet at the corner of 9 St and Centre Ave NE
accessible-parking: 2-hour parking on-street, free on Sundays

title: Victoria Park: Historic, Adaptable, Diverse & Walkable
shortdescription: One of Calgary's oldest neighbourhoods is also one of its youngest and hippest. Oh, and should we mention chocolate and ice cream?
longdescription:
Victoria Park is becoming one of Calgary's foremost diverse, dense & walkable urban neighbourhoods.

The tour will cover the diversity of Victoria Park, one of the oldest neighbourhoods and one of the youngest and hippest. The tour will begin with an introduction to the historic sandstone school in Haultain Park, weave through the eclectic mix of businesses along 1 St SW, and move to the adaptively reused heritage sandstone and brick buildings in the Warehouse District. We will present some of the modern mixed-use buildings popping up in the skyline, and visit some of the independent shops and restaurants in the area.

Visits include Endeavour Arts Gallery and Events Space, Taste restaurant, Vine Arts, Bernard Callebaut Factory & Village Ice Cream.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Haultain School in Haultain Park, 225 13 Ave SW

team.name-first: Julie Brache & Amanda Machell, Victoria Park BRZ
team.bio:
Julie Brache is a graduate from the Master of Architecture program at the University of Calgary, and is involved in urban planning and community development in the area.
Amanda Machell is a recent graduate from the interdisciplinary BA Urban Studies program at the University of Calgary, a resident of the area, and interested in urban planning and transit-oriented development in Calgary.
Victoria Park BRZ is a not-for-profit organization that works to develop, beautify, and improve the area, and is an advocate for important community issues.

accessible-info: City streets & sidewalks; 18+ for visit in wine store
accessible-transit: LRT stations: 1 St SW from the East or 3 St SW from the West. Buses: #6 stops in front and #3 is close by
accessible-parking: On-street pay parking (?)

title: Public Art in the Plus 15s
shortdescription: Discover art pieces in every Calgarians' art collection, displayed in Calgary's iconic walkway system
longdescription: Did you know that the City of Calgary holds an art collection in trust for all Calgarians? Discover some of the art pieces in your art collection by joining a tour of the art displayed in our +15 system. Come see what you may have missed.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Calgary Public Library, Central Branch, 616 Macleod Trail SE, at the info desk on the main floor

team.bio: Marian is part of Calgary Public Library's volunteer team and regularly leads tours of public art on display in and around the Central Library.  She continues to be intrigued by the pieces and by the artists, and by the stories of how these pieces came to be in our city. You will be too!

accessible-info: Please let us know at the beginning of the tour if accessibility is a concern for you, and we'll do our best to accommodate you
accessible-transit: C-train stops at City Hall or at Olympic Plaza
accessible-parking: Many parking lots in the downtown core, on Saturday rates. East Village and City Hall Parkade are most convenient

title: Footprints Around the Fort
shortdescription: Join two local historians for stories from the confluence of the Bow and Elbow Rivers. People have been meeting where these amazing rivers meet since time immemorial; come see why.
longdescription:
Come join us at the confluence of the Bow and Elbow Rivers. This transitional area has provided a gathering place for Blackfoot, Tsuu T'ina and Stoney peoples, a North West Mounted Police presence, a transportation hub, a unique open space and now the heritage anchor for the new East Village redevelopment plan.

Starting from the 9th Avenue bridge and the Elbow River, this walk will follow the path around the Fort Calgary along the Elbow and Bow Rivers and along 6th street, ending at the equestrian statue of Colonel James Macleod near the Fort Calgary parking lot. Stops along the route will provide opportunities to discuss river crossings, islands in the Elbow and Bow Rivers, the survival of the Fort Calgary site as Calgary moved west, transportation proposals from the 1960s and the river valley plan.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: At the buffalo sculpture, between Fort Calgary at the 9th Ave SE bridge

team.bio: Historians Donna Zwicker and John Gilpin promote the importance of historical perspective and context in the understanding of our urban environment.

accessible-info: Will stay on city bike path and pathways
accessible-transit: Bus 31, 31 and 302
accessible-parking: Fort Calgary has graciously allowed us to use their parking lot for the duration of this walk

title: Riverdale's Community Walking Map
shortdescription: EPSB School Board Trustee Dave Colburn, who supports healthy schools and communities, has challenged neighbourhoods in his Ward to participate in a Jane's Walk. Riverdale has taken up the challenge!
longdescription:
School Trustee Dave Colburn, known for supporting the health of children in schools, is now turning his attention to supporting the health of communities. He is challenging neighourhoods to participate in a Jane's Walk this May 4th and 5th.

Riverdale has taken up this challenge!

We will gather at Riverdale House and the walk will end at the house with light refreshments provided by the  Community League to celebrate the launch of our new community walking map.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Riverdale House - 9231 100 Ave NW

team.name-first: Allan Shute, with guest guide Dave Colburn
team.bio: Riverdale's historian Allan Shute will be leading the community walk starting at Riverdale House. He will be introducing Riverdalians to our new Community Walking Map.

accessible-parking: Free on Street Parking Available

title: Westminster Pier Park
shortdescription: More details to come.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Main entrance of Pier Park

title: Port Royal: Sawmills to Swing Sets
shortdescription: The mighty Fraser splits in two | changing shorelines/changing uses | industrial heritage | new urbanism (ala J. Jacobs) | new architecture | environmental stewards | barges & birds.
longdescription:
Queensborough, at the eastern tip of Lulu Island, has seen many changes: from First Nations, to settlers' farms, sawmills, ship yards, plants, and now public walkways, housing, parks, gardens and new roads.  We'll chat about all this and how urban change is a natural "ecological" process.  Like in nature, it needs to stay in balance between respect for the past, environmental stewardship and the needs and desires of living in a modern metropolis.

We'll end at Frankie G's Pub where the clam chowder is not too shabby.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Q'boro dog park: Duncan & Mercer Sts.

team.bio: Eric is an architect living and practicing in New Westminster with a particular interest in working with site context and adaptive reuse of historic buildings.

accessible-info: gravel paths, crossing train tracks
accessible-parking: nearby streets or at the pub
accessible-find: white cap

title: Break Down Barriers and We Will Come!
shortdescription: This year’s walk will raise awareness about pedestrian safety, age friendly and accessible spaces.  Plus, come try out a wheelchair and see what it’s like to navigate the neighbourhood and experience accessibility from a new perspective!
longdescription:
What does accessibility mean to you?  It’s more than just curb cuts and ramps.  The sidewalk width and grade, or shop entrance and aisle widths can make a huge difference.  Good lighting, easily defined steps, and smooth pavements all add to how easily and safely a person moves around their neighbourhood.

The Anne Johnston Health Station will lead an accessibility walk in the Yonge & Eglinton area.  Through sharing their personal stories, both long time residents and newcomers to the community will introduce walkers to who Anne Johnston is and why the Health Station is named after her, as well as provide a history of the neighbourhood.  In addition, drawing on Jane Jacobs’ principles, they will outline how the neighbourhood has seen changes in accessibility over the years, and draw attention to the current state and future goals of accessibility and people friendliness in the community.  To further illustrate their point, wheelchairs, courtesy of Motion Specialties, will be provided to participants so that they can discover, first hand, what it’s like to travel around the area by wheelchair and experience what is accessible and what is not.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: The Anne Johnston Health Station: 2398 Yonge, Toronto, ON M4P 2H4

team.bio:
This walk will be led by a renegade gang of barrier breakers, from the Anne Johnston Health Station, a not-for-profit community health centre providing a wide range of programs and services that promote the health and well-being of seniors, youth and people with physical disabilities.   
Volunteers, Adam, Lynda, Chris, Grania, Mary Lynn, Denzil, Murray, Henry, John and Betty will lead the walk.

accessible-info: Accessible
accessible-transit: One light north of Yonge and Eglinton / TTC subway: Eglinton Station, on West side of the street

title: 200 Years at Yonge & Lawrence
shortdescription: A look at how has this intersection and surrounding community has evolved from  1813 to 1913 to 2013.
longdescription:
Join local history columnist Gary Schlee for a walk up Yonge Street north of Lawrence, experiencing it in 1813, 1913 and 2013.

  • Visualize the area when it was dominated by trees and a few pioneer settlers clearing land on their 200-acre farms.
  • Visualize the area when the first two-storey storefront strips  were being built.
  • See the vibrant thoroughfare today and learn about some of the stories it has to tell.

This Jane's Walk is being sponsored by the Yonge Lawrence Village BIA (Business Improvement Area) and the Fairlawn Neighbourhood Centre. (Photos above from the Toronto Public Library [first] and Google [second].)

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Yonge & Lawrence (southeast corner), behind the Locke Library at the William McDougall plaque

team.bio: Gary Schlee is a former communications professor and journalist with an interest in local history. For 10 years, he wrote The Story Of A Community, a column about the Bedford Park neighbourhood at Yonge and Lawrence. It appeared in Community Life, a neighbourhood paper distributed by Fairlawn Avenue United Church. Many of his columns can be found at bedfordpark.wordpress.com.

accessible-info: Curbs at cross-streets are cut out.
accessible-transit: Lawrence subway station, exit at the south end and cross to the southeast corner of Yonge & Lawrence
accessible-parking: Street parking on Yonge and Lawrence.

title: Westminster Pier Park: The Design Rationale- The River, The Past, The People
shortdescription: Learn how the image, feel and theme of Westminster Pier Park embraces the rich heritage and history of the city of New Westminster.
longdescription: New Westminster has the noble distinction of being the oldest city in British Columbia. Located prominently on the banks of the Fraser River it was first settled in 1859. Throughout its long history, the City’s waterfront has been primarily used as a commercial and industrial hub. Join us for the walk to hear how New Westminster’s rich history was taken into consideration when designing Westminster Pier Park.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Entrance of Pier Park

team.bio: Bruce Hemstock, New Westminster resident and Principal of PWL Partnership, a leading Vancouver-based landscape architectural firm with over thirty years experience in public and private sector planning and design across Canada, the U.S. and internationally.

accessible-info: Access from Begbie Street via parking lot adjacent to the Fraser River Discovery Centre
accessible-parking: Paid parking at Front St.Parkade or Larco Parking Lot

title: Singles Walk- Finding Romance in Toronto
shortdescription:
According to the 2006 census, in Toronto, almost one in three households consists of people living alone, up 11 per cent from 2001.

Join Leehe and  Mimi, two singles, as they lead your through a walk in some of Toronto's most scenic spots.  On this walk you'll be introduced to several romantic places to bring a date.  Meet other singles who share a love of exploring urban green spaces.  We encourage singles of all ages and sexual orientations to join this unique walk.
longdescription:
According to the 2006 census, in Toronto, almost one in three households consists of people living alone, up 11 per cent from 2001.

Join Leehe and  Mimi, two singles, as they lead you through some of Toronto's most scenic spots.  You'll be introduced to several romantic places to bring a date.  Meet other singles who share a love of exploring urban green spaces.  We encourage singles of all ages and sexual orientations to join us on this unique walk.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Davenport & Spadina (bottom of the Baldwin Steps)

team.bio:
Leehe Lev is a Personal Trainer, Pilates Instructor and Water Exercise Specialist,  owner of Whole Self Fitness.  She's been enjoying the green spaces around St. Clair west for over 10 years.
Mimi Lau is a community planner who is enthusiastic about all that relates to a sense of place. She currently lives in the in-between world of Mississauga.

accessible-info: There are several stairs and dirt paths.
accessible-transit: 5 minute walk north on Spadina from Dupont Station OR Spadina stop on the Davenport bus
accessible-parking: Metered parking along Davenport
accessible-find: Bottom of Baldwin Steps

title: Albert Park: From Hamlet to City Neighbourhood
shortdescription: You can still see the footprint of the original village if you know how to look. Spend the late afternoon in this understated Calgary neighbourhood with 102 years under its belt, and see how it's creating its future.
longdescription: A discussion of the origin of Albert Park as one of three hamlets east of Calgary that were eventually annexed.  Of note are the form factors remaining from the village's original footprint, the transformation of 17 Avenue into a major highway, and 100 years of development of housing and commercial space.  The walk ends with the recently built Albert Park Centennial Garden.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: APRH Community Hall

team.bio: Mark grew up in a several small towns in Southern Alberta.  Upon moving to Albert Park he noticed a lot of similarities with the small towns where he grew up - right in the middle of the city.  He's been a proud member of the community for four years.

accessible-info: On city streets and sidewalks
accessible-transit: Route 1 to Forest Lawn Shopping Centre, then walk two blocks north
accessible-parking: Plenty available at community hall
accessible-find: We'll meet at the Albert Park / Radisson Heights Community Association hall, tour begins about 4:00 pm.

title: Graffiti in Toronto
shortdescription: Walk "Graffiti Alley" with Jason Kucherawy of Tour Guys to learn about the history of graffiti, its place in Toronto's urban culture, and the subculture around this controversial art form. There's more to it than writing on a wall.
longdescription:
Graffiti is all around us. This tour will be a primer on graffiti and the different types seen on the streets and in the alleyways and feature a stroll down "Graffiti Alley" (Where Rick Mercer does his "rants" on CBC) past some of the most remarkable graffiti pieces in the city.

You'll learn key graffiti vocabulary, tips on how to read the sometimes indecipherable writing, and what's happening both on the street and in City Hall with regards to graffiti art and vandalism.

Accompanied by a professional tour guide with a fine arts and cultural anthropology background, this will be a walking discussion on the past, present and future of graffiti in Toronto.

Bring your camera and an open mind!

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: The "HUG Tree" at the NW corner of Queen St W and Soho St.

team.bio:
Jason Kucherawy started Tour Guys in 2009 with his good friend Steve Woodall with the intent to offer quality city walking tours to locals and visitors. They began by offering free public walking tours in their respective cities (Jason in Toronto and Steve in Vancouver) while working for tips and eventually branched out into specialty tours with a cost attached. In Toronto, Tour Guys runs tours covering such topics as history, beer, ghosts, culture, rock & roll, and bacon. And graffiti too, of course. 
Jason has an excellent working relationship with school groups, educational tour companies, and in-bound tour operators, and is a proud member of Tourism Toronto. He has an educational background in fine arts and cultural anthropology (York University '99) and more than 15 years experience in improv and stand-up comedy coupled with an equal number of years working in travel and tourism.
For more information on Tour Guys find us: 

on the Web - www.tourguys.ca
on Facebook - https://www.facebook.com/TourGuys 
on Twitter - https://twitter.com/toronto_tourguy

accessible-transit: From Spadina Station, take the Spadina streetcar to Queen St and walk a block east. Or from Osgoode Station, take the Queen streetcar west to Soho St.
accessible-parking: Public parking lot next to the starting location and street parking in the neighbourhood.
accessible-find: We will gather at the "HUG Tree" at the north west corner of Soho and Queen St W. It's across the street from the Black Bull Tavern and next to a public parking lot. Your guide will be holding a can of spray paint.

title: Changing Demographics on North Bathurst
shortdescription: Once predominantly Jewish, the Bathurst-401 area is now also home to a fast growing Filipino community. Come explore a unique neighbourhood in transition!
longdescription:
The walk will begin at Wilson and Bathurst and head 2 km south along Bathurst to Lawrence.  On the way we will pass various Jewish schools and synagogues as well as the massive Baycrest geriatric centre.  We will also check out both  the  Jewish and Filipino retail scene along the strip.

 The walk leader, a long term local resident, will interweave personal memories and anecdotes of the neighbourhood going back to the 1950's.

Please be advised that there will be a film crew of four people present during the walk.  By attending, you may be on camera, so please be aware that your image and/or voice may be recorded.  If you have any questions or concernes, please contact me beforehand.  Also, if you've appeared on camera, you may be approached with a release form at the end of the walk.  Thank you for your co-operation!

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: The parkette on the SE corner of Bathurst and Wilson.

team.bio: David Teitel's family first moved into the Bathurst-401 neighbourhood in 1956 and he has lived there on and off  ever since.  (He's been back since 2004.)  He attended the local Hebrew school for 13 years and feels uniquely qualified to lead this walk,  because in addition to Hebrew and Yiddish, he can get by in basic Tagalog!

accessible-info: The narrow sidewalk underneath the 401, may be challenging for wheelchairs. Otherwise the terrain is flat and paved.
accessible-transit: A short ride on the Wilson bus either west from the York mills sta. or east from the Wilson station.  Or a 30 minute ride on the Bathurst 7 bus from the Bathurst station.
accessible-parking: Side street parking off Bathurst, north of Wilson.
accessible-find: A light green umbrella!

title: Unemployed organizing in East Downtown Toronto during the Great Depression
shortdescription: During the Great Depression thousands of single unemployed men filled the city's relief shellters, many of which were located in East Downtown Toronto. Who were these men and what organizations did they belong too?
longdescription: During the Great Depression thousands of single unemployed men filled the city's relief shellters, many of which were located in East Downtown Toronto. They organized against the living conditions in overcorwded city shelters, demanded an end to the forced labour test, and called for cash relief and the abolishment  of hostels. Who were these men and what organizations did they belong too? The walk will explore how the unemployed  organized to change their living conditions in city hostels during the Great Depression.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: All Saints Church - South East corner of Sherbourne St  and Dundas St. E.

team.bio: Gaetan Heroux is a long time anti-poverty activist with the Ontario Coalition Against Poverty who has worked in East Downtown Toronto for 25 years.

accessible-transit: Take Dundas St. W (or Dundas Street E.) street car to Sherbourne  St.
accessible-parking: Free parking along Dundas St. E - East of Sherbourne

title: A Working Habitat (stage 1)
shortdescription:
Micro-enterprise has a unique position in the urban environment. Micro-entrepreneurs often use low-cost infrastructure and a tenuous position in the public marketplace to make a living for themselves. And, in profiting from our public spaces, they enrich those spaces, through the local circulation of economic activity, the curation of community atmosphere and the stewardship of public space.

Join Howard Tam and Jon Woodside of the Working Habitat to explore how micro-enterprise already works in our city and discuss ways that role can be expanded.

See you there!
longdescription:
Micro-enterprise has a unique position in the urban environment. Micro-entrepreneurs often use low-cost infrastructure and a tenuous position in the public marketplace to make a living for themselves. And, in profiting from our public spaces, they enrich those spaces, through the local circulation of economic activity, the curation of community atmosphere and the stewardship of public space.

Market 707 on Dundas East of Bathurst


With an increasingly unpredictable economy and the consistent cuts to the social safety net micro-enterprise is more important than ever. Join Howard Tam and Jon Woodside of the Working Habitat to explore how micro-enterprise already works in our city and discuss ways that role can be expanded.

This walk will take place on May 4th at 11:00am is the first of a two-part walk series. We will begin in Chinatown and Kensington Market and end at Market 707 by Scadding Court Community Centre - just in time for lunch. Bring an appetite and help support your local micro-entrepreneurs.

Stage two will take place at the end of June in Thorncliffe Park where we will discuss how the ideas explored downtown could be translated to our underserviced, suburban communities. Stay tuned for more details as they arrise.

See you there!

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: 215 Spadina Avenue - Outside the Centre for Social Innovation, Spadina branch

team.bio:
The walk will be lead by Howard Tam and Jon Woodside principals and founders of The Working Habitat. A project focussed on building awareness of the opportunities and importance of micro-entreprise across Toronto.
 Check out our brand new facebook page.

title: Off the Grid: Vaughan Road
shortdescription: Grab an ice cream with Councillor Joe Mihevc and enjoy a walk along Vaughan Road, one of the city's oldest roads.
longdescription:
Most Toronto city streets follow a grid plan, but have you ever wondered about streets that go off the grid? On May 4th join us for a walk along Vaughan Road. Learn about the history of one of the city's earliest roads which runs parallel to the buried Castle Frank brook and the failed Spadina Expressway, learn about local communities that have shaped the city, the development of higher-density areas in Toronto, see the house where anarchist Emma Goldman died, and more!

You are invited to walk, listen, and tell your own story. We'll start the walk on the west side of Vaughan & Bathurst, at 1pm.  If it's a nice day, you may want to stop first at Dutch Dreams at St. Clair & Bathurst to grab an ice cream cone. The walk will end at Oakwood & Vaughan.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Bathurst & Vaughan Road

team.bio:
Joe Mihevc is City Councillor for Ward 21. His deep concern for social issues has led him to be an advocate for strong neighbourhoods, healthy communities, a clean environment and safe streets. As a City Councillor, Joe has helped transform the area with a variety of innovative projects, including the building of the Artscape Wychwood Barns and Park, the Oakwood Village Library and Arts Centre and the redevelopment of St. Clair Avenue West’s transit infrastructure and public realm. 
 
Local resident Arlene Clement first got to know Vaughan Road and its surrounding neighbourhoods while out on long walks with her sleeping baby.  She continues to explore the area, and looks forward to sharing what she has discovered and learning more about its histories, environment, and the people who live here.

accessible-transit: Take St. Clair Streetcar to Vaughan road, walk 1 block south OR Bathurst St. bus to 1 stop south of St. Clair
accessible-parking: Green P Parking Lot at St. Clair & Pinewood, west of Vaughan

title: Edmonds Today
shortdescription: Walk along Edmonds from Tommy Douglas' home in Burnaby to his namesake library.  Learn about the contributions of the immigrants in this neighbourhood.
longdescription: Walk along Edmonds from Tommy Douglas' home in Burnaby to his namesake library. Learn about the contributions of the immigrants in this neighbourhood.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: 7415 Sixth Street, Burnaby (near corner of Sixth Street and 17th Avenue)

team.bio: Oana Capota has lived in Burnaby for over 11 years, with six of those years in the Edmonds area.

accessible-transit: Bus #106 from New Westminster Station or Edmonds Station.

title: Islands of Green
shortdescription: This walk doubles as the Peterborough Field Naturalists' Sunday morning Wildlife Walk. We’ll have a leisurely walk around the South Drumlin, one of Trent University’s Nature Areas. We’ll talk about the historical land uses in the area and how the land is used today.
longdescription:
We'll have a leisurely walk around the South Drumlin, one of Trent University’s Nature Areas. We’ll talk about the historical land uses in the area and how the land is used today. You may be surprised to learn that the lumber mills once operating nearby were among the largest in Ontario.

After the walk you should also have an understanding of what a drumlin is and why and why this landform is characteristic of the Peterborough area. We’ll observe the contrast in the vegetation below the drumlin, which has been completely modified by humans, and the relatively undisturbed sugar maple – American beech woodland on top of the drumlin.

Weather permitting, there will likely be a nice show of spring wild flowers and the songs of migrating birds. We’ll talk about the special value of such remnant natural areas and ways that you can speak up for them.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Nassau Mills Road and Armour Rd, Peterborough, ON, Canada

accessible-info: We will be walking on a trail with some rough sections and moderate inclines on the slope of the drumlin. The walk will take about 1.5 hr and the distance is approximately 2 km.
accessible-parking: Parking on side of road, top of Armour Road
accessible-find: Look for "the Cabin", (which used to be Reggie's Grill) on the north end of Armour Rd

title: A Children's Walk
shortdescription: The children’s walk is intended to allow our children to experience the dense, urban downtown Chicago environment as they walk along the Chicago River.
longdescription:
Meet at 151 East Wacker Drive, the Hyatt Regency Hotel, at 10:00 AM for refreshments before starting the tour!

We'll meet at the Columbian room, which is on the Bronze Level of the West Tower.   It is reached from the West Tower entrance (one level below) and East Tower Valet Parking.

The children’s walk is intended to allow our children to experience the dense, urban downtown Chicago environment as they walk along the Chicago River. Throughout the adventure, we will ask our children to stop and consider the as-built environment, and associated land planning principles, while engaging in an interactive trivia game.

Some  fun spots we'll  explore:

    • Stairs that go up and down to places that are hidden from most people;

    • Wonderful east, west and river views of Chicago.  This is something no other city has: the wonderful open views that set of the buildings;

    • There are some really cool  old and new buildings that are the real Chicago;

    •  There is a Fannie May store on the corner – one of the few left!

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Meet at 151 East Wacker Drive, the Hyatt Regency Hotel, in the Soldier Field room, which is on the Bronze Level of the West Tower.   It is reached from the West Tower entrance (one level below) and East Tower Valet Parking.

team.bio:
Lee Bey has had a distinguished career in the built environment as an architecture critic, mayoral advisor, adjunct professor and civic leader.  Gigi McCabe-Miele is an architect in Chicago.  It is truly an honor to have both of them lead the children on this walk of our beautiful city. 
(From the Friends of the Downtown Board-thank you Lee!)

title: Contentious Ribbon of Green: Exploring the Parkway Corridor
shortdescription: We will enjoy a 4 km walk along the most beautiful and biologically-rich section of the Parkway Trail and learn about its flora and fauna, history and present-day recreational use. The Parkway Trail is controversial because of the very real possibility that it may become an arterial road.
longdescription:
The Parkway Trail is one of Peterborough's premier natural areas, serving as a wildlife corridor across the city. It is also a beautiful place to walk, bike and discover near-by nature. However, it may very well end up becoming a two-lane arterial road to improve north-south traffic flow across Peterborough. What is the value of green, urban corridors and should road development go ahead?

We will walk the Parkway Trail, starting behind Northminster United Church and continuing to just south of Cumberland Ave - a total of 2 kms up the trail and 2 kms back.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: 300 Sunset Blvd, Northminster United Church (meet in parking lot behind the church)

team.bio: Drew Monkman is a local naturalist and nature writer who has had a special interest in the future of the Parkway Trail and corridor for many years. He writes a weekly nature and environment column in the Peterborough Examiner and is the author of two books. His most recent book, "Nature's Year in Central and Eastern Ontario" describes the main events in our flora and fauna each month of the year. A retired teacher, Drew used to take his students on regular outings along the Parkway Trail as part of his science and physical education program.

accessible-info: The entire route is paved. We will, however, have to cross a 25 metre grassy area to get to the trail.

title: The Square Revisited
shortdescription: Expect to be entertained and inspired as local architects, artists and community leaders walk us through the past, present and future of the Goderich Square.
longdescription:
Celebrate spring by joining us for a healthy walk around the Goderich Square.  Expect to be entertained and inspired as local speakers walk us through the past, present and future of the Square.  This is a great time to get active and share your experiences in the Square with your neighbours. 

What were some of the best and worst moments in the history of the Square?  What does the future hold for a thriving, walkable downtown Goderich?   Jane's Walk on the Square will get you thinking about all this and more.  Listen in or participate in discussions about architecture, youth issues, accessibility, urban agriculture, history, and downtown living.

4-6pm:  Join us after the walk at Joe Friday's to celebrate the 97th birthday of the late, great  Jane Jacobs. 

Questions? Please contact janeswalkgoderich@gmail.com

Saturday April 20th, 2pm, at the Huron County Museum:    The Goderich Documentary Group, in partnership with the Maitland Trail Association, will be screening the documentary Urban Goddess: Jane Jacobs Reconsidered.  Doors open at 1:30pm, film starts at 2pm. Lug a mug for Coastal Coffee Company coffee and enjoy treats and great discussion after the film.  Pay-What-You-Can, suggested donation $5. 

For more info on the film, visit: 

http://moving images.ca/store/products.php?urban_goddess

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: In front of the Livery

team.bio: The walk will be led by several local people, including Gerard Creces, David Yates, Adolfo Spaleta, Amy Zoethout, Dean Whalen, Susan Whalen, Sandra Thompson and Lorie Falconer.

accessible-parking: Behind the Livery, Coffee Culture, side streets

title: TANJONG RUSA RAMBLE
shortdescription:
Stop the press, Jane’s Walk had finally invaded the shores of Singapore.

For our first ever Singapore JW, we have chosen the quaint & historical Tanjong Rusa also known as “Changi” to make our historical debut.

Located on the eastern end of Singapore, this area is rich with history and folklore. Led by our wacky guide Kid, you will pick up interesting snippets of interesting information pertaining to this quaint little corner of Singapore.
longdescription:
TANJONG RUSA RAMBLE

Our walk will start from Changi Beach where the infamous Sook Ching massacre was carried out during WWII. From there, we will be following the Changi coastline via the Changi Point Boardwalk that begins from Changi Creek in the east and stretches to the western rocky coast near Changi Beach Club. Along the way, you can admire the architecture of various historical buildings including the one built by wealthy Jew Manasseh Meyer. Looking beyond the sea, we can admire the greeneries of Pulau Ubin, and if visibility is good, we may even spot Frog Island that is part of the Ubin Island folklore.  Along the way, be fascinated by stories of the various greeneries that abound in this area including the Sea Hibiscus, Sea Lettuce, Sea Almond to the Simpoh Air. Admire the different views from the various sections of the boardwalk including Creek Walk, Beach Walk, Sailing Point Walk, Cliff Walk, Kelong Walk & Sunset Walk. From the Changi Beach Club, we will then switch over to the Changi Walking Trail with its series of Heritage Trees including the Sepetir, Olive Tree, Rengas, Damar Hitam and the Strangling Fig. We will also catch sight of the famous Old Changi Hospital with its spooky tales. We will end our walk back in Changi Village.

Registration: Pls send name, email contact & mobile contact to luvadventure888@yahoo.com.sg to register.
That way we can keep track of how many people are coming & be able to arrange the resources accordingly.
(Do not call to ask me to wait though, that will not be fair to others. Try to look for us on the Changi Boardwalk)

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Changi Village Hotel (beside the road)

team.bio:
Kid from Luv@Adventure had been leading local Singapore treks for more than 20 years now. Many of the walks are of his own creation and they often provide an unique and interesting experience for those who have followed him. Known for his quirkiness and varied knowledge of all sorts, he can often be trusted to spin a yarn or two during the treks spewing on topics that range from the useless, mundane to those that are interesting, jaw-dropping and sometimes profound. His walks or treks are popularly received although sometimes in the not so expected ways. But be it good or bad, you will still walk away learning something new from him. 
OK, enough of self promotion ... lest I self immolate. 
For those who are interested to check out his treks or even follow him on some of his local treks & activities, do check out and join his Luv@Adventure FB Group at:
 https://www.facebook.com/groups/102357963199140/
 
From Kid
LUV@ADVENTURE
Adventure with panache

accessible-info: Easily accessible by public transport
accessible-transit: Take bus to Changi Village Bus Terminal & take a short 3 mins walk to the hotel
accessible-parking: Lots of public car parks around vicinity of Changi Village but they can get crowded during weekend
accessible-find:
Just look out for someone tall, dark & handsome (he only matches 2 of the criteria)
…or just look out for a group of serious looking trekkers, you can’t go wrong. 
Anyway, if in doubt, call 90685973.

title: Charles Sauriol Conservation Reserve
shortdescription: Join us on a walk through the Charles Sauriol Conservation Reserve along the East Don River.
longdescription:
Join us on a walk through the Charles Sauriol Conservation Reserve along the East Don River.

The Charles Sauriol Conservation Reserve was established in 1989 by the Toronto & Region Conservation Authority, named after the late naturalist Charles Sauriol.  It remains one of the most natural areas in Toronto.

title: Brentwood Celebrates 50 Years!
shortdescription: Come hear the stories that have special meaning for long-time Brentwood residents and for anyone who is curious about the history of this wonderful neighbourhood.
longdescription: The walk will cover a section of the community of Brentwood and will focus on the buildings, landmarks and features from when Brentwood was first developed to what we see in the community now. There will be stories of  people and events that have special meaning for long-time residents and those interested in the history of this area.

markers.description: Nose Hill Library, 1530 Northmount Drive NW

team.bio: I am the Customer Service Manager of the Nose Hill Library and love to talk about the connection between libraries and community individuals and groups. I appreciate the strong community spirit in Brentwood and want to celebrate with residents and friends as they recognize 50 years as an established community in Calgary.

accessible-info: City streets & sidewalks
accessible-parking: At the library

title: Feminist Walking Tour
shortdescription: Discover the unknown stories about Calgary women's activists and talk about what concerns Calgary women today.
longdescription: Curious about how women have helped to create today's Calgary? Join us on a stroll through downtown Calgary to discover some of the unknown stories about Calgary women. We will mark the achievements of women who came before us, highlight the work being done by women today and learn about current issues that women in Calgary are concerned about.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: City Hall, in front of the horses statue

team.name-first: Caterina Gut, Elizabeth Jack & Sarah Winstanley, The Women's Centre of Calgary
team.bio:
The Women's Centre of Calgary is a unique street-front organization that provides a variety of services and opportunities to the women of Calgary. We work in three strategic areas: Get Assistance, Connect with Others, and Work for Change. Our website is http://www.womenscentrecalgary.org/
Caterina is the Education Coordinator, Elizabeth is a dedicated volunteer, and Sarah is a new team member. All are passionate about women's issues.

accessible-info: We will cover about 2.5 km on city streets and sidewalks. We will do our best to keep the walk wheelchair accessible.
accessible-transit: For starting location, use City Hall or Centre Street LRT stations. To come back from Central Park, use buses 13, 6, 7 or 419
accessible-parking: Downtown parkades on Saturday rates; Lots 24 & 36 of the City parkades are near by

title: International Avenue - Short Form
shortdescription: Join us for an insider's look into what makes International Avenue so special. There's so much to see - this 2 hour walk is just a taste.
longdescription:
International Avenue is a vibrant business district with a diverse ethnic composition located on 17th Avenue S.E., from 26 to 61st streets. There is an interesting mix of business representative of the cosmopolitan neighbourhoods surrounding the Avenue. It is an area of one-stop shopping with access to a selection of restaurants and grocery stores from around the world, as well as a wide range of other retail goods and services.

On this walk, we'll talk about the past, visit some unique food stores, try some amazing food, and give you an insider's look into the Avenue.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: 2601 17 Avenue SE, in the park overlooking the Bow Waters Canoe Club

team.bio: As a tireless advocate for the area working as the Executive Director for International Avenue BRZ, I'll give you the real goods on what makes this community special.

accessible-info: Some stores may be hard to access but we'll make our best effort to accommodate you
accessible-transit: Buses #1 or #305
accessible-parking: At the meeting place

title: Chinatown Tour
shortdescription: The murals of Chinatown depict stories of how the Chinese community planted roots in Calgary. Visit alleyways and community businesses in the heart of Calgary and see for yourself. You'll even get to try your hand at Chinese calligraphy!
longdescription:
Want to know more about Chinese culture but never got a chance to visit China? The Chinatown Tour will be the best choice for you!

Chinatown is a small reflection of China embedded in brilliant culture and exuberant history. We have murals that were painted to fight graffiti and to share stories of how the Chinese community planted roots in Calgary. You won't want to miss  the 100 year-old Canton Building Dinning Block that serves tons of amazing traditional Chinese food, the Chinese Cultural Centre that holds great Chinese events, Sien Lok Park that is always promoting Chinese language, philosophies and culture, and the Dragon City Mall with its many Chinese businesses.

Plus we will end our walk by writing Chinese calligraphy. Want to have your first piece of Chinese writing? Then join us for our 2013 Chinatown Tour!

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Calgary Chinese Community Service Association - #1 128 2 Avenue SW

team.bio:
CCCSA empowers current and future generations in the Chinese community by acting as a bridge to mainstream institutions and organizations, through education, facilitation and advocacy in addressing multicultural and diversity issues. 
We ran a successful Jane's Walk for each of the last four years - and this will be our fifth year! We hope we can promote Chinese culture and bridge the connection between Chinese community and Canadian society through leading this tour.

accessible-transit: Walk 5 blocks North from the LRT - Centre Street or 1 ST SW stations. Or take bus #3
accessible-parking: Street parking and parking lots

title: Dearborn: the grandest street in the US
shortdescription: Between Congress Parkway and Wacker Drive, Dearborn Street in Chicago has more important art and architecture sites from the past 125 years than any other street in the US. From Jenney to Mies, Calder to Picasso, Tiffany to Chagall, stainless steel to Cor-ten, it's all there for you to experience in a couple of  hours on a Saturday Jane's Walk with art and architecture historian Rolf Achilles.
longdescription:
This Jane’s Walk along Dearborn Street, from Congress parkway north to Wacker Drive celebrates the greatest street in the United States for architecture and sculpture ranging from the 1880s to the 1980s.  Tour highlights include:

  • the first step- back skyscraper in the world, Jenney’s Manhattan Building;
  • the Monadnock, the tallest all-brick building in the world, by Burnham and Root;
  • the Fisher Building, which set a world’s speed record in construction;
  • Mies’s incomparable Federal Center, with Calder’s largest stabile ever;
  • Next, look up at the Marquette Building to see the first Chicago windows, decades later internationally acclaimed as picture windows.
  • The Inland Steel building towers as the first stainless steel clad building and the first ever in the US with tinted glass.
  • Pause across the street at Chagall’s Four Season mosaic before looking up at the first A-frame skyscraper.
  • Continue on the Daley Plaza where public sculpture in Chicago started anew with the Picasso.
  • Look up at the delicate step backs in cor-ten steel of the Daley Center and then over your shoulder at the Miro sculpture and the skyscraper Methodist Temple.
  • Across the street is Block 37, once home to several movie palaces;
  • At Randolph Street see several more movie palaces and stage theatres, the Oriental, the double Michael Todd and see an early cement prefab structure, a typewriter factory;
  • And where the once mighty Woods stood as the L rumbles by as we step towards the Leo Burnett Building by Roche-Dinkeloo and one of Chicago’s very rare brut skyscrapers before we look across the River to Bertrand Goldberg’s iconic Marina Towers.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: corner Congress and Dearborn

team.bio: Rolf Achilles is a widely published art and architecture historian and curator of the Smith Museum of Stained Glass Windows. For more information see rolfachilles.com

accessible-info: several street crossings, 2 hour walk, few benches along way
accessible-transit: CTA
accessible-parking: city parking lots
accessible-find: Meet at 1 pm in front of Jenny's, at the Manhattan Building, corner of Congress and Dearborn.

title: Drills, Hills and Thrills - The Cedarvale Circuit
shortdescription: Get a little more toned in body and mind as you do a circuit training workout while learning about the history of the Cedarvale Ravine.
longdescription:
Join fitness expert Leehe Lev (of Whole Self Fitness) as she guides you on a fitness walk through Cedarvale Park. You can participate in the circuit stations along the route, or just walk. However you choose to enjoy this walk, you’ll be introduced to one of Toronto’s hidden gems, which was frequented by Ernest Hemingway.

In the 1960s and 1970s, there were plans to build the Spadina Expressway through Cedarvale Park, but Jane Jacobs successfully lobbied against construction, and the project was halted.

As you descend into the ravine, you’ll feel increasingly removed from a busy urban environment. This walk will expand your idea of where and how you exercise, complement your gym membership, and show you how to get a full body workout outside! You’ll experience beautiful views, and the constantly changing flora and fauna of this picturesque park. This walk is suitable for all fitness levels.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Eglinton West and Everden Road (Ben Nobleman Park)

team.bio: Leehe is a  Personal Trainer and Group Fitness instructor, specializing in Pilates and water exercise.  She uses Cedarvale Park both for herself, and her clients.  Her company, Whole Self Fitness has been providing on-site fitness and wellness services since 2005.

title: Stroll Along the Quay
shortdescription:
Saturday, May 4
1:00 to 2:30
Join Fraser River Discovery Centre volunteer Mike Hoyer for a leisurely stroll along the Quay and learn about the history, the geography, the plant and animal life, as well as efforts to keep the Fraser River healthy and sustainable.  Meet at 1:00 p.m. at the Fraser River Discovery Centre, 788 Quayside Drive, New Westminster.
longdescription: Join Fraser River Discovery Centre volunteer Mike Hoyer for a leisurely stroll along the Quay and learn about the history, the geography, the plant and animal life, as well as efforts to keep the Fraser River healthy and sustainable.  Meet at 1:00 p.m. at the Fraser River Discovery Centre, 788 Quayside Drive, New Westminster.

team.bio: Mike Hoyer has been volunteering at the Fraser River Discovery Centre for 8 years. A former teacher, Mike has offered walking tours for the Discovery Centre in the past, and also enjoyes working with the school groups who attend the Centre.

title: Aldershot’s Past, Present and Future
shortdescription: Rediscover your neighbourhood by foot or bike!
longdescription:
Join us for a walk or a ride and rediscover your neighbourhood. 

Walk: A comfortable, leisurely walking tour will begin at Holy Rosary School and walk along Plains Road to King Road and back along the opposite side of Plains Road highlighting the history, current services, and future projects along the way.

Bike: An 8km bike tour will also begin at Holy Rosary and it will go through La Salle Park and a long North Shore Blvd and up the multi-use path to Plains Road and along Plains Road back to Holy Rosary. This tour will highlight interesting historical points of interest

There will be break for a healthy snacks and refreshments at Skyway Diner. Please register so we can order food for everyone. Note that this event is FREE as are all of Jane's Walks. 

All ages and abilities are welcome! 

The event will take place rain or shine!

markers.title: Meeting Place

Jane's Ride Leader: Don Thorpe, long time resident of Aldershot and chair of the Burlington Cycling Committee

title: FIND IT in Inglewood
shortdescription: Interested in the 'pop-up' phenomenon for building community? Learn about FIND IT Calgary, the series of one-off urban food and arts events in Inglewood and Ramsay. Join dynamic mother-daughter team Meg & Julie Van Rosendaal to learn what's happened and help imagine what could happen next.
longdescription:
Join us for a discovery tour of the village of Inglewood. We'll poke our noses into some unusual corners and together imagine "what could happen here?" We'll introduce you to Calgary's original main street and Inglewood's well-loved food- and arts-related treasures (some of them people!). From back lanes and community gardens to studios, galleries, shops and eateries, we hope you'll fall in love with our favourite part of town!

 

Start location: http://cafegravity.com/

End location: http://www.eskerfoundation.com/

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Cafe Gravity - 909 10 St SE in the Inglewood Art Block

team.bio:
Julie Van Rosendaal is a foodie: food writer, CBC food columnist, food blogger and self-described "eater." 
If Julie's a foodie, her mom is an "artie": long involved in the arts in Calgary, Meg is currently co-chair of FIND IT Calgary, a series of one-off pop-up urban food and arts events in Inglewood and Ramsay.

accessible-info: We'll adapt our route to suite the accessibility needs of everyone who comes on the tour
accessible-transit: Route 1 (Bowness/Forest Lawn): Exit at corner of 8 St & 9 Ave SE; Route 305 (BRT Bowness/17 Ave SE): exit at corner of 8 St or 12 St SE & 9 Ave; also routes 17 or 24
accessible-parking: Street parking on 9 Ave and 10 St SE is free on Sundays

title: Glenn Gould's Toronto
shortdescription: This walk will navigate the landmark places and institutions in the career of celebrated pianist Glenn Gould, examining their impact on his music, philosophy, and relationship with technology.
longdescription: Glenn Gould was one of the most celebrated pianists of the twentieth century. Despite his widespread success, he gave up concert performance early in his career to focus on studio recording and take on other musical projects, including broadcasting, composing, conducting, and writing. This walk will navigate the landmark places and institutions where Gould pursued this work, examining their impact on his music, philosophy, and relationship with technology. In particular, we will explore Gould's creative uses of technology in the recording studio and his ideas about the influence of technology on musical aesthetics and communication, drawing a parallel with his understanding of the relationship between the built and natural environments in Toronto. This walk will end with an optional group lunch at Fran's Restaurant on College Street, the oldest surviving location of Gould's favourite diner.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Bench statue of Glenn Gould in front of the CBC building, 250 Front Street West

team.bio: Erin Scheffer is a PhD candidate in musicology at the University of Toronto studying John Weinzweig's early career at the CBC and pre-Massey report CBC docudramas. Melissa Wong is a PhD candidate in music at the University of Cambridge, where she uses cover versions to examine aesthetic values, the influence of technology, and the rise of historical consciousness in popular music. Their past events include Cityscape/Soundscape: Exploring Our Sonic Environment and Unsilent Night Toronto.

accessible-transit: Take the subway to Union and walk west along Front Street to the CBC building.
accessible-find: We will be sitting on the bench beside the statue of Glenn Gould.

title: Fascination Street brings you Jane's Walk Adelaide
shortdescription: Adelaide, uncovered. uncensored
longdescription: Last year, Jane’s Walk focused on the much loved entertainment precinct of Adelaide. In contrast, this year’s walk will focus on the city’s less loved yet hotly contested city blocks. As the city grows southwards, the nature of existing neighbourhoods change. This growth contributes to escalating rent, corporatizes the city street and the runs risk of losing valued heritage increases. Through visiting disused car parks, reappropriated shopfronts and city squares, Janes Walk 2013 and our guest speakers will pace through the city wherever robust and passionate discussions arise.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Corner Angas st and Pulteney st

team.bio: We are a collective of Adelaide artists, architecture graduates and designers focused on urban place-making.We believe in creativity, curiosity, collaboration and coffee. We see ourselves as a creative collective with a background in architecture but passionate about all things art and design. We do not act within the bounds of definite creative disciplines. We see creativity as a way of thinking, one which infiltrates everything that we do.

accessible-info: No foreseeable problems here folks
accessible-parking: Plenty
accessible-find: Look for the Orange fruiterer in the Carpark! Situated adjacent an intersection, all attendees will be able to see a congregation in the middle of the  disused carpark. We greet all walkers with a cup of freshly squeezed Orange juice!

title: Coming out: The Gay Village Walk
shortdescription:
The "coming out" story of Canada's biggest Gay Village!
 
Advisory warning: not all of the stories told on this Walk will be of the PG variety.
longdescription:
This walk is for anyone that wants to learn more about the "coming-out" story of Canada's biggest Gay Village.    On this walk you will learn about the Village's cultural and historical development.   This is a no holds barred walk that will give an honest look on how Queer people in Toronto were treated over the last one hundred years. This is a fascinating walking tour that is more than just about the buildings but about the people that lived in them and what was going on at the time.  

The walk will start at Wellesley subway station then proceed up North on Yonge; then East on Isabella St. and then back south on Church St. where we will end the tour at Allan Gardens. The walk will take about 2 hours, so wear your most fabulous and comfortable shoes.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: In front of Wellesley Subway Station.

team.bio: Mathew MacLean has been leading the only walking tour of the Gay Village for the last 2 years.  He has been working with the community to have a better understanding of the changes that have been happening over the last few years. Mathew is continuingly learning more about this fascinating  community and all it has to offer. To learn more about his tours go to http://www.torontoqueerwalkingtours.com/

accessible-info: Parts of the walk are not child appropriate.
accessible-transit: Get off at Wellesley Subway Station.
accessible-parking: Green P parking across from Wellesley Subway Station
accessible-find: Look for the guy with the MOOSE hat at Wellesley Subway Station.

title: "My Village" - Not Just Business As Usual At Church & Wellesley
shortdescription: My Village is about the importance of local businesses, how they support each other as a community, and what it means to them to be part of "My Village".
longdescription:
This walk will be an insider's look at  the business culture in the Gay Village and why their shops are so important to the gay community and broader neighborhood. Business owners will meet us to tell their stories on how they have helped to keep the Village alive and well.

We will also talk to those business leaders who belong to community organizations in the Village, which support those with different, unique needs. The walk will give us an understanding of the past,  present, and  future of this important community. The walk will also have some historical and cultural surprises along the way!

The walk will start at Wellesley subway station then proceed up North on Yonge; then East on Isabella St. and then back south on Church St. where we will end the tour at Allan Gardens.

title: All That Glitters: Night Life In The Village!
shortdescription: This walk will focus on the night life of The Gay Village with some the historical and cultural insights thrown in for good measure.
longdescription:
The best time to experience the Gay Village is at night! When the stars come out is when the Village comes alive with the many different people that make up this wonderful community. Besides people-watching, we will tell stories about the historical and cultural events that have shaped the Village. Each stop will have its own story  about what made the Village a safe space for anyone who has felt different and came here to find community. 

After the walk,  for those who will be looking for something to eat or drink, we will be going to Mick E. Fynn's  at Church and Carlton...please feel free to join us and keep the conversations going!

title: Davenport Perth's Chalk Walk
shortdescription: Explore the Davenport Perth neighbourhood and  chalk up the streets with local residents to draw the kind of changes we want to see!
longdescription:
Did you know that Davenport Perth has one of the oldest churches in Toronto? Have you ever seen the huge Earlscourt community garden? Do you want to learn and discuss the issues facing Davenport Perth's community residents like affordable housing, food security and social programmes? Do you like CHALK!? Then this Jane's Walk is for you! 

Come explore Davenport Perth by walking alongside local community members of The Stop Community Food Centre and Davenport Perth Neighbourhood and Community Health Centre as we chalk up the streets together showing Toronto the change we want to see in our neighbourhood.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: In Front of Joseph J. Piccininni Community Recreation Centre,1369 St. Clair Ave W

team.name-first: Mike, Sandi, Anthony, Flori, Michael & Victoria
team.bio:
Left to Right: Sharon Francis, Anthony Smith, Victoria, Flori, Sandi Reed Bottom row: Mike Letort (Absent: Michael Smith)
Mike Letort: In September of 2010, after several weeks of sitting at the front lobby of DPNCHC I met a wonderful and approachable lady, she is Eileen the Adult Services program worker. I began attending the Drop-In program despite being a very shy person. I felt very comfortable talking to the Program Staff. She asked me if I was interested in becoming a volunteer and I was more than happy to try. I put my name on the list for orientation and got accepted as a volunteer. I began doing the Adult Drop-In placement. I began doing a lot of other programs too, Community Dining, Walk Fit Feel Good. We even go to Wasaga Beach in the summer too. I love it. It’s like going on a vacation. The Art Gallery was amazing and the Science Centre. During the winter we go skating at Wallace Emerson, I did not have any knowledge of how to skate but I went and had an amazing time, practice makes perfect. The Bike Project was another one I truly enjoyed because it taught me how to do basic repairs on a bike. We also went to Woodbine Beach and this was my first time ever being there too. I also participated in Bill 114. This summer we will go swimming with the adult drop-in’s program at Wallace Emerson. All this helps me to feel good about myself. I even got the Welcome Policy through Eileen. Now I go to the gym to workout. Thanks to the staff at DPNCHC it’s been an amazing learning experience. I will never forget this, it’s priceless.
Sandi Reed: Good friend brought me to Davenport Perth Neighbourhood Community and Health Centre. I think it’s a great place to meet people. Down the road I eventually start to volunteer with the Community Dining Program. I also volunteer for the Walk Fit Feel Good Program. I have been with both programs for a few years now. Thanks.
Michael Smith, a Davenport resident since June 2011 has community engagement in his best interest. Being a member of The Stop’s Community Action program, Bread and Bricks as a participant and former intern, Michael has seen the impact and transformation of a community. He also is an avid photographer and currently is a student at University of Toronto.
Anthony Smith, a Davenport resident since June 2011 has seen the transformation and impact of the Davenport West community with his involvement in Bread and Bricks, The Stop’s Community Action Program as well as serving in volunteer roles both at The Stop CFC and Davenport-Perth Neighborhood and Community Health Centre. Anthony has experience in leading music and worked as Music Director for the United Church of Canada.

accessible-info: There is a short steep downhill on a sidewalk
accessible-transit: Travel to St Clair West Station. Board the 512 St Clair and travel to Lansdowne. Walk west to 1369 St Clair Ave W.
accessible-parking: Yes

title: Downtown Gallery Tour
shortdescription: Interested in Calgary's art scene but not sure where to begin? Take a walk with me through Calgary’s downtown core to explore some of the beautiful art galleries in this city.
longdescription:
Always wanted to know more about the world of art galleries, artists, and the art scene in Calgary?

Take a walk with me through Calgary’s downtown core where we will explore some of the galleries that make up Calgary's art scene. We will take a look at a complete spectrum of artists' spaces starting with student-run galleries, moving to independent galleries, and finishing with a public non-profit gallery and a museum. Explore a wide variety of current art and engage in discourse about with is happening in the Calgary Art Scene!

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Safeway parking lot 813 11 Ave SW

team.bio:
Sarah is relatively new to Calgary, having grown up in the Greater Toronto Area, and she is loving every minute of exploring all that Calgary has to offer. 
With an educational background in fine art and English literature, and working at the Art Gallery of Calgary, she is an enthusiastic participant in Calgary’s active cultural district and art scene.
Her hobbies and interests include (but are not limited to): reading, writing, swimming, yoga, tap dancing, scotch and beer tasting, sour candy, laughing, bike riding, and rap and folk music.

accessible-parking: Please don't park at Safeway; there's a pay lot about 1/2 block further west

title: We Are Highland Park! Increasing Density in an Established Community
shortdescription: Here's a canvas Jane Jacobs would have enjoyed - An historic lesser-known neighbourhood on the cusp of dramatic increases in density. Walk with Kevin Bentley, community activist and local historian and get to know the neighbourhood that inspires.
longdescription:
Some of the earliest land claims (1882) in all of present day Calgary were in Highland Park.

Join us for a thought-provoking walk (there's fun stuff too) along Centre St. N. through an established community at the cusp of dramatic increases in density through build-out on a 50 acre former golf course and re-development of the Centre Street corridor.

Jane Jacobs would have enjoyed the canvas that Highland Park presents in discussing the creation of livable neighbourhoods and complete communities.

"Smile when you call me that name." Which of the many characters who lived in the area uttered those words? Was it a former Mayor of Calgary and Premier of Alberta? Or the Virginian, a famous cowboy what married here in Calgary and had the Sundance Kid as his best man? Or maybe another colourful resident of Highland Park? Or perhaps it was all of them! Come find out.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Park n'Ride Parking Lot, Centre St & 36 Ave NW. (It's across from Buchanan Elementary School)

team.bio: Kevin Bentley is a community activist in Highland Park. He's spent the last few years researching the history of this community. And has now worn out two pairs of shoes walking around the community talking with residents and exploring what he calls the Spaces, Places and Faces of Highland Park.

accessible-info: We will be walking on sidewalks along Centre St near higher volumes of traffic
accessible-transit: Bus #3 stops on Centre Street & 36 Ave NW, at Buchanan Elementary School
accessible-parking: On-site at meeting location, or on-street parking along 36 Ave on either side of Centre St

title: What's Missing From this Neighbourhood?
shortdescription: Enjoy an evening walk of "noticings" in Crescent Heights by paying close attention to nature in the city. Find out what's there and remember what's missing.
longdescription: The walk consists of two parts: A few stops along the way, and noticings of "What is missing" from this neighbourhood. Some of the stops include: 1) Meeting with Sasha, a very old and friendly husky dog, 2) Marvelling at a heritage poplar tree (1927) and a 100-year-old apple tree, while 3) enjoying the company of squirrels, rabbits, and magpies.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Sun's BBQ Restaurant, 1423 Centre St NW

team.bio: As I treasure nature, my Métis last name Laplante (literally meaning "the plant" in the English language) is brought into deep contemplation when I observe a changing landscape; I question my inherent interconnectedness to place, space, and species of numerous kinds.

title: History+Parkour Mash-Up
shortdescription: The uncertain fate of Century Gardens has brought together two unlikely Calgary communities - heritage activists and Parkour practitioners. Come spend time with these real movers and shakers.
longdescription:
In the heart of downtown, Century Gardens was developed in 1975 to celebrate Calgary's Centennial and is listed on Calgary's Inventory of Evaluated Historic Resources. The park's design is a unique example of mid-century brutalist style landscape architecture. Today the mash-up of built form and water - evocative of Alberta's mountains, rivers and plains - has become a key stop in the global Parkour movement. Come explore it with us in a mash-up of history and movement. 

 

Are you thinking: Sounds great but what's Parkour?

Parkour is a physical practice where practitioners aim to move quickly and efficiently through their environment using only their bodies and their surroundings to propel themselves, negotiating obstacles in between. They try to maintain as much momentum as possible without being unsafe. Parkour can include running,  climbing, swinging, vaulting, rolling, and so on, whatever's most suitable for the situation. Parkour is non-competitive. It is usually practiced as a creative playful reinterpretation or subversion of urban spaces.  (Thank you wikipedia)

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Century Gardens Park, NE corner of 8 ST and 8 Ave SW

team.bio:
Cynthia Klaassen is President of the Calgary Heritage Initiative Society, raising awareness of the importance of Calgary's built heritage one project at a time. She is past President of Doors Open Calgary and a co-chair of the award-winning "Century Homes Calgary" project.
Steve Nagy is a leader in Calgary's burgeoning Parkour Community and recently produced "Mindfire."

accessible-info: Century Gardens is a small park so there won't be lots of walking. We'll be talking history & architecture and watching Parkour.
accessible-transit: LRT station 8 Street SW if you're heading east and 7 Street SW if you're heading west
accessible-parking: Metered parking on Saturday rates on 8 Ave SW

markers.description: כיכר החתולות

team.bio:
אסתר סעד - מורת דרך ירושלמית, דור שמיני בירושלים. מאוהבת בירושלים, נושמת את דופק העיר לא מפסיקה להתרגש ולהתפעם ממנה. מדריכת סיורים בירושלים כבר למעלה מ-15 שנים מתמחה בדתות חגים טקסים, חברה חרדית, העיר העתיקה על המגוון האנושי שבה, נחלאות, שוק מחנה יהודה וסיורים קולינרים (סיור מאפיות, סיור טעימות בשוק מחנה יהודה, ויה גלוקוזה – (חנויות ממתקים בעיר העתיקה) וגינות נסתרות.
עינת גומל - אשת תרבות ירושלמית, פעילה חברתית ומפיקה. עד לא מזמן אחראית על תחום תרבות בפרוייקט מרכז העיר של עיריית ירושלים. מרכזת את הליכות ג'יין בירושלים.

title: Acadia Arts, Culture and Good Eats
shortdescription: Buskers. A visit to 10,000 Villages. A sneak preview of where the community garden's going to be. Time with the Suburban Calgary Artist Network. What else would you want?
longdescription:
Immerse yourself in the arts, culture and good eats of Acadia. Check out the site for our new community garden, visit local food establishments, see local art, and enjoy performances from a few buskers along the way.

Acadia is 10,000 people strong - one of the largest residential districts in Calgary. Lovely green spaces.  The ARC (Acadia Recreation Complex) that hosts events like records sales, antique markets, curling, ringette, squash and hockey. The Eagles Hall. There's lots to check out in Acadia. So much that we've got a bus ready to take us back from the walk's end point to where we started.
