team.bio: I live, work, play and love in Acadia. I raise a family of two with my husband. Geoff. We celebrated 25 years of marriage this year. Geoff is an artist and I am an arts champion. I am the president of the Acadia Community Garden Proposal and organizer of the Suburban Calgary Artist Network.

title: Neighbours on a Mission: Piloting Revitalization in Calgary's Inner City
shortdescription: Take a tour of what might be, as a new approach to inner city revitalization is piloted. Can collaboration work? Can a troubled road in disrepair and facing development pressures be given new life as a main street?
longdescription:
On a snowy Saturday morning in January of 2011, over 60 Parkhill, Erlton, Roxboro and Rideau Park neighbours met to discuss the future of Mission Road SW - a busy commuter route through their communities that was falling into disrepair while also experiencing development pressures. This meeting was a precursor to an Innovation Project undertaken by City Council that sought to pilot a new approach to inner city revitalization intended to engage landowners, citizens, and city staff in an unprecedentedly collaborative approach to planning and implementation. In June 2011, an international team spent a week with residents and produced a vision for the area that not only re-envisioned Mission Road as a main street seam connecting Parkhill and Erlton, but also rationalized a neighbourhood structure for the area that reconnected these communities with their LRT station and reestablished a relationship with the working landscapes of Manchester.

Come join Councillor Gian-Carlo Carra for a tour of what might be and discussion of barriers and challenges to implementation.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: NE corner of Mission Rd SW & 34 Ave SW (vacant lot on an open field)

team.bio:
Gian-Carlo Carra was elected to Calgary City Council to serve his first term as Alderman for Ward 9 in October 2010. Gian-Carlo was raised in both Calgary and New York City. This upbringing provided him with a unique perspective on living in large urban cities and a special appreciation for Calgary's people, neighbourhoods and natural landscape.
An award-winning urban design professional, Gian-Carlo is committed to helping shape a more sustainable future for Calgary. He bring to Calgary City Council a passion for building walkable, safe, and fiscally responsible communities designed to contain a diverse range of lifestyles and opportunities. 
Prior to becoming Ward 9 Alderman, Gian-Carlo operated a Calgary-based urban design consulting business and was an active public speaker, community activist and academic researcher.

longdescription: Learn about the street and the people who moved here to make a community and built, rebuilt and renovated their churches as community centres.  We can discuss architectural styles, cultural communities and Edmonton's settlement past.  Come share what you know of the community.

title: The Death and Life of Inglewood
shortdescription: Perhaps no Calgary neighbourhood better illustrates the themes of the work of Jane Jacobs than Inglewood. Inglewood faced the same threats during the same era as Jacobs' beloved Greenwich Village in New York City. And mounted the same kind of remarkable citizen-led struggle for community and survival. Come be inspired by tales and insights from Calgary's misremembered past.
longdescription:
This walk will discuss Jane's first and last books as illustrated by a couple of blocks within Inglewood.

Our community faced the same threats, within the same era, that Jane Jacobs' Greenwich Village faced in NYC. The Death and Life of Great American Cities, while not ours, is a testament to the power and the beauty of communities at their best in the face of the worst - it is almost ours. But despite the success of both The Death and Life as well as Inglewood's own remarkable struggle for community, Jane's last book represents a warning. Dark Age Ahead offers little optimism and suggests that when we fail to remember where we've come from, our future darkens. 

Walk with me and let's rediscover our city's misremembered past in the patterns and echoes of its oldest neighbourhood.

If you think the era of a warm welcoming close-knit neighbourhood is over, come spend time with these wonderful women in Pineridge, a neighbourhood developed in the 1970s and cherished by people who live there.

Lots of history (schools, churches, landowners) and one of the Mayor's favourite restaurants. Learn about clubs, businesses and activities right in Pineridge.

title: Geylang Serai & Joo Chiat Uncovered
shortdescription: This abridged 2 hour version of the Joo Chiat/ Katong food walk (the regular tour is 7 hours long) will bring you through the past, present and perhaps the future of the district. This neighbourhood is Singapore’s largest architecture conservation district; usually associated with the Malay, Peranakan Straits Chinese and Eurasian communities. As we traipse through the backlanes, shortcuts and hidden gardens we will snack on street foods that are popular with the neighbours. This neighbourhood is earmarked in the State’s Master Plan to be one of the 4 new secondary cities outside the Central Business District and it’s a district in transition as it tries to make sense of the current and new developments.
longdescription:
We will explore on foot of the origins of the migration of the natives along the Geylang River and learn why Geylang Serai is still regarded as the heart of the Malay community (local & expatriate) here in Singapore.


 

Circumnavigate the diverse variety of residential housing from mass housing HDB apartments, nouveau riche condominiums/ houses, award winning conserved shophouse homes and rare “Malay Houses”.

At the top of a HDB apartment, enjoy broad views across Singapore (and of Johor Malaysia and even of Batam Island Indonesia)

 

Along the way, sample the famous snacks of the Malay, Peranakan Straits Chinese, Eurasian and of new Vietnamese community that appears to have also stake a claim to the district.

 

Registration --> tony@betelbox.com
Please remember that these walks are open and free, we just need to have an idea of numbers to allocate volunteers.

title: Rooster to Rocket : Bridging the Don Valley
shortdescription: Traversing the Don Valley from Riverdale to Cabbagetown with reflections on the historical and future developments that have shaped the Don Valley and its adjacent neighbourhoods.
longdescription:
This walk traverses the Don Valley from Riverdale to Cabbagetown with reflections on the historical and future developments that have shaped the Don Valley and its adjacent neighbourhoods. Some of the highlights:

  • Evidence of the east bank of the Don Valley as a camping/ hunting ground from 4,000 years ago
  • Mill ponds and undergrounds watercourses
  • Architecture new and old
  • One of the oldest continuously inhabited houses in the city (1807)
  • Highwaymen and river crossings
  • Street names and church steeples

The walk starts and ends at two of Toronto’s choice spots for fantastic coffee - The Rooster on Broadview and Jet Fuel on Parliament!

title: The Future of the Gay Village
shortdescription: Toronto’s queer community is more visible than ever but with more neighbourhood options, the Church-Wellesley gaybourhood is challenged to find its place in our city and community. Come add your ideas and stories.
longdescription:
Toronto’s queer community is more visible than ever but with more queer residential and social options, the Church-Wellesley gaybourhood is challenged to find its place in our city and community.

Church Street remains the effective headquarters of the queer community by hosting annual Pride celebrations, The 519 Church Street Community Centre, health and social service agencies the AIDS Memorial in Cawthra Square Park and a wide variety of pubs, restaurants, clubs, shops and services. A wide spectrum of people consistently seek out The Village as an 'arrival neighbourhood' - a safe,  lively and inclusive place that provides a vital lansdscape of freedom and self-expression.

These trends are unfolding at the same time that traditional patrons and residents are venturing further afield for entertainment, shopping, services or housing. And although Church Street is highly walkable and well served by transit, the retail sector is struggling. Mainstay restaurants and boutiques like Zelda’s, Flatiron’s, This Ain’t The Rosedale Library, Ma-Zone, and Jaz Hair Studio have gone under, downsized or moved away due to rent increases and flagging sales. And while social acceptance and affluence is increasing, prejudice and discrimination remain a factor in queer life.

Church Street is not alone - these widely studied shifts in the demographic and spatial distribution are happening in LGBTQ communities across Europe and North America including San Francisco, Miami, Berlin, New York and Montreal.

Join us for a walking conversation about the future of our village. We’ll consider whether a gay village still matters to the queer community and the city as a whole, what people need or want from it and how Church Street can or can’t adapt. Our conversation will contribute to a current study of the Church Wellesley Village– to learn more about the study which is being led by The 519, visit http://www.the519.org/newsfeed/thevillagestudy

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Aids Memorial in Cawthra Square Park, beside 519 Church Community Centre

team.name-first: Jane Farrow and Doug Kerr with special guests.
team.bio:
Jane Farrow specializes in bringing people together for constructive dialogue and creative city-building initiatives. Her career highlights include stints as CBC Radio One host and producer, best-selling author,  executive assistant at city hall and founding director of Jane’s Walk. She is currently working with Park People to promote civic engagement in our green spaces and is an Associate with Nicole Swerhun Inc., a public consultation and community engagement firm that specializes in making large, complex multi-stakeholder projects constructive and manageable.
Doug Kerr has been active in the Church and Wellesley neighbourhood for over 15 years. Since moving to the village in 1995 from Taipei, Doug has volunteered for such organizations and groups as the 519 Church St Community Centre, the Lesbian and Gay Community Appeal (now Community One Foundation), Pride Toronto, the Pride Coalition for Free Speech and Sherbourne Health Centre. Professionally, he is a nonprofit management consultant and teaches at the University of Toronto's Faculty of Social Work and Centennial College.  He is one of the co-owners of Glad Day Bookshop, the oldest surviving queer bookstore in the world. He is also  on the Steering Committee for WorldPride 2014 and is co-charing the WorldPride International Human Rights Conference. Doug met his husband, Mike in a parking lot just off of Church Street and they are raising a little boy named Malaki, who loves playing in the fountains in Cawrtha Square Park.

title: The Other Danforth: The Life and Death of Upper Midway
shortdescription: The Danforth, a traditionally blue collar, gritty neighbourhood best known for serving the best Greek food in Toronto, is about to experience a wave of gentrification, investment, and development. Learn about its historical trajectory while discussing with us the ways in which we can actively shape its future.
longdescription:
For many Torontonians, the Danforth is the main street of Riverdale or a place to eat Greek food. But that image covers just a small strip of this storied street, formerly known as the Second Concession, the Danforth Plank Road and The King's Highway No. 5. Danforth east of Pape, often referred to as the "Other Danforth," wasn't really developed until the 1920s, after the Bloor viaduct opened. The Other Danforth has always tended to be blue collar and gritty. And while it has seen hard times, especially in the past four decades, the area is almost certainly about to see a wave of gentrification, investment and development.

How do we as a community maximize the chances that we get the type of change we want? What factors are key to making neighbourhood economies thrive? How do we ensure that our sidewalks become more welcoming and pleasant and useful? A good starting point would be to read (or reread) the first three Jane Jacobs books -- especially the first: The Death and Life of Great American Cities. A good second step would be to join us for the sixth annual Upper Midway Jane's Walk, as we try to understand how and why this stretch of the Danforth developed as it did, what made it a thriving pedestrian-friendly place for so long, and why it slipped into decline. The idea is to identify factors and lessons from the past to foster discussion and to help serve as guides for the future. Along the way, we hope to show you a lot of good reasons to get into the habit of putting your feet and your eyes on the street.

Midway was largely a default name for the area between the City of Toronto (whose eastern boundary was at the Ashbridge's Creek, just east of Greenwood) and the Town of East Toronto (whose western boundary crossed Danforth about a half kilometre east of Woodbine). In its entirety, Midway, which was annexed by the city in 1909, ran down almost to Queen. This walk will focus on Upper Midway, which was north of the Grand Trunk Railway tracks, as well as the former Church of England Glebe lands north of Danforth.

We're going to concentrate on the history and character of the three main Upper Midway intersections (Woodbine, Coxwell and Greenwood), as well as the three lost creeks that crossed this stretch of the Danforth -- creeks that still affect the way land is used.

title: Connecting, Bridging and Weaving Together a Neighbourhood
shortdescription: Toronto's Concord CityPlace is an emerging and vibrant community, that has an incredible network of shared spaces and places. As community connection points, they sit among a dramatic landscape of public art that captures the imagination of visitors and residents alike.
longdescription:
Toronto's Concord CityPlace is an emerging and vibrant community, that has an incredible network of shared spaces and places. As community connection points, they are woven through a dramatic landscape of public art that captures the imagination of visitors and residents alike.

This walk will kick-off with an opportunity for everyone to get their hands dirty! Come find us by the Canoe Landing sign at the north side of the park where we will be planting calla lily bulbs. (Note: If you're dividing spring perrenials (rudbeckia, echineacea, please bring a clump!) 

We will then make our way through the dog park, an animated and central zone which serves as a communal gathering place. 

The next stop at the Red Canoe will offer surprising views,  perched high on a bluff overlooking the Gardiner Expressway. Walk participants are welcome to sit in the canoe and view the city from this unique perspective. 

Just west of the Spadina Ave. bridge (between Front St. and Bremner Blvd.), we will see Mark Di Suvero's  massive steel sculpture "Flower Power," newly restored and installed.

Strong communities are pedestrian-friendly. When faced with the necessity to create lighting for an underpass that runs beneath Spadina Avenue, just south of Front St., the developer enlisted artist Maha Mustafa to intervene with a more creative solution to the problem. The result is an elegant sculptural lighting installation, which floods the 45-metre underpass with an incandescent blue light.

Francisco Gazitua 2012, Located over the busiest railway corridor in Canada, the “Puente de Luz” is a sculptural pedestrian bridge and the largest public art installation in Canada. The name “Puente de Luz,” or “Bridge of Light,” was chosen to signify the link between North and South and the connection between the two countries that came together to build it – Canada and Chile. The bridge’s unique yellow color was chosen to stand out against the grey background of the surrounding area.

The last stop will be the expressive large artwork by Maha Mustafa entitled “Approaching Red.” At the north-end of the public Mews between two residential buildings, the sculpture is not only a landmark, it is a natural meeting place.

To learn more about public art at CityPlace, and to download a printable PDF tour map, please visit: CityPlace Art Space.

The tour will combine some documented histories, anecdotes gathered from alumni and some lost rivers knowledge.

title: Rouleauville: Pour tout le monde
shortdescription: Calgary a des racines francophone très profondes. Nous allons découvrir le quartier de Rouleauville, l'original quartier français de Calgary. Cette promenade de Jane sera en français. This Jane's Walk will be in French.
longdescription:
We will discover the neighbourhood of Rouleauville, the original French quarter in Calgary. Calgary's history has very deep francophone roots, from Rouleauville in the Mission area to Father Lacombe's home in Midnapore. City Council recently supported calling on the federal government to recognize the establishment of Rouleauville as an Event of National Historic Significance. Find out why.

Nous allons découvrir le quartier de Rouleauville, l'original quartier français de Calgary. L'histoire de Calgary a des racines francophone très profondes, à partir de Rouleauville à Mission, qu'à la maison du père Lacombe à Midnapore. Le Conseil Municipal a récemment soutenu une demande au gouvernement fédéral de reconnaître la création de Rouleauville comme un événement d'importance historique national. Découvrez pourquoi.

This Jane's Walk will be in French. Cette promenade de Jane sera en français.

title: The Calgary That Could Have Been
shortdescription: Learn about the charming, ambitious, scandalous, and sometimes simply nutty past plans for Calgary's inner city neighbourhoods. Take a walk into Calgary's never-neverland.
longdescription: Some Jane’s Walks tell you about what used to be along your walking tour, or what is there. This walk explains what never happened, and why. From the Prince’s Island museums to the downtown freeway and East Village schemes gone awry, join a unique trip down memory canal (er, lane) into Calgary’s never-neverland.

title: Calgary Stampede Art Walk
shortdescription: Did you know that one of North America's largest public art sculptures was installed on Stampede grounds last summer as part of The Calgary Stampede's 100th anniversary celebrations? Or that all the murals were restored? If not, this is a great opportunity to come see for yourself.
longdescription: The Calgary Stampede celebrated its 100 year anniversary in 2012. As part of the Centennial celebrations the Public Art Committee and Historical Committee created the Artwalk which showcases 15 significant outdoor art pieces, including bronze sculptures and murals. All 8 murals have been restored over the past year and in June of 2012, the Stampede proudly unveiled “By the Banks of the Bow”, one of North America’s largest public art sculptures. This walk will take participants around Stampede Park, which has been an important part of our community for well over a century – a role it will continue to play through a number of exciting park developments in the years to come.

team.bio: The Public Art Committee was created in 2008 with a mandate to reach out to the community at large, tell the story of, and retain our western heritage and values. The Historical Committee promotes the history of the Calgary Stampede through displays, outreach, and other programs.

title: Griesbach - Innovative Urban Design and Military Heritage
shortdescription: Join Tony Druett for a walk around one of Edmonton's newest walkable communities - Griesbach
longdescription:
This walk covers 2 main themes:

 

Innovative Urban Design   -   The walk will pass through a variety of streetscapes, including different housing types and a short section of the 1950's military housing.  It will show how some of the old housing has been incorporated into the new streetscapes, and the way in which the orgiginal vegetation has been retained in the new development.  It passes through Griesbach Stage 8, which was one of Edmonton's first LEED Nd. Gold developments.  It gives a good example of how customized urban design and traditional architecture can create a feeling of uniqueness and community.

Edmonton's Military Heritage   -   Legacy features along the walk are dedicated to the Loyal Edmonton Regiment and the PPCLI.  There is a story behind each of the street names.  For instance, the LER was formed in WW1 by William Griesbach, who in 1907 was Edmonton's youngest mayor.  His wife, Janet, was Edmonton's first telephone operator.  The walk will also include stops at statues, monuments, pedestals and storyboards depicting the history of Canada's Navy, Military Engineers, and the Airborne Regiment that was based in Griesbach in the 1970's.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Roundabout at the intersection of Griesbach Parade NW & Gault Boulevard NW

team.bio: Tony Druett is a semi-retired civil engineer.  In his 40 year career in land development he has worked on several innovative legacy projects, including Griesbach which is being developed by Canada Lands into one of Edmonton's most walkable communities.

accessible-parking: Free on Street Parking Available
accessible-find: Look for Tony in his bright orange Jane's Walk T-Shirt

title: Jane's Walk Bowness (City Meets Village - A Neighbourhood of Contrasts)
shortdescription: Take a walk through the last century of development in Bowness along the beautiful and distinctive Bow Crescent as it follows the curve of the Bow River.
longdescription: Take a walk through the last century of development in Bowness, beginning at the Hextall bridge where the tram cars crossed the river on their way to Bowness Park. We'll walk along the beautiful and distinctive Bow Crescent as it follows the curve of the river. Hear the Bowness story as you meet residents, old and new, along the way. Enjoy the green spaces and eclectic architecture, including the only Hextall home in east Bowness. We'll check out the controversial Gas Plus site that backs onto the Crescent, meet the architect who is planning a rebuild of our beloved Mary's Corner Store, ask questions of our resident historian, Carole Carpenter. Several Bow Crescent residents have invited us into their yards.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: John Hextall Park, corner of Bow Crescent & Bowness Road NW, beside the Hextall pedestrian bridge at the east entrance to Bowness

team.name-first: Bowness Community Association, Carole Carpenter (Bowness Historical Society), various residents
team.bio: An eclectic group of Bowness volunteers (residents, historians, architects, builders) want to share our story of a vibrant historic community that is trying to integrate old and new, wealth and poverty, residential and local commercial.

accessible-info: Route is approximately 2.5 kms. No hills, only a slight incline at the start. Plus the #1 and #40 buses are usually kneeling buses
accessible-transit: Buses #1, #40 & #407 have stops no more than 1/2 block from the meeting location, whatever direction you''re coming.
accessible-parking: Street parking

title: Building Community in Swansea
shortdescription: An in-depth exploration of how the Village of Swansea built its community identity, which we will compare with the principles espoused by Jane Jacobs.
longdescription:
Despite its proximity to Toronto, the Village of Swansea has maintained a distinct identity even with its amalgamation into the City in 1967. How did Swansea build a sense of community, and how did this process compare to the principles written about by Jane Jacobs? This walk will pass some Swansea community institutions and gathering places to provoke discussion of what builds a community, past and present. We hope to have long-time residents telling their stories and those giving a more contemporary perspective in discussion as the walk proceeds.

 

Arial Photo of Swansea in 1937.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: The walk will begin at the western entrance to the Runnymede Subway Station.

team.bio: The Swansea Historical Society was started in 1985 by a group of people interested in preserving and promoting the history of the Swansea area. It was incorporated as an affiliate to the Ontario Historical Society and is a not-for-profit charitable organization. It holds monthly meetings the first Wednesday of each month (except January and the summer), an annual walk the first Saturday of June, and runs the William Small Memorial Archives.

accessible-transit: Bloor-Danforth subway to Runnymede Station.
accessible-parking: There are Green P lots near subway station, north of Bloor Street.

title: Helsinki Seaside Route
shortdescription: Leisurely walk from the Meilahti via Töölö to Jätkänsaari. Experience the city's principle of the walkable and accessible seaside. Exchange views on the historical layers of the area ending the walk in the newest development of vacated port area.
longdescription: The Finnsih environmental NGO Dodo will organise urban walks in four cities: Helsinki, Jyväskylä, Tampere and Turku. In Helsinki we'll walk along the seaside from Meilahti to Jätkäsaari. A combination of greenery, historical buildings, and new development.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Lastenlinnantie 2, Helsinki

team.bio: Dodo is an environmental organisation for urban folk which relies on the power of knowledge and argument. Dodo is about talking and doing. It organises public events, discussion groups, projects and more. Dodo brings together people from different backgrounds to exchange expertise, experiences and ideas. We work out ideas and then we work on some of them to carry out experiments that might improve things and solve environmental problems. Voluntary-based NGO is focused on global environmental issues, urban development and urban lifestyle. www.dodo.org

title: Creek Mystique
shortdescription:
Before the canal system tamed the rapids of the Otonabee River, its less tumultuous tributary, Jackson Creek, drove the paddle wheels that powered the mills of the growing town of Peterborough. Still flowing through the heart of the City, Jackson Creek now glides quietly under parking garages and buildings. Even when it does emerge to daylight, it is still largely invisible, a silent backdrop to the commerce and bustle of urban life.

Starting at the Trans Canada Trail, at the corner of Brock Street and Bethune, we will go with the flow, exploring the creek within the city.  We will look at how, and why Jackson Creek is constrained by walls engineered to keep its banks in check, at efforts to restore its shores to a more natural state, all the while looking for, and discussing, the potential to reconnect the residents of a city built by water, to its own stream. The tour will follow paved pathways and city sidewalks (possibly travelling through some gravel parking lots), ending on the path behind Tribal Voices and Stickling’s Bakery, just south of Charlotte St.
longdescription:
Before the canal system tamed the rapids of the Otonabee River, its less tumultuous tributary - Jackson Creek - drove the paddle wheels that powered the mills of the growing town of Peterborough. Still flowing through the heart of the City, Jackson Creek now glides quietly under parking garages and buildings. Even when it does emerge to daylight, it is still largely invisible, a silent backdrop to the commerce and bustle of urban life.

Starting at the Trans Canada Trail, at the corner of Brock Street and Bethune, we will go with the flow, exploring the creek within the city.  We will look at how, and why Jackson Creek is constrained by walls engineered to keep its banks in check, at efforts to restore its shores to a more natural state, all the while looking for, and discussing, the potential to reconnect the residents of a city built by water, to its own stream. The tour will follow paved pathways and city sidewalks, ending on the path behind Tribal Voices and Stickling’s Bakery, just south of Charlotte St.

title: 40 Years in Providence
shortdescription: A walk through the heart of Providence, discussing the major public projects that have reshaped and redefined Providence as a great small urban city for the 21st century.
longdescription:
We will start in the state house/capital center area and walk south through the historic downtown, into the Jewelry District/I-195 redevelopment area towards Narragansett Bay, ending up back in downtown.  Along the way we will look at and talk about the last 40 years of major public projects that have reshaped and redefined Providence as a great small urban city for the 21st century. 

We will look at new development, historic preservation, new and existing public space, the role of government, the role of the arts in Providence revitalization, urban design, and what's next.

markers.title: Meeting Place

team.bio: Steve Durkee is an architect who has been involved in architecture/planning and real estate in Providence for 25 years.  He served as Chairman of the Providence City Plan Commission, a member of the Capital Center Commission and is currently a board member of RIPTA, the statewide transit agency.  He lives and works in downtown Providence.

title: Very Slow and Very Sudden: History and Change in Mt. Hope Neighbourhood
shortdescription: Mount Hope Neighbourhood's 5th annual Jane's Walk. An interactive discussion of the many changes happening in this historic central neighbourhood along with some of its history as Busy Berlin's industrial core and residential district.
longdescription:
Join us for Mount Hope Neighbourhood's 5th annual Jane's Walk. We will be engaging in an interactive discussion of the many changes about to happen in this historic central neighbourhood, starting with the removal of houses along Weber St., already well underway. 

Along the route, we'll mix in some of the neighbourhood's history as Busy Berlin's  industrial core and largely working class residential neighbourhood.

 Meet at George Lippert Park at the corner of Weber St. West and Louisa St. in Kitchener. Our walk will end at the former Sacred Heart school site on Moore Avenue where we'll enjoy some after-walk treats with our neighbours from Extend-A-Family's Working Adults Learning Empowering Skills (W.A.L.E.S.) program.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: George Lippert Park, Weber St. W. and Louisa St., Kitchener

team.bio: Ted Parkinson, Joan Lazarski, Mary Sehl and Wayne Miedema have led Mount Hope Neighbourhood's popular Jane's Walks for the past 5 years. All four are residents of  the neighbourhood. Ted is the Communications Director of the Mt. Hope-Breithaupt Park Neighbourhood Association. Wayne will also be leading his annual Jane's Walk in the Mt. Hope Cemetery in the afternoon. See  Famous families, fugitive slaves, and a forgotten soldier: 150 years of history in the Kitchener Mount Hope Cemetery on the Jane's Walk site.

title: Bukit Brown Heritage Ramble
shortdescription:
Come visit Bukit Brown Heritage Park and see for yourself why this place is currently ranked among the top ten attractions of Singapore by TripAdvisor: http://www.tripadvisor.com.sg/Attraction_Review-g294265-d2547770-Reviews-Bukit_Brown_Cemetery-Singapore.html

It is history, heritage and habitat concentrated in an area 173 acres is worthy of preservation.
longdescription: Join me and a group of heritage enthusiasts on a leisurely 3 hours tour, as we walk through the pages of  Singapore history, visiting the largest Chinese cemetery outside China. Discover stories of valour, hardships, selflessness, and contributions to society, as we learn how certain individuals, and groups, helped to shape this young nation, to what it is today.  Learn about the movers and shakers of society, the educators, the businessmen, the bankers, etc, how they contributed to changes in Singapore, as well as to our neighbours as well.

Long pants and long sleeves if you are prone to insect bites or sunburn. Bring sunblock and natural insect repellent.  3. Wear comfortable non-slip shoes as safety is important. title: What Makes Maylands?
shortdescription: Let's start with a pineapple and finish with cakes! Mmmm.. yes, Maylands has long been associated with yummy treats, but what else makes Maylands unique? Come along on this walk and join in the discussion ... between mouthfuls of cake, of course!
longdescription:
Let's start with a pineapple and finish with cakes! Mmmm.. yes, Maylands has long been associated with yummy treats, but what else makes Maylands unique? Come along on this walk and join in the discussion ... between mouthfuls of cake, of course!

 

The What Makes Maylands? Jane's Walk will attempt to answer the question, in a very small way, of what makes Maylands the unique place that it is today. Maylands locals, lovers and enthusiasts are all welcome to come along and share your opinions and stories.

There is only so much we can cover in one Saturday afternoon, but this walk aims to highlight specific locations and activities  that demonstrate links between Maylands past and Maylands present. 

In tribute to  May 4th being Jane Jacobs' birthday we'll also be discussing the values that Jane, as urban thinker, writer and activist promoted, which are evident in Maylands today. Just a few of these being diversity, walkability, mixed use and 'new ideas in old buildings'.

The walk should take two hours at the most, which ensures we'll finish before cake shop closing time and/or local bar opening time.

Please sign up to the facebook event page to let me know you're coming! If you have any questions please do hesitate to email me at: taskam@our.ecu.edu.au or give me a call at 0450 415 710. 

BYO sunscreen and water. Pineapple, lemon squash and cake will be provided.

Well, mostly shine - this is Perth we're talking about. She is currently undertaking a PhD research study about walking, spaces and culture based in the beautiful suburb of Maylands.

title: Be Here Now: Mindfulness & the Art of Sensing
shortdescription: A quiet walk in which we will use all of our senses to explore the moment in Jackson Park, as well as how our personal experiences are influenced by the experiences of those around us.
longdescription:
A quiet walk in which we will use all of our senses to explore the moment in Jackson Park.

Life’s busy, and we often forget to take time to pay attention to what’s going on around us.  Join us on a relaxed and quiet walk that will focus on slowing down and really listening, seeing, smelling, feeling, and perhaps even tasting, as much as our time in Jackson Park has to offer.  We will also explore how our personal experiences are influenced by the experiences of those around us.

title: A Tour of Transition
shortdescription: Join watershed biologists, Meredith Carter and Erin McGauley, to explore the natural and cultural history of Beavermead Park, Little Lake and Meade Creek. Stops along the route will interpret changes that have occurred during the area’s transformation from its industrial past to its current recreational focus. Did you know that Roger’s Cove was once a marble factory?
longdescription:
Join us to explore the natural and cultural history of Beavermead Park, Little Lake and Meade Creek. Stops along the route will interpret changes that have occurred during the area’s transformation from its industrial past to its current recreational focus. Did you know that Roger’s Cove was once a marble factory?

We will walk to Ecology Park for our first stop, then we'll head north through Beavermead Park to Lock 20 and back along a fully accessible paved path. Walkers of all ages are welcome to join us as we discuss the natural heritage, recreational and industrial highlights along this route. Our stops will include information about naturalized shorelines, local flora and fauna, and recreational opportunities in the area.

title: The Stelco Tower and James Street North
shortdescription: Beginning at the 21st floor of the Stelco Tower at 100 King St. West, this walk will take you up James Street North past numerous galleries to the Lister Block and then to the Armoury. All locations are part of Open Doors Hamilton.
longdescription: You won't believe the view... and not everybody gets access to the Stelco Tower so when we heard it was on the Open Doors Hamilton roster we knew it would be a great jumping off point (so to speak) for a Jane's Walk. Twenty-one stories in the air and wrap around windows give up an unobstructed view of the city, the bay, the escarpment, the industries, the teeny tiny people on the streets, and a pretty good view of what's left of Ivor Wynne Stadium. From the Tower on to the street and the Lister Building... a chance to wander the completely restored floors of the Lister Block; not open to the public 363 days a year but open to us... tours by qualified guides had Steve saying... yes, I'll do this one! And then on to the Armory (where nobody gets in unless you're in uniform) except for us on this weekend... History buffs and just about everybody else who's wandered up James St. North has wondered what goes on there... and we're about to find out. (We got as far as the courtyard a few days ago, and now we're really curious!) Mulberry Cafe is across the street and that's where we'll say good bye.

title: Lawrence Park at 100+
shortdescription: When Lawrence Park, W. S. Dinnick's flagship "garden suburb" development, was laid out just over 100 years ago, it was on the fringe of the city. Now, almost in the geographic centre of Toronto, it is under redevelopment pressure. This walk will feature a number of the older homes and will highlight redevelopment issues.
longdescription: Starting at the south-east corner of Yonge and Lawrence, the walk will proceed through the western part of Lawrence Park. The history of the development will be outlined and a number of homes will be described in detail. Current problems facing the area will be mentioned.

title: King and Spadina: One of The Two Kings
shortdescription: Jane Jacobs precept that "new ideas must use old buildings" is central to the narrative of this Jane's Walk, exploring the decision-making behind Toronto's innovative creative hub 401 Richmond, the re-zoning of King and Spadina in 1997, and much more!
longdescription:
In 1996 a very innovative zoning change was introduced to two historic manufacturing districts on the edge of Toronto’s downtown core. Jane Jacobs worked with then-Mayor Barbara Hall to establish these “Reinvestment Areas”. They were dubbed “The Two Kings” – King and Parliament; and King and Spadina. The Two Kings are a unique Toronto success story. 

In the case of King-Spadina the area took on new life – almost immediately. Formerly vacant warehouses and factory buildings were filled with new uses within just a couple of years after the new zoning was implemented and the area has never looked back. Now, a decade later, there is enormous real estate pressure from condominium developers (often aided and abetted by the OMB) who are keen to maximize real estate values which requires the demolition of the historic fabric of the neighbourhood. Will the area be killed by its own success, or will the planners and politicians make sure that the vision that created this lively and vibrant neighbourhood – so essential to the City’s economy - is protected?

On this walk we will, in part, explore one of Jacobs’ precepts in Death and Life of Great American Cities – that “new ideas must use old buildings”. Inside the historic buildings of this neighbourhood (and others like it) – the new ideas, that will fuel our city’s economy long into the future, are percolating. These types of spaces (“a good lot of plain, ordinary, low-value old buildings, including some rundown old buildings”)* are essential and precious to any vibrant urban economy.

This walk will commence at the Roastery – the café at the entrance to 401 Richmond. 401 was definitely inspired by Jane’s thinking. We will do a quick tour of parts of the building (taking in the 10 foot square portrait of her created by artists John Scott and Deborah Waddington and roof garden – which Jane loved and wrote about in the New York Times magazine). We will then proceed through the streets of King Spadina and discuss the history of the zoning changes that occurred in ’97 and the impact it had on the area, the buildings and people.

 *Death and Life of Great American Cities - Jane Jacobs; Random House; 1961. Chapter 10: The need for aged buildings.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: The Roastery, 401 Richmond St. West.

team.bio:
Margie Zeidler is a developer and board member of the Centre For City Ecology. She won the Jane Jacobs Prize in 2003. Her projects are 401 Richmond and 215 Spadina (Centre for Social Innovation). 
Paul Bedford was Toronto's Chief City Planner from 1996-2004 and the original architect of the Kings experiment. He is a former member of the Metrolinx Board of Directors, serves on the Waterfront Toronto Design Review Panel, the National Capital Commission Planning Advisory Committee and teaches urban planning at both Ryerson and the UofT. He is a frequent speaker and writer on urban affairs and is passionate about his native city.
Both illustrate Jane’s dictum that “new ideas must use old buildings”.

title: The Crescent Heights Dish
shortdescription: Crescent Heights was once a village on the outskirts of Calgary before it was swallowed whole by the big city in 1910. Come hear about "Shady Ladies", "Bible Bill", a Titanic Survivor and Calgary's first 'Piece' Bridge, all of which have impacted our community over the years."
longdescription:
Join raconteur Lindae Stokes as she guides you past some notable Crescent Heights Century Homes, including the sites of some that didn't survive to fete their centenaries. Along the way, she'll regale you with some tantalizing historical tidbits about one of Calgary's oldest but least well-known communities.

Our tour will end near Calgary's Brunch Belt, as Avenue Magazine puts it, so attendees will be able to avail themselves then of some well-deserved refreshment.

We suggest  walking shoes as the walk involves some hill-climbing. Don't forget your water bottle.


To find the Church and Cultural Centre: Go to Meredith Road, which is one block North of Memorial Drive.  The Church and Cultural Centre are on the right (North) side of the road, half way up the pretty steep hill.

title: A Streetcar Suburb and New Urbanism
shortdescription: Grid pattern streets, a town center and parks for the neighbours. These and much more are the qualities of both the best in new urban design and the historic, turn of the century streetcar suburb. The Highlands Neighbourhood is a classic example of a streetcar suburb advocating for the best urban design from both eras.
longdescription: Grid pattern streets, a town center and parks for the neighbours. These and much more are the qualities of both the best in new urban design and the historic, turn of the century streetcar suburb. The Highlands Neighbourhood is a classic example of a streetcar suburb advocating for the best urban design from both eras.

title: Calgary Centre City - All That Jazz
shortdescription: Centre City plan was approved by Council in 2007. It outlines a vision for Calgary's Centre City as a livable, thriving and caring place. Come get jazzed by the new public spaces, improved streetscapes and other urban design gems as this award-winning plan comes to life.
longdescription: Centre City is experiencing tremendous transformation. Since Centre City plan is adopted by City Council, new public spaces are created, streetscapes improved, new office and residential buildings and high quality public art added. Objective of this tour is to showcase some of the latest urban design gems and to discuss what is planned in the near future.

team.bio:
Sonny is an internationally recognized, award-winning urban design practitioner, policy maker and educator with more than twenty six years of experience in large scale planning and urban design projects in Europe, Canada, the Caribbean and United Arab Emirates.
He is Manager of the Centre City Planning and Implementation division where he oversees policy planning, urban design, development applications and implementation of the award-winning Calgary Centre City Plan he helped creating in his previous City of Calgary post. 
Sonny led one of the first Jane's Walks in Calgary six years ago to introduce Calgarians to the Centre City Plan. It's a treat to have him back with an update on how the plan is unfolding.

title: Where will the next generation live?
shortdescription: Will young people be able to live in the neighbourhoods they grew up in? That depends on the decisions we make. Join me as we look for affordable housing solutions in three ordinary city blocks.
longdescription:
Families of modest means used to live on my east end street. Now there’s a house for sale for over $1.1 Million. I couldn’t afford to buy or rent on my own street today, and neither could my kids.

It’s a story played out all over downtown Toronto. In this walk we’ll look together at opportunities to could keep the "mix" in mixed-income neighbourhoods -- from second suites to social housing,  rooming houses to REITs -- and keep downtown homes affordable for the next generation.

Join us on a Jane's Walk from south of Eastern Ave to the Jack Layton Way at Broadview and Gerrard to see some of Jack's great projects in transportation, energy, the arts and city building.
longdescription: A walking tour of South Riverdale from Lake Shore Blvd and Logan Ave to Jack Layton Way at Broadview Ave and Gerrard St East. A chance to look at Jack Layton's handiwork and to see some the significant landmarks Jack was attached to and part of.

title: German Traces Toronto - Walk Conducted in German (Deutsche Spuren in Toronto - Stadtführung in deutscher Sprache)
shortdescription: Our walk will take you on a two hour walk through downtown Toronto, highlighting many places in the city with German connections - historical facts, modern presence, quirky connections or advice where to find German food and drink.
longdescription:
Our walk will take you on a two hour walk through downtown Toronto, highlighting many places in the city with German connections - historical facts, modern presence, quirky connections and advice on where to find excellent German food and drink.

This walk is inspired by the mobile website "German Walk Toronto", developed by the German Consulate General. It was originally outlined by Shawn Micallef, author of "Stroll" and Toronto Star columnist. Together they have set out to highlight the many contributions and cooperations - past and present - that link Germany and Germans to Canada's largest city.

www.germanwalk.ca

Please note that this walk will be guided in German only.

title: Discover East Oliver!
shortdescription:
Discover the history, the people and the gems of East Oliver.
Monday, May 6/13
Meet at Oliver Community League Hall, 10326 118 St
7 to 8:30 pm
longdescription:
Discover Oliver East! The gems, the history, the people.

 

Leaving Oliver Park we will walk east along 103 Avenue  towards 115 Street and walk through Kitchener Park. Here we stop to view the amazing mural on the utility building!

We go south on 114 Street to 102 Avenue, cross the street and go east along 102 Avenue to Railtown Park.

 

Do you know or remember what occupied this land? Follow the pedestrian/bike path to the crossroad turn south following the path to Jasper Avenue.  Look left ...imagine what structure stood  there.

We cross Jasper Avenue and walk up the slight incline to the alleyway and turn left, then right to follow the pedestrian/bike path. Here is where you can catch the Radial Railway Streetcar to Old Strathcona during the summer months.

Following the pathway to 100 Avenue , turn right and walk west along 100 Avenue. As you cross 110 Street, look south and you can see a glimpse of St Joachim's Church.  Continue along 100 Avenue to 111 Street.  Looking north imagine rows of greenhouses with flowers galore in full bloom! This was the site of Ramsey Greenhouses (1905-1944), the largest greenhouses in western Canada.

Crossing the street, continue west along the Avenue, you come to the Edmonton General Hospital which was built in 1895. It was a three storey brick building. Over the years various expansions have taken place. For the last two years, what Christmas spectacle takes place here?

Continue along 100 Avenue, look across the street to the Victoria Avenues houses (11219, 11223, 11229). Do you know what famous woman lived a few years at 11229? Across the street at 11302,  Judge Lucien Dubuc lived from 1912 to 1956.

Continuing down the avenue to 114  Street, look south and you see the magnificient Westminister Apartment built in 1912.

As you continue west, you approach Le Marchand Mansion  on the south side of the avenue.It was built between 1909-1911 as "the most luxurious of its kind in Canada" for Rene Lemarchand. (and that's another story!) Across the parking lot is Grant Notley Park. Here you have a wonderful vista of the river valley!

Crossing 116 Street, turn right and go north we pass Fresh Cafe, a quaint cafe.  Continuing along 116 Street, crossing Jasper Avenue, turn left and walk along Jasper Avenue to 118  Street.  Do you remember what grocery chain once occupied this site?

At 118 Street turn north and walk to 103  Avenue passing the west side of Oliver School.  At 103  Avenue cross the street where you arrive at Oliver Park and the Oliver Community League Hall.

title: A CBD DoddleJot
shortdescription: I've located spaces in Melbourne that are special to me, starting with an earlier Melbourne and looking to its future. We'll doddle down through town, enjoying the best of the city while undertaking a range of jotting activities.
longdescription: Taking Jane Jacob's lighthearted but critical approach to looking, this walk makes its way downhill, emphasising the crucial element of the social in a good city's form and life.  I've located spaces in Melbourne that are special to me, starting with an earlier Melbourne and looking to its future, and will share stories of their personal and public significance. We'll doddle down through town, enjoying the best of the city while undertaking a range of jotting activities.

Annie has lived in Melbourne for nine years and has still not bled it dry!  She is  principal consultant at Annie Bolitho & Associates and previously worked at Melbourne Sustainable Society Institute, Victoria's Department of Sustainability and Environment and in diverse community settings.

title: The Islington Village Mural Walk: Second Take
shortdescription: A stroll through the village of Islington from Montgomery's Inn along Dundas Street to Kipling Avenue, with stops at all of the Islington Murals to discuss the history behind them.
longdescription:
A stroll along Dundas St. West from the 19th century Montgomery’s Inn at Islington Avenue to Kipling Avenue brings the history of Islington Village to life via 25 amazing, handpainted wall murals along the way.

Our guides, Ron Quinn and Valerie Gibson, will tell visitors about not only the development and creation of the murals, (most of them by the talented artist John Kuna), but give the local history that lies behind the stories they show for a most entertaining walk.

The Islington Village murals are a partnership of the Village of Islington BIA, the Heritage Etobicoke foundation and Toronto Economic Development.

The cost (over $300,000) was provided by area business and commercial property owners, the City of Toronto Mural Grants, area developers and in-kind donations from Benjamin Moore through the Village Paint and Wallpaper store. Another $300,000 has been spent on streetscaping.

The first mural was completed in 2004 and there are now 25 to be viewed.

Further information can be found on the Village of Islington website.

Note:    This walk will also be held on Saturday May 4, 2013 at 3:00 pm.

team.bio:
This walk is put on by a volunteer team known as NEAT (Newcomers Explore and Appreciate Toronto) West, which is part of the CultureLink organization. CultureLink is a settlement organization that assists newcomers to Canada with various community based programs.
Our team consists of a mentor, Julia, and four mentees Mahdi, Asta, Miro and Janet, who recently joined the group. We have been putting on community walks in various locations of Toronto since 2011. Our walks have ranged from haunted tours at Halloween to Treasure Hunts and neighbourhood discovery walks. We are happy to announce will be our second Jane’s walk!
To find out more about NEAT walks place check us out on meetup.com and facebook:
http://www.meetup.com/NEATwalks/
https://www.facebook.com/NEATwalks
 
Hope to see you at the walk!!

title: Wet your Whistle
shortdescription: Port workers refreshed their throats at end of shift.  Quirky stories about Vancouver's Port, especially sugar, brews and CPR, while indulging senses on walking through Industrial Input.  Be entertained in story and beverage.
longdescription:
Wet your Whistle  refers to workers refreshing their throats after their shift in the Port.

Whistle also marked shift changes in factories and industries.

Walk along part of Powell and return on Franklin discussing quirky stories about Vancouver’s development, past to present, with reference to sugar, brews, CPR and the Port.  Indulge your senses.   

End with the opportunity to wet your whistle at craft breweries, historic pubs and modern coffee shops. 

Come with a sense of imagination and senses  alert to local Industrial input.

Meet at the Pelican Seafood Restaurant,  1895 East Hastings;  N W Hastings at Victoria.

Wears a red hat and cheery grin.
 The CD of her stories, Celtic Otherworld, won a Storytelling World Award.  www.marycelticstory.ca

title: Transforming Queens Quay -- Toronto's Main Waterfront Street
shortdescription: Learn more about the $110 million revitalization project now underway that is completely transforming Queens Quay – Toronto’s main waterfront street – into a world-class boulevard.
longdescription: Join Waterfront Toronto and West 8+DTAH for an inspiring walk along Queens Quay -- Toronto's main waterfront street.  With construction now underway , the new Queens Quay is becoming a reality. During the tour, you'll learn about the visionary design for Queens Quay and see firsthand how construction is unfolding. As we walk, you'll  see where 2.5 million pieces of granite will be laid for the project's impressive new promenade; you'll see how the new road is being configured; and you'll learn how we're bringing a tree-lined boulevard to the waterfront. Along the way, we'll also climb the wavedecks and stop at Canada's Sugar Beach to see just how beautiful that red and white Canadian granite will be when it's installed on Queens Quay.

markers.description: Spadina WaveDeck (Queens Quay and Lower Spadina Ave)

team.bio:
Christopher Glaisek is Vice President of Planning and Design for Waterfront Toronto.  An architect and urban planner for nearly twenty years, he manages all precinct planning, public realm and building design initiatives for Waterfront Toronto.
Jelle Therry is the West 8 + DTAH Design Manager for the Queens Quay Revitalization Project . West 8 is an award-winning international urban design and landscape architecture firm headquartered in Rotterdam.

longdescription: This walk will take us through four blocks of Northern Elmwood which will include viewing an exquisite and mostly hidden from the public mural, a significant urban heat island, a community-built playground and park, a community garden, vacant lots and foreclosed/boarded houses, and down the center of a National and City Historic District rich with history (The family who started Fruit of the Loom once lived here during what has been called, Elmwood’s heyday), the Knight Memorial Library and onto The Broad Street Synagogue just in time to join an optional tour of this once glorious site of rich and vibrant Jewish communities given by the RI Jewish Historical Association and RI Historical Society. Click here for more information.

title: An Evening Ramble with the Toronto Field Naturalists
shortdescription: Join us for this, TFN's 7th annual walk to celebrate Jane Jacobs' birthday and the halting of the Spadina Expressway. We'll observe both significant events as we follow Allen Road, cross Ben Nobleman Park, and move through Cedarvale Park and Ravine. Every year, like every spring, is different. In previous years we've seen yellow warblers, Baltimore orioles, chimney swifts, red admirals, and an American kestrel. We've seen emerging rushes, drooping catkins, unfurling leaves, and dozens of kinds of spring flowers.
longdescription: Join us for this, TFN's 7th annual walk to celebrate Jane Jacobs' birthday and the halting of the Spadina Expressway. We'll observe both significant events as we follow Allen Road, cross Ben Nobleman Park, and move through Cedarvale Park and Ravine. Every year, like every spring, is different. In previous years we've seen yellow warblers, Baltimore orioles, chimney swifts, red admirals, and an American kestrel. We've seen emerging rushes, drooping catkins, unfurling leaves, and dozens of kinds of spring flowers.

title: Sir John A.'s Toronto
shortdescription: This historical walk will interweave highlights from Sir John A. Macdonald's colourful life and the contributions he made to Canada to local sites around Queen's Park and the University of Toronto.
longdescription: This historical walk will interweave highlights from Sir John A. Macdonald's colourful life and the contributions he made to Canada to local sites around Queen's Park and the University of Toronto. At stops along St. George Street, we'll learn about Sir John's brief residence in Toronto while out of public office, as well as his relationship to adversaries Ontario Premier Oliver Mowat and George Brown, founder of the Globe and Mail newspaper. Other stops, including Women's College Hospital and Baldwin street will share lesser known details about Sir John A's role in the women's suffrage movement and Canada's early multiculturalism.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Base of Sir John A. Macdonald Statue at South end of Queen's Park in front of the Legislative building (2 Bloor St East).

team.bio:
Patrice Dutil, Professor at Ryerson.
 
Patrice Dutil is Professor in, and Interim Chair of, the Department of Politics and Public Administration, and a member of the Yeates School of Graduate Studies, at Ryerson University. Before joining the department in August 2006, he was the Acting Executive Director and Director of Research at the Institute of Public Administration of Canada (IPAC).
In addition to a PhD from York University, Patrice Dutil received a BA (Hon.) from York University, an M es Arts from the Université de Montréal.  He started his career in the Ministry of Intergovernmental Affairs in 1987 as a policy advisor, and then joined TVOntario where he worked in corporate policy and then in programming. He became Director of Research at IPAC in 1999.  In 1991, he founded and edited for five years the monthly Literary Review of Canada.  He is the President of the Champlain Society and is the director of the "Parliament-to-Campus" program of the Canadian Association of Former Parliamentarians.
Patrice Dutil’s main research interests are political and public sector leadership, institutionalism and the policy development process.  Dutil is a frequent commentator on public affairs on radio and television, and his op-ed pieces have appeared in the Globe and Mail, the Toronto Star, the Winnipeg Free Press and La Presse.  Dutil sits on the editorial committee of the International Review of Administrative Sciences and is the Editor of the IPAC Series in Public Administration and Governance published with the University of Toronto Press and of the Collection Administration et gouvernance published with the Presses de l'Université du Québec.

accessible-transit: Exit at Queen's Park Subway Station.
accessible-parking: Very limited on street parking available. The closest Green P is at 9 Bedford Road (in the Hotel Intercontinental).

title: Famous families, fugitive slaves, and a forgotten soldier:  150 years of history in Kitchener Mount Hope Cemetery
shortdescription: Among others, we will remember a soldier from World War 1 that was forgotten for 90 years until someone found his war medal in a thrift store, a pioneering black family that escaped slavery in the southern US in the 1840s, and some famous families that still have their names on buildings.
longdescription:
A cemetery is the memory of the community.  It’s  the last place where people otherwise forgotten can be remembered and have parts of their stories told.

On this walk, we will tell the story of a soldier from World War 1 that was forgotten for 90 years until someone found his war medal in a thrift store, a pioneering black family that escaped slavery in the southern US in the 1840s, and some famous families that still have their names on buildings.

We'll also tell the story of a former mayor and his son (known as the city's most outrageous mayor) who chummed with a famous button maker who employed a famous sausage maker who was married by a pastor ...  all people who lived and worked together in this city and most of whom have memorials within several feet of eachother.

... and then there is the felt maker whose daughter once wore a crown of light bulbs for a very special occasion ...

Join us to hear these stories and more.

team.bio: My own time in Kitchener is short.  But learning the history of this city through the stories of its citizens now in this cemetery has helped me feel grounded in my new home.

title: A Writer's Memory Lane
shortdescription: Join a Jane's Walk lead by a prominent Singaporean poet and professor. As you walk with Professor Kirpal Singh through the city centre he will recount personal experiences and provide insight to Singapore's cultural heritage. Expect a lively session complete with musings, anectodes, commentary on society and politics, maybe even ﻿﻿﻿﻿a poem or two!
longdescription:
Beginning at the Lobby of the Admin Building of the Singapore Management University – 81, Victoria St, Professor Kirpal Singh will guide you to the National Library, then to the InterContinental Hotel and then through Beach Rd via the rich district of Jalan Sultan to slowly arrive at Raffles City. You will then explore CHIJMES and cross over to the Singapore Art Museum.

All along he will share memories of what these places had meant to him when I was young and how the broad socio-political landscape has seen changes both by design and accident!

After the Walk, do join Kirpal back at SMU for a short discussion over coffee, tea, or wine!

Registration --> ofori.abena@gmail.com

Please remember that these walks are open and free, we just need to have an idea of numbers to allocate volunteers.

He is currently an Associate Professor with the Singapore Management University (SMU).

title: Victoria Avenue Alley Ways of History and Art
shortdescription:
Come explore the back streets along Victoria Avenue as we walk this historic neighbourhood with local artists, area business owners and the Thunder Bay Heritage Advisory Committee.
From where the earliest streets that are the site of a 1980’s urban renewal project – Victoriaville Centre to the city’s latest large construction project- the new court house, the Victoria Ave. area has a wealth of architectural history and stories of redevelopment.
longdescription:
Come explore the back streets along Victoria Avenue as we walk this historic neighbourhood with local artists, area business owners, and the Thunder Bay Heritage Advisory Committee.

From where the earliest streets that are the site of a 1980’s urban renewal project – Victoriaville Centre – to the city’s latest large construction project- the new court house, the Victoria Avenue area has a wealth of architectural history and stories of redevelopment. 

Unique heritage gems such as  First Wesely, St Stanislaus School, the Royal Edward Hotel, the Roy Building, the Times Journal Building and the Dyke Block recall the earliest history of the neighbourhood. 

Great city stories are told here too - from the site of the Dominion Room to the place of infamous “America’s Most Wanted”.   Art spaces are also are found in the neighbourhood: we will visit the unique studio space of Derek Khani , a favourite site for wedding photography and hear about the Bank Space Art Place project with Carol Kajorinne. 

With a final stop at the Learning Café, we will discuss a space that provides a unique learning environment and supports community development while we enjoy refreshments .

Presented by the Thunder Bay Heritage Advisory Committee and the Fort William BIA, with support from The Community Arts and Heritage Program.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Lake Superior Art Gallery, 605 Victoria Ave E (in Victoriaville Centre)

team.name-first: Thunder Bay Heritage Advisory Committee and the Fort William BIA
team.bio:
The Heritage Advisory Committee advises City Council on the protection of Thunder Bay’s built, natural, and cultural heritage. The Committee educates and promotes awareness of this heritage, so that future planning and development takes into consideration the rich history of these assets.
The Fort William BIA's mission is to promote, enhance and make safe downtown Fort William and make improvements to municipally owned properties.

title: Harbord Village West
shortdescription: Explore the diverse west side of the Harbord Village in this two-part Jane's Walk in partnership with Doors Open!
longdescription:
Harbord Village, enclosed by Bloor, Spadina, College, Bathurst, is a neighbourhood of late 19th century and early 20th century homes (about one quarter of which are members of Harbord Village Heritage Conservation District.) It is bounded by a diversity of retail, dining and entertainment venues and is close to the University of Toronto, Queens Park, Kensington Market, Little Italy and Chinatown.

This walk looks at the West half of Harbord Village with fresh eyes.  Thinking about how the relationship between planning, organic development, and neighbourhood activism in the formation of a successful community -- are there any lessons we can learn?

The 10:00am walk explores the western half of Harbord Village, south to College St then north-west to finish at Honest Ed's at Bloor and Bathurst at 12:00 noon. Join us for the next leg of the tour at 2pm on May 4th (the same day).

title: Kingston’s Queer Community - Past and Present
shortdescription: Did you know that there was a gay “Kiss-In” on the steps of City Hall in 1985? That in 1997 a small group of people protested being kicked out of a local dance club because two men in their party were dancing together? That Kingston has hosted a popular queer film festival for over thirteen years? Come listen to these and other stories about the development of Kingston's queer community!
longdescription: Did you know that there was a gay “Kiss-In” on the steps of City Hall in 1985? That in 1997 a small group of people protested being kicked out of a local dance club because two men in their party were dancing together? That Kingston has hosted a popular queer film festival for over thirteen years? Grounded in long-standing participation in the queer community and over three years of historical research, this walk follows some of the key developments in Kingston’s GLBTQ community. Peppered with oral accounts from local oral histories, archival photos, and on the ground stories, this tour is sure to provide you with a better understanding of where the queer community has been and where it is today.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: In front of City Hall, Ontario St.

team.bio:
Matt Salton is a native Kingstonian with a long history in both the arts and activist communities.  Matt has been raising the profile and visibility of the queer community in Kingston for over 14 years through the Reelout Arts Project Inc.
 
Marney McDiarmid has been an active member of Kingston’s queer community for over fifteen years. Much of the foundation for this walk is based on her MA thesis on Kingston’s lesbian and gay history from 1940-1980.

title: Bike to the Future- a walk on the cycle side
shortdescription: We will walk along 7th St and explore the construction of the new protected bike lane which will open Summer 2013.
longdescription: Take a walk along 7th St S.W. where Calgary's first cycle track is being installed. Learn about the City of Calgary's  Council approved Cycling Strategy, how 7th St was identified for a cycle track, key features of this protected bike lane and how a whole network will create connectivity in the downtown core.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: South entrance of the Peace Bridge

team.name-first: City of Calgary Transportation Solutions staff
team.bio:
Tom Thivener has been The City of Calgary’s Bicycle Coordinator since June 2012, a position created by the Council approved Cycling Strategy.  Previously he worked as the City of Tucson’s Bicycle and Pedestrian Coordinator for five years where he played a key role in moving Tucson beyond just being a recreation riding community. Tom co-founded Cyclovia Tucson, an annual open-streets event drawing tens of thousands of participants. He authored the City’s Bicycle Boulevard Plan, consisting of a 180-mile lower-stress bikeway network to complement the existing bike lane network on the main roads. He also secured funding for over 30 pedestrian signals and lead a pilot to incorporate bikes into the design at some of the signals. A native of Arizona, he has a Master’s Degree in Planning from the University of Arizona.  Tom developed an interest in planning and sustainable living while living in Sweden and in Vancouver, British Columbia.
Katherine Glowacz, the new Active Transportation Education Specialist in Solutions. Katherine was the Bicycle Friendly Community Program and Youth Education Program Manager at the Share the Road Cycling Coalition for Ontario. She has also worked as the Active School Travel Coordinator for Green Communities Canada and spent some time as the Transportation Demand Management Planner with the Region of Waterloo.

title: Ballard's Urban Diversity Celebrates the Neighborhood's Past & Present
shortdescription: Learn how Ballard's past and present work together to support a lively neighborhood that includes a mix of residential and commercial pockets supporting where people live, work and play.
longdescription:
Learn how Ballard's past and present work together to support a lively neighborhood that includes a mix of residential and commercial pockets supporting where people live, work and play.  This two-hour walk will start at Park Blvd, which when completed will run along the old trolley line. The tour will end at the Ballard Centennial Bell Tower, which was created to hold the old Ballard City Hall bell at the site where the City Hall stood, and marks the Ballard Avenue Historic District. 

We'll stroll parts of the proposed Ballard Greenways and along the way, we'll introduce the project "Threading the Needle", which provides an important connection to the waterway. Get a close up view of the new Greenfire campus and how this development is playing an important roll in supporting people of all ages through transit oriented development.  We will end at the popular Ballard Farmers' Market at noon and participants will be invited to continue the conversation over a no-host lunch.

team.name-first: Lisa Quinn, Feet First Executive Director
team.bio:
Over the last 17 years I have been involved in the sustainable transportation industry while working for the City of Tacoma, San Luis Obispo Council of Governments on the Central Coast of California, a consulting firm in Palo Alto, California, the University of Washington and numerous non-profits, including  BEST (Better Environmentally Sound Transportation) in Vancouver, Canada. I have developed award winning social marketing campaigns, facilitated and trained employees, received over $500,000 in grants and designed programs to leverage every $1 spent $5 was returned in volunteer and business contributions. 
I graduated from San Jose State University with a Bachelor in Science in Advertising (do you find humor in this? You should!) with an emphasis on sociology and environmental studies. I walk my talk--I have been car-free most of my adult life and select to go by bike, bus, and foot. I am  grateful to have been rewarded with jobs that align with my values.

shortdescription: The International District has a rich history that goes back to Seattle's founding along the Duwamish.

We will see historic buildings that celebrate Asian culture and enterprise, as well as those that reflect on the occasional hardships. Best of all, see how this historic area on the edge of downtown is active as a modern neighborhood. There are both everyday activities as well as unique sights, and the best way to see them is on foot.

title: The Olmstead Vision: The Arboretum, Interlaken Park, and Volunteer Park
shortdescription: On this Feet First Jane's Walk, we'll sample the legendary Olmsted Firm's formative impact on Seattle by exploring this trio of important, Olmsted-designed parks. They march in sequence to the top of Capitol Hill, passing through the Montlake, Stevens, and Broadway neighborhoods, respectively.
longdescription:
On this Feet First Jane's Walk, we'll sample the legendary Olmsted Firm's formative impact on Seattle by exploring this trio of important, Olmsted-designed parks. They march in sequence to the top of Capitol Hill, passing through the Montlake, Stevens, and Broadway neighborhoods, respectively.

Along the way you'll view the vibrant residential architecture that was being created for a newly prospering middle and upper class, just as the Olmsted Firm embarked on its 33-year planning partnership with the city in 1903. There are cool and unusual stairways along the way, too. Interlaken Park has stairs that force you to carefully watch where you're putting your feet, because each hand-hewn stone step is shaped differently from the one before. Then there's Volunteer Park Water Tower, where a steel staircase spirals up 106 steps, sandwiched narrowly between the water tank and its outer masonry shell. At the top you'll have a 360-degree view, along with a comprehensive exhibit on the history of the Olmsted Firm in Seattle.
4.2 miles, 2 hours; 243 steps down, 359 steps up

title: Seattle Urban Orchard Walk with City Fruit
shortdescription: Come learn about the history and status of urban orchards and what volunteers are doing to steward this invaluable, public resource.
longdescription:
Celebrate the life and work of Jane Jacobs by joining us on a walking tour of some of South Seattle's urban orchards. The tour will start promptly at 10:30am at the Seattle Children's Play Garden and continue to four other sites where we will learn about the history and status of different orchards and what volunteers are doing to steward this invaluable, public resource. 

The first part of the walk will be leisurely, with one or two larger hills. This is a dog and child-friendly walk, however please note that pushing a stroller or wheelchair up a steep hill or two could be very challenging.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Seattle Children's Play Garden, 1745 24th Avenue South, Seattle, WA 98144 (between S Grand and S Massachusetts.) Walk will end at Bradner Gardens Park, 1730 Bradner Place South, Seattle, WA 98144 (between S Grand and S Massachusetts), about six blocks from the meeting location

team.bio:
City Fruit promotes the cultivation of urban fruit in order to nourish people, build community and protect the climate. We help tree owners grow healthy fruit, provide assistance in harvesting and preserving fruit, promote the sharing of extra fruit, and work to protect urban fruit trees.
Urban fruit trees are a valuable community resource. Often fruit goes unused because people are not sure when to harvest it, how to eat it, or they are put off by damage caused by preventable disease and pests. We are reclaiming the urban orchard, showing people how to harvest and use what they need, and to share the rest with others. Join us in reclaiming urban fruit!

title: Victoria Park: Still the same, with all the changes
shortdescription: Victoria Park has been the center of Berlin / Kitchener for almost 120 years. While its general outline has remained much the same, tremendous changes have altered the landscape, the uses and the way people use the park. In a two-hour walkabout, people will gain insight on changes from the 1895 construction as well as what recent modifications have been made to the landscape.
longdescription:
On Sunday May 5, Kitchener's Victoria Park will reveal some of its historical secrets as we walk over landscape that has (not) changed considerably since its Grand Opening in 1896. There are trees and features remaining from that special August day so long ago but there are also some brand new park components about to enjoy their first summer. What differences have these old and new changes made in the way people view the park -- and more importantly -- how people use the park? Combining elements such as landscape, nature, built-features, surrounding neighborhood, city government intentions and citizens' perceptions, the two-hour walkabout will ensure that those participating come away with a more appreciative understanding of the city's major recreational site.

Walkers should wear sturdy and waterproof shoes or boots especially if the weather is, or has been, wet. Wobbly walkers would be wise to bring a staff. Cameras, binoculars, waterbottles, snacks also suggested. There are two sets of washrooms in the park which we will pass by. The host welcomes attendees to bring any old family photos of Victoria Park for show and tell.

Turn left inside the stone entrance gates, follow the curving drive beside the playground and then branch right alongside the picnic grounds, skirting the Dill Street gates to the parking lot near the maintenance compound.

team.bio: rych mills, Victoria Park historian, member of the Victoria Park Historical Committee (operators of The Gallery, the park museum), author of the book Victoria Park: 100 Years of a Park and Its People, and member of the Victoria Park Working Group
