title: Historical Walking Tour of Yorkville (Part 1): The Parks of Yorkville
shortdescription: Join Councillor Kristyn Wong-Tam and Architects Ken Greenberg and Michael McClelland for a walking conversation on how the future of Yorkville can be shaped in the context of current development, while taking in the unique heritage of Yorkville, including the Yorkville Public Library and the award-winning Village of Yorkville Park.
longdescription:
Yorkville, one of Toronto's most historic and culturally rich neighbourhoods, has seen dramatic transformation over the past two hundred years and remains subject to further change. But is this change sustainable?

Growing from a mixed industrial and suburban area in the 1830s, to the hub of bohemian culture for famous Canadian writers and activists including Margaret Atwood and Neil Young in the 1960s, Yorkville began to take on the cultural and commercial landscape of today in the 1980s with the arrival of internationally renowned designers, high-end shops, cafes, galleries, and residences.

Intense commercial and residential development continues today within the neighbourhood from Yonge Street to Avenue Road, Bloor Street West to Davenport Road. 

While the strong retail presence and heritage characteristics have generated tourism and contributed to a vibrant neighbourhood, it has also brought intense residential development pressures for pedestrians, business owners, vehicle drivers, and challenges from a  streetscaping and urban design perspective. 

On Saturday May 4, 2013 join Councillor Kristyn Wong-Tam and Architects Ken Greenberg and Michael McClelland for a walking conversation of pedestrianization efforts and how the future of Yorkville can be shaped in the context of current development proposals, while taking in the unique sights of heritage buildings including the Yorkville Public Library, Heliconian Hall, and the award-winning Village of Yorkville Park.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Yorkville Public Library, 22 Yorkville Avenue.

team.name-first: Councillor Kristyn Wong-Tam, and Architects Ken Greenberg and Michael McClelland
team.bio:
Councillor Kristyn Wong-Tam has an extensive career investing in the City of Toronto through both the public and private sectors. As a tireless community advocate, Councillor Wong-Tam has championed for the expansion of green public spaces and farmers' markets, including improvements to parks and ravines. She has lead efforts to defend the rights of tenants to obtain affordable and decent standards of rental housing and helped create a neighbourhood association to preserve and protect heritage buildings and historical landscapes in the ward.
Prior to being elected to City Council in 2010, Councillor Wong-Tam was an accomplished real estate professional and supporter of the arts. She has curated art installations for Scotiabank's Nuit Blanche and is the principal of a Toronto-based contemporary fine art gallery.
Councillor Wong-Tam continues to be a champion for sustainable living and environmental health and plays a vital role in ensuring the vibrancy of our city and its economic and social development.
Ken Greenberg is an architect, urban designer, teacher, former Director of Urban Design and Architecture for the City of Toronto and Principal of Greenberg Consultants. For over three decades he has played a pivotal role on public and private assignments in urban settings throughout North America and Europe, focusing on the rejuvenation of downtowns, waterfronts, neighbourhoods, regional growth management, and new community planning.
Cities as diverse as Toronto, Amsterdam, New York, Montréal, Washington DC, Paris, and San Juan Puerto Rico have benefited from his advocacy and passion for restoring the vitality, relevance and sustainability of the public realm in urban life.
In each city consensus-building approach has led to coordinated planning and a renewed focus on urban design. He is the recipient of the 2010 American Institute of Architects Thomas Jefferson Award for public design excellence and the author of Walking Home: the Life and Lessons of a City Builder.
Michael McClelland OAA, FRAIC is a registered architect with over twenty years of experience. His work covers urban design and heritage planning in addition to building conservation. He is also actively involved in the public promotion of Canada’s architectural heritage. He is a founding member of the Canadian Association of Heritage Professionals (CAHP).
Prior to establishing ERA Architects Inc. with Edwin Rowse in 1990, Michael McClelland worked for the Toronto Historical Board, advising on planning, permit and development applications, and on the preservation of City-owned museums and monuments. In 1999 he was awarded a certificate of recognition from the Ontario Association of Architects and the Toronto Society of Architects for his outstanding contribution to the built environment and to the profession of architecture and in 2006 he was made a Fellow of the Royal Architectural Institute of Canada.

Join our walk in St. James Town and get the opportunity to know the real faces of one of the most diverse neighbourhood. Hear the stories from members of the community.


We will introduce the past, present and future that gives life to St. James Town. Get to know St. James Town and how it developed.  Learn how it became one of the most densely populated communities in North America.

Start picturing the future of this Community. This walk will open your eyes to a lively and colourful neighbourhood; and will introduce you to the new possibilities and the new vision this community has to offer.

title: Attractiveness and life in the city
shortdescription: The theme of Gävle's Jane's Walk treats attractiveness and life in the city. What makes places in the city attractive and life-filled?
longdescription:
During the Janes walk there will be discussions about what can be provided in the locations to create attractivity, life and greater use of them. For example, events that can bring more life into the town center, or aesthetic additions more benches, vegetation, etc.

The idea is that identity is the basis of commitment and thus, several different identities come together and talk about the situation on the ground.

title: Three Centuries of Corktown
shortdescription: Join a team of residents and local heritage experts as we walk through the changing lanes of Corktown, one of Toronto’s oldest neighbourhoods!
longdescription: This tour will explore the changing landscape of Corktown - home to government, industry, immigration and constant change since the late 18th century. Visit the site of Ontario’s first purpose-built parliament buildings, and see the homes and workplaces of Victorian-era immigrant labourers. Learn about the sweeping changes brought by industry and progress throughout the 20th century. Get the scoop on recent developments in the area, new building initiatives and fascinating stories of the people and places within our neighbourhood. The tour will be led by area expert Lynne Kurylo, long-time Corktown resident Helène St. Jacques, and Alison Little, Site Coordinator at Enoch Turner Schoolhouse.  This tour is being co-hosted by Jane's Walks and Doors Open Toronto, to be offered on both May 5, 2013 and May 26, 2013.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Enoch Turner Schoolhouse, 106 Trinity Street

team.name-first: Lynne Kurylo, Helène St. Jacques and Alison Little
team.bio:
Lynne Kurylo is the Chair of Liberal Studies within theSchoolofContinuing EducationatGeorgeBrownCollege, and a former museum educator who has operated City Walks tours for over 10 years.


Helène St. Jacques is the Founder and President of Informa Market Resarch, a longstanding Board member of the Enoch Turner Schoolhouse Foundation, and volunteers with FoodShare Toronto, and the Toronto Food Policy Council. She has lived in Corktown since the mid-1980s.


Alison Little has been the Site Coordinator at Enoch Turner Schoolhouse for nearly 3 years. In leading walking tours of Corktown, she has conducted extensive research on the residents and industry of the area from the late 18th to mid-20th centuries.

Vincent's easy-going style, lyrical and expressive voice and generous servings of humour add to the enjoyment and value of the imagineTHAT! experience. Home-made music, song and audience participation are added to the blend thus creating an enjoyable and memorable experience.He has performed for all ages at school and library programs, conferences, meetings, concerts, festivals, informal gatherings and hoolies across Canada and Overseas.

title: West Broadway - Get me to the Church on Time!
longdescription:
Our walking tour of the historic, century-old neighbourhood of West Broadway begins at 10 AM at the corner of Broadway and Colony.

We’ll begin with an incredible peek inside Gothic-style All Saints’ church, guided by rector’s warden and history buff Barb Hicks who will share some of the history of All Saints’, with a specific focus on its stunning collection of stained glass windows - one of the largest collections of William Morris stained-glass windows in North America.

We’ll then head west to begin our stroll through West Broadway. A number of places of interest will be identified and you will be surprised to learn how Good Street got its name, which local resident sailed on the Titanic, where Budweiser got its famous Clydsdales, and a whole lot more during our short time together.

Walking tour guide and long-time resident Rob Shaw’s passion for the place he calls home, along with his light-hearted approach and intimate knowledge of the area makes this a do-not-miss tour.

More information: http://www.meetup.com/weriers-walkers/events/102249692/

title: Walk Through "Little Jerusalem"
shortdescription: Join this walk to learn about the origins of Kingston's Jews, where they lived, and what they did for a living a century ago. Sites include the first synagogue in Kingston, early places of business, and a forgotten spaces of cultural importance.
longdescription: How do you walk through an environment that no longer exists? Professor Gordon Dueck was faced with this challenge while planning his Jane's Walk  through Kingston's  "Little Jerusalem" and other areas that were of importance to the Jewish community but have since been paved over or converted. The Sleepless Goat Cafe, for instance, was formerly a cigar shop owned by Simon Oberndorffer in the late nineteenth century. Well, we can no longer smoke a Principal Grant Cigar, but we can at least recapture these hidden Kingston narratives and meet other interested community members in the process.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Samuel Springer Memorial Parking Lot on Queen Street

team.bio: Dr. Gordon Dueck designed this tour for the centennial of the Beth Israel congregation in 2010. He is a professor of History and Jewish Studies at Queen's University.

Aqueduct monument, Settlers Monument, Jordan Van Sewell's art installations in Stephen Juba Park. Themes will be the early history of the area, and its transformation to become the poster child for downtown living. We will also discuss downtown living issues.

team.name-first: Jim Smith - Historian/Archivist North East Winnipeg Historical Society Inc.
team.bio:
Jim Smith is a member of the North East Winnipeg Historical Society Inc., where he serves as the Historian/Archivist for the society.
Jim Smith B.A. History (University of Manitoba) has been researching the history of North East Winnipeg, (Elmwood, East Kildonan and North Kildonan) for the past 12 years and has recently started researching the history of the West Kildonan and Old Kildonan areas.  With many hours spent transcribing documents from local archival locations, Jim’s historical research can be found on the Miles Macdonell Collegiate Alumni Association website www.mmcalumni.ca click on the ‘History’ link.
Jim comes from a family of public service.  His mother has and is still involved in many community based services.  His father had served as City Councillor, a School Board Trustee, many board positions; his last  as a  Justice for the Court of Queen’s Bench.  Jim’s service has included sitting on many boards in director and chair positions.  The Miles MacDonell Collegiate Alumni Association as director for many years, the 60th Anniversary Chair, Parent/Teacher Chair, and many more.

title: Making and Remaking Olneyville
shortdescription: A walk through the Olneyville neighborhood of Providence, exploring its industrial heritage and current revitalization efforts.
longdescription: We will start at RiversideParkand walk along three stretches of Olneyville: Manton Avenue, Valley Street, and Olneyville Square, ending up back at RiversidePark.  The tour will walk and talk about the industrial and urban development of Olneyville in the 19th and 20th centuries and about recent efforts to green the neighborhood and provide new recreational opportunities, to organize neighbors, to redevelop historic buildings, and to provide new places for people to live and work.  Sites include historic mills and churches, new parks and community gardens, and a variety of housing from early 19th-century millworkers’ cottages to newly developed multi-family homes.  We also plan to visit several neighbors during the tour and hear about their experiences of Olneyville.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Riverside Mills (Woonasquatucket River Greenway), Aleppo St.

team.name-first: Johanna Walczak, Sarah Zurier, and Mark Sawtelle
team.bio:
Johanna Walczak is the Community Building Program Manager at Olneyville Housing Corporation, a non-profit neighborhood-based community development organization. She organizes neighborhood events and celebrations and coordinates the Olneyville Collaborative, a coalition of neighborhood organizations working to improve the quality of life in Olneyville.
Sarah Zurier is a Providence native and a historian at the Rhode Island Historical Preservation & Heritage Commission.  She has given bike and walking tours of Olneyville and the Valley neighborhoods for the Woonasquatucket River Watershed Council and The Steelyard.
Mark Sawtelle is a longtime fan and resident of Providence. During the mid-1980s, he and his wife lived in Olneyville, with her family, who had lived and worked there since the 1940s. He continues to have a variety of regular ties to the neighborhood.

title: Patches of Wildness
shortdescription: Guided walk along the Brock Trail identifying various tree species.
longdescription:
This walk will take people along the Brock Trail fromElm streettoBeecher street.

The Brock trail is a favourite green space. I use it almost every day either walking or on my bike. I watch it through the seasons as it changes.

The guided walk will proceed along a wild corridor of the city. Walkers will observe, identify and appreciating some of the native and non-native tree species of the urban canopy.

Along the way walkers will examine several tree species, looking at historic tree uses, natural history and folklore.

Diverse species of trees bring diverse species of birds. The trees are the birds’ larder [nuts, seeds, and fruit]. Trees provide homes and building materials for birds. They are the perches birds seek in the spring when they call out to attract mates. Trees attract insects which attract hungry birds. Listen closely for the drumming of a hairy/downy woodpecker excavating bark for a meal. Up the trail we will see the black locust. When it flowers in June it will attract thousands of foraging bees. Its nectar will fill hives with honey.

Above left: Horse Chestnut  /  Above right: Black Locust

Above: Paper Birch

title: Vancouver's CBD
shortdescription: This walk looks at the many styles of architecture in downtown Vancouver and the stories of how it was made possible.
longdescription:
This walk looks at the many styles of architecture in downtown Vancouver and the stories of how it was made possible.

The walk starts at the Waterfront Station and extends up Burrard Street, looking at the city's central business district, featuring the Marine Building, Guinness Tower, Bentall Centre & Park Place.

Other highlights include Christ Church Cathedral, the Hotel Vancouver, and the Law Courts, ending at Robson Square.

title: Providence’s Jewelry District: An Important Historic Neighborhood in Transition Once Again
shortdescription: This walk will take participants along narrow streets in what was originally a modest, densely packed residential neighborhood that was transformed in the 19th century into an industrial powerhouse, and faces new transformations today.
longdescription: Led by Jewelry District residents, Peter McClure and Phoebe Blake, this sixty to ninety minute walk will take participants along narrow streets in what was originally a modest, densely packed residential neighborhood that was transformed in the 19th century into an industrial powerhouse. One hundred years ago Providence was the richest city in America. And jewelry was one of the reasons why. Today the District is home to health and educational organizations along with artists, design studios, small startups, restaurants, clubs, and considerable open space that the City and State is looking to for future growth.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: The corner of Richmond St & Ship St

team.bio: Peter McClure and Phoebe Blake are active members of the Jewelry District Association and its Planning and Zoning Committee of which Phoebe is Chair. Both are members of the Providence Preservation Society and the City’s Hospitality Resource Partnership. Peter is also a board member of PICA , the State’s largest food pantry.

title: Murals of North Central Regina
shortdescription: Marvel at the dynamic colours and designs of some of our neighbourhood murals created by emerging & established Regina artists. Some culturally significant, some just for whimsy, and others an expression of rabid Roughrider fandom.
longdescription: North Central Regina has many hidden gems expressing our pride of place.  Once tarnished as "Canada's Worst Neighbourhood" (Macleans Magazine 2007) our  community has always participated in projects to engage and beautify our surroundings. From our history to our innovative programming to our murals, North Central welcomes you to view our neighbourhood as we see it.

title: The Trees of Thornton
shortdescription: The arboretum (Tree Museum) on Vancouver's welcome mat in front of the Station, is an often unappreciated gem. Get to meet some tree species ~ you don't need to hug 'em to say 'Hi!'
longdescription:
Thornton Park, at Main & Terminal, in front of the train & bus station, is Vancouver's welcome mat to many. It also happens to be a significant arboretum, a tree museum, with specimens  from many parts of the world. Along with species and geographical origins there will also be literary references to things like "A Tree Grows in Brooklyn" by Betty Smith and "The Copper Beech" by Maeve Binchy.

The park's history ... False Creek landfill during World War One (& being a side of the old Westminster Bridge before that) to being in the midst of a train shipping and warehousing district, to being a fresh air space in a residential, artistic and educational neighbourhood today, and some of what may be in the plans for tomorrow ... will be touched on. Others may share information & insights.

The Walk is planned to run about 90 minutes.

markers.description: Middle of the Park (Thornton Park, Main & Terminal) path intersection by The Marker for Change, women's memorial, circle of stones

team.bio:
Joe Thompson has lived across from the park in Citygate for 20 years. (Previously at the Ford, Hastings & Main, Gastown & the West End.) I have a Bachelor's Degree of General Studies from SFU, with courses in 14 departments, an omnivorous mind. I am a photographer, writer and gardener, among other things. Jane Jacobs is one of my intellectual heroes, a plain person of deep insight. If you can spare 10 minutes, here is a video which clarifies her value ~ http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZXeEMD6U0NY  ... I am a citizen of a city; my own well-being is contingent upon the quality of my surroundings. Ah, but it is a reciprocal relationship; my city needs engaged citizens in order to grow well.
There may be tree seedlings available after the walk.

title: Walking The Drive
shortdescription: Come see what Commercial Drive is all about!
longdescription:
Come walk Commercial Drive and explore this gem of commerce and culture.  This historic working class street has a vibrant history: from early entrepreneurs to Italian immigrants; from feminist roots to a strong, inclusive community.

 This street is well walked and dearly loved by those who frequent it.  With a focus on grocery shopping, dining and drinking, The Drive deliciously provides the space needed to develop and maintain a community. 

Explore the history of The Drive.  View the past through the present; and get a sense of what has shaped The Drive, what has been fought for, and what has been forgotten.  

Discover the informal commerce that animates; the public and private spaces that physically shape; and the individuals who breathe life into Commercial Drive.

From Clark Park at the south end, to Venables at the north, take a stroll down Commercial Drive and see what this creative, cultural and unique street is all about.

This walk will be roughly 1 -1/2 to 2 hours.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Clark Park (1500 E 14th Ave.)

team.bio:
I have lived in Vancouver and on the East Side since 2005.  The Drive quickly captured my imagination and heart, and eventually became the focus of my master’s thesis (UBC School of Architecture).  
I sought to understand how the physical street fostered such a strong community. Then, I worked to develop a strategy for securing and advancing those spaces and places that define The Drive while allowing for continued commercial development.  
Today, along with my golden retriever Tucker, I am an avid walker of The Drive.

accessible-transit: Close to Skytrain and 99 B-Line (Broadway)
accessible-parking: Street Parking Available
accessible-find: We will collect at the top of  Clark Park, at the south end of Commercial Drive (at 14th Ave).

title: Williamsburg Walk
shortdescription: Looking into the past and the future of Williamsburg neighbourhood
longdescription:
Whole walk maximum 2 hours – or you may join us along the route!
(If it rains, we will do the walk on May 5th at 10:30) 

Join members of Williamsburg Community Association,  and Councillor Kelly Galloway-Sealock for a gentle walk and a friendly conversation in Williamsburg. Connect with your neighbours and with the places in your neighbourhood:

Start – Max Becker Common and future development plans

 

Stop 1 – Wililamsburg Public School, history and heritage

 

Stop 2 – Bleams Road, view at future development of South Park

 

Stop 3 – Laurentian Wetlands, natural sanctuary

 

End  – Donnenwerth House, and the best view over Williamsburg!

 

We can talk about our favorite places, best loved parks, popular walking routes with our pets, vital shortcuts, safest bicycle trails, and about the permanent location for Williamsburg community centre.

Come out and share your ideas about making our neighbourhood more walkable, welcoming, fun and safe.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Max Becker Common Park

team.name-first: Kelly Gallowey-Sealock, RBJ Schlegel Urban Development team, and Williamsburg Community Association
team.bio:
Kelly Galloway-Sealock has represented the citizens of Kitchener since 2006 as the Councillor for Kitchener's South Ward. Following the election and ward boundary changes, Kelly was honoured to be elected as the councillor for the new Ward 5.
She has been a strong advocate for new parks and park development through studies like Kitchener's first Growth Management Strategy and the Parks and Open Space Master Plan.  Kelly was instrumental in the formation of the Williamsburg Community Association while securing a location for the Williamsburg Community Centre - Kitchener's newest community centre.  
She works closely with the neighbourhood association she represents and is actively involved in issues concerning youth, accessibility, women in government and growth. 
Sarah Code, graduated from the University of Waterloo with a Bachelor of Environmental Studies in Planning; specializing in land development. Working for Schlegel Urban Developments. She has learned the importance of planning unique and complete communities that ensure a high quality of life for all residents. She looks forward to sharing the history of Williamsburg with you!

team.bio: Every year, the students of the Jane Jacobs Club for Urban Literacy at University of Toronto Schools host a Jane's Walk, an interactive and informative tour of the neighborhood. Each walk is completely open to the public and revolves around a central theme, with significant stops along the way. Past themes have included changes in local business and the importance of urban art in Toronto. This year, Jane's Club has murder on the mind.

בהליכה בין שתיים מתוך 42 הגינות הקהילתיות בירושלים, נגלה את הסיפורים שמאחורי תופעה אזרחית עירונית שורשית ירושלמית אמתית. נדבר על מה זו בכלל גינות קהילתיות, מי עומד מאחוריהן, איך הן עובדות, למה הן קמות (ולפעמים נופלות), ועל איך הן הופכות את העיר למקום טוב יותר ואת הפעילים בהן למנהיגים קהילתיים.

title: "Oh Dear": Unhinging North York's Modesty
shortdescription: This talk looks at North York's civic centre and surrounding cultural buildings through a post-amalgamation lens, and specifically through the eyes of some local artists slated to install public works over the summer.
longdescription:
This walk reflects on North York's centre (Willowdale), a strip of Yonge Street between Sheppard Avenue to the south and Finch Avenue to the north, that provides distinct aesthetic markers of the past 6 decades. A post-war suburban district transformed into North York's city centre, today the area surrounding Mel Lastman Square and the North York Civic Centre, serves as a central post-amalgamation Toronto hub for new Canadians. With its rapidly expanding and changing population, it offers a mix of built conditions: soaring high rises and greater density; the preservation of the wide single dwelling lots that surround its main artery; post-war housing replaced in favour of monster homes; and public art and other planning attempts to both create and dissolve a centralized civic centre created before the 1998 amalgamation of Toronto. This mix today offers a microcosm of frugality and excess, and of new and old urbanism, that progress outside the purviews of critical taste. This talk is an introduction to a multi-site exhibition planned for this summer entitled"Oh Dear", which will offer a critique of this area, roughly twenty-five years after its' major civic buildings have been built. 

A "Dear John letter" is a letter written to a spouse or partner to inform that a relationship is over because the author has found someone else. Such letters were common and likely originated during war times, when servicepersons were stationed away from home for several months or years, and either they or their partner started a new relationship rather than wait for the original one to return. "Oh Dear" is an exhibition that examines and plays with the veneer of modesty and morality typically associated with North York. The project explores a middle road between professionalism and passion, or more precisely, a proletariat-like sorting of work and life. As the title intends, this proposed exhibition and this Jane's Walk embraces both the directness of a "dear" letter and the endearment of the "dearest" of salutations reserved for those we love and keep close to home.

Some of the project's participating artists who practice, grew up or live in the area will also be at this walk. Presented together with North York Arts.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Reflecting Pool at Mel Lastman Square

team.bio: Paola Poletto's work involves a lot of people with a whole bunch of viewpoints, much like the Surrealists did, and the occasional solitary retreat into craft-based objects. She is artist coordinator and co-editor of Oh Dear (RZLBD Post, slated 2013), Tel-talk (Tightrope Books, 2012), Boredom Fighters! (Tightrope Books, 2008), Ourtopias: Cities and the Role of Design (Riverside Architectural Press, 2008), and Kiss Machine (2000-5). Paola has held curatorial and programming positions at Art Gallery of Ontario (2013- ), City of Mississauga's Culture Division (2008-13), Design Exchange (2000-8) and Toronto's Italian Cultural Institute/Consulate General of Italy (1993-8). She lives nearby Mel Lastman Square with her husband and twin daughters.

title: תל אביב/ברלין: מנדלסון ושטראוס נפגשים בקפה מרסנד
shortdescription:
הליכה בעקבות המורשת הגרמנית בתל אביב בין מוקדי התרבות הייקית ברחוב בן יהודה והמושבה שרונה. בהליכה נשוחח על הקשרים המקומיים של הבונים החופשיים והבאוהאוס למורשתם של אישים יהודים כגון מנדלסון, שטראוס, ארלוזורוב וקרליבך בתל אביב

הסיור יכלול נסיעת אוטובוס עירונית קצרה בתשלום
longdescription:
אלפי הישראלים המתגוררים בברלין הופכים את הקשר בין  תל אביב וברלין  לקרוב ויום יומי. 

אבל לקשר בין שתי הערים יש היסטוריה ארוכה הרבה יותר. בהליכה בין מוקדים מרכזיים בעיר נספר את סיפורם הפחות מוכר של הייקים, כינוי ליהודים – גרמנים שהגיעו לארץ בשנות השלושים. היקים הביאו עימם לתל אביב תרבות עשירה – שפה, ארכיטקטורה ועיצוב, מוסיקה, אוכל ואמנות. הסיור ייקח אותנו אל בין כתלי בן יהודה שטראסה - מעוז התרבות הייקית בתל אביב, במהלכו נבקר בקפה מרסנד הברלינאי. נסייר גם במושבה הטמפלרית שרונה, נלמד על הקשר בין הבונים החופשיים הגרמנים והצברים, נטייל בין בניינים שנוסדו על ידי חלוצי הבאוהאוס בישראל, ונתבונן במורשתם של אישים כמנדלסון, שטראוס, קרליבך וארלוזרוב ברחבי העיר.


הסיור יכלול נסיעת אוטובוס עירונית קצרה בתשלום

title: A Walk Through the Parks
shortdescription: New Westminster has more parks than just Queen's, although Queen's Park certainly is beautiful.  If you enjoy walking amongst huge ancient trees and down leafy streets lined with heritage homes while the birds flit about and the flowers bloom, come for a walk with me.
longdescription:
We'll start with a stroll through some beautiful old trees, walking diagonally across Moody Park, from there we'll take a brief walk along a block or two of New Westminster's 'uptown' to see how the commeracial district relates to the residential and park areas.  From Uptown, on our way to Queen's Park, we'll walk down residential streets that are lined with blocks of heritage homes, many of them with beautiful gardens.  We'll continue our walk via the northwest entrance to Queens Park.  Be ready to see some lovely big old trees - we'll exit the park on 3rd Avenue - on our way to yet another park.  Soon we'll be at Tipperary Park, a surprisingly beautiful little park that includes both open areas and landscaped gardens.  We'll visit the Friendship Gardens before heading west along Royal to end our walk at Simcoe Park.

There - we've done it - those are a few of New Westminster's parks. You can complete the circle by walking back to Moody Park via 9th Street or, if you still have energy after this walk, come with me down to the Quay for one of the most delicious gelatos in the lower mainland - at an Italian cafe in the Quay.  They make a terrific cappucino as well. 

If you drive to New Westminster, it might be a good idea to park either neara Moody Park or in the lot at the Quay, depending on where you wish to end your walk.

title: זכויות דיור ביפו-יאפא: הליכה בין הטיילת והסמטאות של עג'מי
shortdescription: הליכה ברחבי שכונת עג'מי ביפו שתתמקד בזכות לדיור של תושביה הפלסטינים של יפו. נעבור בין בתים ומקומות שמייצגים את מאבקם של תושבי יפו לדיור בעירם ונבחן את השינויים לאורך השנים: חוק נכסי נפקדים לאחר מלחמת 1948, זכויות כדייר מוגן מול חברת עמידר, והבירוקרטיה סביב שינוי ייעוד קרקע. במהלך הדרך נבחן כיצד שינויים אלו באים לידי ביטוי במרחב העירוני הדומם. נדבר עם תושבי יפו, ונשמע כיצד סיפורים אישיים וקהילתיים מגלמים בתוכם מגמות אורבניות והיסטוריות.
longdescription:
אמנסטי אינטרנשיונל ישראל מזמין אותך לסיור ברחבי שכונת עג'מי ביפו, שיתמקד בזכות לדיור של תושביה הפלסטינים של יפו: נעבור בין בתים ומקומות שמייצגים את מאבקם של תושבי יפו לדיור בעירם ונבחן את השינויים לאורך השנים (חוק נכסי נפקדים לאחר מלחמת 1948, זכויות כדייר מוגן מול חברת עמידר, והבירוקרטיה סביב שינוי ייעוד קרקע), וכיצד שינויים אלו באים לידי ביטוי במרחב העירוני הדומם. בנוסף, נדבר עם תושבי השכונה ונראה כיצד סיפורים אישיים וקהילתיים מגלמים בתוכם מגמות אורבניות והיסטוריות.
אשרו הגעה גם בפייסבוק, והרשמו בטופס המקוון שלנו.

(יש להגיע מצויידים במכשיר שמע אישי + אוזניות ולהוריד את הקובץ מבעוד מועד / להאזין עם חיבור אינטרנט באמצעות הסמארטפון)
* ביום שישי 5/3 בשעה 11:00 יתקיים מפגש עם האמנית, אשר תסביר על העבודה, הרקע ותחום הסאונדארט כמאפשר חקר והצגה של תרבות תלויית מקום.
היצירה מנחה את המאזין/משתתף להליכה אישית ואמנותית באמצעות קול וסאונד, מזויות אישית ואלטרנטיבית.
הליכות סאונד התפרסמו בעיקר בעשור האחרון מתוך התפתחות של אומנות הסאונד-ארט. ביצירות מסוג זה ניתן לאפשר חקר והצגה של תרבות תלויית מקום (פורמט די נפוץ בערים רבות באירופה וארה"ב).
בפורמט שמציעה אמנית הסאונד והמוסיקאית יפית ראובני, ניתן להוריד באופן עצמאי קובץ שמע, וללכת אותו בזמנכם החופשי. המסלול מתחיל במדרחוב אגריפס/כיכר אבן ישראל, עובר דרך גלריה אגריפס 12, הולצר ספרים, גלריה שודדי י-ם ומסתיים בגלריה "ברבור".

title: עושים שוּק - הליכה בשוק לוינסקי
shortdescription: סיור לאורך שוק התבלינים המוביל בארץ - שוק לוינסקי - מרחוב הרצל לרחוב העליה. במהלך הדרך נפגש עם כמה מסוחרי השוק המובילים את היוזמה להתחדשות המקום. ההליכה "עושים שוק" היא ניסיון לראות מקרוב הצעה להשקעה אחרת במרקם עירוני קיים שנשענת על פתיחת האזור להולכי רגל המגיעים מקרוב ומרחוק.
longdescription:
לוינסקי הוא שוק התבלינים המוביל בארץ. הוא אזור פיוטי לא רק בזכות הסופר אלחנן ליב לוינסקי על שמו קרוי הרחוב, אלא בייחוד בשל הרקמה האנושית התוססת של מסחר בתבלינים, פיצוחים ובתי אוכל שמתקיימת בו. יש בו קסם שנתמך על מסורת ארוכת שנים ועירוניות שוקקת ומפעימת לב. לאחרונה הצעתי במועצת העיר ת"א יפו כי הרחוב והאזור הסמוך לו יוכר כשוק ויפעל כמדרחוב בימי שישי.  ההליכה "עושים שוק" היא ניסיון לראות מקרוב הצעה להשקעה אחרת במרקם עירוני קיים שנשענת על פתיחת האזור להולכי רגל המגיעים מקרוב ומרחוק. הסיור יארך באזור שוק לוינסקי מפינת הרצל ועד לרחוב  העליה תוך מפגשים עם כמה מסוחרי השוק המובילים את היוזמה.

למידע נוסף: 

http://sharonmalki.com/2013/03/923

title: מסע אופניים בין התרחשויות אקולוגיות בירושלים
shortdescription:
בסיור הרכוב עם יונתן, נחשף להתרחשות אקולוגית בירושלים ולפרוייקט הקומפוסט בשיתוף מהפח ירוק, נסחט מיץ תפוזים טרי במוזיאון הטבע ונעשיר את הגינה, נלגום תה צמחים בגינה בברודי ונקנח בכוסית ערק בגינה הקהילתית בזמנהוף.

מי שירצה יוכל להשאר בזמנהוף לארוחת בוקר מפנקת, שתילות ועבודה עם פעילי הגינה המקסימים. 
הרכיבה בעברית ובאנגלית באחריות הרוכבים
נא להגיע עם קסדה
ו5-10 שקלים סכום סמלי לכיסוי הדרינקים
longdescription:
סיור רכוב, סביבתי-חברתי בין פחים וגינות קהילתיות.
נחשף להתרחשות אקולוגית בירושלים ולפרוייקט הקומפוסט בשיתוף מהפח ירוק, נסחט מיץ תפוזים טרי במוזיאון הטבע ונעשיר את הגינה, נלגום תה צמחים בגינה בברודי ונקנח בכוסית ערק בגינה הקהילתית בזמנהוף.
מי שירצה יוכל להשאר בזמנהוף לארוחת בוקר מפנקת, שתילות ועבודה מענגת עם פעילי הגינה...
הרכיבה בעברית ובאנגלית באחריות הרוכבים. יש להגיע עם קסדה, אופניים תקינות ו5-10 שקלים סכום סמלי לכיסוי הדרינקים.
* המידע המעודכן כאן אינו סופי, יש לשוב ולהתעדכן לקראת האירוע.

title: Jane's Ride Regina
shortdescription: Explore bikeability in and around downtown Regina and join in a discussion on how to make the city a more bike-friendly place!
longdescription:
Come with us to explore parts of central Regina on bike. If you've ever wondered what travelling through the city is like on a bike, join us in a discussion on bikeability around the downtown area. Help us identify easy to travel and more challenging areas to travel on a bicycle.  How can we make the city a more bike-friendly place?

Don't forget your bike, helmet and bell!

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Stage at City Plaza Downtown

team.bio: Bike Regina is a community group in Regina with the objective to make cycling to work, to school and to other daily activities safe, convenient and fun for people of all ages and abilities in the city. Through partnerships, outreach and events, we advocate for a better cycling environment that promotes safety, physical activity, health, equity and environmental sustainability.

title: The Spaces & Places in between Parkdale and the Bow River
shortdescription: Let's talk about how our rivers shape us and we shape our rivers.
longdescription: From the secrets underneath your streets to the Bow River stories of the past, join us for a one-hour guided walk exploring Parkdale’s unique connections to the river.  We’ll talk about how the river shaped Parkdale’s history and we’ll also chat about the role we all play in creating a community that harmoniously connects and protects our Bow River.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Parkdale Community Centre, 3512 5 Avenue NW. We will meet in the front green space.

team.bio: Matt Dorma is a Water Wise Educator with the City of Calgary's Water Services Community Outreach team. Matt is a life-long Calgarian, a history buff and a sustainable cities geek. In his spare time, Matt loves to explore Calgary, on either bike or raft, through the beautiful river and pathway system.

title: שיטוט בקריית המלאכה
shortdescription: סיפורה של קריית המלאכה – מתחם תעשייתי שנבנה בתחילת שנות השישים ומשנה את פניו בשנים האחרונות. תוך כדי שיטוט נשים לב לארכיטקטורה ולמרקמים, נשוחח על אמנות רחוב, ונתבונן בעבודות הגרפיטי של מיטב אמני הרחוב בעיר. מטרת הסיור היא לחוות הכרות עם סביבה לא מוכרת ומלאת השראה, להתבונן בה בעיניים חדשות ולנסות להבין את חוויית השוטטות.
longdescription:
סיפורה של קריית המלאכה – מתחם תעשייתי שאין דומה לו בארץ. המתחם נבנה בתחילת שנות השישים בשולי העיר ומשנה את פניו בשנים האחרונות כשאמנים רבים שוכרים בו סטודיו. תוך כדי שיטוט נשים לב לארכיטקטורה ולמרקמים, נשוחח על אמנות רחוב בכלל ואיך היא משתלבת במרחב העירוני. נפגוש כמה מציורי הגרפיטי של מיטב אמני הרחוב הפעילים בעיר. הסיור כולל הצצה לסטודיו של אחד מאמני הרחוב ותצפית פנורמית לא שגרתית מהגג. מטרת הסיור היא לחוות הכרות עם סביבה לא מוכרת ומלאת השראה, להתבונן בה בעיניים חדשות ולנסות להבין את חוויית השוטטות.

פרטים נוספים על הסיור ברשימה בבלוג המשוטטת eli7notes.com

http://elishevanotes.com/?p=67463

longdescription:
הליכה בעקבות עולמה התרבותי של קהילת מבקשי המקלט בישראל, עולם המורכב מהתנגשויות בין תרבות מסורתית למערבית וישראלית, במקום שמהווה תחנת ביניים בחיים לקבוצה  גדולה של אנשים.

נצעד אל איזורי הבילוי בתחנה מרכזית חדשה, נכיר את חיי הרחוב במדרחוב נווה שאנן ואת החיים במרקם מורכב של איזור  התחנה הישנה. בדרך נפגוש פעילים, אמנים ויוצרים מהקהילה. נסיים  בהקרנת הסרט הקבועה של מוצאי שבת בספריית גן לוינסקי

title: שכונת הקצה של לב העיר
shortdescription:
במתחם שבין הרחובות יהודה הלוי ומנחם בגין, וילסון והרכבת, על קו התפר שבין שדרות רוטשילד ואזור התחנה המרכזית בדרום תל אביב, דקה אחת מנתיבי איילון, נוצר עם השנים מרקם  ייחודי, עדין, המשלב ניגודים של דת וחילוניות, עושר ועוני, חיבור של עסקים ומגורים, תהילה ואנונימיות.
במהלך הדרך נעבור בין מבנים לשימור ועצים ותיקים, נערוך היכרות עם השכונה ונדון בשאלות של זהות מקומית, התחדשות מול שימור ויצירת קהילה בלב המע"ר של ת"א.
longdescription:
במתחם שבין הרחובות יהודה הלוי ומנחם בגין, וילסון והרכבת, על קו התפר שבין שדרות רוטשילד ואזור התחנה המרכזית בדרום תל אביב, דקה אחת מנתיבי איילון, נוצר עם השנים מרקם  ייחודי, עדין, המשלב ניגודים של דת וחילוניות, עושר ועוני, חיבור של עסקים ומגורים, תהילה ואנונימיות ועוד. באזור זה ישנם  מבנים רבים שהוכרזו כראויים לשימור ואוסף נדיר של עצים ותיקים.  דווקא  תהליך השימור לעתים  מוחק  מרקמי חיים  שנוצרו לאורך השנים . אנו שואפים להכיר, לסמן ולשמר את המאפיינים הללו.

תנופת ההתחדשות העירונית עדיין לא חצתה את שדרות רוטשילד ולא הגיעה לכאן ועל כן ניתן, עדיין, לחשוב מחדש ולבסס שימור היודע לא רק לדייק חומרי טיח  לציפוי הבניינים  אלא מותיר  ומשמר  את הייחוד  של  החצרות  והרחובות וחיי היום יום  שביניהם. לצד  סיור ההכרות עם השכונה אנו נקיים דיון שיעסוק בשאלות בנושאים של זהות מקומית, התחדשות מול שימור ויצירת קהילה בלב המע"ר של ת"א.

title: אתגרים והזדמנויות בשכונת שפירא
shortdescription: שכונת שפירא מאופיינת במפגש בין תרבויות מהגרים שונות מאז הקמתה לפני תשעים השנים האחרונות. לעיתים המפגש הבין תרבותי הוליד חברויות ויצירה משותפת, לפעמים התנגשות בלתי נמנעת, הקמת בתי כנסת מתחרים ויריבויות. בסיור נבקר במקומות שהולידו המפגשים הללו, ונחשוב מה יצר ויוצר המפגש בין התרבויות בעבר והיום.
longdescription: שכונת שפירא מאופיינת במפגש בין תרבויות מהגרים שונות מאז הקמתה לפני תשעים השנים האחרונות. לעיתים המפגש הבין תרבותי הוליד חברויות ויצירה משותפת, לפעמים התנגשות בלתי נמנעת, הקמת בתי כנסת מתחרים ויריבויות. בסיור נבקר במקומות שהולידו המפגשים הללו, ונחשוב מה יצר ויוצר המפגש בין התרבויות בעבר והיום.

title: From Suburban to Urban: 30 years of change along Sheppard West
shortdescription: Let's talk about how Jane Jacobs' ideals of walkability and mixed-uses are changing the suburbs!
longdescription:
Can better planning lead to walkable streets in the  suburbs? This walk is all about exploring that question.

Sheppard Avenue between Allen Road and Bathurst Street has gone through a remarkable transformation since the early 1990s. Plans influenced by Jane Jacobs' ideal of vibrant streets, have guided most of the streets redevelopment. Is it working? The only way to come out is to take a walk.

Learn about 30 years of city planning. Find out about what jargon such as "mixed-use mid-rise urbanism", "secondary planning areas", and "reurbanization" mean for streets like Sheppard West.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Allen Road and Sheppard Avenue West

team.bio:
Eric Sehr is a graduate from the School of Urban Planning at McGill University. He spends lots of timing thinking and reading about planning in neighbourhoods built in second half of the 20th century.   He currently works for the City of Toronto, but this walk is about his personal interests, not his professional. 
You can follow his blog at http://ericvery.wordpress.com

accessible-find: In front of Downsview station on the south side of Sheppard Avenue West.

title: ‘Tales from the campus’ led by Kate Dunton
longdescription: This short, lunchtime walk around the University of Essex campus will incorporate stories, urban myths and oral narratives to explore the coming of the university to Wivenhoe Park, including the sale of the land by the Gooch family, the envisioning of the new university by the first VC, Albert Sloman, the responses of the locals to their new neighbours, and the student protests of the late 60s and early 70s.

Note: the walk is actually 45 minutes long to fit comfortably into lunch breaks (an extended version of this walk is being given on Mon 6th, see below).

What’s your Castle Park?

title: Walking War and Peace for 1812:  Dundas Street for York and Roncesvalles for Spain
shortdescription: The theme of this year’s walk was chosen to coincide with the anniversary of the War of 1812 (1812-1814). We will start on the future site of what we hope to be a Peace Garden to commemorate the history of battles fought and peace that followed.
longdescription:
This year’s theme is focussed on the impact of the North American War of 1812 on the area. It also examines the Napoleonic War, in particular the encounters between the British and Spanish forces. Both these wars left their imprint on the area in surprising ways: from the way the streets are shaped, to what they are called.

 

This walk is connected to the Parkdale Historic Society's Queen Street Walk  entitled The Architectural Legacy of the Village of Parkdale 1879-1889 which follows after a short break.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: the intersection of Roncesvalles and Dundas Streets

team.bio: The Roncesvalles Village Historic Society has been researching local history since it was formed in 2009. For more information please visit us on Facebook, or come to our monthly meeting at the High Park library. We are a group of amateur historians with a passion for the history of the Roncesvalles neighbourhood. We are thrilled to be participating in a Jane’s walk for our 3rd year.

title: Brampton, Downtown - 2013 Culture & History
shortdescription: Downtown Brampton has many Historical features that intertwine with modern society. New to the city! Learn our language, see the sites, modern & old. Even some hauntings will be told. 2 hours of fun.
longdescription:
The tour starts at the front steps of  Brampton City Hall. We will do a loop and finish there.

Visit and tour  all the features of Gage park.  Check out the old Etobicoke Creek route and see walled remains of the old channel.

Visit the old courthouse and jail at Wellington & Main.  Find out when it was built, who died there and who haunts it. Travel around the back of Main St and find out who used to reside in some of these buildings.  Next to Chapel and Queen St to one of Brampton's oldest historic corners. What's the Dominion building? Why is Rose Square there and is buried treasure hidden in the area? Why is Main St crooked ? Am I on Main St or Hurontario St? What is so Heritage about Heritage Theatre? If you are new to Brampton either from another city or town or from another country this tour gives the quick & simple facts of the city.  When you have visitors, use this tour to take your fiends and relatives for a walk, show them something different.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Brampton City Hall, Front steps

team.bio: Steve Collie is a member of the Brampton Heritage Board, and the Brampton Historical Society. A member of Heritage Toronto and its walking tours for 17 years. 20 years at Fort York. In the last 7 years a paranormal researcher and ghost tour guide with tours in Brampton and the Exhibition grounds Toronto.

title: והיא הייתה לי מדינה אחרת
shortdescription: סיור לילי בשכונת נווה שאנן להיכרות עם השכונה ושיחה על סוגיות חברתיות, תכנוניות ואדריכליות במזרח העיר
longdescription:
בתל אביב מתענגים על הישן, משמרים אותו ומכירים בערכיו.  אולם, בצידה המזרחי של העיר  קיימים עדיין אזורים נסתרים כמו שכונת נווה שאנן הזקוקים לשימור האוצרות המתפוררים שמסתתרים בהם, רגע לפני שייהרסו סופית.  גורלה של שכונה מזרחית זו, שהוקמה ב-1922 כתוצאה ממצוקת הדיור ששררה ביפו,  נחרץ מספר שנים מיום הקמתה עם שרטוטה של תוכנית גדס שציירה קו ברור בין "חדש" ו"ישן", והכניסה ללקסיקון העברי שני מונחים חדשים: "צפוני" ו"דרומי".

.נווה שאנן הוזנחה. בסוף שנות ה-80 החלו להיאסף בה מהגרי עבודה, שעד היום מצטופפים בדירות הקטנות,

זירה של זנות ופשע הפכה לשמה הנרדף. כיום מתגוררים כאן כ-20 אלף איש ובסופי שבוע נמצאים כאן 60 אלף תושבים או מבקשי מקלט. על רקע  יוקר המחיה במרכז תל אביב, השכונה הפכה לאחרונה לאופציה נדל"נית קוסמת למשקיעים: מחירי . הדירות עלו משמעותית בשנה האחרונה, ואין זה פלא בהתחשב במרחק הקצרצר בינה לבין לב העיר הגדולה. אנחנו מזמינים אתכם להליכה מרתקת להיכרות עם השכונה ושיחה על העבר, ההווה והעתיד של השכונה.

title: לאורך הים - כיצד פוגשת תל אביב את הים התיכון
shortdescription: בסיור לאורך הטיילת בין מלון הילטון למלון דן, נשוחח על האופן בו פוגשת העיר את החוף. בסיור נשאל כיצד עובדים הרחובות,  הגינות, הכיכרות, בתי המגורים, המסחר ובתי המלון. נעבור דרך חוף הילטון, בית העלמין הערבי, שכונת מחלול עליה הוקם פרויקט כיכר אתרים, חוף ובריכת גורדון, שגרירות ארצות הברית, אנדרטת ההעפלה, גן לונדון ומלון דן. הסיור יתמקד בהיבטים תכנוניים, אדריכליים, היסטוריים, חברתיים וכלכליים המרכיבים את חיי המקום ויציע למשתתפים דרך להתבוננות חדשה על מפגש העיר והחוף.
longdescription: עד לשנות השבעים הפנתה תל אביב את הגב לים, שתפקד בעיקר כבריכת ניקוז ביוב עירונית וכמוקד זנות ומין. אך דברים השתנו. תל אביב היא לא רק עיר חוף אלא גם עיר עולם הנמצאת בגלעין המטרופולין. בסיור לאורך הטיילת בין מלון הילטון למלון דן, נשוחח על האופן בו פוגשת העיר את החוף. בסיור נשאל כיצד עובדים הרחובות,  הגינות, הכיכרות, בתי המגורים, המסחר ובתי המלון. נעבור דרך חוף הילטון, בית העלמין הערבי, שכונת מחלול עליה הוקם פרויקט כיכר אתרים, חו ובריכת גורדון, שגרירות ארצות הברית, אנדרטת ההעפלה, גן לונדון ומלון דן. הסיור יתמקד בהיבטים תכנוניים, אדריכליים, היסטוריים, חברתיים וכלכליים המרכיבים את חיי המקום ויציע למשתתפים דרך להתבוננות חדשה על מפגש העיר והחוף.

מיכאל יעקובסון הוא אדריכל, כתב אדריכלות באתר אקסנט וכותב הבלוג חלון אחורי

title: שיטוט בפלורנטין
shortdescription: שיטוט בסמטאות במערב שכונת פלורנטין במהלכו נגלה ציורי גרפיטי של מיטב אמני הגרפיטי בעיר. במהלך הדרך נשאל מהו סוד הקסם של שיטוט בכלל ובסביבת שוליים בפרט? אילו חוויות מעניק הרחוב למשוטטים בו? על מה אנו מתבוננים כשאנו הולכים ברגל ומה אנו מגלים?
longdescription:
רחובות מערב שכונת פלורנטין נראים כגלריית רחוב – קירות הסימטאות הצרות והציוריות מכוסים בציורי גרפיטי רבי סגנונות שהפכו חלק בלתי נפרד מהנוף. בסביבה תעשייתית צפופה זו פועלים בתי מלאכה ונגריות, והיא מאוימת ע"י רבי קומות שצומחים מכל צדדיה.

מהו סוד הקסם של שיטוט בכלל ובסביבת שוליים בפרט? אילו חוויות מעניק הרחוב למשוטטים בו? על מה אנו מתבוננים כשאנו הולכים ברגל ומה אנו מגלים?

בדרך נפגוש את מיטב יצירותיהם של אמני הרחוב הפעילים בעיר ונכיר את סגנונם האישי. נשוחח על המשמעות שהרחוב מעניק ליצירותיהם ונראה איך הם בוחרים "לוקיישן", איך ציוריהם יוצרים קולאג' ומשתלבים בסביבה הבנויה ונשאל מדוע הם בוחרים לעבוד במרחב הציבורי.

הסיור כולל מיפגש עם אורי בן צבי, מעצב ונגר - אמן בסטודיו שלו – הוא יספר איך השוטטויות שלו מניבות רהיטים מעוצבים.

title: The Architectural Legacy of The Village of Parkdale 1879 – 1889
shortdescription: Come with us on a trip down old Queen Street, to a time when life was slower, and less frantic
longdescription:
Jack Gibney, of The Parkdale Village Historical Society and Meghan Edmonds, of the Roncesvalles Village Historical Society invite you on a trip down old Queen Street, to a time when life was slower, and less frantic. We will see examples of beautiful historic architecture, some in need of care, and hear a tale of murder in 1894 on Jameson Ave. Learn the unusual origins of street names such as Tyndal, Spencer,  as well as  landowners O’Hara and Brock . Discover why Parkdale is one of the most historic and architecturally beautiful neighbourhoods of Toronto. 

 

This walk is intended to be a companion piece to  "Walking War and Peace for 1812:  Dundas Street for York and Roncesvalles for Spain"after a brief break  for a meal, but it also can be done on its own.

markers.title: Meeting Place

team.bio:
Jack Gibney is looking for volunteers to build the Parkdale Village History Society. He is a local history buff and has a keen interest in preserving our heritage buildings. Meghan is Co-Chair of the RVHS (Roncesvalles Village Historic Society), and revealer of the murder in Parkdale.
 
 
Contact: Jack Gibney: 416 837 2835

title: The Mighty Oaks of the Beach
shortdescription: The Beach neighbourhood is home to some of the oldest and largest trees in the city. Join us on an exploration of the area's historic oak forest canopy. The walk will highlight examples of how to protect these valuable assets from the pressures of development, including a house built on stilts to preserve the roots of four giant oaks and restoration efforts in the picturesque Glen Stewart Ravine.
longdescription: The Beach neighbourhood is home to some of the oldest and largest trees in the city. Join, Todd Irvine, arborist and co-creator of The Toronto Tree Tours, and local Councillor, Mary-Margaret McMahon on an exploration of the area's historic oak forest canopy. The walk will highlight examples of how to protect these valuable assets from the pressures of development, including a house built on stilts to preserve the roots of four giant oaks and restoration efforts in the picturesque Glen Stewart Ravine.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Northwest corner of Queen Street and Glen Manor Drive

team.bio: Todd Irvine is a consulting arborist specilizing in the protection of mature trees during development. He is a founding editor of Spacing magazine and co-creator of the Toronto Tree Tours. Mary-Margaret McMahon is the City Councillor for Ward 32 and a long-time resident of the Beach. She is the Vice Chair of the Toronto Parks and Environment Committee and a strong advocate for the urban forest.

accessible-parking: Limited on-street meter parking

title: Urban Wilderness Walk
shortdescription: Discover the birds and gardens in and around Birkdale Park!
longdescription: Come learn about the urban wilderness!  There will be a one hour talk in the Birkdale Community Centre at 12 noon, followed by a 1.5 hour guided walk.  There will be a short reception after the walk where we can continue the conversation.  This walk will follow a paved and grassy trail in and around Birkdale Park.  Hosted by the Midland Park Community Association, this walk will be lead by the Toronto and Region Conservation Authority (TRCA) and Birds Unlimited.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Birkdale Community Centre (1299 Ellesmere Rd.)

team.name-first: Toronto and Region Conservation Authority (TRCA) and Birds Unlimited
team.bio: GREG JOHNSTON (TRCA):Greg Johnston is the Highland / Don Watershed Assistant for the Toronto and Region Conservation Authority (TRCA). Greg has been an Education Guide at Black Creek Pioneer Village for nearly a year, and has working as a teacher within the Toronto District School Board. He has a background in education and Canadian history. Prior to working for the TRCA, Greg taught overseas in the United Kingdom. He lives in Scarborough and enjoys mountain biking, golfing, and lacrosse whenever he gets the chance.LYNDA & JIM MACKIEWICZ (WILDBIRDS UNLIMITED): Jim and his wife Lynda own the Wild Birds Unlimited Nature Shop in Toronto. Jim and Lynda have almost 25 years of learning and practical hands on experience on how to attract and feed birds in their backyard, and 12 years of experience in helping members of the local community enjoy the fun hobby of backyard birdwatching.Jim was a featured speaker at the 2011 POND (Places of Natural Discovery) Conference held at Humber College to help educators understand how bird watching/feeding can help children learn about their environment and wildlife. Over the past ten years Jim has appeared on local TV shows such as CTV National News, Breakfast Television, City Line, and Canadian Living TV. Jim has also written numerous birding articles for Ontario Gardening, and has contributed to articles in the Toronto Star, Metro daily papers, and BirdTracks.

title: Habitat Forum '76 Site - Urban Archaeology Tour at Jericho Beach
shortdescription: Join writer Lindsay Brown--who attended and volunteered at Habitat 76 as a child--for a semi-archaeological tour of traces of Habitat Forum.
longdescription:
It's a little known fact that in 1976 people came to Vancouver from nearly every country in the world to discuss problems faced by the world's growing cities. As participants in what was the largest UN conference that had ever been held, Mother Teresa, Margaret Mead, Maggie & Pierre Trudeau, Buckminster Fuller, Paolo Soleri and many other thinkers, leaders, urbanists and architects all gathered at Jericho Beach to discuss what we now call urban sustainability.

They met in five World War I and II seaplane hangars formerly known as the Jericho Beach Flying Boat Station. Beautifully restored especially for Habitat, the art deco military hangars were nevertheless destroyed soon after the event was over.

Join writer Lindsay Brown--who attended and volunteered at Habitat 76 as a child--for a semi-archaeological tour of traces of Habitat Forum. The tour is accompanied by a variety of as-yet-unpublished visuals. After the tour, feel free to stay on and chat with us in the Sailing Centre cafe, where you can buy lunch if you choose. Were you at Habitat? Bring your mementos and photos!

http://habitat76.ca

markers.title: Meeting Place

team.bio: Lindsay Brown is a Vancouver designer and writer currently writing a book on Habitat 76.  She is also involved, from time to time, in civic troublemaking regarding development and property speculation.

title: ‘Colchester through the lens of old postcards’
longdescription:
A trail of notable Colchester buildings and their stories, then and now, told through postcards from the past 100 years, led by local historian Jess Jephcott. This walk cut its teeth in bitter wind and rain at Jane’s Walk 2012. Even then, it was one of the most talked about...

The walk is listed for 2 pm but please arrive at 1 pm for the Jane's Walk weekend launch and One-Idea-One-Minute event. For more information, see final page of timetable here: http://www.walkcolchester.org.uk/assets/j/w/jw_timetable_2013-v5.pdf

title: ‘Exploring Colchester’s Urban Fringe’
longdescription:
A joint Ramblers and Jane’s Day walk with Colchester Ramblers, heading out from the town centre into the surprisingly natural fringes of the town, past Abbeygate, the Roman Circus, the Cemetery, Bourne Mill, Bourne Valley and Distillery Ponds, St Leonard's on Hythe Hill, the Moors and back into town. Time to take photographs, swap stories about the areas we walk through, do some geocaching: whoever comes, decides.

5.5 miles

title: ‘A Monday in Friday Woods’, with Colchester in Bloom.
longdescription: A walk organised by the Colchester in Bloom team, venturing off the beaten track and identifying some of the wild flowers in Friday Woods and led by Michael and Christine Lavelle who are both lecturers at Writtle College, Chelmsford. Friday Woods will abound with Wood Anemones and Bluebells, but we will visit and see the start of the abundance of the many other species in bloom during the summer months. All welcome.

team.bio:
Michael and Christine Lavelle are both lecturers at Writtle College in Chelmsford
Their horticultural achievments and quantity of books written are many. They include Michael winning prestigious gold medals in 1999, 2003 and 2005 at the RHS Chelsea Flower Show and Christine being awarded the Sir Joseph Hooker Prize by Sir David Attenborough and the Kew travel scholarship by Professor David Bellamy to study plant conservation in the Galápagos Islands. Together, they won the Garden Media Guild Practical Book of the Year Award in 2003 and 2008 for their books Organic Gardening and How to Create a Wildlife Garden.

title: Welche Farbe hat die Schöneberger Insel?
shortdescription: Ein psychogeografischer Spaziergang zum Thema "Die Farben der Stadt" über die Schöneberger Insel in Berlin.
longdescription:
Können Kieze Farben haben? Und wenn ja, wie materialisieren sie sich? Welche Farbe hat ein Kiez, wenn wir die visuellen Eindrücke außer Acht lassen und uns auf die gehörte, gerochene oder gefühlte Farbe konzentrieren? Lassen sich Stadträume farblich verstehen und folglich auch farblich darstellen? Welche Funktionen übernehmen Farben dann und wie wirken diese Farben, wenn wir die visuellen Eindrücke mit den empfundenen Farben in Relation setzen? Bekommen Farben an Gebäuden, die Farbe der Infrastrukturen und Verkehrsmittel, farbig beleuchtete Häuser und Plätze eine neue Bedeutung? Werden wir durch Farben beeinflusst?  Das Buch „Welche Farbe hat Berlin“ von David Wagner hat uns inspiriert unsere Stadtwahrnehmung auf die Frage nach der Farbigkeit der Stadt zu fokussieren.

Auf Spaziergängen, die wir zu diesem Thema unternommen haben, sind uns viele relevante Fragestellungen eingefallen, vor allem aber sind uns funktionelle Farben aufgefallen. So gibt es z.B. Unterschiede in der Farbwahrnehmung zwischen Tag und Nacht. Nachts z.B. werden durch farbige Beleuchtung Leerstände sichtbar, die tagsüber in den Immobilien zu verschwinden scheinen. Dynamische Beleuchtungen, die sich dem Tageslicht und dem Sicherheitsbedürfnis anpassen tauchen Plätze und Tunnel in farbiges Licht, das jenseits der Bewusstseinsgrenze in der Lage ist Emotionen zu steuern u.a.m.

Farben spielen also tatsächlich eine große Rolle, auch in der Stadtliteratur und künstlerischen Stadtforschung: Über das erwähnte Buch des Flaneurs David Wagners hinaus fragt das Stadtblind-Kollektiv nach „Die Farben Berlins“ und gibt Antwort in Form eines Farbkarten-Index Berliner Orte und Tina Saum unternahm im Köln synästhetische Stadtrundgänge, um einige wenige Beispiele zu nennen.

Im Rahmen des diesjährigen Jane`s Walk wollen wir einen Spaziergang anbieten, der sich innerhalb eines kleinräumlichen Areals mit dem Thema „Farben einer Stadt“ auseinandersetzt und ein erfahrungsbasiertes Format zur Entdeckung dieser anbietet. Exemplarisch soll die Schöneberger Insel im Berliner Süden begangen werden und einige Orte im öffentlichen Raum untersucht werden.

Mit Hilfe von Methoden, wie z.B. der psychogeographischen Stadtkartierung, können die Teilnehmenden ein künstlerisch-wissenschaftliches Format kennenlernen und im Kollektiv eine Antwort auf die gestellten Fragen formulieren. Die Teilnehmenden bekommen ein Flaneurs-Set zur Hand und bahnen sich eigenständig einen Weg innerhalb des vorher abgesteckten Gebietes. Wahrgenommene und an bestimmten Orten assoziierte Farben werden kartiert und über Notizen und /oder Stichpunkten auf Papier erweitert. Gleichzeitig werden die Farberlebnisse fotografisch festgehalten, wodurch ein Fotoalbum mit Farbimpressionen entsteht.

Abschlissend wollen wir den Verlauf des Spaziergangs und die Erfahrungen reflektieren und die Ergebnisse der individuellen Farb-Karten und Pläne in eine gemeinsame Karte übertragen. Hierüber entsteht ein Austausch der verschiedenen Eindrücke unter den Teilnehmenden. Die persönlichen Eindrücke können von anderen bestätigt werden oder es kommen neue „Farben“ und Vorstellungen hinzu. Man erhält Informationen über die erlaufenen Orte: Was dominiert, was wiederholt sich, was für überlagerungen gibt es, d.h. in welchem Farbfeld sind wir eigentlich unterwegs gewesen und woran macht sich das fest?

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Brückengeländer an der Julius-Leber-Brücke nahe der Eisdiele

team.name-first: Andrea Respondek und Karsten Michael Drohsel
team.bio: Andrea Respondek (Dipl.-Ing. der Landschaftsplanung) und Karsten Michael Drohsel (Cand.-Ing der Stadt- und Regionalplanung) haben gemeinsam das Label mikromakrowelt ins Leben gerufen. Wir beschäftigen uns schon geraume Zeit mit Fragen der Wahrnehmung von Landschaft und Stadt und haben mehrere wissenschaftliche Arbeiten zu diesen Themen verfasst. Gemeinsam versuchen wir für Belange der jeweiligen Planungsdisziplinen zu sensibilisieren und entwickeln Formate für eine synergetische wahrnehmungs- und erfahrungsbetonte Betrachtung. Unser Schwerpunkt liegt darauf, die unterschiedlichen Wahrnehmungsmuster und Deutungen von Räumen sichtbar zu machen und diese in einen Diskurs zu überführen. Hierbei spielen für uns gerade die unsichtbaren Phänomene (Akustik, Olfaktorik, Emotionen) von Orten, Räumen oder Städten eine wichtige Rolle.

accessible-info: Sollten besondere Anforderungen notwendig sein, bitte vorab eine kurze Mail an uns. Wir versuchen uns dann entsprechend einzurichten.

Wir werden mit einem Hinweisschild am Treffpunkt auf Euch warten. Der Spaziergang soll pünktlich beginnen, deshalb bitte auch pünktlich erscheinen.
Die Teilnahme erfolgt auf eigenes Risiko und ist kostenlos. Jedoch wäre es schön, wenn jede teilnehmende Person ein Spende für die Materialien geben könnte.  Am Ende des Spaziergangs ist eine Einkehr geplant, um das erlebte zu reflektieren.
Infos unter www.mikromakrowelt.de

title: Exploring the “Lively Experiment”: Religious Freedom and Providence’s Communities

title: Pedestrian Infrastructure & Issues: Bloor-Yorkville
shortdescription: What makes a place good for walking? Explore the existing pedestrian infrastructure and the issues it raises in the bustling Bloor-Yorkville district.
longdescription:
Sidewalks can give rise to an unexpected number of contentious issues, and it takes a lot of different elements to make a sidewalk that works.

Join Dylan Reid, former co-chair of the Toronto Pedestrian Committee and a co-founder of the new group Walk Toronto, and guest speakers for a look at the nitty-gritty of walking infrastructure and some of the political issues it provokes. We'll look at issues like street food vending, street furniture, intersection design, accessibility, the role of local businesses, graffiti and more. Our canvas will be Bloor-Yorkville, a busy pedestrian area where the sidewalks have recently been transformed and more improvements are planned.

Co-designed by Walk Toronto.

team.bio: Dylan Reid is a founder and senior editor at Spacing magazine. He was co-chair of the Toronto Pedestrian Committee from 2007-2010 and recently helped to start the new pedestrian advocacy group Walk Toronto.

title: The Roots of Mack Avenue
shortdescription: Participants of “The Roots of Mack Avenue” walk can expect to learn the about the past, present and FUTURE of the once bustling commercial corridor of Mack Avenue with the introduction of the Green Thoroughfare project.
longdescription:
"The Roots of Mack Avenue"

Participants of “The Roots of Mack Avenue” walk can expect to learn the about the past, present and FUTURE of the once bustling commercial corridor of Mack Avenue with the introduction of the Green Thoroughfare project.  In its heyday, this section of Mack Avenue was home to theaters, furniture stores, bakeries, & a host of other retail shops. Today less than ten businesses remain among the 111 parcels in this corridor. Along this walk of the past and present, we will discuss the future.

                                 

The Green Thoroughfare is a Lower Eastside Action Plan and Mack Avenue Business Association endorsed project that will convert the targeted Mack Avenue Corridor to a green, clean, safe and productive byway for a new generation of economic and community development.

The walk will conclude with food and music for its staff and participants. See you Saturday, May 4th

The walk is 2.1 miles. The map is below:

title: 'Secrets of New Town’
longdescription: It was a new adventure – to build a new town rivalling Colchester. It used new designs and new materials to create the housing and the factories for Colchester’s rising industrial classes. It was boasted to have everything a town should have from sewerage even to gas street lights. It was the birthplace of Colchester’s cooperative movement, and the home of England’s very own foreign legion – the German Legion. All this and more in The Secrets of New Town.

title: Exploring the Queen Anne Community
shortdescription: Come join this eclectic walk and explore the similarities and differences of Upper and Lower Queen Anne.
longdescription:
Meandering from Upper to Lower Queen Anne, this walk will feature an eclectic mixture of lively business districts, charming, tree-lined neighborhood streets, some of Seattle’s best architecture and parks with stunning views and multiple personalities.  In short, everything that makes Queen Anne so unique.  Along the way we’ll have a chance to observe and discuss such issues as: street front retail, neighborhood traffic calming, pedestrian safety, mixed-use development, the role of parks and whatever else you want to talk about.

 

This walk does include some stairs and hills (mostly going down).

team.name-first: Dave Ramsay, Board President of Feet First
team.bio:
David Ramsay is President of Feet First.
Why walkability matters to Dave:I think that being a walkable city is fundamental to being a good city.  Going for a walk is fun; but it goes way beyond that.  Walking is the “silver bullet” of public policy.  Better health, improved environment, reduced car traffic, connected communities, safer streets and healthy business districts all happen when people walk. What other strategy can accomplish all that? I want to help make a difference by getting more people walking more often; for business and pleasure.

title: West Seattle Triangle - Transforming the Urban Experience and Updating Junction Lifestyles and Mobility
shortdescription: Eyeing SmartGrowth - Embracing Change - Preserving Liveabilty.
longdescription:
The portal to West Seattle is getting a facelift. West Seattle Junction is changing fast. Apartments along Avalon Way are being connected to West Seattle Junction through the West Seattle Triangle. The old Huling Brother's car dealership is being torn down and filled in with apartments and commercial space. 
 
We'll visit five new large-scale building developments in The Old Junction and the new West Seattle Triangle. 
 
We'll reminisce and recollect the community character we value and prefer to see incorporated into the fast changing landscape.

team.name-first: Timothy Lowry, PE, LEED AP and Feet First Neighborhood Walking Ambassador
team.bio:
Timothy (PE, MBA, LEED™ AP) is a Neighborhood Walking Ambassador because moving around self-powered is key to sustainable communities and healthy living. Leading Stairway Walks is very empowering because neighbors experience access unavailable to cars. Access that is often more direct and usually quite whimsical and uplifting. 
Timothy is a sustainability expert, Professional Civil Engineer, and urban planner focusing on strategic sustainable development including transportation planning and watersheds planning.  Additional experience includes green building, solid waste management, flood plain management, rainwater harvesting, permeable pavement, and community engagement. He was also the Low Impact Development LID Coordinator for Pierce County, WA, fostering rural and suburban sustainable site design.
Timothy enjoys rollerblading and biking in West Seattle with his wife and two very energetic boys. He also run-commutes to downtown and leads West Seattle Ultimate Family Frisbee.

title: Love Behind the Bargain
shortdescription: Love Behind the Bargain is a performative walking tour that brings participants to various stops in Toronto’s downtown Chinatown. These stops are of significance for the artist/ tour guide Alvis Parsley as they lived, worked and socialized in the neighborhood to connect, survive and search for their identity during their 1.5 years in Toronto as a temporary resident, genderqueer person of color, who flew 7600 miles here for love.
longdescription:
Love Behind the Bargain is a performative walking tour that brings participants to various stops in Toronto’s downtown Chinatown. These stops are of significance for the artist/ tour guide Alvis Parsley as they lived, worked and socialized in the neighborhood to connect, survive and search for their identity during their 1.5 years in Toronto as a temporary resident, genderqueer person of color, who flew 7600 miles here for love.

Participants enter a world beyond the stereotypes of Chinatown. At each stop, Alvis Parsley tells site-specific stories illustrating their journey of freedom and love, and the rarely discussed side of Toronto’s Chinatown, a self-contained community that is home for numerous immigrants.

The piece exposes intimate stories that reflect the day-to-day happenings in Chinatown and touches on themes of racism, labor exploitation, sexuality and cultural stereotypes. Participants will experience the neighborhood from a micro-narrative perspective. Reality becomes a live cinema as the artist narrates to the surroundings.

Photo credit: Bonz Merlin

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Dragon City Mall (In front of the fountain/waterfalls) Address: 280 Spadina Ave  Toronto, ON M5T 3A5

team.bio:
Alvis Parsley is the founder of Fantasy is Reality Unlimited (FiRU). Previous projects include Coming Out for Dummies – Chinese Family Edition (2013), Falling in Love with Audre Lorde (2013), How To Do Gay in Canada – A Survival Kit for Chinese Lesbian Newcomers (2012), PWYC (2012), and Recycling Love (2011). Their performances and talks were presented at Whippersnapper Gallery (Toronto), MARKIT (Toronto), HTMlles10 (Montreal), Radical Queer Semaine (Montreal), Meow Mix (Montreal), and Blue Lotus Gallery (Hong Kong).
Alvis Parsley’s ongoing research focuses on identity issues relating to race and sexuality, safe space and open discourse, human rights, migration, survival. Their projects often explore the boundaries between day-to-day practices and performances, relating their personal experiences as a genderqueer person of color, while questioning the roles and responsibilities of institutions, authority, and the ecosystem of the arts.

title: #WiTOpoli: The Past and Present of Toronto Women's Activism and Engagement
shortdescription: A 4 km stroll through some of Toronto's most important moments in women's activism, great and small, early, recent--and happening today!  Join us and get engaged - we're half the city!
longdescription:
Want to tap into Toronto politics and the issues that affect Toronto women, not just historically, but today? Join us for a walk around the downtown core for a history of some of the landmark moments in Toronto feminism - and find out who's making history right before your eyes!

We'll visit the sites of political firsts, protests and institutions that have worked to improve equality for women - Toronto Police Headquarters, City Hall, the Courts, and the original Toronto Women's Bookstore - as well as the places where grassroots movements such as the original Toronto Women's Bookstore and Take Back the Block were born, while finding out about ways we can get involved in making our city a kinder and more equal place. 

Join us for a 4 km, 2-hour trip through a women's view of Toronto from Police Headquarters to Bellevue Square Park, and learn how you too can get involved!

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Toronto Police Headquarters, 51 Division, North side of College between Bay and Yonge

team.bio:
Women in Toronto Politics (@WiTOpoli) aims to generate ideas about how to include and engage more female voices in online and offline conversations about Toronto politics. In support of this goal, we advocate through social media, promote women writers, and host events to build active networks and foster skills development. Women in Toronto Politics believes that social media provide unique opportunities for women to become engaged in politics and political discussions and that political engagement is crucial to ending gender discrimination and inequality.
Join us in including and supporting more women's voices in Toronto politics (#TOpoli) - we're half the city! We're also on Facebook.
www.witopoli.com

title: High Park Labyrinth
shortdescription: The journey TO the labyrinth in the middle of the tress in the centre of the city. A hidden treasure that is a journey within a journey. Come walk we us and celebrate World Labyrinth Day.
longdescription: The journey TO the labyrinth is as interesting as the journey of the labyrinth itself. The High Park Labyrinth as been a jewel of the local landscape for many years. Nestled in the centre of the park in the middle of a grove of trees, it is not always easy to find or obvious unless you know it's there. This makes walking the labyrinth itself magical. It is hidden in the centre of a grove of trees in the centre of the city. Truly magical. Join me at the entrance to High Park and we will walk to the labyrinth to celebrate World Labyrinth Day.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Entrance to High Park, Bloor Street

accessible-transit: Entrance to High Park (the beginning of the walk) is located just south of High Park Su
accessible-parking: Yes, outside the park, inside the park.

title: In Our KGO Backyard
shortdescription: The Residents Rising Community Association in Kingston-Galloway/Orton Park (KGO) is proud to be organizing a Jane’s Walk this year.  Our walk, In Our KGO Backyard, will focus on some of the amenities and community projects that make KGO a special neighbourhood in Toronto.
longdescription:
Kingston-Galloway/Orton Park is a suburban neighbourhood in the southeast end of Toronto.  It is bounded by Scarborough Golf Club Rd on the west, Ellesmere Rd on the north, Manse Rd on the east, and Coronation Dr on the south.  This neighbourhood has a lot to offer its residents, businesses, employees and as well as those passing by/visiting.  There are many amenities and community projects that make this neighbourhood a special place.  This walk will uncover these gems that make KGO shine.  We will start at the East Scarborough Storefront (the Storefront), make a clockwise loop going from Lawrence Ave E to Kingston Rd and then to Galloway, Rd; we will end at the Point with some refreshments to wrap up the walk.  Please see list of sites below.

Meeting Location/Stop One: 4040 Lawrence Ave + 4000 Lawrence Ave E  - The Storefront, community garden, tower renewal project, mural of Jack Layton under bridge + salmon run.

Stop Two: St. Margaret's Church + Farmers’ Market (4130 Lawrence Ave E)

Stop Three: Morningside Mall + Shopping in the Area (southeast corner of Morningside Ave and Kingston Rd)

Stop Four: Original Location of Residents Rising (4403 Kingston Rd)

Stop Five: Sunrise Restaurant (4351 Kingston Rd)

Stop Six: Indoor market (4301 Kingston Rd)

Stop Seven: Native Child and Family Services of Toronto/Ghesig House (136 Galloway Rd)

Stop Eight: The Point (4117 Lawrence Ave East, Unit 100A)

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: East Scarborough Storefront (The Storefront), 4040 Lawrence Ave East

team.bio: Dianne Sahadeo is the walk leader.  She is a community member of KGO and is very active and involved in her community.  She is a member with Residents Rising Community Association, runs a children's and youth soccer program call KGO Kicks, and contributes to her community in many other ways.

accessible-transit: Take 54A Lawrence Ave East and get off at Overture Rd and walk east on Lawrence Ave E for 1 min and arrive at the Storefront on the north side of Lawrence Ave East
accessible-parking: You'll find parking at the meeting place and end location (more spots at this site).  They are 5-10 min apart on foot
accessible-find: You'll find Dianne at the meeting location with her name tag + organge flag.

title: Tap to Toilet 2013
shortdescription: Join City Councillor McMahon on Toronto's Eastern Beaches waterfront.
longdescription: Feel the sea-breeze on eastern Toronto’s waterfront. Walk from the RC Harris “Palace of Purification” (sorry, no tour inside the waterworks) to the Ashbridge’s Bay Sewage Treatment Plant, learning about Toronto's complicated relationship with its lake and visiting several Blue Flag Beaches for an existential moment with the water that sustains, hydrates, cleanses and atones us.
