title: Through the Photographer's Lens: A Snapshot of the Junction
shortdescription: Visit a selection of CONTACT Photography Festival venues, learn a bit of the area history at the local fire station and snap a few photographs of your own. Grab your camera and join us on a tour that will end at the Photography in the Junction's opening night reception.
longdescription:
This Jane's walk  will focus on photography and showcase locally relevant landmarks and participating venues in Photography in the Junction and the CONTACT Photography Festival. 

The walk will meet on the southwest corner of Keele & Dundas streets and begin with a tour of the Junction Fire Station no. 423’s historic photographs and memorabilia.  We will then explore a selection of the participating venues, where you will get the opportuntity to hear about the work in front of you firsthand from the  artists themselves! 

The tour will finish at the Opening Reception for Photography in the Junction at Pacific Ave. & Dundas, where the party will just be getting started.

Throughout the walk you can snap photographs of your own, which you can later submit to a monthlong Junction Photography Contest to win great Junction prizes (more information here). Come for an afternoon walk, and stay for an evening's worth of photography.

For further information please see our website!

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Keele and Dundas St. West, southwest corner

team.bio: For more information about the Junction BIA and Photography in the Junction, please see our website.

accessible-transit: Subway to Keele Station, take the 41 or 89 bus to Dundas
accessible-parking: Green P lot at Dundas and Medland and street parking

title: SOUNDwalk led by Darren Copeland (presented by New Adventures in Sound Art)
shortdescription: Join us for a lunch hour SOUNDwalk, exploring sound environs in the area of the Artscape Wychwood Barns. Participants should be sure to wear appropriate footwear and clothing for any weather condition.
longdescription:
What is a SOUNDwalk? In a soundwalk, the listening “audience” moves through a place and the environment “performs.” The walking listener and the environment create a unique piece together that can only occur during the time of the walk. In a soundwalk we take the time to hear the environment: we are its true ear witnesses. And like any musician, the environment offers us its sounds for our consideration.

For Jane's Walk 2013, we will be exploring the many sound environs surrounding the Artscape Wychwood Barns. Participants should be sure to wear appropriate footwear and clothing for any weather condition.  At the end of the walk, you are welcome to check out "where white pines lay," an audio/visual installation by Julie Nagam (@ the NAISA Space) that includes narrated Indigenous stories of place in the City of Toronto. It is a collection of voices and the knowledge of historians, archeologists, elders, various texts, the land, maps and archival documents and testimonies.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: 601 Christie Street #252, Artscape Wychwood Barns, Toronto, ON, M6G 4C7

team.bio:
Darren Copeland is a Canadian Sound Artist creating work for radio, performance, and installation with a focus on soundscape composition and multichannel spatialization. His concert and radio works have been commissioned and presented worldwide (ZKM, Kunstradio, Engine 27, La Muse en Circuit) and are published on the internationally recognized empreintes DIGITALes label.  He is the Artistic Director for New Adventures in Sound Art, the Toronto-based presenter of  Deep Wireless, Sound Travels, and SOUNDplay. Darren Copeland has created site-specific sound installations for Kitchener City Hall (Open Ears Festival), Metro Toronto Convention Centre (Interactive05 during Toronto Art Fair), and with Andreas Kahre, he co-created a permanent sound installation that uses 4 Audio Spotlights at the new Queen Elizabeth Pool in Edmonton.
New Adventures in Sound Art (NAISA) is a non-profit organization, based in Toronto, that produces performances and installations spanning the entire spectrum of electroacoustic and experimental sound art. Included in its productions are: Deep Wireless, Sound Travels, Arts Birthday and SOUNDplay. The objectives of NAISA are to foster awareness and understanding locally, as well as nationally and internationally, in the cultural vitality of experimental sound art in its myriad forms of expression. This objective will be achieved through the exploration of new sound technologies in conjunction with the creation of cultural events and artifacts.

accessible-transit: Take subway to St Clair W. station; walk west (or take St. Clair streetcar) to Wychwood; walk south on Wychwood one block to the Artscape Wychwood Barns; go to 2nd floor (#252) to meet.
accessible-parking: Available on Wychwood or Christie
accessible-find: Darren Copeland will be carrying a sign that reads:  Sound Travels, are you listening?  SOUNDwalk

title: Sudbury Jane's Walk / History Hike
shortdescription: The Rainbow ROUTES Association (RRA) Hike Club will walk the McNaughton Subdivision and Downtown Sudbury in this Jane's walk based on the the RRA History Hikes. Come join us!
longdescription:
The Jane's Walk in Sudbury will be lead by the the Rainbow ROUTES Association Hike Club.

When: Saturday, May 4, 2013 - meet at 9:45am to sign waivers.
Where: McNaughton Subdivision and Downtown (click for details and route). We will be leaving from the Sudbury Rowing Club parking lot at 506 Elizabeth Street.
Length: Approximately 2 hours

For details visit www.RainbowROUTES.com

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Sudbury Rowing Club parking lot at 506 Elizabeth Street

team.bio:
The Rainbow ROUTES Association (RRA) Hike Club was formed to provide an opportunity for people to explore local routes in a safe, friendly environment.  Hikes are generally two hours long and range in difficulty from easy to challenging.  Each month a new trail is selected in order to provide a sampling of the trails in the City.  Hikes run on the first Saturday of each month between October and June from 10am to noon.
The Walk Leader for this Jane's Walk will be Stan Koren. 
Prior to each two hour free hike with the RRA Hike Club, Stan hikes the route on his own to identify unique features to highlight. He’s been known to share stories about Sudbury’s unique history and facts about rocks, trees and wildlife in the area. He is a certified hike leader (by Hike Ontario), who truly loves walking and being outdoors.
In the five seasons since the RRA Hike Club was formed it has grown in popularity, bringing hikers of all ages and abilities to discover some of the hidden gems in our city of lakes. In the 2011 – 2012 seasons, Stan guided the “Hike Club-ers” as they walked a total 2250km.
After he helped launch the Hike Club, Stan joined the Rainbow ROUTES Association board of directors in 2009. In addition to his role as the Hike Club leader, Stan participates on the Trans Canada Trail committee for RRA and helps to identify routes that could be developed into formalized trails.
Stan’s interest in the outdoors was sparked by his involvement with the Land Reclamation Program in 1979 – 1980, where he found seeing the transformation from black rock to green vegetation fascinating.

accessible-transit: Bus routes 181, 182 & 500 - stop near John St. at Paris St.
accessible-parking: Parking available at 506 Elizabeth Street

title: Hillcrest/Mariday Park: Take a walk between a rock and hard place!
shortdescription:
Did you know....
·       There are famous rocks in Hillcrest Park that show evidence for a meteorite impact 1000km away?
·        There is a house in Mariday Park with a secret room that could be sealed off during prohibition?
·       That your neighborhood is full of interesting people doing amazing things?
·       That there are plans to improve our neighborhood for all to enjoy?

Come out Saturday May 4th at 10am and join your friends and Neighbors as we walk through the neighborhood, visit some interesting local treasures and get to know each other.
longdescription:
Did you know....

  • There are famous rocks in Hillcrest Park that show evidence for a meteorite impact 1000km away?
  •  There is a house in Mariday Park with a secret room that could be sealed off during prohibition?
  • That your neighborhood is full of interesting people doing amazing things?
  • That there are plans to improve our neighborhood for all to enjoy?

Come out Saturday May 4th at 10am and join your friends and Neighbors as we walk through the neighborhood, visit some interesting local treasures and get to know each other.

title: Recorregut Jane Jacobs - Recorrido Jane Jacobs

As every year, we propose a walk in a neighborhood of Barcelona, This year we will walk in the neighborhood of Poble Secw with neighborhood organizationRepensar el Poble Sec and with all people who wants to join us. The meeting point is the entrance of metro Paral·lel at Plaça Bella Dorita (it is the square in front El Molino) on Sunday May 5th at 11:30 am. This invitation is open to all people interested in learning, sharing, listening and looking at our urban environment through the the view of Jane Jacobs.

Com cada any proposem un recorregut per un barri de Barcelona. Aquest any caminarem pel barri del Poble Sec juntament amb l'associació Repensar el Poble Sec i amb totes aquelles persones que s'hi vulguin sumar. El punt d'inici és a la sortida del metro de Paral·lel a la plaça Bella Dorita (és la plaça de El Molino) el diumenge 5 de maig del 2013 a les 11:30 del matí. Aquesta convocatòria està oberta a totes les persones que els interessi aprendre, compartir, escoltar i mirar el nostre entorn urbà a través de la mirada de Jane Jacobs.

title: Landmarks Along The Water
shortdescription: Music, singing, and even a bit of dancing characterize this fun and interactive Jane's Walk led by the participants of CORE (Centre for Opportunities, Respect, and Empowerment)! Come let loose and celebrate spring along the lakeshore with us!
longdescription: Let loose on this interactive walk which explores landmarks along the water, guided by the participants of CORE.  We'll begin and end at our home base in Parkdale, and head down to the lake to discuss topics including entertainment, sports, history, and environmental issues from the participants' unique points of view.  In true CORE style, there will be lots of music, singing, and even a bit of dancing!  Come learn about your city and get to know the people in your community better.  We hope to see you there!

longdescription: What was it like to shop in Sunnyside prior to the existence of the chain grocery stores? We will take a walk along the "main street" to discover what stores served the hungry residents of this older community.

title: Broadway Modern
longdescription:
Broadway between Main Street and Osborne Street has long been an address of prestige, book-ended by two dominant, significant works of architecture – Union Station to the east and the Manitoba Legislative Building to the west. The early history of the avenue was as a desirable residential neighborhood, with little commercial activity. A building boom in the late 1950s to early 1970s, however, was responsible for the development of the Broadway as we know it.

This tour will focus on the post-1945 development of the area as a premier business district and the collection of modernist architecture designed by some of Winnipeg’s most notable firms.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Broadway and Main, in front of the Manitoba Club

team.bio: Susan Algie is Executive Director of the Winnipeg Architecture Foundation. She has a keen love of Winnipeg architecture, particularly the city's wonderful collection of modernist buildings and landscapes.

accessible-info: The meeting point is served by public transit and bicycle routes. The route is flat and accessible to wheelchairs and strollers.
accessible-parking: There is on-street parking available.

title: Village Urbanism: Explorations in North Point Douglas
longdescription:
Point Douglas is one of Winnipeg’s oldest and well-known placenames, and yet the neighbourhood itself -- hidden away from the rest of the city by the Red River, CP railway, Disraeli bridges, and Main Street -- remains an enigma to many citizens.


This walk will explore North Point Douglas, and look at its many layers of historical development, transitions, and complexity over time. This neighbourhood continues to evolve today.

The walk will look at the history and current state of places like the oldest industrial building in the city, which played a critical role in the 1919 General Strike; a quiet riverside park that is home to a new community oven; a small Euclid Avenue storefront that has operated as a thriving butcher shop for more than a century; and 19th century houses that line the narrow, tree-lined streets.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: In front of 140 Meade St. N.

team.bio: Robert Galston has lived on Hallet Street in North Point Douglas for more than seven years. His writings on city planning, Winnipeg history, and urbanism have appeared in the Winnipeg Free Press, Spacing, and the Spectator Tribune.

accessible-info: Cycling: bike-lock structure available nearby
accessible-transit: Transit: the 45 Kildonan Place bus operates on Euclid Avenue, as well as numerous busy routes that stop at Main and Jarvis (less than five minutes away).
accessible-parking: Parking is available on Meade and other nearby streets.

title: Detroit's Cass Corridor
shortdescription: One of Detroit's oldest neighborhoods and one of its fastest growing
longdescription: The Cass Corridor Museum and Preservation Detroit are sponsoring a walk in the Cass Corridor on Sunday, May5, 2013, from noon until 2 PM. We will meet at the museum site, 4470 Second Street between Prentis and Canfield.There will be a tour guide, but there will also be self directed tours available. At the midpoint, Preservation Detroit will hold their Victorian building open for those who want to see the interior of this beautifully restored house. The circuit will include all aspects of the incredible history of this wonderful neighborhood.

title: Victoria Park: invisible memories & lost meaning
longdescription:
The story of Victoria Park in Winnipeg is integral to the story and history of the Winnipeg General Strike of 1919. The story of the Strike and the Park, are not well known to most Winnipeg citizens. Although it is unknown or misinterpreted and misunderstood many believe that the Winnipeg General Strike is the most significant event in our city’s unique history. The events of the Strike took place on the streets you and I travel every day. The site where the Strikers and their leaders rallied was a small 1.6 acre park in the east Exchange between Pacific and James Streets.


Topics:

1. Winnipeg circa 1900: Immigration, rapid growth, poverty, North End slum conditions,
2. Description of Victoria Park: Size, location, year built, who used the park
2. Origins of the Strike and lead up events : WW II, poor working conditions and labor practices, inequalities, international influence
3 Strike time-line, major players and politics
4. Outcomes and long term legacy
5. Destruction of Victoria Park

6. Friends of Victoria Park, importance of history, lobby for an interpretive heritage park, rezoning of the river bank for commercial development

Themes: social justice, human rights, social reform, Winnipeg history, civic pride, educational and tourism value.

markers.title: Meeting Place

title: Riverview: Beer, Bears, Boxing and a Roller Coaster Ride through Time
longdescription:
Source: http://www.winnipeglovehate.com     All rights reserved by bryanscott

 Riverview is the true centre of Winnipeg and the Capital of Fort Rouge. Walk through the last 100 plus years of interesting characters and places that have made this neighbourhood a classic Jane’s place. From its early days as a transportation hub to becoming Winnipeg’s premier entertainment destination, Riverview has a unique story. Join, lifelong Rouger and urbanist, Jino Distasio on a walk that highlights his 40 plus years of living the South Osborne dream!

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Banana Boat, Osborne Street

team.bio: Jino Distasio is a lifelong Riverview resident who would be prepared to run for Mayor of Fort Rouge should that become an option. His day job is teaching and researching urban issues at the University of Winnipeg's Institute of Urban Studies. For over 15 years, he has taught courses on urban development and city planning issues. A key area of interest includes looking at what makes neighbourhoods like Riverview great!

accessible-info: Located on major bus routes with street parking nearby. Flat walk on main sidewalks only.

title: The Edge Condition: Main Street between the Disraeli and Neechi Commons
longdescription: The edge condition, centered on the underpass between the North and the South end of Winnipeg will be traced between the Disraeli Freeway and the newly opened Neechi Commons. We will meet some of the people who have personally invested in Main Street, look at the different uses of the street over time and critically observe the nature of transition in this area.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Southwest corner of Alexander and Main

team.bio: Wins Bridgman is an architect, heritage architect, artist and community advocate who along with fellow Director Marcella Poirier lead BridgmanCollaborative Architecture at Higgins and Main.  We are the architects for Neechi Commons, Barber House, Eagle wing Day Care, Manitoba Indigenous Cultural Education Centre, Build, the (old) Dominion Bank in the area of this Jane's walk and planners for the William Whyte Neighbourhood Housing Plan and the Dufferin  Neighbourhood Housing Plan. Perhaps the most important thing we have done is to, for a short time, locate public toilets at Higgins and Main in an effort to afford the dignity of a toilet within the safety of a monitored environment.

accessible-info: The route is wheelchair accessible.
accessible-parking: Free parking is available behind 678 Main Street (BridgmanCollaborative Architecture) or for a fee in adjacent parking areas.

title: Gage Park, the Jewel of the East
shortdescription: A glorious past, a devastating decline and a grand master plan for revival...
longdescription: A glorious past, a devastating decline and a grand master plan for revival... but as a true centenarian... what can you expect? From grand beginnings Gage Park has had its share of waxing and waning celebrity status. Owned first by a lawyer; as a garden and orchard, the land was sold to the city in 1918 for the princely sum of $390,000 (and you can bet there was grumbling at City Hall over that... in today's dollars that translates to mere $4 million). Things moved quickly after that and by 1920, the "father of landscape architecture," Howard Gubb and his wife Laurie Dunnington-Grubb were hired to design the park. In 1926 the fountain design was commissioned to Frank Lyle, architect of Toronto's Union Station and paid for through a generous donation by Eugenia Gage with the provision that the park retain the name of her parents. For decades the park shone and was the destination for thousands and thousands of people... a decade ago, it was covered in graffiti and deemed "unsafe". Now, we're pleased to report, the lustre is being revived and the people are retuning... and "the best kept secret in Hamilton", Gage Park, couldn't be happier to lose its "secret" status.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: The Tropical Greenhouse

team.bio: Born, raised, and educated in Hamilton's Ward 3 (he stepped outside the Ward for his B. Sc. and his MBA... all the way to MacMaster in Westdale), Bernie Morelli's impressive CV includes: Dofasco Senior Manager, MacMaster lecturer, School Trustee, and City Councillor, taking the seat in 1991 and being re-elected 6 times. What you learn from Bernie on this tour will astonish you... Bernie has the, let's just say, "good" stories about Gage Park and the surrounding area... and knew, personally, the characters and their antics that make this history interesting.

title: The Beach, the Bridge, and the Steam Museum
shortdescription: Due to the length of this route, this is a cycling tour. Sam's very own Crown Point... 5 kilometres of stories including the one about the impossible odds stacked against someone who just wanted to make the beach accessible... and, of course, its happy ending. See the Steam Museum (you know you've been meaning to get there!) and hear the story of the bridge. Whoosh down the boardwalk to... Hutches! For some of you, it will be  your introduction to Hamilton's Beach... for others, well, Hello Summer!
longdescription: We'll meet at the Lowe's hardware store at Barton/Woodward. Join Councillor Merulla as he rides through the north end of Crown Point along the Woodward bike lanes to the Museum of Steam & Technology for a tour, then over to the Red Hill Valley Trail and the new East Hamilton trail bridge which spans the QEW... yes, the bridge. Back in 2004, the Bridge was but a glint in Sam Merulla's eye and it only took 7 years of elbow grease and convincing to see it built. Talk about a long gestation... the bridge, you'll learn, is Sam's baby. After taking in the view from the bridge, we'll wrap-up at a Hamilton institution — Hutch's Restaurant, along the Lake Ontario Waterfront Trail. There'll be ample opportunity to continue along the Waterfront Trail, or head back. The route is about 5 km (one-way), 1 hour on a bike; including stops at the museum, bridge, and restaurant.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Lowe's hardware at Woodward and Barton

team.bio: Councillor Sam Merulla, Ward 4 East Hamilton, is Made in Hamilton and proud of it!

title: Give Me Liberty!
shortdescription:
A tour of Toronto's fastest developing areas...from the old buildings in West Liberty to the jam-packed condos and shops in East Liberty...
Broadcaster/performer Jaymz Bee will share his insights and entertain while you stroll through his neighbourhood.
longdescription:
Jaymz Bee has enjoyed decades of adventures in Liberty Village. His early memories in the 1980's included rehearsing with his band, Look People on Hannah, wild boozecans on Fraser and working for Nelvana Pictures when they were based on Atlantic. He has lived in the neighbourhood for the past decade and also works at JAZZ.FM91 which is located on Pardee Avenue.

Jaymz will give historical facts about the area as well as his own anecdotes and stories told to him  by  locals. The tour will include a look inside a few buildings that you normally wouldn't get to see.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: AROMA (technical address is 120 Lynn Williams St., but it is on Liberty St)

team.bio:
Jaymz Bee is an artist, entertainer, writer and broadcaster. He was author of the best-seller "Cocktail Parties for Dummies" in 1996, has recorded and produced dozens of albums for his own groups and others and is an on-air host at JAZZ.FM91, which is based in Liberty Village.
His jazz ensemble "Jaymz Bee & The Royal Jelly Orchestra" have put out seven albums and toured Canada several times and his latest pop project "Bonzai Suzuki" will release their second CD this summer.
 
Jaymz has lived in Liberty Village almost ten years and has enjoyed watching this "work in progress" since the eighties when it was barely inhabited right up till the present where Liberty East feels like the movie inception. Bee states: "By the time you order a cup of coffee - poof - another buildling just went up!"

accessible-info: Walking on sidewalks mostly but we do go in a few buildings with stairs.
accessible-transit: Take the Ossington Bus and ask to be let off at METRO (Liberty St. at Lynn Williams St.)
accessible-parking: Cheapest parking is at Liberty St. and Atlantic St.
accessible-find: We meet at AROMA which is on East Liberty. If you are hungry arrive early for a bite...Jaymz promises to be there by 11! You can't miss him - He'll be wearing a white and olive sear sucker suit making "nummy noises" while enjoying brekkie!

title: Northdale Revisited - A New Story for a Near-Campus Neighbourhood
shortdescription: Northdale was once a notorious near-campus neighbourhood that some called an unsightly student dominated ghetto. Find out how the city, residents and campus communities worked together to forge a new vision and future for Northdale. Learn where and how the new story of a vibrant, mixed-use and mixed demographic neighbourhood is already emerging, and what is yet to come. The next chapter in Northdale's history will transition it from an eyesore to a mixed-use and diverse demographic neighbourhoood, and from an embarrassment to something we can all be proud of.  Northdale is now a neighbourhood with a bright future.
longdescription: Northdale was once a notorious near-campus neighbourhood that some called an unsightly student dominated ghetto. Find out how the city, residents and campus communities worked together to forge a new vision and future for Northdale. Learn where and how the new story of a vibrant, mixed-use and mixed demographic neighbourhood is already emerging, and what is yet to come. The next chapter in Northdale's history will transition it from an eyesore to a mixed-use and diverse demographic neighbourhoood, and from an embarrassment to something we can all be proud of.  Northdale is now a neighbourhood with a bright future.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Veteran's Green (University Avenue and Hazel Street)

team.bio:
Jeff Henry is a City of Waterloo Councillor representing Ward 6, Central-Columbia, which includes the Northdale neighbourhood. Working with local residents, the campus communities, and planning consultants, he championed bringing change to Northdale at City Council, seeing the new plan adopted unanimously last June. His family resides just outside Northdale.
Christine Carmody and her family are long term residents of Northdale. She was a passionate advocate for change as she was upset with the downward direction of her neighbourhood. Christine was a key member of the Northdale Special Project Committee, advising the City and its consultants on the transformational Northdale Land Use and Community Improvement Plan.
Both Jeff and Christine are active members of the City's Town and Gown Committee, where post-secondary institutions, local government, and residents come together and work towards a more seemlessly connected community that student and non-student residents are proud to call home.

title: From Actors to Olympians; an incline and a jar on a bar.
shortdescription: We meet at 1 o'clock for a tour of the Stinson School Project, so, if you've already done that, meet us at 1:30 as we leave for the bottom of the Wentworth Stairs for a little theatrical history, on to the Corktown Pub for the good stuff, and continue westward for some low down on the down town.
longdescription: We meet at 1 o'clock for a tour of the Stinson School Project, so, if you've already done that, meet us at 1:30 as we leave and head over to the bottom of the Wentworth Stairs where you're going to hear the remarkable story of the Summer Stock Theatre; a story of wild exaggerations, stairs, and impossible ticket sales... a tale of inclined railways and street names and heart break. And that's all *before* you get to the bar. The bar...and the story of the "jar on the bar", the story of Olympic dreams and princes sprinting, and heroes returning, and a longshot named Cicely that made it all possible.  On to the magnificent T.H.& B. train station, over to the Whitehearn home and (sshhh) SECRET GARDEN!!!!!, then off to the Art Gallery for a (free) peak at Napoleon's (ssshhh) "posessions", and from there to the panoramic views of the 21st floor of the Stelco Tower. This walk promises to be an entertaining, informative, cultural, happy, eye-opening, educational, and everything-you've-ever-wanted-in-your-entire-lifetime-from-a-walk walk! We're not kidding. Well, kinda not kidding.

And we say: Knowledgeable and entertaining, Lance is a storyteller of the highest calibre.

title: Charity Wards to Private Rooms: Evolving Health Care Practices at Kingston General Hospital
shortdescription: Learn about the history of Kingston General Hospital during an informative outdoor walking tour led by Museum of Health Care Curator Dr. Pamela Peacock and CARE Fellow Dr. Ashley Waddington, MD, FRCSC.
longdescription: The tour will introduce participants to the early history of Kingston General Hospital, with a focus on the developments from 1835 to 1914. Dr. Pamela Peacock will cover the shift from a charitable institution to one that aimed to bring in more paying patients, the connection between KGH and the Queen’s Medical College, changes in nursing training and practice, as well as increased medical specialization. If you have an interest in the history of healthcare, or the Kingston General Hospital, you will enjoy walking past the different hospital wings, learning about their role in the development of today’s hospital. The walk will conclude with a 30 minute discussion, led by Dr. Waddington, on the current context of medical training and delivery, as well as recent practices in hospital funding.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Museum of Health Care at Kingston, 32 George St, K7L 2V7

team.name-first: Dr. Pamela Peacock and Dr. Ashley Waddington
team.bio:
Dr. Pamela Peacock is the Curator of the Museum of Health Care at Kingston. She holds a PhD in History from Queen's University, a Masters in Museum Studies from the University of Toronto and a B.A. in History from the University of  Western Ontario
Dr. Ashley Waddington is a Critical CAR E FEllow, Queen's University. She attained her medical degree at MacMaster University in 2006. Her clinical activities and research intrests include complicated contracception cases, adolescent contraception and pregnancy, pediatric and adolescent gynecology, health care access and public policy. She is currently pursuing a Masters in Public Administration from Queen's University.

title: El Virrey Cordobés (Personajes olvidados de Córdoba)
shortdescription: Un cuento histórico que tiene como centro a uno de los personajes españoles más influyentes del siglo XVIII. Antonio Caballero y Góngora, Virrey de Nueva Granada, Obispo de Córdoba e impulsor y mecenas de la expedición botánica de Celestino Mutis, que inventarió la flora americana, es el hilo conductor de un paseo por sus escenarios vitales en la ciudad.
longdescription:
Una Córdoba asolada por la peste, con apenas 11,000 habitantes en un casco urbano similar al actual, es el sorprendente escenario "romántico" donde se cultiva uno de los personajes más interesantes que ha dado al mundo la Córdoba cristiana. Con Carlos III fue virrey de Nueva Granada, un vasto territorio que desde el Caribe se extendía por Panamá,Venezuela, Colombia y Ecuador. Hablaremos de su excelente labor allí, de su mecenazgo en el inventario de Flora de José Celestino Mutis, de su impulso a la cultura estableciendo los primeros periódicos de América y la primera universidad. Pero sobre todo nos centraremos en su labor en Córdoba, que no fue poca y que hoy forma parte de la fisonomía icónica de la ciudad. También hablaremos de alguna obsesión y,  porqué no, de algún defecto que también tuvo este brillante y olvidado cordobés.

El paseo se desarrolla por los lugares que mantienen la huella de este interesante cordobés. Partiendo de la Plaza de S. Hipólito, nos dirigiremos por S.Nicolás hasta la plaza de la Trinidad, para desde ahí, a través de la judería llegar a la Mezquita y el Triunfo, desde donde caminaremos hasta la Posada del Potro, fin del paseo si unas cañas no lo remedian.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Plaza de San Hipólito (Plaza del Ángel)

team.bio: Luis es cordobés y diseñador gráfico. Ha desarrollado su profesión principalmente en Madrid, especializándose en diseño editorial, ha trabajado para numerosos medios: Diario MARCA, Revista Telva, Diario Expansión y semanario Actualidad Económica. Colaboraciones gráfica en el semanario político El Globo y Diario El País. El último medio en el que ha trabajado es el semanario La Clave dirigido por José Luis Balbín. En el año 2000 se traslada a Córdoba continuando con el trabajo de diseño. Funda la empresa COSO Producciones culturales, que entre otras actividades, organiza y dirige talleres internacionales de Arte Contemporáneo en Baeza con el patrocinio de la Universidad Internacional de Andalucía, en Córdoba con el patrocinio del Ayuntamiento de Córdoba y en Zaragoza en colaboración con Zaragoza Cultural y Centro de Historia de Zaragoza.

shortdescription: Do you know the story behind Simpson/Ogden's Sundial Park? How about the history of the Ukrainian Labour Temple? Come explore the hidden treasures with a dedicated group of seasoned walkers in one of Thunder Bay's best loved neighbourhoods.

title: Layers of Kensington
shortdescription: Come explore the multiple layers of Kensington Market—historical, social, political—and engage in urban archaeology.
longdescription:
Kensington Market has many visible layers; from the early British Park Lot to Victorian suburb to the beginnings of a Market with the arrival of Jewish immigrants in the early 1900’s.  Each new wave of immigration to this city has left its mark in Kensington, often arriving, setting up a new business and then moving on. Kensington Market has also been the site of some intense grassroots activism. Political initiatives that arise out of the particular needs of this dynamic community have helped change the Market cityscape, making it the truly unique neighbourhood it is today.

 

The different layers of Kensington are still visible. Come and engage in a little urban archaeology.

 

The sharing of personal stories about the Market will be encouraged but not required.

title: Modernist Architecture happened to me!
shortdescription: As I grew up in downtown Regina in the 1950s, Modernism happened to me. Before my eyes, the city shed its Victorian roots to embrace Modernist architecture.
longdescription: We will look at buildings that still stand,  Modernist buildings that have been erased or refaced, and talk about the Victorian buildings that were once there.    This walk will begin at Victoria Avenue and McIntyre Street, the corner where my father's grocery store (and our home) once stood, and end at RPL Central Library.

markers.title: Meeting Place

team.bio: Jeannie Mah is a ceramic artist who has studied in Regina,Vancouver, Banff, and France.    With Lorne Beug and Anne Campbell, she is co-editor of Regina's Secret Spaces:  Love and Lore of Local Geography (Canadian Plains Research Centre, 2006), a psycho-cultural field guide to her home town, and the forthcoming  RPL 100 Years, with Susan Birley and Anne Campbell.  Her work can be seen on the cover of Gail Crawford's recent book, Studio Ceramics in Canada, at the Gardiner Museum of Ceramic Art in Toronto, Regina’s City Hall, the Nouveau Gallery, Glen Elm Library, and in collections across Canada and abroad.

title: Modernist Architecture happened to me!

title: All About Withrow Park
shortdescription: Learn about the many plans, activities, events in Withrow Park and how you can get involved!
longdescription:
Who is that person planting flowers in the park?  How can I adopt a tree?  When can I next see a Shakespeare production at Withrow?  When is Dusk Dances returning?  Who are all those people gathered at the rink throughout the Spring?  What has been happening to improve the soccer field?  What improvements are planned for our playgrounds?  What can I expect to find at the farmers' market this year?  How can I get involved in these activities?

Take a walk around the park with members of Dusk Dances, Shakespeare in the Ruff, the Withrow Park Farmers' Market, Pink Turf, Downtown Soccer, the Riverdale Horticultural Society, the Friends of Withrow Park , the Withrow Park Ball Hockey League to find out about their plans, activities and events in the park.  Hear from Councillor Fletcher about the plans to upgrade the playgrounds.  So many exciting plans and activities- join the walk and the conversation about the diverse activities at Withrow Park.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: North East Field of Withrow Park (Corner of McConnell and Carlaw)

team.bio: This walk is led by the Friends of Withrow Park with the help of its many friends.  All of the speakers contribute to the life and activity of this great neighbourhood park and want you to learn more about their activities and, if you are interested, how you can become involved.

accessible-transit: Nearest subway stations are Chester or Pape.

title: Regina Revitalization Initiative
shortdescription: A walk around the RRI project area to discuss and contextualize both challenges and opportunites going forward.
longdescription:
Regina is growing.  Every day, there seems to be news of a building project or new phase going forward in a suburban development. 

Conscious of this change, the City of Regina is undertaking various planning processes to help shape the development of the city.  One of these projects is the Regina Revitalization Initiative (RRI).  The RRI is an ambitious plan to build a new civic stadium, put infill housing onto the Taylor Field site and redevelop a portion of the CP rail yards at the heart of the city.

This walk will make a loop around the area in question so participants can visualize changes that are planned and imagine what changes they would like to see.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: In front of the Delta Hotel, 1919 Saskatchewan Drive

team.bio: I have a BA in Geography from the University of Regina, focusing on urban issues.  I'm interested in neighbourhoods, topophilia, downtowns, shops and soccer fields. What is facinating about these features is how they combine, change, and engage with all the pieces of civic life through time.

accessible-info: There are no specific points on inaccessibility but the conditions of sidewalks, roads and parking lots, because of ice and water, may be difficult.
accessible-transit: A block north and two blocks East of the main trainsit hub on 11th avenue.
accessible-parking: Downtown parking, on the streets near the Delta hotel.

title: All the World’s a Stage: A Close Up of Regent Park’s Arts & Cultural Scene
shortdescription: Toronto’s Regent Park neighbourhood has been undergoing a massive transformation and the Arts & Cultural Scene in the community is as vibrant as ever. Take a walk and explore!
longdescription:
First walk starts at 11:00am, walks run every half hour, with the last walk starting at 12:30pm.

Toronto’s Regent Park neighbourhood has been undergoing a massive transformation and the Arts & Cultural Scene in the community is as vibrant as ever.

Join us on this walk and;

Get inspired by Regent Park Focus Youth Media Arts new studio, and film your walk to our next stop;

Behold local talent on display in the gallery of the Paintbox Condominium’s lobby, meet the neighbours next door and;

Nom on deliciously crafted eats at the Paintbox Bistro;

Make your way to the spectacle at Daniels Spectrum and where you can dance and improv along to the beat;

 Across the street, view all that glimmers at the new Aquatic Centre; and

Arm yourself with knowledge as you pass through Daniels Centre of Learning.

title: Up the Down Staircase(s)
shortdescription: Leave your fingers off the buttons, ladies and gentlemen, and step away from the doors... we're taking the stairs.
longdescription: Any time of the day or night you'll see the people... moving up and down the Kenilworth and Wentworth stairs... fitness (um...) types, and people who just like to experience the (um...) thrill of climbing, and people who like to set goals. If you're like me, a fascinated by-stander who has great intentions of "doing the stairs"  but never seems to make it there... here's your chance. Matthew Green is the man who can make it happen... he's leading a walk up the Kenilworth stairs (all 298 or them) along the Mountain Brow, down the Wentworth Stairs (there are 498 of those) and back to the starting point via the Rail Trail. If you've got any one of those destinations on your "To do" list I think you've just found your walk.  Don't be shy, as Matt wanted you to know... this is *not* a workout, it's a pleasure walk... and here's what you need to know about Matt: if you're single, be prepared to fall in love, if you're not single, be prepared to make room in your life for another love.  Oh... and if you're a current stair-master, you're oh, so welcome to come along!

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Kenilworth Stairs at Kenilworth and Lawrence

team.bio: Matthew Green is a business man and athlete... and you can take the picture of the guy you just imagined out of your mind right now. Matt's business is health and his most treasured client is his community. Not only does Matt volunteer to take on issues he believes in, his company, FreeStyle Fitness donates 25% of net profits to a fund a foundation to support local charities. He's the kind of business person we need more of.

accessible-find: Matt will be the confindent, happy (but maybe somewhat sleepy) guy at the bottom of the Kenilworth Stairs. He'll probably be wearing something orange.

longdescription: The Old Strathcona Foundation believes that heritage is the infrastructure that supports arts and culture and this is evident in the wide variety of options available in this eclectic community including live music, theatre and public art.  Join us for a tour of the more than 30 murals created on public utility boxes for the Centennial Mural Project in 2004 as well as some of the amazing murals found on the sides of many of our heritage buildings.

title: Old Strathcona Heritage Tour
shortdescription: Join Historian Laureate Shirley Lowe for a tour of historic Old Strathcona
longdescription: Join Edmonton's Historian Laureate Shirley Lowe for a tour of Historic Old Strathcona and learn more about the buildings and builders that played a part in creating this unique community.  As you walk through this Provincial Historic Area (one of only two in Alberta) we will highlight the streetscape as it existed more than 100 years ago and share stories of some of the personalities that helped shape this destination district as well as the story of how this gem was almost lost forever.

title: Gibby's Field:  Where Gibson Creek Met Davey Creek
shortdescription: A walking tour along the paths of two creeks, Davey Creek and Gibson Creek, that met at Gibby’s Field in Kensington-Cedar Cottage, including a tour stop "on" a bridge over Gibson Creek at East 20th Avenue.
longdescription:
Taking its name from farmer Moses Gibson (1850-1937), who once owned considerable land locally, Gibby's Field is where two local creeks once met.  One of them was Davey Creek.  The other was Gibson Creek, probably the longest creek in the once-vast China Creek system.  This creek system included Trout Lake and used to enter False Creek near the VCC--Clark SkyTrain station.  

The tour will stop along the path of Davey Creek, and "on" a bridge over Gibson Creek at East 20th Avenue, near the location of Moses Gibson's farmhouse.  If circumstances permit, the latter tour stop will be accompanied by a senior who remembers when the creek ran under the bridge, past her home.  

Gibby's Field is one of 125 Vancouver sites to receive a historical plaque as part of the Vancouver Heritage Foundation's "Places That Matter" project.    Join us at 2pm for the ceremony to mark the installation of the plaque at Gibby's field, and the reception afterwards at Tyee Elementary School at 3pm, where a school plant sale is taking place from 3pm to 8pm.   See www.vcn.bc.ca/gibbys/plaque.htm for more details.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Tyee Elementary School, 3525 Dumfries Street (at East 19th Avenue, one block west of Knight Street)

team.bio: Dan Fass is a member of the Gibby's Field Subcommittee, a group seeking to preserve Gibby's Field as a community greenspace.  He is author of a 32-page booklet called "Historical Walking Tour of Gibson Creek Through Kensington–Cedar Cottage" (1.25 MB PDF file).  Dan is also on the board of the False Creek Watershed Society, which seeks to raise awareness about past and present creeks in Vancouver.

accessible-info: This walk will be mainly on pavement, plus some gravel at the school
accessible-transit: Tyee Elementary is walking distance from Knight Street (022), Kingsway (019), and King Edward Ave (025)
accessible-parking: Parking available on East 18th, Dumfries, and East 20th
accessible-find: At the plant sale at Tyee Elementary School, follow the signage and/or ask at the reception taking place at 3pm after the Gibby's Field plaque ceremony at 2pm.

title: A través de las murallas
shortdescription: La idea es ir contrastando las diferencias en la tipología de edificios y formas de vida entre la ciudad antigua, en este caso el interior de la Axerquía Norte (barrio de Santa Marina principalmente), y la ciudad moderna, aquella surgida con la Revolución Industrial que llegó a nuestra ciudad en el siglo XIX, pero que se ha visto transformada por la expansión urbana a partir de los años 60 del siglo XX. Un contraste en cuanto a vías (su ancho, su uso), ruidos, espacios públicos... El eje será la muralla de la Axerquía iniciada por los almorávides.
longdescription:
La idea es ir contrastando las diferencias en la tipología de edificios y formas de vida entre la ciudad antigua, en este caso el interior de la Axerquía Norte (barrio de Santa Marina principalmente), y la ciudad moderna, aquella surgida con la Revolución Industrial que llegó a nuestra ciudad en el siglo XIX, pero que se ha visto transformada por la expansión urbana a partir de los años 60 del siglo XX. Un contraste en cuanto a vías (su ancho, su uso), ruidos, espacios públicos... El eje será la muralla de la Axerquía iniciada por los almorávides.
Partiremos de la Puerta del Rincón (explicando su denominación) y seguiremos por la calle Adarve, (nombre también a explicar), contemplando los restos de muralla. Al llegar a la Torre de la Malmuerta explicaremos su realidad confrontada con su leyenda. Continuaremos por avd. Ollerías (topónimo también interesante) y nos acercaremos al principal hito de la rev. industrial en Córdoba en esa zona: el chimeneón. Luego volveremos a los restos más históricos: la puerta del Colodro y su historia, sin descartar una breve incursión en la plaza de la Lagunilla y su toponimia (tal vez con alguna sorpresa). Seguiremos la muralla almorávide a través de la plaza de Rafael Botí y de la calle Muro de la Misercordia, donde se aprecian restos de esa muralla y explicaremos el nombre, así como una tipología de casas ya casi deaparecidas. Luego la calle Fernando de Lara, el antiguo manicomio y finalmente el comienzo de la muralla del Marrubial. 
 
Para más información mi direccion email es rajial2004@yahoo.es y móvil 692 568 429.

title: Muskegon Jane's Walk

Discover the Possibilities of Downtown Muskegon - we will start our exploration at the Western Avenue and 2nd Street (the former Muskegon Savings Bank Building). title: Cronotopos - Espacio Público / Mujer Privada. Coordenadas espacios temporales para entender la relación de las mujeres con la ciudad de Córdoba y su memoria colectiva
shortdescription:
En este paseo de Jane, el colectivo Al Raso propone rememorar algunas mujeres que contribuyeron a la historia de la ciudad pero que no han sido reconocidas o han sido mal representadas en el ideario de su memoria colectiva. Al mismo tiempo aprovecharemos el paseo para introducir algunas contribuciones que mujeres urbanistas han pensado en torno a la relación entre las mujeres y la ciudad.
Proponemos un recorrido que versa la Córdoba romana de lado de Pola Argentaria y Helvia, la Córdoba musulmana recordando la figura de Wallada, Beatriz Enríquez de Arana nos servirá para rememorar la Córdoba moderna y al pasado más reciente nos acercaremos desde la restitución de la memoria de María Teresa López . Para ello nos encontraremos en Claudio Marcelo, caminaremos juntas/os hasta la Mezquita e iremos paseando hasta San Pedro, deteniéndonos por un momento en la plaza del Potro. 
De este modo veremos espacios que son bien conocidos pero haciendo una relectura de esos espacios a través de la mirada de algunas mujeres de la historia de nuestra ciudad que aún hoy están ausentes o injustamente visibilizadas.
longdescription:
En la 2ª edición de Paseos de Jane, Córdoba, el colectivo Al Raso propone rememorar algunas mujeres que contribuyeron a la historia de la ciudad pero que no han sido reconocidas o han sido mal representadas en el ideario de su memoria colectiva. Al mismo tiempo aprovecharemos el paseo para introducir algunas contribuciones que mujeres urbanistas han pensado en torno a la relación entre las mujeres y la ciudad.

Proponemos un recorrido que versa la Córdoba romana de lado de Pola Argentaria y Helvia, la Córdoba musulmana recordando la figura de Wallada, Beatriz Enríquez de Arana nos servirá para rememorar la Córdoba moderna y al pasado más reciente nos acercaremos desde la restitución de la memoria de María Teresa López . Para ello nos encontraremos en Plaza de las Tendillas, nos acercaremos a Claudio Marcelo, caminaremos juntas/os hasta la Mezquita e iremos paseando hasta San Pedro, deteniéndonos por un momento en la plaza del Potro.

De este modo veremos espacios que son bien conocidos pero haciendo una relectura de esos espacios a través de la mirada de algunas mujeres de la historia de nuestra ciudad que aún hoy están ausentes o injustamente visibilizadas.

Metodología del paseo:

Proponemos un espacio dinámico de aprendizaje colaborativo e interactivo, centrado en la conversación y el multiálogo entre las personas participantes y las personas miembros del colectivo Al Raso, para construir un conjunto de saberes en torno a la memoria colectiva de las mujeres de la ciudad de Córdoba.

En los emplazamientos señalados en el plano a continuación, compartiremos nuestros conocimientos sobre las mujeres cordobesas anteriormente citadas y cómo eran las vidas de esas mujeres en las épocas históricas de Córdoba. Además proponemos lecturas acompañadas por el sonido de la guitarra flamenca, que hacen mención a dichas mujeres o que fueron escritos o narrados por ellas mismas.

Durante los paseos entre las distintas ubicaciones, iremos conversando sobre las aportaciones que se han venido realizando en torno a la relación entre las ciudades y las mujeres.

Así mismo, otra persona miembro de Al Raso se encargará de documentar audiovisualmente el paseo.

title: Garrison Creek Part 2: Planting Our Feet and Ears to the Ground
shortdescription: Help us bring an urban watershed back to the surface so it can sustain Canada’s first Homegrown National Park! Join us with open ears, dressed in green and blue, and be ready to start a new chapter for Garrison Creek.
longdescription:
Join the team of Neighbourhood Park Rangers, and trace the past, present and future of Toronto neighbourhood that once had a river running to through it.

Inspired by an idea from authors Richard Louv and Douglas Tallamy, the David Suzuki Foundation is launching a project to crowd-source a green urban corridor in downtown Toronto along the former path of Garrison Creek, one of the city's most notable "Lost Rivers”. 

Together, we can bring nature home, one act at a time: to yards, balconies, roofs, alleyways, parks and green spaces.

We can make this urban corridor one of the greenest, and bluest, in the country.

To start,  let's "get out and walk" , look and listen to what is already flowing and growing in the heart of the city.

SUGGESTION: Trace the Garrison in 2 parts: start with Jon Harstone's Jane's Walk: "Landscape Archeology of Garrison Creek" Sunday at 1:30pm, then join "Garrison Creek Part 2" at 4:30pm.

title: Harbord Village West (Reprise Walk for Doors Open)
shortdescription: Explore Harbord Village West in this two-part series on Jane's Walk and Doors Open!
longdescription:
Harbord Village, enclosed by Bloor, Spadina, College, Bathurst, is a neighbourhood of late 19C and early 20C homes (about one quarter of which are members of Harbord Village Heritage Conservation District.) It is bounded by a diversity of retail, dining and entertainment venues and is close to the University of Toronto, Queens Park, Kensington Market, Little Italy and Chinatown.

The 10:00am walk explores the western half of Harbord Village, south to College St then north-west to finish at Honest Ed's at Bloor and Bathurst at 12:00 noon.

This is a Doors Open Toronto Jane's Walk, with a second leg of the tour on May 25th or 26th! Click here for full program details.

This walk will also be happening tomorrow. Click here for information.

Tim Grant is the Chair of the Harbord Village Residents' Association.
Richard Longley is a Member of the Harbord Village Heritage Conservation District Directory Committee.

accessible-transit: Bathurst Subway Station

title: How Green was my Valley(view)
shortdescription: Valleyview Drive is one of Edmonton's most spectacular view points, and one of its best streetscapes of midcentury modernist architecture.  Edmonton Journal columnist Paula Simons returns to the neighbourhood where she grew up, to lead a look at Valleyview's surprising social and architectural history.
longdescription: Valleyview's "opening" in 1957 coincided with a golden age of modernist architecture in Edmonton - and Valleyview Drive's earliest residents gave themselves licence to commission some of Edmonton's most cutting-edge architects, including Peter Hemingway and Don Bittorf,  to build them dramatic and original homes on the edge of the river, employing styles reminiscent of Frank Lloyd Wright and Arthur Erickson. Now, some of those original modernist mansions jockey for space with upstart infill projects, as a neighbourhood that's always been home to larger-than-life characters makes room for a few more. Edmonton Journal columnist Paula Simons grew up in Valleyview. Join her for a look at some of Edmonton's most striking homes and river valley views -and for the tales of the personalities who weren't afraid to push things right to the edge of the city. (With optional extension into the ravine/dog park behind Valleyview Crescent.) https://maps.google.com/maps?hl=en

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Andy's Valleyview IGA, 9106 - 142nd St.

team.bio: Paula Simons is the Edmonton Journal's City columnist. She grew up in Valleyview, where her parents still live, and had her first horsey ride at Andy's Valleyview IGA. She is a co-author of the best-selling popular history, Alberta: One Hundred Years a Home, and the writer-producer of a number of Ideas documentaries about western Canadian history.  In November 2008, she was honoured by the Edmonton Historical Board for her writings on Edmonton history, architecture and heritage preservation.

accessible-info: Optional extension - if weather and terrain permit, we may walk down into the ravine and off-leash area; this will be an optional extension for those without mobility concerns.
accessible-parking: Some parking available near the IGA, and on neighbouring service roads. Please be respectful of the parking needs of IGA customers.

title: Osborne Village - Good Urbanism in Action
longdescription: This walk will explore the Village through sidewalks and back lanes. Discussions will touch on urban design, transit oriented development and current redevelopment projects. Come share your thoughts and see why the neighbourhood was named one of Canada's greatest neighbourhoods as part of the 2012 Canadian Institute of Planners, Great Places in Canada Contest.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: River and Osborne, the circle in front of Subway at the Gas Station Theatre - not to be confused with the Osborne Village Cleanup BBQ

accessible-info: The route is wheelchair, walker, stroller accessible although the back lanes are often cracked and uneven. We can adjust to accommodate. Keep in mind that the neighbourhood is over 100 years old and land drainage can be an issue. With the late spring we could be in for some wet ground and mud. The walk will be about 2.5 km in total.

title: WPGxHBC - A Company's Influence on the City
longdescription:
Ever wonder about the origins of downtown’s grid street pattern? Or how Memorial Boulevard lined up so perfectly with the Legislative Building? Who built the first traffic bridges in Winnipeg? Why the Princeton Apartments on Broadway look so posh?

The Hudson’s Bay Company has existed here for quite some time – far longer than the city itself! Over the years the company has had an enormous influence on Winnipeg’s urban development. On this walk you’ll learn about controversial land swaps, real estate monopolies and incredible changes in retail culture that have had lasting effect on the shape of our city.

The walk will begin on Main Street near Broadway and end at Portage & Memorial, so bring your walking shoes!

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: 170 Main Street, the parking lot behind V.J.'s Drive Inn

team.bio: Abigail is a University of Winnipeg MA in Curatorial Practices student who has spent a long but totally exciting year searching through the Hudson’s Bay Company Archives.  Find out more about the project at www.wpgxhbc.com.

accessible-info: The walk will follow paved sidewalks.
accessible-transit: Start and end points are located on major bus routes (Main Street and Broadway)
accessible-parking: Street parking available on Broadway and local parking garages.

title: The Communities, the Campus & the Re-Generation
longdescription:
Next to downtown, the University of Manitoba is the second most commuted to destination in the City of Winnipeg. Take a walk on the wild side through the residential communities of Fort Richmond and University Heights which sandwich the U of M Campus.

Experience the walkability in these communities which surround the University of Manitoba. Walk through Smart Park; a 'Community of Innovators’, peruse the sparkling Investors Group Field, new home to the Winnipeg Blue Bombers, and stroll on the trails of what was once the prestigious Southwood Golf Course.

The communities and the campus are undergoing a transformation – a re-generation. Michelle and Janice will provide an in-depth overview of what is currently underway in both the communities and on Campus.

team.name-first: Michelle Richard, University of Manitoba Campus Planner, and Janice Lukes, Winnipeg Trails Association & community resident

title: Condo Creep around Bayview Village - North York's Condo Expansion Experiment!
shortdescription: Condo expansion is evident throughout Toronto, including in Bayview Village alongside Sheppard Ave East in Lower Willowdale. A historical single family house suburb, let's explore how this neighbourhood is being impacted by the construction boom in condos. Join us in taking a Jane Jacobs Walkabout to check out this phenomenon together!
longdescription:
We will start by exploring the Concord Park Place (a condo development on south Sheppard Avenue).

Next, we will explore the impact of traffic flows and noise pollution from the placement of McDonald's and Canadian Tire, the evolution of local coffee shops, dental offices, Ikea, NY General  Hospital, the 401 highway, and the Oriole Go Station.

We will take a short cut via Esther Shiner Blvd & Old Leslie St to enter the East Don River park system ending at Clarinda Park.

We will exit via 100 step wooden steep stairs  & explore the exclusive million dollar home district of Bayview Village surroundings.

Ending our walk at the Bayview Village Shopping Centre built in the 1960's, which is under transformation. It should be worthwhile to compare housing development with condo development & greenspace stress on our walk.


Approximate hike time 1.5 hours at a leisurely pace. Bring comfortable walking shoes and be prepared to climb the steep stairs from the Don River East Trail up to Clarinda Park. The stairway has secure handrails. There are no  readily available washrooms except at Bayview Village (next to Bayview Subway Station) and  please dress for current weather conditions on May 5th.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Bessarion Subway Station South Side Exit at Sheppard Ave East

team.bio:
I am a new resident in this part of South Willowdale (Bayview Village Catchment Area) just north of the 401 and have led a Jane Walk before within the St.Clair/Warden Park/Urban system in Scarborough, where I previously resided.
I have enjoyed Jane Jacobs influence through her writings and have observed Jane's as well as others urban planning thinking about the Metro Toronto area.

title: Un paseo por el río Ebro en Zaragoza
shortdescription: Pasear por las riberas del Ebro, desde el Pilar hasta el Parque del Agua, el Arrabal y Las Fuentes
longdescription:
Quiero dar un paseo por las riberas del Ebro, en Zaragoza, celebrando el Jane's Walk, con quien quiera recordar a Jane Jacobs, la "urbanista" que nos enseñó que las ciudades no se estudian, se viven.

Saldremos de detrás de la basílica del Pilar. Si andamos río arriba o río abajo, es una decisión que tomaremos en ese momento. La idea es volver y terminar en el mismo sitio, caminando por la Almozara, por el Parque del Agua, por el Arrabal, por Vadorrey y por Las Fuentes.

title: ?ראשון לציון, העיר העברית הצבעונית הראשונה
shortdescription:
ראשון לציון, למרות סיפורה ההיסטורי העשיר, נתפסת כפרוור שינה חסר ייחוד במרכז הארץ. פרויקט "שיפוץ חזיתות הבתים" שיזם לאחרונה ראש העיר, מר דב צור, מבקש לשנות את המצב. הפרויקט שם דגש על שילוב צבעוניות בהתחדשות מרכז העיר ונעשה בשיתוף התושבים. 
במהלך ההליכה נבקר בבנייניי הפרויקט, נפגש עם דיירים שהיו שותפים לתהליך ההתחדשות ונכיר את אחד הקבלנים של הפרויקט. במהלך הדרך נדון בשאלת הצבע בכלל ובעיר בפרט.
longdescription:
ראשון לציון, למרות סיפורה ההיסטורי המפואר, נתפסת כפרוור שינה חסר ייחוד במרכז הארץ. אולם לאחרונה נדמה כי פרויקט "שיפוץ חזיתות הבתים" שיזם ראש עירה, מר דב צור, עתיד לשנות את כל זה. הפרויקט שם דגש על שילוב צבעוניות בהתחדשות מרכז העיר, ובכך משיב אליו את אותה רוח חלוצית אשר אפיינה את המושבה ההיסטורית בראשית דרכה.  

ההליכה פונה אל תושבי העיר, במהלך ההליכה נבקר בבנייניי הפרויקט, נפגש עם דיירים שעברו את התחדשות ונכיר את אחד הקבל"נים של הפרויקט. כמו כן נדון בשאלת צבע בכלל ובעיר בפרט.

כתבה על הפרויקט: http://www.xnet.co.il/architecture/articles/0,14710,L-3099813,00.html

 

מספר המקומות מוגבל ויש לתאם הגעה מראש במייל: riglor1@gmail.com או בטלפון: 054.2645770

title: שוות ומשפיעות. בדרכה של אילנה צ'רנברודה //  הדר, ואדי ניסנס  //  Wadi Nisnas Equal and Influencing
longdescription:
הטיול יעבור לאורך ציוני דרך בחייה, עיסוקיה והשקפת עולמה של אילנה צ'רנברודה ז"ל, מחלוצות הפמיניזם החיפאי, ומי ששימשה כיועצת למעמד האישה ויו"ר מועצת הנשים ליד ראש העיר חיפה. כפמיניסטית ופעילה חברתית היא האמינה בזכות לשוויון לכל אזרחי המדינה, ובמסגרת אמונתה הפוליטית יזמה פעילויות בין נשים ערביות ויהודיות ואף נפגשה עם יאסר עראפת בעזה, בימים שמעטים העזו לעשות זאת. בדרך נפגוש אנשים שונים שהיו קשורים לפועלה ולמעשיה בתחומי מעמד האישה ושיוויון מגדרי, פעילות חברתית ומפלגתית, חינוך צעירים ובני נוער, חינוך לדו-קיום ושלום עם שכנינו. דרך ההליכה תצטייר דמותה של אישה מיוחדת ואמיצה, בעלת ראיית עולם פוליטית והומנית, מלאת חסד ואהבת אדם.

(נקודת מפגש: עירית חיפה, חסן שוקרי 14 (קווי אוטובוס 103,108

נקודת סיום: בית הגפן
מדריכת הסיור: ד"ר יהודית זוסמנוביץ, חברת נשיאות מועצת אירגוני הנשים בישראל

משך הסיור: שעתיים

   

ستسير الجولة وفقًا لمحطات في حياة، نشاط ومواقف المرحومة إيلانه تشرنبروده، وهي من رائدات النسوية الحيفاوية، وقد شغلت وظيفة مستشارة لمكانة المرأة ورئيسة لمجلس النساء إلى جانب رئيس بلدية حيفا. كنسوية وناشطة اجتماعية كانت تؤمن بحقّ جميع مواطني الدولة في المساواة، وفي إطار إيمانها السياسيّ بادرت إلى تنظيم نشاطات بين النساء العربيات واليهوديات، كما التقت بياسر عرفات في غزّة، في الأيام التي لم يجرؤ فيها كثيرون على فعل كذلك. في الطريق سنلتقي بأشخاص مختلفين كانت تربطهم صلة بعملها ونشاطها في مجالات مكانة المرأة والمساواة الجندريّة، النشاط الاجتماعي والحزبيّ، تثقيف الأولاد والشبيبة، التربية على التعايش والسّلام مع جيراننا. عبر المشي سترتسم شخصيّة امرأة مميّزة وشجاعة، ذات وجهة نظر سياسية وإنسانيّة، مفعمة بالخير وبمحبّة الإنسان.

 

نقطة الالتقاء: بلديّة حيفا، حسن شكري 14 (خطّا الباص 103، 108)

نقطة الختام: بيت الكرمة

مدّة الجولة: ساعتان

title: Los Veneros por la Collación de Santa María.
shortdescription: Aprenderemos: Recorrido de las diferentes aguas. Localización de los Partidores de Agua, así como su funcionamiento interno. Daremos una visión general de cómo se repartía el agua por la Mezquita Catedral y por su collación.
longdescription:
Os propongo el siguiente recorrido por las calles de la Judería:

Un buen punto de salida puede ser la Puerta de Almodóvar. Después bajaremos por la calle Cairuán hasta llegar a los  Baños Califales con parada frente a la Torre del Homenaje.  Llegado a este punto hablaremos del agua que llegaba al Alcázar y despues nos desplazaremos a la calle Torrijos a la altura del antiguo Hospital San Sebastián. Continuaremos por la Puerta Norte de la Mezquita-Catedral para después pasar al Patio de los Naranjos.  En dicho patio hablaremos del reparto del agua en las fuentes y partidores y también del Aljibe de Almanzor.

title: גינות  // Gardens
longdescription:
סיור בין 3 גינות קהילתיות, מתוך 11 גינות שקיימות היום בחיפה. בין פרחים, פירות וירקות נפגוש את פעילי הגינות, ואת רכזת גינות קהילתיות בחברה להגנת הטבע, ונשמע על העקרונות של גינה קהילתית. לבאים באוטובוס – מומלץ לרדת בתחנה ברח' דוד המלך בנווה דוד. לבאים ברכב פרטי - ניתן לחנות ברח' דוד המלך. 

 

جولة في 3 حدائق جماهيرية، من بين 11 حديقة قائمة اليوم في حيفا. بين دعامات الزهور، الفواكه والخضار سنلتقي ناشطي الحداق، ومركّزة الحدائق الجماهيريّة في جمعية حماية الطبيعة، وسنسمع عن الأيديولوجيا وعن الممارسة المتعلقة بالحدائق الجماهيرية. للقادمين بالباص – يُنصَح بالنزول في محطّة شارع دافيد هميلخ في نفيه دافيد. للقادمين بسيارة خاصة – يُمكن ركن السيارة في شارع دافيد هميلخ.

 

نقطة الالتقاء: الحديقة الجماهيرية نفيه دافيد، شدروت ههجناه، خلف مدرسة "كورتشاك" ومدرسة "شوف" سابقًا

title: Fields of Dreams in Jane-Finch
shortdescription: Jane-Finch is home to an 8 acre organic farm that is teaching locals how to grow food in fields, balconies and backyards. The site includes a heritage farmhouse, barn and fields that extend into the Black Creek ravine, all within walking distance of eight schools and thousands of local residents.
longdescription:
Imagine walking through an urban park and ravine system that is home to a community food forest, an organic urban farm, beautiful native pollinator flower gardens, and demonstration backyard and balcony food gardens. In these gardens and woodlands local residents share their experience in growing food and farming in far away lands, or perhaps learn from scratch how to plant seeds and tend to crops in local conditions. The food these urban farmers grow becomes a local bounty shared year round within the neighbourhood and beyond.

That’s the vision for the Black Creek Community Farm project located on Toronto and Region Conservation land in the densely populated and culturally rich neighbourhood of Jane/Finch. The farm occupies an eight acre property that includes pristine fields, a heritage farmhouse and barn, and a surrounding forest that extends down in the Black Creek ravine, all within easy walking distance of eight schools and thousands of local residents. 

In its early stages, the Black Creek Community Farm will produce it’s first harvest this summer and promises to redefine the urban park experience with an innovative community green space for people of all ages, abilities and backgrounds.

NB: We will be walking in farmers fields - wear boots that can get dirty, especially if it's at all wet! And yes, we will encourage you to get your hands dirty!


The Black Creek Community Farm is a project of the game-changing Everdale Farm and Environmental Learning Centre which trains farmers in sustainable agriculture and operates out of Erin, Ontario.  For more information visit www.everdale.org

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: 4929 Jane Street, just south of Steeles, driveway on east side.

team.name-first: Damian Adjodha, Jane Farrow & Anan Lololli
team.bio:
Co guides  Jane Farrow, Anan Lololli & Michael Scahill
Jane Farrow excels at bringing people together for constructive dialogue and creative city-building initiatives. Her career highlights include stints as CBC Radio One host and producer, best-selling author, dynamic facilitator and moderator, and executive assistant at City Hall. She was founding director of Jane’s Walk and is currently working with the NGO Park People as well as Swerhun Inc, a public consultation and community engagement firm. 
Anan Lololli, Founder and Exec Director Afri-Can FoodBasket, a non-profit community food security movement that is committed to meeting the nutrition, health and employment needs of members of the Toronto African Canadian community, in particular, those who are economically and socially vulnerable. Through community food security, leadership development and collaborative partnerships, the Afri-Can FoodBasket  advances the interests of the community in these areas.
Damian Adjodha , B.sc Envi U of  T, Master farmer, specialist in soil science, Production Manger, Backyard Organics. "I have been growing organically since I was a child here in Canada.  After receiving the honours B.Sc. from the University of Toronto in 1999, I travelled to my parental homeland in the Caribbean and began growing soy beans and other mixed crops on river valley volcanic soils of the St. Lucian coastal foothills. The challenges of tropical agriculture forced me to question every aspect of traditional agriculture and I soon began designing farming systems based on advanced organic farming/ permaculture system I had been exposed to throughout my travels in the region to Dominica, Cuba and Jamaica, where I successfully completed training to become an internationally recognized organic farm inspector (IOIA). Recently my life has shifted gears as we are raising three baby boys all born within 3½ years!  I am happy to be back here in the land of my birth building gardens on the fertile soils I was raised."

accessible-info: Walking on fields can be a muddy and slippery, definitely a challenge in rainy conditions especially.
accessible-transit: Jane Street bus, we're north of Finch, just south of Steeles.
accessible-parking: Parking will be on the farm driveway at 4929 Jane St. Carpooling encouraged.
accessible-find:
We will gather at the farmhouse, right off  4929 Jane Street (just south of Steeles, north of Finch). There is a circular drive in front of the heritage farmhouse where we'll be hanging around there and heading out into the adjacent fields. Parking is limited so please carpool and take transit where possible.
And remember, we're walking in farmers fields - so wear boots that can get dirty and muddy, especially if it's at all wet!

title: נשים בחיפה האדומה //  Women in Red Haifa
longdescription:
נתחיל באמפיתיאטרון ברחוב נורדאו, ומשם נלך ללנ"י - ליגת נשים בישראל ובית החלוצות ברחוב יל״ג. נמשיך לבית  מפ״ח (מועצת פועלי חיפה), ומשם למקום שבו נערכו הבזארים המפורסמים של ארגון אמהות עובדות, בחלוץ 45 . נעבור על פני בית התרבות של הנשים החיפאיות בשנות ה-50 וה-60, ונזכיר דמויות בולטות כמו חנה חושי, שפרה אלמוגי, מינה בן צבי, ועוד. נדבר על ארגון אמהות עובדות ונעמת ועל קיפוח נשים בשוק העבודה החיפאי, ונפגוש את תמי ברק, יו"ר נעמת בחיפה והקריות. 25 עותקים של הספר ״נשים בחיפה האדומה״ יחולקו למשתתפות הסיור. 

 

نبدأ من المدرّج في شارع نوردو، ومن هناك نتجه إلى دوري النساء في إسرائيل وإلى بيت الطليعيات في شارع "يلاغ". ثمّ نواصل السير إلى بيت "مجلس عمّال حيفا"، ومن هناك نتوجّه إلى المكان الذي أجريت فيه البازارات المشهورة الخاصة بمنظمة أمهات عاملات، في شارع هحلوتس 45. نمرّ بجوار بيت الثقافة للنساء الحيفاويات في سنوات الـ50 والـ60، ونذكر شخصيات بارزات مثل حانه حوشي، شيفرا ألموغي، مينه بن تسفي وغيرهنّ. نتحدّث عن منظمة أمهات عاملات و"نعمت" وعن التمييز ضد النساء في سوق العمل الحيفاويّة. وسيتمّ توزيع 25 نسخة من كتاب "نساء في حيفا الحمراء" على المشاركات في الجولة. 

 

نقطة الالتقاء: المدرّج، طرف شارع نوردو

نقطة الختام: الجسر فوق شارع هحلوتس 45

مرشد الجولة: د. إيلي نحمياس، رئيس القسم المالي والعقارات في الهستدروت

مدّة الجولة: نحو ساعة

 

In this walk we will visit the landmarks of Hifa's red women, such as the Israel Woman League, the Pioneers House and the House of Haifa's Worker's. We will mention famous figures such as Hana Husi, Shifra Almogi, Mina Ben Zvi and more. We will discuss Working Mothers Association and Naamat, and will meet Tami Barak, the head of Naamatin Haifa and the Krayot.

title: מסיבת התה של דודה דינה // Auntie Dina's Tea Party
longdescription:
דודה דינה היא לא בדיוק דודה שלי, אבל במשפחה כולם קוראים לה "דודה דינה". את סיפורי ילדותה ונעוריה בחיפה של שנות ה-20 וה-30 מכירים בני המשפחה לדורותיהם: היא נולדה בחיפה לאמה הכובענית ולאביה פועל הרכבת, שמת בגיל צעיר משחפת. המשפחה עברה דירה כמעט מידי שנה, וכל דירה השאירה אחריה זיכרונות ומעשיות. בעקבות הסיור שהובילה דודה דינה לפני כשנה, תתנהל ההליכה לאורך הציר שבין המזח הקיסרי ועד לחנות "אופנת פריז" שבה תפרה אמה יהודית כובעים, ומאוחר יותר גם שמלות כלה, לנשות חיפה המנדטורית. לאוהבי חיפה, על ידי מי שאמץ לו את דינה לדודה. 

 

العمّة دينا هي ليست بالضبط عمّتي، لكننا في بيتنا نطلق عليها جميعًا "العمّة دينا". قصّة طفولتها وشبابها في حيفا خلال سنوات الـ20 والـ30 يعرفها أبناء عائلتنا بمختلف أجيالهم: وُلِدت في حيفا لأمّ تعمل في صناعة وتصميم القبّعات ولأبٍ يعمل في القطار توفي في سنّ مبكّرة بعد إصابته بمرض السلّ. بدّلت العائلة شقّة سكنها كلّ سنة تقريبًا، ودائمًا كانت تختار البلدة التحتا كمكان سكنٍ لها، وقد تركت العائلة في كلّ شقة أقامت فيها ذكريات وأعمالاً. في أعقاب الجولة التي قادتها العمّة دينا قبل نحو سنة، سيتمّ تنظيم مسيرة المشي على امتداد المحور القائم بين الرصيف القيصري وحتى حانوت "موضة باريس" التي حاكت فيها أمّها يهوديت القبّعات، ولاحقًا فساتين الأعراس، لنساء حيفا الانتدابيّة. لعشّاق حيفا، ولكلّ مَن تبنّى دينا كعمّة له. 

 

نقطة الالتقاء: شارع يافا زاوية شدروت بن غوريون، قرب ساحة الكوركار

نقطة الختام: المركز التجاريّ القديم (سوق الأتراك، شارع هعتسمؤوت)

مرشد الجولة: شارون شطاينبوك، مهندس معماريّ وراوٍ

مدّة الجولة: نحو ساعة ونصف الساعة

 

An autobiographical tour of a native of the city of Hifa, who was born and raised here in the 20's and 30's. We will walk in the path of the many apartments she lived in during her childhood in the city.

title: Jane's Walk Coming to Cornwall
shortdescription: Guided Tours of Cornwall's Waterfront
longdescription:
Starting at the Corwall Community Museum this walk with take you from Lamoureux Park and continue west towards the bridge.

This SD&G Historical Society guided tour will include Cornwall's beginning as Pointe Maligne, the Loyalist Landing, our industrial history and finally to the Seaway International Bridge.

You can expect vivid commentary and human interest stories.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Cornwall Community Museum, Lamoureux Park 160 Water St. W.

accessible-parking: Parking at the Museum and Lamoureux Park

title: ים, תושבים ודלק // Sea, Citizens and fuels
longdescription:
למי שייך חוף הים – לתעשייה, למיכלי דלק, או לתושבים? בקרית חיים פועלת מזה שנים חווה של מיכלי דלק. המיכלים ישנים, דולפים, ומזהמים את סביבתם. לפני למעלה מתשע שנים הוחלט להעביר את החווה למיקום חדש אך מאז לא קרה דבר. בסיור נראה מקרוב את המיכלים, נדבר על ההשפעה הסביבתית, הבריאותית והחברתית של מיקומם, וניעזר בנתונים ממחקרים הקשורים בדלק, סביבה ובריאות. בדרך נפגוש בחברים מועד קרית חיים ובפעילים נוספים היוצאים למאבק נגד חוות מיכלי הדלק.

 

لمَن شاطئ البحر تابع – للصناعة، لحاويات الوقود، أم للسكان؟ توجد في كريات حايم منذ سنوات مزرعة لحاويات الوقود. الحاويات قديمة، تسيل، وتلوّث البيئة المحيطة. قبل أكثر من تسع سنوات تمّ اتخاذ قرار بنقل المزرعة إلى موقع جديد، لكن لم يتمّ تنفيذ أي خطوة عملية منذ ذلك الحين. في الجولة سنشاهد عن قرب الحاويات، وسنتحدّث عن تأثيرها البيئيّ، الصحّي والاجتماعيّ على الموقع، وسنستعين بمعطيات من أبحاث مرتبطة بالوقود، البيئة والصحّة. في الطريق سنلتقي بأعضاء من لجنة كريات حايم وبناشطين آخرين يقودون نضالاً ضد مزرعة حاويات الوقود.

 

نقطة الالتقاء: هوم سنتر، إلى جانب مفرق "حلوتسي هتعسياه"، "هئيستديون 1"، كريات حايم

نقطة الختام: مدرسة دغانيا، دغانيا زاوية زلمان إيرن

مرشدة الجولة: رونيت بيسو، المديرة العامة لتحالف صحة الجمهور

مدّة الجولة: نحو ساعة ونصف الساعة

 

Who owns the sea shore - the industry, or the citizens?

For decades now, a large number of fuel storage tanks have been located in Kiryat Haim. The tanks are old, leaking and pollute the environment. More than nine years ago, it was determined to move those tanks to a different location, but nothing happened since. In this walk we will closely watch the tanks and discuss the environmental, health and social impacts of their location. In our way we will meet environmental activists who fight to move this fuel storage site.

title: עם הפנים לים //  Facing the Sea
longdescription:
סיור במורדותיה המערביים של חיפה, עם נוף מהיפים בארץ - סטלה מאריס, מערת אליהו, ואד אל ג'מאל-עין הים ותל אל סמק-שקמונה. ההליכה תעבור בין ארכיאולוגיה לבנייה של שנות ה-60, תוך איזכור מקומות שהיו מרכזיים בעבר הרחוק, בעבר הקרוב והיום, כמו הבית שבו התחיל בית הספר הניסויי עין הים, פסיפס עתיק, בתי כנסת, כנסיות ומבנה חקר ימים ואגמים. הליכה עם מבט אל הים, ברחובות ששמם העוגן, התורן והתכלת, כיאה למיקומם מול הים. מומלץ להגיע באוטובוס מס. 115, ולרדת בתחנה ליד כיכר בית הלוחם. יש לקחת בחשבון הליכה ממושכת ברגל, ונוף מרהיב.

 

جولة في التلال الغربيّة من حيفا، مع أحد أجمل المناظر الطبيعية في البلاد – ستيلا مارس، مار الياس، وادي الجمال-عين هيام وتل السمك-شكمونا. المسيرة ستتضمّن علم الآثار والمباني خلال سنوات الستين، مع الإشارة إلى الأماكن التي كانت ذات مكانة مركزيّة في الماضي البعيد، في الماضي القريب واليوم، مثل البيت الذي بدأت فيه المدرسة التجريبية عين هيام، فسيفساء قديم، كنس، كنائس ومركز بحث البحار والمحيطات. السير مع الإطلال على البحر، في شوارع أسماؤها هي "هعوغن" (المرساة)، "هتورن" (الصارية) و"هتخيلت" (اللازورد- الزرقة السماويّة)، وذلك بما يتناسب مع موقعها على مقربة من البحر. يُنصَح بالقدوم بخطّ باص رقم 115، والنزول في المحطّة الواقعة قرب ساحة "بيت هلوحيم". تذكّروا أننا نتحدّث عن جولة سير طويلة، في أكناف منظر طبيعيّ خلاب.

 

نقطة الالتقاء: ستيلا مارس، في موقف السيارات قبالة الكنيسة (ساحة القطار الهوائيّ الأعلى)

 

نقطة الختام: تل السمك-شكمونا

مرشدة الجولة: فدوى سروجي، ناشطة اجتماعيّة ومن سكّان الحيّ

مدّة الجولة: ساعتان

 

A walk in Haifa's western slopes, through one of Israel's most amazing paths and views. W     e will pass through Stella Maris, Eliho's Cave, Vad el Gamal (Eye of the Sea) and Tel el Sameq (Shekmona). We will walk through archeological sights to buildings from the 60's.
