title: סחר בנשים בפריפריה  הצפונית //  Human Trafficking in the Northern Periphery
longdescription:
סיור בעקבות התופעה של סחר בנשים, שראשיתה בארץ בימי המנדט הבריטי. בשנות ה-90 של המאה הקודמת לבשה התופעה ממדים חדשים, ובחיפה היו לה מאפיינים מיוחדים, בהיותה עיר נמל ותיירות. בשנות האלפיים צצו ברחבי העיר דירות דיסקרטיות שבהן שוכנו נשים שהובאו ממזרח אירופה. במסגרת הסיור יסופר על ההיסטוריה של סחר בנשים בארץ, ועל תעשיית הזנות בחיפה היום, בין השאר דרך פגישות עם בעלי עסקים קטנים בשכונת הדר. כמו כן תוצג הפעילות של הארגונים לזכויות אדם, ועבודתם עם המשטרה. 

جولة في أعقاب الاتجار بالنساء، وهي ظاهرة تعود بداياتها في البلاد إلى أيّام الانتداب البريطاني. خلال سنوات الـ90 من القرن الماضي اتسعت هذه الظاهرة لتصل إلى أحجام جديدة، وكانت لها في حيفا سمات خاصة، لكون حيفا مدينة ميناء وسياحة. خلال سنوات الألفين ظهرت في أنحاء المدينة شقق سريّة تمّ فيها إسكان النساء اللواتي أحضرنَ من أوروبا الشرقيّة. في إطار الجولة سيُروى عن تاريخ الاتجار بالنساء في البلاد، وعن صناعة الزنا في حيفا اليوم، وسيشمل ذلك، ضمن أمور أخرى، لقاءات مع أصحاب مصالح صغيرة في حيّ الهدار. كما سيتمّ تناول وعرض نشاط منظّمات حقوق الإنسان، وعملها مع الشرطة في هذا المجال.

 

نقطة الالتقاء: أرلوزوروف 118 (خطوط الباص 133، 37، 28، 21، 12)

نقطة الختام: يوسيف 23

مرشدة الجولة: ريتا حايكين، مديرة مشروع مكافحة الزنا والاتجار بالنساء، جمعيّة المرأة للمرأة- مركز نسويّ، حيفا

مدّة الجولة: نحو ساعة

 

This walk will follow the path of human trafficking in Hiafa, beginning in the days of the British Mandate in Israel and through the 90's and the last decade. We will meet small business owners in Hadar as well as Human Rights activists.

title: רוגבי נשים //  Women's Rugby
longdescription:
נסייר בטכניון, נראה את מרכז הספורט, ונשקיף על נוף המפרץ. נעצור להדגמת משחק רוגבי קצר, ונכיר את כדור המשחק הייחודי. נדון בפריחת תרבות הספורט בארץ, ובפעילות ספורטיבית בטכניון, ונשאל את עצמנו מה מושך סטודנטיות לעזוב את הספרים פעמיים בשבוע לטובת מגרש הדשא. בדרך (אולי) נפגוש אקדמאים מהודו שמארגנים מידי שבוע משחקי קריקט בטכניון. בסוף - מבחן רוגבי למשתתפות!!!

 

نتجوّل في التخنيون، نشاهد مركز الرياضة، ونطلّ على منظر الخليج. نتوقّف لتجسيد لعبة رجبي قصيرة، ونتعرف على كرة اللعبة المميّزة. نناقش ازدهار ثقافة الرياضة في البلاد، والنشاط الرياضي في التخنيون، ونطرح على أنفسنا السؤال: ما الذي يجذب الفتيات ليتركن الكتب مرّتين في الأسبوع لصالح الملعب العشبيّ. في الطريق (ربّما) سنلتقي بأكاديميّين من الهند ينظّمون أسبوعيًّا ألعاب كريكت في التخنيون. في الختام- اختبار رُجبي للمشاركات!!!

 

نقطة الالتقاء: شاعر نفيه شأنان، التخنيون (خطوط الباص 17، 19، 32، 11، 77، 76. للقادمين بسيّارة خاصّة – موقف كوركور نحو 50 مترًا قبل بوّابة التخنيون)

 

نقطة الختام: شاعر نفيه شأنان، التخنيون

 

مُرشدة الجولة: ياعيل (عيلي) فريدمان، حين بار-ليف، لاعبتان في دوري الرُجبي للنساء، اتحاد الرياضة الأكاديميّ - التخنيون

مدّة الجولة: ساعة ونصف الساعة

 

We will walk through the Technion, Israel's Institute of Technology, will visit its sport's center, watch the bay's view and will get a chance to watch a Rugby game. We will discuss this game and its appeal to young students.

title: סיור בילדות רב-תרבותית //  Tour in Multi-cultural Childhood
longdescription:
הליכה בחליסה תחתונה, השכונה היהודית/ערבית שבה גדלתי, דרך לשכת הסעד, ביה"ס היסודי, גן הילדים, בית החרושת לקרח, בית הקולנוע השכונתי ועוד. חלק מהמבנים נהרסו, חלקם עומדים להריסה ואחרים עברו הסבה. במהלך הטיול נפגוש אנשי עסקים ותושבים, וותיקים וחדשים, נבדוק מי גר היום בשכונה ומה הקשר שלהם לתושבים משכבר הימים.

 

السير في الحليصة التحتا، الحيّ اليهوديّ/العربيّ الذي ترعرعتُ فيه، مرورًا بمكتب الرعاية الاجتماعيّة، المدرسة الابتدائيّة، روضة الأطفال، معمل الثلج، سينما الحيّ وغيرها. بعض المباني دُمِّر، وبعضها يتهدّده خطر الهدم، أما البعض الآخر فقد جرى تحويل غايته. خلال الجولة سنلتقي برجال أعمال وبمواطنين، من القدامى والجدد، وسنفحص مَن يسكن اليوم في الحيّ وما علاقتهم بالسكان القدامى.

 

نقطة الالتقاء: نتان ألباز 2، بجوار محطّة الشرطة، مفرق طريق بار يهودا ويروحام تسيزل

 

نقطة الختام: سوق هبشبشيم (سوق الخردوات)

title: הביתה, מהחנות של אבא //  Going Home from Father's Shop
longdescription:
סיור אוטוביוגרפי בחיפה דרך נקודות ציון בחיי. נתחיל במקום שהייתה החנות של אבי, לפני שנמכרה והפכה לחלק מבית קפה ידוע בעיר התחתית. משם  נעלה לשד' אליהו גולומב, שם ביליתי בנעורי ב"קן הדר" של הנוער העובד והלומד. בבגרותי חזרתי לאותו רחוב ממש, לבקר אצל אמי כשהייתה מתאשפזת בבי"ח בני ציון. הזדמנות ראשונה לדבר אנגלית "באמת" ניתנה לי כשנשלחתי ללוות תייר בריטי לרח' יפה נוף. משם למרכז הכרמל, עם בית קפה פאר וקולנוע אורלי. לבסוף הבית בשד' מוריה 23, שבו נולדתי וגדלתי, ושבו חיו הורי עד סוף חייהם. למצטרפים לסיור, שימו לב: מדובר בטיפוס מהעיר התחתית ועד

לכרמל!

 

جولة أوتوبيوغرافية عبر أماكن شكّلت محطات في حياتي. سنبدأ من المكان الذي كانت توجد فيه دكان أبي، قبل بيعها وتحوّلها إلى جزء من مقهى معروف في البلدة التحتا. ثم نصعد إلى شدروت إلياهو غولومب، حيث قضيت هناك فترة شبابي المبكرة في "عش الهدار"، في حركة الشبيبة العاملة والمتعلمة. في مرحلة البلوغ عدتُ إلى الشارع نفسه بسبب رقود أمي للعلاج في مستشفى "بني تسيون". وكذلك: فرصة أولى لتحدّث الإنجليزية "حقًّا"، عندما أرسلتُ لمرافقة سائح بريطانيّ حلّ ضيفًا في بيتنا، إلى شارع "يافيه نوف"؛ مركز الكرمل، مع مقهى بئير وسينما أورلي. والبيت في شدروت موريا 23، الذي وُلدتُ وترعرعتُ فيه، وعاش فيه والداي حتى آخر حياتهما. للمنضمّين إلى الجولة، انتبهوا: نحن نتحدّث عن جولة تصعد من البلدة التحتا حتى الكرمل!

title: In the Footsteps of Ikhtiyyah, Saraya and Manya // בעקבות אח'טיה סראיא ומניה. מכיכר העגלונים לשווקים שנעלמו ואינם
longdescription:
סיפורן של שלוש נשים הוא הקו שינחה את הסיור בשווקים ובסמטאות שנעלמו - אח'טיה וסַרַאיַא, בת השד הרע, גיבורות ספריו של אמיל חביבי, ומניה שוחט, כפי שהיא מצטיירת מעדויות של זאב וילנאי על ימי ילדותו בחיפה. סיפורן של הנשים יובא באמצעות תמונות, מפות ויומנים, וישולב בסיפור התהפוכות שעברו על העיר. ב"אֶחְ'טַיֶּה", (ספרו מ-1985) כותב חביבי: "את כיכר 'אל-ח'מרה' (היין) הפכו לכיכר פריס, כדי שלא ינדוף ממנה ריח של בארים מפוקפקים, ולא ידעו שאל-ח'מרה הוא שמה של משפחה ערביה ותיקה. אותה כיכר נקראה לפנים כיכר אל-חנאטיר, לאמור, כיכר הכרכרות, ואבותינו העגלונים נהגו ללעוג שם לכובעיהן של התיירות הזרות, כמין עציצים של פרחים מלאכותיים, וקראו להם 'כובעי פריס'".

 

قصّة ثلاث نساء هو المسار الذي يُوجّه الجولة في الأسواق والأزقة التي اختفت – إخطيّة وسرايا بنت الغول، وهما بطلتا روايتي إميل حبيبي، ومنية شوحط، كما توصف من خلال شهادات زئيف فيلنائي عن أيّام طفولته في حيفا. يتمّ عرض قصة النساء بالاستعانة بصور، خرائط ومفكّرات، وستُدمَج ضمن القصّة التقلّبات التي مرّت بها المدينة. يكتب إميل حبيبي في "إخطيّة"، (كتابه من سنة 1985) ما يلي: "لقد حوّلوا "ساحة الخمرة" إلى "ساحة باريس"، ظنًّا منهم بأنّ الاسم العريق - نسبة إلى عائلة الخَمرة العريقة - يعود إلى المُحرَّمات... لم يستطيعوا، لو يعلمون، الهروب منّا، فمنذ "ساحة الحناطير"، في الزّمان الأوّل، كان آباؤنا "العربنجيّة" يتندَّرون على قبّعات السّائحات الأجنبيّات، الفاقعة كأصص زهرٍ اصطناعيٍّ مُغبر: إنّها قبّعات فارسيّة".

 

نقطة الالتقاء: ساحة الحناطير

نقطة الختام: سوق هبشبشيم، جامع الاستقلال

مرشد الجولة: نفتالي شوشاني، مرشد ومركّز دورات المرشدين السياحيين في كليّة السياحة في جامعة حيفا 1992-2001

مدّة الجولة: نحو ساعتين

 

A walk in the pass of three women, in long gone alleys and markets. Ah'tih and Saraya, the heros of Emile Habibi's books, and Mania Shohat, as she appears in the testimonies of Zeev Vilnai. The stories of these women will be told through photos, maps and journals, and will be incorporated into the story of the city.

title: טבע עירוני //  Urban Nature
longdescription:
ההליכה תתמקד בטבע עירוני, הנסתר בדרך כלל מן העין, אך נוכח בכל מקום בכרמל, ומתגלה רק כאשר מתעכבים ומשהים עליו את המבט. הטיול יתמקד ברחוב איינשטיין, רחוב המייצג באופן נפלא את הטבע הגלוי והסמוי בכרמל, בין פינת חמד אחת לשנייה. בדרך נספר סיפורים, נקרא שירים על טבע נסתר וגלוי, ונתפעל מרחוב שמוקף ביער, וגם הוא עצמו מעין יער, מלא בעצי שסק, אורנים, שיחי לוטם, ציפורים ופרחים. נפגוש באמניות תושבות האזור - נטלי לוין , אנה לוקשבסקי, אנה פסטרנק, לידה שרת מסד, ונשמע מהן על הקשר לטבע, לסביבה, ולחיפה. 

ستتمحور المسيرة حول الطبيعة المدينية، الخفيّة عن العين عادةً، إلا أنها حاضرة في كلّ مكان في الكرمل تقريبًا، وتظهر عندما نتريّث ونديم النظر إليها فقط. ستجرى الجولة في شارع أينشطاين، وهو شارع يمثّل، بشكل رائع، الطبيعة الظاهرة والخفيّة في الكرمل، حيث سننتقل من ركن هادئ إلى آخر. في الطريق سنحكي قصصًا، نقرأ أشعارًا عن الطبيعة الظاهرة والخفيّة، وسنستمتع حتى الاندهاش بشارع محاط بغابة، وهو نفسه على شكل غابةٍ أيضًا، تنتشر فيه أشجار الإسكدنيا، الصنوبر، شجيرات اللاذن، الطيور والزهور. سنلتقي بفنّانات المدينة – نتالي ليفين، آنا لوكيشفسكي، آنا بسترناك، وليدا شاريت مساد، وسنستمع منهنّ عن علاقتهنّ بالطبيعة، بالبيئة وبحيفا.

 

نقطة الالتقاء: مدرسة أينشطاين (خطوط الباص 37، 24، 29)

title: בקרנות רחוב //  In Street Corners
longdescription:
את הסיור תוביל המשוטטת, ילידת חיפה, ותוך כדי הליכה יתרחשו פעולות איסוף, אגירה, אילום, אצירה, דחיסה, קיפול, קשירה, חיפוש, חיטוט, איתור, נבירה, פשפוש ועוד. במהלך הדרך תתמלא עגלת המשוטטת חפצים שנפלטו או נזרקו, יעלו לדיון נושאים כמו בית, אגירה, נדידה, חפצים, שוטטות, וגם יוצעו לקריאה טקסטים בנושאים עירוניים. נקודת הסיום תהיה לא רחוק ממקום הולדתה של המשוטטת, ליד בית חולים רוטשילד ושד' האו"ם, שהפכו לשד' הציונות. המשתתפים בסיור מוזמנים לקחת חלק פעיל בשוטטות וליזום פעולות או נושאים לשיחה. 

 

ستقود هذه الجولة المتجوّلة، وهي من مواليد حيفا، وخلال المسير سيتمّ القيام بعمليات مثل جمع، خزن، رزم، حفظ، ضغط، طيّ، ربط، بحث، سبر، كشف، نقب، تفحّص وغيرها. خلال الطريق ستمتلئ عربة المتجوّلة بالأغراض الملقاة أو المرميّة، وستُطرَح للنقاش مواضيع مثل البيت، الخزن، التنقل، الأغراض، التجوّل، كما ستُقترح نصوصٌ للقراءة حول مواضيع مدينيّة. نقطة الختام ستكون على مقربةٍ من مكان ولادة المتجوّلة، بجوار مستشفى روتشيلد وشارع الأمم، الذي أصبح شدروت هتسيونوت. ندعو المشاركين في الجولة إلى المساهمة بشكلٍ فعّال في التجوّل والمبادرة إلى خطوات أو إلى طرح مواضيع للحوار.

 

 

نقطة الالتقاء: يافا، مقابل محطّة القطار هشمونا

نقطة الختام: شبتاي ليفي 26، متحف حيفا للفنون

title: אורה מורג מספרת סיפורי מתח //  Ora Morag Tells Thrillers
longdescription:
סיור בעקבות סדרת ספרי המתח ההיסטורית על שם טוביה מורג מאת אורה מורג, ילידת חיפה. ההליכה תתנהל בין הקזינו לבריכת השחייה הישנה, בין שיכון חיילים משוחררים לטחנת הקמח של הטמפלרים (העליה 22), ותסתיים במנזר שבבית החולים רמב"ם. לאורך הדרך תספר מורג קטעים מספריה המוכרים המתרחשים בתקופת מלחמת העולם השנייה ואחריה - "המרגל שבא מן הים", "הפנים שפרצו מן הדף", "החטיפה מן המנזר". בקזינו מובטחת הדגמה של שליחת שדר מורס! מוזמנים לסיור תושבי חיפה וכמובן קוראי הסדרה הצעירים, עם הוריהם והורי הוריהם. ניתן יהיה לרכוש  ספרים בחתימת הסופרת.

 

 

جولة في أعقاب سلسلة كتب الإثارة التاريخيّة على اسم طوفيا موراغ التي كتبتها أورا موراغ، من مواليد حيفا. المسيرة ستبدأ بين الكازينو وبركة السباحة القديمة، بين بناية الجنود المسرّحين ومطحنة القمح التابعة للتمبلريين (هعلياه 22)، وستنتهي في الدير الكائن في مستشفى رمبام. على امتداد الطريق ستروي موراغ مقاطع من قصصها المعروفة التي تجري أحداثها في فترة الحرب العالمية الثانية وما بعدها – "الجاسوس القادم من البحر"، "الوجه الذي اندفع من الصفحة"، "عملية اختطاف من الدير". في الكازينو سيتمّ تجسيد إرسال رسالة إلى مورس! ندعو سكان حيفا إلى الجولة، وبالطبع قرّاء السلسلة الشباب، مع أهاليهم وأجدادهم. كذلك، في الإمكان شراء الكتب موسومة بتوقيع الكاتبة.

 

 

نقطة الالتقاء: الكازينو في بات جليم

نقطة الختام: مستشفى رمبام

مُرشدة الجولة: أورا موراغ، كاتبة أطفال وشبيبة

مدّة الجولة: نحو ساعة ونصف الساعة

title: הליכה נסרגת // Knitting a Walk
longdescription:
קיבוצניקית לשעבר, לבושה בשמלת קטיפה ובסמרטוטים, תוביל את הקהל, בעזרת גלילי צמר אדומים ומסרגה, לסיור בהדר. הנה התחנות, לפי סדר ביוגרפי: כאן ירדתי מהאוטובוס, כאן ראיתי את "חלף עם הרוח", כאן הפכתי קפה הפוך... שרוך ייסרג לאורך הדרך, הקהל יחזיק בו וילך בעקבותיו, ולמעשה בעקבות מובילת הסיור - מי שהייתה, מי שהייתה רוצה להיות. המשתתפים יוכלו גם הם לרקום או לסרוג ולהוסיף זיכרונות משלהם לדרך המתפתלת, או לשמלתה של זו ההולכת לפניהם. היא מבטיחה: נלך, נשיר, נרקום, נסרוג, נשאיר סימני דרך. לפעמים במילים, לפעמים בפעולות.

عضوة كيبوتس سابقًا، ترتدي فستانًا مخمليًّا وخرقًا، ستقود الجمهور، بمساعدة لفائف صوف حمراء وإبرة، إلى جولة في الهدار. وها هي المحطّات، حسب الترتيب البيوغرافيّ: هنا نزلتُ من الباص، هنا شاهدت "ذهب مع الريح"، هنا سكبت قهوة بالحليب... الحبل يُحاك على امتداد الطريق، الجمهور يمسك به ويسير في أعقابه، وفي أعقاب قائدة الجولة – من كانت، مَن كانت تريد أن تكون. يستطيع المشاركون أيضًا أن ينسجوا أو يُحيكوا مُضيفين ذكريات منهم للطريق الملتوية، أو لفستان تلك السائرة أمامهم. إنها تؤكّد: نمشي، نغني، نطرّز، نحوك، نترك علامات في الطريق. أحيانًا بالكلمات، وأحيانًا أخرى بالنشاطات.

 

نقطة الالتقاء: هحلوتس زاوية هنفيئيم

 

نقطة الختام: هرتسليا، محطات الباص

مرشدة الجولة: هداس غرطمان، فنانة معروضات، خيّاطة، عضوة كيبوتس في المدينة الكبيرة

مدّة الجولة: نحو ساعة

title: רחל המשוררת בחיפה // Rachel the Poet in Haifa
longdescription:
ב-1910-1911 עבדה רחל המשוררת, אז בת עשרים, בחווה חקלאית של האגרונום החלוץ, אליהו בלומנפלד. היא הגיעה לשם בעקבות המדריכה החקלאית הנודעת, חנה מייזל. בסיור אספר את סיפורן של שלוש דמויות אלה בחיפה, וגם על חלוצי העלייה השנייה האחרים בעיר. אקרא קטעי זיכרונות ועדויות מאותם ימים, וכמובן את שירה של רחל "גַּנֵּנוּ", שנכתב על תקופה זו: אַתְּ זוֹכֶרֶת?  אָבִיב וּבֹקֶר  /  (הָאָבִיב, הַבֹּקֶר – אַיָּם?) / לְרַגְלֵי הַכַּרְמֶל – גַּנֵּנוּ, / וּמִנֶּגֶד לוֹ – כֹּחַל-הַיָּם.

عملت الشاعرة راحيل خلال العامين 1910-1911، وكانت في العشرين من عمرها حينذاك، في مزرعة المهندس الزراعيّ الطليعيّ، إلياهو بلومنفيلد. وقد وصلت إلى هناك في أعقاب المرشدة الزراعيّة المعروفة، حانه مايزل. سأحكي لكم في الجولة قصّة هؤلاء الشخصيات الثلاث في حيفا، كما سأحكي لكم عن طلائعيي الهجرة الثانية الآخرين في المدينة. سأقرأ مقاطع من الذكريات والشهادات عن تلك الأيام، وبالطبع سأقرأ لكم قصيدة راحيل "حديقتنا"، التي كتبتها عن هذه الحقبة من الزمن: هل تذكرين؟ ربيع وصباح / (الربيع، الصباح – رهيب؟) / عند أقدام الكرمل – حديقتنا، / وقبالته – زرقة البحر.

title: וההווה הפמיניסטי של חיפה // Feminism in Haifa - Past and Present
longdescription:
חיפה הייתה ערש הולדתה של התנועה הפמיניסטית בארץ, בשנות ה-70, והסיור יוקדש להיסטוריה של הפעילות הפמיניסטית בעיר. נקודת המוצא היא ליד קפה כרמל לשעבר, במרכז הכרמל, מקום מפגשן של הפמיניסטיות דאז: מרשה פרידמן (ח"כ לשעבר), נעמי נמרוד (חיפאית ותיקה), ורבות אחרות שישבו שם ומכרו את העיתון נלח"ם. משם ימשיך הסיור לבית משכנו של "קול האישה", הארגון הפמיניסטי של שנות ה-70, תוך כדי דיון במצב הנשים, אז והיום. דרך שביל החמורים יגיעו ההולכים לרח' ארלוזורוב 118, לבית של "אשה לאשה", הארגון הפמיניסטי החוגג 30 שנה להיווסדו. מיטיבי/ות לכת וסקרנים/יות מוזמנים להמשיך לבית הקרנות, למקום שבו "נשים בשחור" עמדו במשך למעלה מעשר שנים, מידי יום שישי, במחאה נגד הכיבוש.

 

 

كانت حيفا مهد ولادة الحركة النسويّة في البلاد، خلال سنوات السبعين، وسيتمّ تخصيص هذه الجولة لتاريخ النشاط النسويّ في المدينة. نقطة الانطلاق هي قرب مقهى الكرمل سابقًا، في مركز الكرمل، وهو مكان التقاء النسويّات حينها: مارشه فريدمان (عضوة كنيست سابقًا)، نوعمي نمرود (حيفاوية عريقة)، ونساء آخريات كثيرات جلسنَ هنا وقمن بتوزيع وبيع جريدة "نلحام". من هناك تتواصل الجولة حتى مقرّ "صوت المرأة"، المنظمة النسويّة التي نشطت خلال السبعينات، ويتخلّل المسيرة نقاش حول وضع المرأة، في ذلك الوقت واليوم. ثمّ يبلغ المشاة عبر "شفيل هحموريم" إلى شارع أرلوزوروف 118، وهو عنوان مقرّ جمعية "المرأة للمرأة" النسوية التي تحتفي هذا العام بمرور 30 عامًا على تأسيسها. هواة المشي والفضوليّون/ات مدعوّون/ات إلى مواصلة المسيرة حتى "بيت هكرنوت"، وهو المكان الذي تظاهرت فيه عضوات "نساء بالسواد" كلّ يوم جمعة، على مدى أكثر من عشر سنوات، ضدّ استمرار الاحتلال.

 

 

نقطة الالتقاء: هنسي زاوية إلحنان، بجوار بسطة الجرائد جولدن. القطار الأرضي-الكرمليت، خطوط الباصات 37، 28، 133، 123

مدة الجولة: ساعتان

title: Uptown Waterloo Rainbow Walk
shortdescription:
Have you ever wondered how members of the rainbow community view Uptown Waterloo? Join Jeremy Steffler, Lana Phillips, and Michelle Marée for an informative walk of Uptown Waterloo from the perspective of the Rainbow (e.g., lesbian, gay, bisexual, trans, queer, questioning, and allies) community. 

Sponsored by the Waterloo Region Rainbow Coalition and the Wednesday Night Discussion Group.
longdescription:
The Rainbow Walk will focus on viewing Uptown Waterloo from the perspective of the Rainbow – lesbian, gay, bisexual, trans, queer, questioning, and ally – community!  We will be highlighting rainbow-friendly businesses, local history, and personal stories and experiences.

Join Jeremy Steffler, Lana Phillips, and Michelle Marée for an informative walk of Uptown Waterloo based on their unique perspectives on the Rainbow community.

Sponsored by the Waterloo Region Rainbow Coalition (www.yourwrrc.ca) and the Wednesday Night Discussion Group (www.wndg.ca).

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Corner of Bridgeport and Regina (Near Old Waterloo Post Office Parking Lot).

team.name-first: Michelle Marée, Lana Phillips, and Jeremy Steffler
team.bio:
Jeremy is a lifelong resident of Waterloo who has been recognized for his efforts in supporting the local Rainbow Community. Jeremy has been the lead faciliator of the Wednesday Night Discussion Group for over 10 years, is a board member of the Waterloo Region Rainbow Coalition, and offers workshops on sexual orientation and gender identity in the workplace. Jeremy is looking forward to sharing many of the stories he has heard from members of the Rainbow Community over the years as they related to the establishments that will be visited during the Jane's walk! For more information on Jeremy, visit ca.linkedin.com/in/jeremysteffler.
Lana is an Uptown resident and member of the queer community who spends her days building communities as an urban planner.   Through her work and world travel experience she's grown a passion for exploring communities - the places and people.  She's excited for participating in the Jane Walk to engage with members of the community and open them to an Uptown they may not have seen before.  For a glimpse of other places and people you can check out her travel blog enroutetoanywhere.wordpress.com.
Michelle is a twenty-year community member, who has walked every inch of the UpTown area and remembers when there was a playground opposite the mall, dominated by a giant ABBA mural. When the UpTown Parkade was a hole in the ground, when the KW Little Theatre burned down, and when Waterloo Town Square had a basement pet shop. Michelle looks forward to adding her colourful perspective to the Rainbow Walk.

accessible-info: We will be using public sidewalks.
accessible-transit: On Route 35 and 7
accessible-parking: Parking is available on street and in Public Lots near location (Note: No parking at meeting locaton)
accessible-find: The facilitators will be decked out in Rainbow paraphernalia!

title: צעדים באפלה - מסע אל מתחת לכביש המהיר
shortdescription:
נפגש בשער יפו, נהיה קבוצה קטנה של אנשים מכל רחבי העיר שלא מכירים זה את זה. 
כל אחד יגיד את שמו וזו אולי תהיה האמת היחידה שתשמעו במהלך הסיור. כל השאר - בדיות, סיפורים ורכילות היסטורית, אותה ימציאו המשתתפים והמדריכים. נעבור דלת סודית המובילה אל מעיין נעורים, אל בית מרחץ שנשכח לצידה של דרך שכבר אינה מובילה לשום מקום, ואל אפלה בצל שאון הכביש המהיר. נשב בחושך ונרגיש את הזמן מטפטף מבעד לתקרת הבטון. חובה להגיע בנעליים סגורות ולהצטייד בפנס
כשנסיים, נחזור אל הרחבה של שער יפו - עם חיוך קטן של סוד השמור ליודעי דבר.

אמיר חרש (סופר ומספר סיפורים),

title: Take a Walk on the Wild Side—Wreck Beach
shortdescription: Wreck Beach is Metro Vancouver’s internationally-acclaimed clothing-optional beach. Yet, the beach was famous long before it became part of Pacific Spirit Regional Park.
longdescription:
Photo by James Loewen / 2005 ©

The walk takes participants through an ethnobotanical, natural history, historical, geological and political history of the beach and foreshore.

Learn how both native Musqueam and early pioneers used plants to survive, for medical purposes, and for fishing. Check out the resident and migratory birds, history of naturism, various animals and local threats to the integrity of the beach itself.

We must start early at 10 a.m. because of the tides which become 11.6 feet by 2:30 p.m.. Bring water and a light lunch as we will be stopping along the way!

A free t-shirt will be given to the person who answers the most questions correctly after the hike.

Walkers will encounter challenging terrain, including steep trails with uneven and slippery surface, so please wear sturdy shoes to protect your ankles. Walking sticks might be useful, too!

(Please note this is a clothing optional beach, and nudity may be encountered, rain or shine).

title: Hubbard Farms
shortdescription: A walking tour of the Hubbard Farms national historic district, charting its progress from ribbon farms to present day.
longdescription: A tour through the old neighborhoods re-living that area of Springwells Township at the edge of the City of Detroit, Michigan and now known as Hubbard Farms near Mexicantown at the Far Eastern edge of Southwest Detroit between Clark Park and the Western Boulevard with maps and features of interest from 1837 to present.

A lifelong detroit area resident and city dweller since 1988 (on and off, mostly on) he now lives 1/4" mile from the Detroit River in an historic and magical neighborhood whose recorded history goes back to the earliest days of the city's founding in 1701. Since 2008 he's dedicated many long days to uncovering that history.

title: A short walk of Historical Galt
shortdescription: A 2.5 hr. walk back in time
longdescription:
We will explore the history, built and natural heritage of downtown Galt. The walk will demonstrate the beauty of safe, walkable neighbours established in the mid 1800’s and end with an opportunity to walk the Trinity Park Labyrinth in Trinity Park on World Labyrinth Day at 1:00 p.m.

Stops along the walk include Queen's Square, West Galt, Dunfield Theatre, the Cambridge Sculpture Garden, the School of Architecture, the Farmers Market, Cambridge City Hall, 28/30 Colborne Street, Mill Race Park, Cambridge Mill, Park Hill Dam and back to Trinity Park. Bring your walking shoes and your curiosity!

title: Not Your Typical Regent Park Walk
shortdescription: Approaches designed to transform communities like Regent Park tend to focus on outside interventions such as funding, planning processes, policing and the delivery of social services. But what about the incredible capacity, creativity and resilience of residents who contribute to their communities?
longdescription:
Approaches designed to transform communities like RegentParktend to focus on outside interventions such as funding, planning processes, policing and the delivery of social services. But what about the incredible capacity, creativity and resilience of residents who contribute to their communities? Not Your Typical Regent Park Walk will not replicate past tours, which place an over emphasis on fancy new tenants or the community’s challenges with poverty and violence. Instead, the tour will introduce walk participants to unsung local heroes who Jane Jacobs, if she were with us, would describe as “people capable of understanding and acting upon their own self-interest”.

In addition to shining a light on the capacity of local residents and reframing Toronto’s negative “public housing” narrative; this walk is unique because it isn’t narrowly focused on interesting historical buildings, urban planning or the natural environment. The Not Your Typical Regent Park Walk also takes social issues, the capacity of everyday people and the on-going and messy process of community-building into account. By breaking out of the conventional “walk leader” paradigm and creating space for a diverse range of voices, embracing creativity and asking critical questions about collective community building, the Not Your Typical Regent Park Walk gets to the heart of healthy neighbourhoods while facilitating the “challenging conversations” that Jane Jacobs, a true urban activist, dared to ignite.

Join us at 11:00a.m. sharp in front of Tim Hortons located at Parliament andDundas.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: The Tim Hortons at Dundas St. East and Parliament St.

team.name-first: Jay Pitter, LAL and some of the awesome members of the Regent Park community!
team.bio:
Jay Pitter is a senior communications specialist, writer and narratologist. From the onset of her career Jay was not only interested in developing stories; she was passionate about gaining deep knowledge of narrative as a communicative mode, data, art form, economy, social phenomenon and discourse. This passion led Jay down a gratifying career path working in leadership roles such as Arts Curriculum Writer with the Toronto District School Board, Provincial Grants Officer with the Ontario Arts Council, Director of Communications with DIALOG a premier national architectural firm and a Contributing Columnist with CBC RadioCanada. As a mature student, Jay returned to university to complete graduate research in Narrative Theory and Methodology and now seizes opportunities to contribute to academic and community discourse on narratology and narrative inquiry. She has been a guest lecturer at OISIE, the University of York University, CentennialCollege, Seneca College and other educational institutions. Her writing credits include the Walrus, Toronto Star, Fireweed, Climate Change; Who’s Carrying the Burden and Spacing Magazine. Having grown up in a public housing community, Jay is particularly passionate about shining a light on the incredible capacity of individuals living in TCHC communities likeRegentParkand working with community members to share new stories which exemplify local innovation, kindness and hope.

Formed in 1998 by the dynamic duo of poet, lyricist, activist, singer and Bengali-rooted tough-guy Rosina Kazi and her life partner, producer, sound designer, philosopher, aphorismist and Barbados-born king of chill, Nicholas Murray, LAL has always proved hard to describe. Their musical experience is wide with Murr having been a member of the seminal hip hop collective, da Grass Roots and designed sound for theatre and film and Rosina , a cultural worker who fuses art and social justice. They’re a band, but not only a band - they're a music making magical mushroom, the visible flowering part of a much larger organism, connected with very fine but infinitely resilient roots.
We can talk about LAL’s music using words that eventually abandon us: electronica, trip-hop (remember that?), electronic soul, jazz, pop, protest music, justice jams, downtempo beats, lounge, funk, world, multcult, etc etc. Or we can talk about HOW they make music, How they live their lives, how they run their music-making firm and how the line we draw around. LAL takes the long view, they’re in it for the long haul, obsessed with making music but more obsessed with using the making of music as a way to materialize ways of being together, fostering a sharing of resources, ideas and, at bottom, maintaining a tenacious hope that persists despite the frightening world we live in.

title: Back Side for your Backside
shortdescription: Back Side for your Backside is an accessible fitness walk behind buildings on the west side of Front Street. The discussion themes of the walk include the past, present and future of downtown Belleville’s ‘back side’ and participants are encouraged to share their own stories, memories and ideas. Throughout the walk there will be variety of fitness stops that will be easily adapted for all ages and fitness levels.  The walk and workout will be led by three 20-something Bellevillians: fitness expert Ashton Calnan, Hannah Chittenden, geologist, and Sarah Tummon, BDIA executive director.
longdescription: Back Side for your Backside is an accessible fitness walk behind buildings on the west side of Front Street. The discussion themes of the walk include the past, present and future of downtown Belleville’s ‘back side’ and participants are encouraged to share their own stories, memories and ideas. Throughout the walk there will be variety of fitness stops that will be easily adapted for all ages and fitness levels.  The walk and workout will be led by three 20-something Bellevillians: fitness expert Ashton Calnan, Hannah Chittenden, geologist, and Sarah Tummon, BDIA executive director. Meet them at the Four Corners Saturday, May 4 at 10:30 and then head off to Front Street’s back side, along the Moira.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Century Place (At corner of Bridge and Front Streets)

team.name-first: Ashton Calnan, Hannah Chittenden and Sarah Tummon
team.bio:
Ashton Calnan is the owner/operator of The Right Fit Inc. and is very passionate about helping people change their lives through diet and exercise. With an Honours BSc in Human Kinetics, a certified Personal Trainer & Kinesiologist and extensive experience in athletic therapy, Ashton has the knowledge and background you can trust. As a downtown business owner and a fitness lover, Ashton will demonstrate how we can balance work and exercise in our own downtown.
Hannah Chittenden has her Honours BSc from McMaster University and has recently completed her MSc in Geology from the University of Bern in Switzerland. With an appetite for the outdoors and geology as well as experience working as a tour guide in Germany and the Rockies, Hannah will show you why the backside of Belleville rocks.
Sarah Tummon is the Executive Director for the Belleville Downtown Improvement area (BDIA). As the ambassador for the BDIA, Sarah is passionate about downtown Belleville’s future and revitalization. Sarah will assist in guiding downtown to great things. Listen as Sarah describes where downtown Belleville is headed in the “back side for your backside” walk.

chittenden@gmx.com
executivedirector@downtownbelleville.ca

title: Harvie Passage
shortdescription: Learn about the transformation of the Calgary weir into a safer and more attractive natural area for paddlers, fish, and wildlife
longdescription:
Built in 1908 to divert water to the Western Irrigation District, the Calgary weir remains an important source of water for southern Alberta residents, farmers and industry. The strong undertow of the original design made the area dangerous for boaters and recreation users.

Improvements began in 2009 as a partnership project of Parks Foundation Calgary, The Calgary Foundation, the City of Calgary and the Government of Alberta. The area has since been renamed the Harvie Passage to recognize the significant contributions and efforts of the Harvie family to improve safety and create a continuous passage for recreational users.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Pearce Estate Park, north end of 17 A St SE

team.bio: Howard Heffler is “mostly” retired after about 40 years as an environmental manager in the oil patch in Calgary. Most of Howard’s interests are focused on the outdoors; canoeing, back-country skiing, hiking, and birding. He is a Director of RiverWatch and active with Nature Calgary, Bow Waters Canoe Club and several conservation initiatives. In March, 2000 he had the dream to transform the deadly weir across the Bow River into a safe and attractive rapid that allows downstream passage by recreational paddlers. Now, 13 years later, with the help of many people and organizations, the dream is a reality.

accessible-info: There's some rough ground so not advisable for wheelchair use
accessible-transit: Bus route 1 and 305. Or cycle along the lovely bike path.
accessible-parking: Parking lot at Pearce Estate Park

title: Introducing the exceptional Taylor Massey neighbourhood!
shortdescription: Formerly known as Crescent Town, Taylor Massey is one of the City of Toronto's thirteen priority neighbourhoods. Local residents from five of the main communities - Teesdale, Crescent Town, Dawes Rd., Lumsden & Secord - that make up this vibrant neighbourhood will share their stories, favorite places, and hopes for the future of the neighbourhood!
longdescription:
Come out and join the local residents, ANC,  and other agencies of the Taylor Massey Neighbourhood (formerly known as Crescent Town Priority Neighbourhood) for a Jane's Walk that will lead you through  5 communities within one neighbourhood: Teesdale, Crescent Town, Dawes  Road, Lumsden & Secord.

There will be 12 major stops on this wonderful walk with lots of  conversation during the actual walk itself.

During this walk you will hear from local residents of various ages and ethnicities, as well as some agency staff about all the wonderful things happening in this beautiful neighbourhood.

The 12 stops are as follows:

Stop 1: Begining of walk - 40 Teesdale Place (10:30am) 

Stop 2: Denton at Victoria Park subway (approximately 10:45am - 10:50am) 

Stop 3: Crescent Town - in front of Hasty Market - 1 The Market Place- Crescent Town (approximately 11:05am - 11:10am)

Stop 4: Children's Peace Theatre - Massey Goulding Estate - 305 Dawes Rd. (approximately 11:25am - 11:45am) bathroom break.


Stop 5:  Joshua Crockwright Parkette - 500 Dawes Rd. (approximately 11:55am - 12:00pm)

Stop 6: 10 Gower Street - Dawes Rd. and Gower St. (approximately 12:10pm - 12:25pm) bathroom break

Stop 7: Taylor Creek Park - Between Halsey Ave. and Lumsden Ave. foot paths located in the park (approximately 12:35pm - 12:45pm)

Stop 8: 444 Lumsden Ave - Lumsden Ave and Barrington Ave (approximately 12:50pm - 12:55pm)

Stop 9: 2 Secord Ave. - Secord Ave and Barrinton Ave. (approximately 1:05pm - 1:10pm) bathroom break (Secord C.C. - 91 Barrington)

Stop 10: Dentonia Park - 80 Thyra Ave (approximatley 1:25pm - 1:30pm)

Stop 11: 3036 Danforth Ave - Neighbourhood Link Support Services (approximately 1:45pm - 1:50pm)

Stop 12: Final Stop- 3079 Danforth Ave - Access Point on Danforth - United Way Toronto funded Community Hub.

 Meet the people, hear about all the resident-led projects,  learn the history of the neighbourhood, see the green space, hear about the programs and services offered, see the Massey Goulding Estate, visit  the United Way Funded Community Hub - Access Point on Danforth and hear about all the amazing work being done in this beautifully diverse neighbourhood. 

This is one walk you don't want to miss.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: 40 Teesdale Place - in front of lobby.

team.name-first: Taylor Massey Residents and the local Action for Neighbourhood Change (ANC)
team.bio:
This walk is being led by a group of local Residents with the support of the Taylor Massey ANC.
The Residents who have helped organize and lead this walk are part of the Taylor Massey Neighbourhood Association and / or one of several other local resident groups that are supported by ANC such as Teesdale Pro-Action Neighbourhood Association, Dawes Road Community Network, BELS Neighbourhood Association, as well as youth from various youth groups within the Taylor Massey Neighbourhood.
 ANC is a key component of United Way Toronto's Building Strong Neighbourhood Strategy.  ANC is a community development and a resident engagement initiative that aims to engage, organize, and build the leadership capacity of residents to create a vision for their community, set priorities, and develop action plans and implementation strategies to improve the conditions of their neighbourhood.

accessible-info: The main route is not accessible to all, but there is a secondary route that will be led by a local resident.
accessible-transit: Victoria Park Subway Station - exit at east end of west bound platform, for those using mobility devices please take 67 Pharmacy bus from the bus platform to Teesdale Place stop.
accessible-parking: Parking can be an issue.  We recommend that you take TTC.  If you come by car you will need to park in the TTC parking lot located at Victoria Park Subway Station.

title: BIG STREETS create SMALL VILLAGES
shortdescription: Join local city councillor Adam Vaughan for a walk along, in and around Bloor Street in the heart of the neighbourhood that Jane Jacob's called home. A look at how neighbourhoods, while they may dance along major streets, sing most beautifully when side streets and secret spaces are part of the performance too. This walk will look at what makes this part of Toronto so celebrated. Where the strengths lie, where the challenges are and possibilities lurk to make the community even more spectacular.
longdescription:
In, around and beyond Bloor - a walk through Jane's neighbourhood.

Join local city councillor Adam Vaughan for a walk along, in and around Bloor Street in the heart of the neighbourhood that Jane Jacob's called home. A look at how neighbourhoods, while they may dance along major streets, sing most beautifully when side streets and secret spaces are part of the performance too. This walk will look at what makes this part of Toronto so celebrated. Where the strengths lie, where the challenges are and possibilities lurk to make the community even more spectacular.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Ed & Anne Mirvish Park, 843 Bathurst Street, just north of Bathurst Subway Station entrance.

team.bio:
Adam Vaughan is serving his second term as the Toronto City Councillor for Ward 20, Trinity-Spadina.  Vaughan is successfully championing innovative public policy initiatives to create more family-sized housing, new arts space and affordable housing. Vaughan's approach to development and community engagement is reforming the City's planning process, which includes early community consultation for development proposals - an idea which has been widely praised for its effectiveness. 

As part of Vaughan's responsibilities as Councillor he also serves as a member of the Toronto East York Community Council, Planning and Growth Management Committee, as Chair of the Disability Issues Committee, and as a board member for the Toronto Preservation Board, The Art Gallery of Ontario, Harbourfront Centre, and a host of other community-based agencies. 
Councillor Vaughan has led a Jane’s Walk in Ward 20 every year since the inception of the events, in Kensington & Alexandra Park (2007),  Queen St W (2008),  Richmond & Adelaide Two-Way (2009), John Street Cultural Corridor (2010),  CityPlace (2011) and “You can’t do that at City Hall!” (2012).

accessible-transit: Bathurst Subway Station.
accessible-parking: There is limited on-street parking available nearby.

title: Wild Scarborough
shortdescription: Bring your hiking boots for this rough and ready walking tour of north-east Scarborough where the Rouge River, Toronto Zoo and Malvern community all intersect. Led by local community organizers. Lions and tigers and bears, oh my!
longdescription: Growing up next door to Rouge Park and Toronto Zoo you heard lots of stories about escaped animals - wild beasts that roared and howled and roamed the ravine. We were afraid to go down into the ravine. But that's exactly where we're headed on this walk to take a closer look at what's down there. There will be some surprises but we'll definitely see some crumbling informal structures, the abandoned zoo monorail and maybe, if we're lucky, a close up on a few bison or Malvern's own family of albino racoons. Join us on a tour of the neighbourhood where myth and mystery mingle with neighbourhood geography, farming roots and exciting community projects.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Old Finch Avenue & Morningview Trail

team.bio: Alex Dow has been a resident in Malvern since 1989, growing up in the Morningside/Finch area of north-east Scarborough.  He has been a local community activist and advocate through his role managing United Way's Action for Neighbourhood Change project in the community for the last 4 years.  Join him and other residents as we share our stories and a bit of local history on everything from the neighbourhood's pastoral past and it's future.  The walk will be joined by monorail history buff and Scarborough resident Richard White.

accessible-transit: Nugget 131 from Scarborough Town Centre
accessible-parking: Side of road, adjacent residential streets

title: The Forever Fierce, Queer Newcomer Youth does Jane's Walk 2013!
shortdescription: Youth from the Express program at SOY (Supporting Our Youth) will be showcasing their paths throughout the queer community and its immediate surroundings. Funny stories of love, adventure and friendships will be shared in fierce royal blue colours!
longdescription:
The fierce walk of  the newcomer queer youth begins at the Aids Memorial (The 519 Church Street Community Centre), where experiences of friendship have built emotional support and friendships. Next, we shall be walking south along Church Street,  where many club scenes and coffee places have been the scene of funny stories! Then, we will be going along Carlton Street until we reach our final destination: the Sherbourne Health Centre, where Supporting Our Youth is held and celebrated throughout the year. Indeed, our walk can give you a glimpse of the many activities that capture the queer newcomer young hearts.

Special guest: The Queer App project, which is currently developing an iphone app for the guidance of  various visitors, tourists, and citizens in attending events during PRIDE WEEK. Is not that the best idea ever?! So, expect those cameras to be rolling! Bring your fiercest royal blue attire, hats, make up, and/or flags!

Celebrate your culture with us!

Everyone is welcome!

Supporting Our Youth (SOY) is a dynamic community development program designed to improve the lives of LGBT youth in Toronto.  SOY's goal is to create healthy and inclusive spaces that help provide supportive housing and employment opportunities.

Express support group is part of the  SOY pogram,  specifically heald for queer newcomer youth in need of settlement services, recreation, and legal advice. The drop-in service is on a weekely basis, every Tuesday from 6pm-8pm.

For more information visit: www.soytoronto.org

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Aids Memorial - In the park behind the 519 Church Street Community Centre

team.bio:
Julian A. Perez-Duerto is an active participant of the SOY program. He was born and raised in Caracas-Venezuela, the country from which he immigrated in 2005 to live in Canada. At the age of twenty four, he proudly came out as both queer and trans, a time where his volunteer role within the queer community began to open the doors for networking, friendship and even job opportunities.
Julian is a now a York University student, completing his 3rd year level in the Gender and Women's Studies Honors program. Also, he helds a career as a Registered Early Childhood Educator, a position that has been enriched by the queer community and York University's feminist courses.

accessible-info: Unfortunately, we do not have ASL interpretation.
accessible-transit: The 519 building is located one block east of Yonge Street, just north of Wellesley, on Church Street.
accessible-parking: There is a Green P in front of Wellesley Subway Station (at Wellesley Street and Yonge St).
accessible-find:
The group will be wearing royal blue t-shirts. 
Please go to the back of The 519 building, to join us at the Aids Memorial.

title: Steeles L'Amoreaux Jane's Walk
shortdescription: Join us, the residents of Steeles L'Amoreaux, as we walk and talk about strengthening unity in our communities through resident-led initiatives, Arts Starts, and the new United Way-funded Community Hub!
longdescription:
Join the residents of Steeles L'Amoreaux on our annual walk as we talk about unity in our communities.  Let's celebrate who we are and work together to plan what's to come!

This walk is organized by the residents of the  Steeles L'Amoreaux Neighbourhood Association with support from Steeles L'Amoreaux Action for Neighbourhood Change (ANC) and Art Starts.

Learn about all the exciting things that are happening in our communities.  Hear from many residents of all ages and ethnicities in regards to resident-led initiatives, programs & services being led by local residents and those being offered by Art Starts and other organizations.  You will also hear  plans for a United Way funded Community Hub, and so much more.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: 2821 Birchmount Rd. at the Basketball Court (south side of the building)

team.name-first: Steeles L'Amoreaux Residents (with support from ANC and Art Starts)
team.bio: This walk is and has been organized by residents (since 2009) who are members of the Steeles L'Amoreaux Neighbourhood Association.  This group is supported by the local Action for Neighbourhood Change (ANC)

accessible-transit: From Warden Station you take 17 Birchmount bus to Finch and walk south.  From Finch Station you can take 39 Finch East bus and get off at Birchmount and Finch and cross the lights on the east south side and walk to basketball court.
accessible-parking: Paid parking is available.

title: Take a Walk on the Wild Side! Discovery Ridge
shortdescription: This family-friendly walk will introduce you to one of Calgary's hidden gems: Griffith Woods Park along the beautiful Elbow River
longdescription:
Come and explore Calgary’s best kept secret, a wilderness adventure at Griffith Woods Park.  Located along the banks of the Elbow River in the southwest part of the city, this park offers a great natural escape from the hustle and bustle of the city.  This is a family friendly walk.

http://www.calgary.ca/CSPS/Parks/Pages/Locations/SW-parks/Griffith-Woods.aspx

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: At the trailhead to Griffith Woods Park at the end of Discovery Ridge Link SW.  At the parking lot by the sign and public restroom.

team.bio: Anne-Marie is a former naturalist and nature nut!  She has a passion for wilderness areas and is happy to share stories and quirky knowledge about local plants and animals.

accessible-info: The walk is flat, with no hills, but the terrain is uneven & wheelchairs and strollers are not recommended. Dogs on leash are welcome.
accessible-transit: Routes 439 or 454.  Bus stop at Discovery Ridge Link SW.
accessible-parking: Parking lot at park's entrance

title: Wild Silver Springs
shortdescription: A tour to delight and inspire gardeners, nature-lovers, and anyone who loves to spend time beside the majestic Bow River.
longdescription:
Starting from the community centre, we will walk to Bowmont Park, one of Calgary’s largest natural areas stretching for more than 4 kms along the north bank of the Bow River. The area has various types of wildflowers and an abundance of wildlife including mammals, birds, amphibians and reptiles. We will walk along the ridge and discuss natural habitat, off-leash dog areas, interest groups that enjoy the area, and preservation.

We will then travel to the Birthplace Forest to stroll through the pathways of 7,000 trees each representing a Calgary newborn.

As we continue we will be amazed by various gardens and get excited to see the spring growth in the Botanical Gardens.  http://www.botanicalgardensofsilversprings.ca/

AND we'll visit Calgary’s newest garden labyrinth. The 11 circuit Traditional Labyrinth is 1300 feet in length from the start to the centre, and is constructed with 6000 paver bricks.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Silver Springs Community Centre, 5720 Silver Ridge Dr NW

team.bio:
Judi Vandenbrink is passionate about preserving special places in Calgary like Bowmont Park. She has a degree in ecology and will talk about the flora and fauna in the park as well of some of the challenges the area is dealing with.
Duncan Badger is one of three Directors who manage the Birthplace Forest and Botanical Gardens. He has been continuously involved in upgrading the area since before the Birthplace Forest was established and has a strong connection to this special area.

accessible-info: City streets & sidewalks
accessible-transit: From Dalhousie LRT Station, take Bus 37
accessible-parking: At the community Centre

title: Central Downtown - The Politics of Preserving Downtown
shortdescription: Join former City Councillor Michael Phair on a tour looking at how politics has shaped our downtown.
longdescription: This Jane's Walk begins after the official kick-off of Jane's Walks in Edmonton and will proceed to visit a number of buildings  & areas where 'politics' have played a role in shaping downtown.  After a number of stops, the tour will end at Enterprise Square (Old Bay Building) in the atrium on the main floor.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Front Steps of City Hall

team.bio: Michael Phair is a former member of Edmonton's City Council from 1992 - 2007 representing the downtown/Ward 4.

accessible-transit: Call 311 or go to the ETS Buslink website for the best transit route for you.
accessible-parking: Parking available on-street (meter) or paid parking in City Hall or Library Parkade
accessible-find: Look for Michael in his lovely orange Jane's Walk T-Shirt

title: The Bridge that Built Our City:History and Stories of Our Traffic Bridge
shortdescription: Meet Your City with a history buff to help you understand the significance of the roll of the Traffic Bridge in the history of this City.
longdescription:
Learn about the bridge’s place in our city’s history and the role it played in people’s lives on both sides of the river. View the bridge from above and below. Discover the anchor from the S.S. City of Medicine Hat.
 Before or after the tour, take time to visit the Meewasin Valley Centre interpretive displays on the lower level of the Meewasin building.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Meewasin Place Lobby, Meewasin Valley Building, 402, 3rd Ave. S. North end of the Traffic Bridge

team.bio: Peggy Sarjeant is a member of the Saskatoon Heritage Society.

accessible-info: accessible for wheelchairs along sidewalks and ramps at River Landing. There are also steps leading down to the lower trail adjacent to the river bank.
accessible-transit: bus that travels along 19th street across the Broadway Bridge
accessible-parking: parking metres on the street

title: Neighbourhood Staycation: A tour of community spaces and neighbourhood amenities
shortdescription: This family-friendly and all-ages tour is inspired by happy Saturday afternoons spent together, close to home
longdescription:
Discover some neighbourhood treasures in this quartet of S.W. inner-city communities - Rosscarrock, Westgate, Wildwood and Spruce Cliff. See why a Saturday at home in the neighbourhood can be fun, informative, and so worth doing.

We'll visit Shaganappi Public Library, Shaganappi Golf Course, Wildflower Arts Centre, a local playground, and Bow Cliff Seniors. There will be hands-on activities, friendly location hosts,  plenty of topics to discuss, and interesting people to talk with, including local representatives from The City of Calgary Community & Protective Services such as the Fire Department, Recreation and Animal & Bylaw Services. Plus there will be great neighbourhood residents happy to share the spirit of neighbourhood discovery.

This is a great chance to think about what connects us to our neighbourhoods and to each other as Calgarians. And to learn first-hand about The City of Calgary's Inspiring Strong Neighbourhoods initiative 

http://www.calgary.ca/CSPS/CNS/Pages/Inspiring-Strong-Neighbourhoods/Inspiring-Strong-Neighbourhoods.aspx

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Shaganappi Public Library 3415 8 Ave SW

team.name-first: Members of the ISN Neighbourhood Action Team and neighbourhood friends
team.bio: You''ll spend the afternoon with a dynamic team of community-builders, including Lemlem, Silvia, Joey, Janet, and Lisa

accessible-info: City streets & sidewalks, plus a visit to a golf course. We'll have a bus to help with some of the longer distances so nobody has to walk too far
accessible-transit: West LRT line, exit at Westbrook Station. Or take Bus Route 72 Circle Route, 73 Circle Route, 93 Coach Hill/Westbrook, or 412 Westgate/Beltline
accessible-parking: Park at the end location (Bow Cliff Seniors)

title: DOORS OPEN DAVENPORT
shortdescription: Walk, talk and eat your way through this transitioning west end neighbourhood…
longdescription:
Join us for the inaugural DOORS OPEN DAVENPORT! Hosted and organized by DIG IN (www.digin.ca) -- run on volunteer energy! This urbanist’s delight offers you an opportunity to walk, cycle, learn, chat and share stories in the ever-evolving Bloordale/Junction Triangle. Explore current and former factories, churches, lumberyards and much more! Come out for the afternoon then stay for our Community Dinner at Campbell Park (www.campbellpark.ca).

This is a ‘hop on hop off’ free event. We will try to stick to schedule. All ages welcome.

Saturday May 4th, 2013

1:00pm    Belarusian Orthodox Church, 524 St.Clarens Аvenue

1:45pm    Former General Electric Building & Water Tower, 224 Wallace Avenue      

2:30pm    Former Steam Plant (now Metropolis Factory), 50 Edwin Avenue

3:15pm    Lumber Yard… Boys & Girls Club… Division Gallery, 45 Ernest Avenue

4:15pm    Former Tower Automotive, 158 Sterling Avenue  (former tallest building in the Commonwealth!)   

 

5:30pm    Campbell Park Community Dinner    Pay What You Can  Suggested $5 dinner / $2 dessert / $1 drinks

    255 Campbell Avenue (north-south street west of Lansdowne, east of Dundas, north of Bloor and south of Dupont)

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Belarusian Orthodox Church  524 St.Clarens Аvenue (1 block North of Bloor, 1 block East of Lansdowne)

team.bio: DIGIN is a local community group committed to the cultural, social, environmental and economic vitalization of the Bloor Street West neighbourhood surrounding Bloordale. DIGIN initiates inclusive community and cultural plans and actions that will contribute to sustaining a neighbourhood that is GREEN * CLEAN * SAFE * CIVIL.

accessible-info: Some of the 5 locations are more accessible than others. Between locations we will be using public sidewalks and bike path.
accessible-transit: Lansdowne Subway Station then walk 1 block North of Bloor and 1 block East of Lansdowne
accessible-parking: Street Parking

title: Art & Living in Bathurst/Finch
shortdescription: Explore our neighbourhood while learning about walkability, art and pedestrian safety and enjoying some free food. Expect games, prizes and lots of surprises!
longdescription:
Come explore the Bathurst Finch area with the members of the neighbourhood action group who will share their stories and experiences of the neighbourhood.

The Jane's Walk starts at 10:30 and is followed by entertainment and food from 1-2 pm.

Bring appropriate clothing, shoes, sun protection and your own water bottle.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Bathurst-Finch Community Hub, 540 Finch Avenue West Toronto, ON M2R 1N7

team.name-first: Dina Schneider, Mojgan Rasouli, Marina Slobodkina and Anna Lyulina

accessible-transit: Bus 36 West from Finch subway station
accessible-parking: Yes

title: A Tour of the International Market
shortdescription: Bring your kids out to explore the sounds, smells, and sights of the multicultural markets in the Eglinton West neighbourhood.
longdescription:
Join us for a historical walking tour of the Eglinton Avenue West neighbourhood, starting at the Maria A. Shchuka Library.

See the spots that make our community unique, including:

  • Listen to a poetry reading in the park
  • Meet Toronto City Councilor Josh Colle
  • Check out the Beltline walking path
  • Children’s face painting
  • Learn about a local bookstore
  • Visit a barbershop to hear about “More Than a Haircut”

…and more!

All ages are welcome.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Maria A. Shchuka Branch Toronto Public Library, 1745 Eglinton Avenue West, Toronto ON

team.name-first: Jeffrey Totse &  staff of Maria A. Shchuka Library
team.bio: Jeff, a fresh face in the library world, began his career in 2011 and is an advocate for libraries being a vibrant part of our diverse city; a safe place to sit, relax, read, discuss or surf the web. A true believer in human-powered transportation, he tries to walk and cycle as a part of a healthy lifestyle and believes that walkability and cyclability is part of sustainable city. Jeff has a curious mind and satisfies this curiosity by reading and learning about this great neighbourhood through his neighbours and the library's community partners.

accessible-transit: From Eglinton West Subway Station please walk west or take the 32 Eglinton West Bus a couple stops to Locksley Ave.
accessible-parking: There is street parking available.

title: Personal Geographies: Sharing Our Stories of the City
shortdescription: This unconventional, ‘crowd-sourced’ walk invites participants to share their own stories of Vancouver; come explore Gastown, Chinatown and Strathcona through the eyes of your neighbours.
longdescription:
Image: Vancouver Archive CVA 1435-482  

This unconventional walk invites you to share your stories of Vancouver in its oldest neighbourhoods. Let’s explore Gastown, Chinatown and Strathcona through the eyes of our neighbours and in turn, see our neighbourhood in a new or different way.


This participatory, ‘crowd-sourced’ walk, in the spirit of a dérive, will be created and mapped on the day by the participants; curated and choreographed by your Guides through this beautiful, diverse and historic neighbourhood.


Each stop on the walk will be a specific location that bears some personal significance to a member of the group, who will then share their experience and contribute to a collective geography.


We invite participants to come prepared with a memory, short or long. Where did it happen? How did it change you? Was it a corner, a block, a building? A space that no longer exists?

We will begin at 3pm with participants gathering at Victory Square. There we will collect locations on a map and decide our route, heading in a generally Easterly direction.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Victory Square

team.bio:
Robyn Fenton is a Vancouver based architect and founder of ReForma Architecture. Her interests lie in creating beautiful and functional spaces through an interactive process of collaboration with her clients. Teaching, studying and volunteer work in various disciplines compliment her architectural practice.

www.reforma.ca



Alex Grünenfelder is an artist and designer based in Vancouver, Canada. Employing the media of graphics, text, architecture, sound, video and performance, he pursues a creative practice that combines the project development methods of design practice with the critical discourse and dialogical goals of the liberal arts. 
He is also a director and co-founder of the Vancouver Design Nerds Society, an organization that facilitates interdisciplinary discussion and collaboration between designers, artists and the public. His artwork explores the power of media to shape the perception of environments.
Among his projects:
http://airtasting.com/
http://www.cubeliving.ca/
http://wordsandpictures.info/
 

Robyn and Alex are both members of the Vancouver Design Nerds Society. The VDNS exists to facilitate, promote and support positive social, environmental and urban transformation by providing a platform for face-to-face creative collaboration. 

We design, expedite and improve civic engagement processes and techniques that, through the use of dialogue, art, design, media and other creative methods, act as innovative ways to reconnect citizens with their communities and engage them with their environment.

http://vancouver.designnerds.org/

accessible-transit: Short walk from Waterfront Station
accessible-parking: Pay parking at meters or lots
accessible-find: Meet at the North end of Victory Square, at the corner of West Hastings and Hamilton Streets.

title: North Kipling Rexdale Gets Walking
shortdescription: Our community walking club has been getting out and exploring our area, and on Saturday May 4th we are inviting all Torontonians to discover what we already know - that Rexdale is a fun community to visit via foot power!
longdescription: Start off at the Rexdale Community Women's Health Centre on Panorama Court, visit some of our great local schools and parks and green spaces, then relax and join us for some chat and light refreshments after the walk at ANC North Kipling.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Rexdale CHC, 21 Panorama Court

team.name-first: Rexdale CHC (Tania Fernandes) & ANC North Kipling (Russ Mitchell)

accessible-parking: At the Rexdale TCHC

title: Central District
shortdescription: Check out all that Central District has to offer from the perspectives of both a new and long-term resident.
longdescription: The Central District has a rich and dynamic history. Join Shawn (a new resident) and John (a Feet First Board Member and long time CD resident) on this informative walk. Share your own stories too! This walk is open to everyone and everyone is encouraged to attend.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: The Cherry St. Side of Garfield High School Baseball Diamond at E Cherry St and 25th Ave, Seattle 98122

team.name-first: Shawn, Feet First Neighborhood Walking Ambassador and John, Feet First Board Member
team.bio:
About John: 
I've been involved with pedestrian issues with Feet First for almost ten years now, so I have historical perspective on what's been done, what's worked, as well as relationships with a number of people around the region who are working on pedestrian issues. I'm technologically adept, a good listener, and a strong proponent for neighborhood action and activism. I'm also a good writer and editor.
Why walkability matters to me:
I've been a pedestrian for years - not that we all aren't in one way or another, but I started walking a mile to the bus my freshman year in high school, and realized I really liked to walk. I didn't own a car until I got married at 30, so I spent a lot of time on my feet.
I grew frustrated with the inequity of the power relationship between pedestrians and automobiles, and the sense that our streets were designed to disadvantage pedestrians. So I heard about Feet First in a little note in the PI and went to a meeting (in the food court at Westlake Center no less!) with four or five people...this was in 2000. I've been on the Board since since 2003.

accessible-transit: There are 3 bus lines (MT Route 3, 4, 48) within 1 block of the starting point.
accessible-parking: Street parking available

title: Greenways, Festival Streets, Transit, and More on Beacon Hill!
shortdescription: What is a Greenway, and how will this change the livability and community experience of Beacon Hill?
longdescription:
This walk will begin by heading south on Beacon Ave, the "Main Street" of North Beacon Hill, towards Jefferson Park, a neighborhood favorite. We will then head back up the the light rail station, this time heading north along Beacon Hill's brand new Greenway route. Along the way we will talk more about greenways, festival streets, transit, neighborhood development, supporting local, independent business, cultural groups and activities, and parks.

After the walk is over, stick around for a bit! El Centro de la Raza will be having a Cinco de Mayo celebration starting at 1 pm, so be sure to stay and join in on the festivities.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: In front of the Beacon Hill Light Rail Station, 1639 South Lander St, Seattle WA 98144. Cross streets are Beacon Ave. S. and S. Lander St., and there's a pay parking lot across from the light rail station as well.

team.name-first: Devor Barton of Beacon B.I.K.E.S. (Better Infrastructure Keeping Everyone Safe)
team.bio:
As many of you know, there is a growing movement among Beacon Hill residents interested in safely getting people of all ages and abilities around and to destinations within our neighborhood on foot and bicycle. This propelled Beacon B.I.K.E.S., a growing group of community members, to obtain the knowledge and expertise of a consultant to bring our collective vision to fruition.In Spring 2010, Beacon B.I.K.E.S. received a generous matching funds grant from the Department of Neighborhoods. We used our Small and Simple grant to hire Alta Planning + Design as our transportation consultant from among three enthusiastic applicants. Beacon B.I.K.E.S. believes that pedestrians and cyclists encounter similar obstacles in getting around our neighborhood and that facilities that address both modes make the most sense. This philosophy is in line with Alta’s belief in “integrating all modes of travel (including walking and bicycling) into the daily lives of residents and creating healthy, safe, and sustainable communities.” Most importantly, they offer an interactive approach geared to keeping the neighborhood informed and involved throughout the process. Alta's final report and recommendation was released June 2011. Our approach is to adopt Portland's innovative greenway network and incorporate it within our unique neighborhood. Greenways are low-speed streets that are perfect for family bike rides, walking seniors, and parent's pushing strollers. For more information, please visit our homepage to download a copy of the report.
http://www.beaconwalksbikes.org/events.html

accessible-transit: MT Route 36 and Route 60 bus lines, Link Light Rail (same station as meet up location)

title: Pioneer Square, Present and Future (and Past)
longdescription: A discussion of the livability and walkability of Pioneer Square with a focus on recent and upcoming changes to the  neighborhood, including new construction (particularly residential), new retail, alleyway activation, and the waterfront. And although isn't a  historical tour, the history of the neighborhood and Seattle is sure to  come up.

title: Roof ready Regina
shortdescription: Mapping homelessness in Regina's Downtown and Heritage.
longdescription:
The Roof Ready Regina walk, mapping out homelessness in Regina's Downtown and Heritage communities, is an opportunity to discuss issues around effective affordable housing strategies, urban planning, and marginalisation.

The walk will begin in front of the YWCA (1940 McIntyre St). From there we will walk past Vic Park on Victoria street and head to the "wet" detox centre: Brief and Social Detoxification Services (1640 Victoria Ave). The walk will also bring us to Carmichael Outreach (1925 Osler St), Marian Centre (1835 Halifax St), Souls Harbour soup kitchen ( 1836 Halifax St), and the Salvation Army Waterston Centre (1845 Osler Street). We'll end by walking back on 12th Ave towards the downtown Plaza ending at the Regina Public Library (2311 12th Ave).

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: In front YWCA 1940 McIntyre Street

team.bio:
Dr. Marc Spooner is an associate professor in the Faculty of Education, University of Regina. He specializes in qualitative and participatory action research translating theory into action-on-the-ground. His interests include: creativity/deviance, homelessness & poverty, “at risk” or “at-promise” youth, social justice, activism, & participatory democracy.  He has been published in a variety of venues including peer-reviewed journals, book chapters, government reports, and popularizations. 
Together with colleague Dr. Patrick Lewis, he co-chairs a popular discussion series, Talkin' about School & Society which takes place not at the University, but rather at a local resto/bar.  The series aims to move the discussion of critical issues that ultimately affect us all outside of academia and into the wider community.   In 2006, he was a founding faculty member of RPIRG (Regina Public Interest Research Group) at the University of Regina; Saskatchewan’s first public interest research group. Marc has served on the boards of several community-based organisations in Regina, including John Howard Society-Regina and Carmichael Outreach.

title: ¿Mis hijos solos? Ni hablar!!! De la Protección a la Educación en Autonomia.
shortdescription: Nuestro camino trascurre por una zona muy bien equipada con parque, biblioteca, piscina..., con caminos anchos y seguros, sin cruces peligrosos... ¿por qué no vemos más niños y niñas yendo y viniendo solos?... sin la compañía constante de sus mayores? ¿Qué ha pasado? Hay más peligros ahora que hace 20 años? Acompáñanos en nuestro paseo y cuéntanos tu experiencia, tus miedos y/o tus valentias y osadias. Os enseñaré una Zona de Córdoba, la manzana del antiguo Cuartel de Lepanto y cómo estos terrenos han sido recuperados para la ciudadanía cordobesa.
longdescription:
Os voy a mostrar parte de mi barrio, concretamente la zona de Levante Sur. Una zona muy bien cubierta de servicios para la infancia y para el resto de la ciudadanía gracias a la recuperación de los terrenos del Antiguo Cuartel de Lepanto. Conoceremos las Instalaciones que hoy existen en esta manazana y los servicios que nos ofrecen (Colegios, Centro de Deportes, Parque Madre Coraje, Centro de Salud, Centro de Voluntariado de Cruz Roja, Casa Ciudadana y Bibliotenca Central). Deseo mostraros este paseo como modelo de barrio vivo, paseable y seguro.  Visitaremos varias de estas instalaciones (guiadas) , conoceremos su historia y nos adentraremos hasta dónde nos permitan, incluyendo el antiguo patio central del cuartel. 

Además de  mostraros estos equipamientos quisiera  charlar sobre la autonomía de nuestros hijos e hijas a la hora de moverse solos por el barrio, sin la compañía de adultos.

¿A qué lugares podrían ir solos? ¿Qué edades veis propicias para que empiecen a ser autónomos? Nos gusta que caminen solos? ¿Qué facilidades tienen? ¿Qué peligros crees que corren? Cuál es tu experiencia?

¿Están cerca de casa los equipamientos? Biblioteca, parque, zonas deportivas, piscina, colegios, centro cívico, puesto de chuches…

Nos encontraremos en el Parque “Madre Coraje” (teletubbies). Pasearemos observando el camino, comentado las facilidades y/o barreras que nos ofrece para posibilitar que nuestros hijos. Nos interesa no sólo la ruta, también sus habitantes.

Tomaremos la calle Sagunto, pasaremos por la sede de Cruz Roja Española en Córdoba, ellos nos comentarán su trabajo en voluntariado y nos contarán cómo era el Antiguo Cuartel. Seguiremos hacia el Centro de Salud Levante Norte, y atravesaremos el aparcamiento… (ojo, hay árboles de morera para los gusanillos). Visitaremos el Centro Cívico de Lepanto dónde podremos conocer qué servicios están a nuestra disposición y a la de nuestros hijos/as. Intentaremos acceder al Patio Central del Cuartel de Lepanto, hoy en deshuso y mal cuidado, pero bonito, muy bonito. 

Tras conocer este espacio, visitaremos la Biblioteca Central, conoceremos sus instalaciones, programa de actividades infantiles y juveniles, qué usos nos ofrecen para los más jóvenes, etc.

Creo que toda la manzana es  un buen ejemplo de recuperación y reutilización de espacio público.

Tras este última visita volveremos a los jardines de Madre Coraje dónde concluirá nuestro paseo, pero en el que podremos seguir charlando de la autonomía que podemos ir dando a nuestros hij@s a la hora de moverse solos por su barrio.

Si quereis podeis mandarme un email, así sabremos con cuantas personas contamos a la hora de las visitas.  Espero que os animéis. Gracias.

longdescription:
בגיל 7 עברתי מגרמניה לירושלים.
לאחר כמה חודשי התאקלמות בדירת הרווקים של אבא שלי בגבעה הצרפתית עברנו לרחל אמנו 26ב'.
בבית זה התקיימו רוב שעות מערכת היחסים הנוכחת/נעדרת שלי עם אבא.
13 שנה אחרי זה הוא נפטר בנסיבות לא ברורות ביחידת דיור בבית שרובר. 
 
הסיור מבית ילדותי, לבית בו נפטר, מזמין את כל מי שהכיר/ה את ד"ר טדי הופמן (1938-1998) לספר לי עליו סיפורים, חוויות וזכרונות.

title: Rossdale Power Plant
shortdescription: Join us for a walk looking at the old Rossdale Power Plant in a historically significant area.
longdescription: This guided walking tour meets in front of the Rossdale Community League Building (historic Little Flower School) at 10135 – 96 Ave. and proceeds to the Traditional Burial Ground and Fort Edmonton Cemetery Commemorative Site, which provides a good view of the historic Rossdale Generating Station. The tour will provide information about the significance of the area with a special focus on the Rossdale Generating Station (Maxwell Dewar Building/Low Pressure power plant), which was designated a Provincial Historic Resource in 2001. Parking is available behind the community league building.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Rossdale Community League 10135-96 Avenue

team.bio:
Allan Partridge is an award-winning Edmonton architect with expertise in combining technology and design in an Integrated Practice setting. His projects have included heritage buildings such as the Legislature Building upgrades, Immigration Hall - Hope Mission, and a study for EPCOR on Rossdale Adaptive Reuse. He is a speaker at national and international conferences on Building Information Modeling and on Heritage and Conservation Management.
Cultural consultant Catherine C. Cole is a local historian whose most recent book GWG: Piece by Piece, a history of Edmonton’s Great Western Garment Company has won several awards. She was the heritage consultant for the West Rossdale Urban Design Plan and has three ancestors buried in the Fort Edmonton Cemetery at Rossdale.

title: Ovcharski - the Neighborhood of the Shepherds
shortdescription:
This walk takes place in Haskovo, Bulgaria, where a 160-year old neighborhood waits to tell its story. 
This is "Ovcharski" - the Shepherds' neighborhood.
longdescription:
Ovsharski is the name of a neighborhood in the city of Haskovo, Bulgaria. 

Why it was called "The Shepherds' neighborhood"? What is its story? What is the story of the people in it? Come to know! 

Your Walk Leader will be a local man whose family roots stand here more than 160 years. 

Our meeting point is at the beginning of the neighborhood - the green corner of Makedoniya Str. and Osvobozhdenie Blvd.

 The beginning of the neighborhood.

 

 The church "Sveti Georgi".

 

Winter view from "Makedoniya" Str.

title: Bet Shemesh: The Beauty with the Sorrow | היפה והכואב בבית שמש
shortdescription:
A tour of the city's cultural centers: past, present, and future. The tour is organized and hosted by KUMI: a local women's grassroots movement for promoting cultural and social awareness. We'll visit the old cinema, Zinman theatre, visit and hear brief recitals at the Andalusian Orchestra and Bet Shemesh Conservatory. Pass by our concert hall/ community center to learn about the Bet Shemesh Classical Chamber Concerts and film series. From there we'll visit 'The Pit' and hear the painful story of our suspended cultural centre. The final stop is at the Psagot Hasheva Matnas where we'll view a dance troup and tour Mercaz Volume School of Music to hear the all-girls choir 'Twilight' (Ben Hashmashot)

 מסע  בעקבות מוסדות התרבות שישנם ואינם בעיר בית שמש לשיחה על  העבר, ההווה והעתיד של העיר. הסיור מאורגן על ידי קבוצת קוּמי בית שמש - ארגון פעולה נשי ליצירת מודעות תרבותית וחברתית בעיר. במהלך הדרך נבקר במתחם בנק לאומי במרכז המסחרי על חורבותיו של בית הקולנוע , במתחם מתנ"ס זינמן ובית הנוער, נקיים אתנחתא מוזיקלית של מנהל התזמורת האנדלוסית בבית שמש, נצפה בתלמידים מצטיינים מנגנים בקונסרבטוריון, נכיר את סדרת הקונצרטים המתקיימת באשכול הפיס, ונבקר בבית התרבות העתידי של בית שמש שזכה לכינוי "הבור הגדול" שהבנייה בו מעוכבת מזה שנים. ההליכה תסתיים במתנ"ס פסגות השבע ומרכז ווליום בו נצפה בטעימות מתוך מופעים של להקת הבנות "בין השמשות" וקבוצת הריקוד DaLinadance"".
longdescription:
עברית אחרי האנגלית

The first Bet Shemesh Jane's walk will be a tour of some of the city's cultural highlights: past, present and future. Some of these institutions are thriving, others are struggling to survive, and many have folded after years of neglect. The walk is hosted by KUMI,  a local women's grassroots movement pooling in women from all  the city's sectors to promote cultural and social awareness.

We'll start with some introductory words by Brenda Ganot, one of the founders of KUMI who will describe the motivating factors behind organizing a Jane's Walk in Bet Shemesh.  Then we'll learn how  years ago when Bet Shemesh was much smaller, we had an operating cinema theatre . From there we'll continue to the Zinman Theatre where Yosef Shriki will talk to us about the Andalusian Orchestra and give us a short violin recital. We'll continue to the former Youth Center to learn about the lively theatre company once hosted there. During the walk to The Bet Shemesh Conservatory,  Miri Shalem, another KUMI founder will tell us about the cultural activities in Ramat Bet Shemesh. At the Conservatory, music director and pianist Marina Friedman will describe its history, achievements, and challenges. We will also hear a brief classical music recital by some star students. Progressing to the Mifal Pais, Nili Philipp will reveal one of the best kept secrets in Bet Shemesh - our celebrated Classical Chamber Concerts with performances by world renown musicians. Also at the Mifal Pais Avner from Kibbutz Tamuz will share with us details about the film series hosted there. A short walk will bring us to The Pit where Meir Malka will disclose one of the most painful stories of Bet Shemesh: the great void that was supposed to be our cultural center and whose construction is currently held up due to political treachery and corruption, costing the city tens of millions of shekels.

Our final stop will be at the Matnas Psagot Hasheva to view a performance of a dance troup with a tour  of the Mercaz Volume Music School by Maimon Ben Hamu. For a grand finale, we'll hear a short concert by the Ben Hashmashot 'Twilight' girls choir outside the Matnas.

 

בית שמש צמחה בשני העשורים האחרונים מעיירה קטנה ואינטימית לכרך גדול המאכלס אוכלוסיות שונות ומגוונות. עולים משנות החמישים, העליות הגדולות מרוסיה ואתיופיה, עולים אנגלוסקסים, קהילות חרדיות שהתיישבו בשכונות נפרדות בבית שמש ותושבים חדשים ממקומות שונים בארץ שהתאהבו בנופים המדהימים ובאווירת הקהילה החמימה. מוסדות התרבות שישנם ושאינם, מספרים את הסיפור של העיר: רב תרבותיות, מתח בין תרבותי,  ועל המעבר מעיירה לעיר.

קבוצת קוּמי  בית שמש מזמינה אתכן למסע  בעקבות מוסדות התרבות בעיר בית שמש ולשיחה על  העבר, ההווה והעתיד של העיר.  הסיור יעבור במתחם בנק לאומי  במרכז המסחרי שנבנה על חורבותיו של בית הקולנוע , במתחם מתנ"ס זינמן לידו שוכן גם בית הנוער, שניהם בעבר ידעו ימים יפים ותוססים יותר. נקיים אתנחתא מוזיקלית של מנהל התזמורת האנדלוסית בבית שמש,  נצפה בתלמידים מצטיינים מנגנים בקונסרבטוריון, נכיר את סדרת הקונצרטים המתקיימת  באשכול הפיס,  נבקר בבית התרבות העתידי של בית שמש שזכה לכינוי  "הבור הגדול" שהבנייה בו מעוכבת מזה שנים. ההליכה תסתיים במתנ"ס פסגות השבע ומרכז ווליום  ונצפה בטעימות מתוך מופעים של להקת הבנות "בין השמשות" וקבוצת הריקוד DaLinadance"".
