title: Toronto's "Old Town": Labour History Walking Tour
shortdescription: Toronto’s Old Town: Labour History Walking Tour invites all to explore the oldest section of Toronto with its vibrant and turbulent past. Learn about the texture of daily life from the 1830s onward, uprisings and hangings and the massive demonstrations of the 1870s to support workers when unions were illegal – as well as an infamous site of the current “imperious clout of corporate Canada.”
longdescription:
Join Mayworks Festival for a labour history walking tour of Toronto’s “Old Town" on Sunday, May 5, 2013 from 10 am - 11:30 am.

Led by JP Hornick, Maureen Hynes and Sue Smith, Toronto’s Old Town: Labour History Walking Tour invites all to explore the oldest section of Toronto with its vibrant and turbulent past. Learn about the texture of daily life from the 1830s onward, uprisings and hangings and the massive demonstrations of the 1870s to support workers when unions were illegal – as well as an infamous site of the current “imperious clout of corporate Canada.” This walk, part of Jane’s Walk, starts in front of St Lawrence Hall at the corner of King and Jarvis, proceeds to several sites with hidden labour history. The tour ends outside William Lyon MacKenzie House (82 Bond Street).


Facebook Event Page


This event is part of the 2013 Mayworks Festival (see below for more details).
It is being co-presented by George Brown School of Labour. It is also being co-sponsored by Jane’s Walk, Elementary Teachers’ Federation of Ontario - Toronto Occasional Teachers, Ontario Secondary School Teachers’ Federation (OSSTF/FEESO).

***
MORE INFORMATION:
Mayworks Festival of Working People and the Arts is a multi-disciplinary arts festival that celebrates working class culture. For more information on other events at the 2013 Festival, please visit www.mayworks.ca.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: In front of St Lawrence Hall (at the corner of King and Jarvis)

team.name-first: JP Hornick, Maureen Hynes and Sue Smith
team.bio:
JP Hornick is the current Coordinator of the School of Labour at George Brown College and a long-time social activist. An experienced educator and steward, she is committed to bringing a socially-progressive labour perspective to students and workers through workshops, training, and events like this.  
 Maureen Hynes worked with David Kidd to create Mapping Our Work:  Toronto Labour History Walking Tours (http://www.labourcouncil.ca/uploads/8/8/6/1/8861416/labourhistorymap.pdf), and contributed historical pieces to Labour Council’s 2011 book, The Spirit of Our Movement. She is the retired Coordinator of George Brown College’s School of Labour, and is an award-winning poet with three books to her name. Maureen is poetry editor for Our Times magazine.
 
Sue Smith thinks we can learn a lot from each other, from walking and sharing stories of our past. Retired after 25 years with the City of Toronto, she still has a keen interest in making cities better places to live, based on a commitment to social change.

accessible-transit: King Subway Station or King and Jarvis Streetcar stop

title: Propuesta ciudadana para mejorar el barrio Regina Magdalena
shortdescription: Ideas y propuestas colectivas para hacer que sus calles, plazas, edificios históricos y equipamientos sean espacios que favorezcan el bienestar común, el paseo, la tranquilidad y la convivencia
longdescription:
Contenido de la ruta:
Uso de la Plaza de la Magdalena: equipamientos culturales, movilidad y accesibilidad. Zona de juegos y deportiva en la plaza de Santa Inés, habilitación de aparcamientos de uso reversible. Ruta de los contenedores soterrados. Patios del barrio y otros equipamientos socioculturales. Rehabilitación y uso de dotación  en la Iglesia de Regina. Plazas y calles para la ciudad amable, aparcamiento de residentes en cine Andalucía, intervención sociocomunitaria y posibles huertos urbanos en Plaza de San Eloy, movilidad y accesibilidad al barrio por calle La Palma. La hegemonía peatonal en la Plaza de Aguayos.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Plaza de la Magdalena: fuente del jardín central

team.bio:
La Asociciación Vecinal Regina Magdalena es un colectivo nacido en el presente año, que tiene, entre otros muchos objetivos,  la defensa de los derechos ciudadanos del vecindario, la promoción de actividades encaminadas a mejorar  el entorno y la vida de sus residentes, la protección de los bienes comunes patrimoniales y medioambientales, la intervención sociocultural y comunitaria en aquellas ocasiones que sean de interés para la ciudadanía y la realización de todas las actividades propias de una asociación vecinal que sean consideradas de interés para la colectividad.
Somos un barrio dentro del casco histórico de Córdoba situado en la Axarquía, dentro de la muralla medieval,  cuya puerta  llamada Torre de los Donceles estaba situada en la entrada a la actual Plaza de la Magdalena,
Empezamos nuestras actividades con mucha ilusión y deseo de ser miembros activos en la participación ciudadana de Córdoba, hemos presentado ya al Ayuntamiento nuestra propuestas iniciales apra mejorar nuestro barrio y estamos inscritos en los órganos de participación ciudadana.  Gracias a todos por la buena acogida que hemos recibido y quedamos a disposición para colaborar con otras asociaciones, instituciones, entidades o personas individuales en aquellos proyectos que contemplen objetivos y necesidades comunes a las nuestras.
También queremos invitaros a pasear por nuestro barrio durante el Mayo cordobés, tanto las Cruces como el Festival de los patios de Córdoba son para nosotros una parte importante de nuestra historia y nuestra cultura. No dejéis de visitarnos.
 
Os presentamos algunas de nuestras propuestas y actividades.

 



 
Paseos realizados
 
Y nuestra invitación a futuras rutas
Anunciamos desde aquí la próxima ruta para el sábado 11 de mayo a las 10, 30 h. Punto de encuentro Plaza de la Magdalena. Contenido: Arqueología, origenes e historia del barrio.

  ¡GRACIAS POR ACOMPAÑARNOS!

title: Jane Jacobs Walk Orillia 2013
shortdescription: Join us for  the second annual Jane Jacobs Walk in Orillia at  2:00 pm Sunday the 5th of May at St Paul’s United Church
longdescription: Jane Jacobs Walk – Join us for  the second annual Jane Jacobs Walk in Orillia at  2:00 pm Sunday the 5th of May.  A walking tour of the neighbourhood will begin in the Parlour of St Paul’s United Church; Northeast corner of Coldwater Road and Peter Street in Orillia.  We will be one of over 500 cities around the world celebrating the life and work of Jane Jacobs.   She was a defender of neighbourhoods, a keen observer of the world around her, with a firm conviction that community mattered.  Explore what is active and healthy about Orillia, what is working, and what needs improvement. The basic route will be: Coldwater, West, Brant, and Matchedash, with brief detours along the way.  Walk, wheel, or even drive there; dress for the weather, bring any refreshment you might need,  and wear comfortable shoes.  Come out and: walk  observe  connect !

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: the Parlour of St Paul’s United Church

team.bio: David J. Stinson will lead the walk.  He is a Community Planner and enthusiastic about how the landscape and streetscape can be used to create thriving habitats for people and nature.  He led last year's walk.

accessible-info: The tour will walk uphill on West Street and downhill on Matchedash Street
accessible-transit: north & south buses of "Laclie" route stop in front of St. Paul's
accessible-parking: St Paul’s United Church and on street
accessible-find: We will begin in the Parlour of St Paul’s United Church with a brief presentation and orientation; after that just watch for the slow moving crowd enroute!

title: Tampere Diagonal
shortdescription: Peaceful, walkable, almost straight route of 2-kilometers provides and interesting and varying cross-section to city.
longdescription: Environmental NGO Dodo will organise urban walks in four cities: Helsinki, Jyväskylä, Tampere and Turku. In Tampere we'll walk a new walkable diagonal through city centre anabled by the new bridge Koskenniska. Starting near wooden houses of Amuri along Puuvillatehtaankatu to new Amuri and across the rapids to Tampella, maybe to Juhannuskylä. Peaceful, walkable, almost straight route of 2-kilometers provides and interesting and varying cross-section to city.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Runoratsupatsas, Savilinnankatu 4, Tampere

team.bio: Dodo is an environmental organisation for urban folk which relies on the power of knowledge and argument. Dodo is about talking and doing. It organises public events, discussion groups, projects and more. Dodo brings together people from different backgrounds to exchange expertise, experiences and ideas. We work out ideas and then we work on some of them to carry out experiments that might improve things and solve environmental problems. Voluntary-based NGO is focused on global environmental issues, urban development and urban lifestyle. www.dodo.org

title: Downsview & You
shortdescription: From an aerospace park where pilots used to train in preparation for battle in WWII to the Downsview Memorial Parkette created to honour local men and women who sacrificed their lives in WWII and designed to be viewable from the air, to Downsview United Church built in 1870, to George Jackson House, which is a 1830 heritage building that hearkens back to settlement times, Downsview is a neighbourhood with a rich social history worth exploring.
longdescription:
Join Councillor Augimeri (Ward 9) in exploring how the rich history of the Downsview neighbourhood has been recognized and interwoven with the present.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 
Begin the journey from MOTH Gardens--Downsview Memorial Parkette, whose architecture spells out MOTH and is designed to be legible from the air. The park is a commemoration of the MOTH aircraft built in Downsview and used in WWII. The park also contains an epitaph dedicated to the local men and women who died in the war and which also serves as the site for Downsview's annual Remembrance Day service.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Walk up to Downsview Park -- a 600 acre space which has a rich history of contribution to Canada's aerospace efforts. The park contains buildings in which some of the world's first orbiting satellites were created, built aeroplanes which trained fighter pilots, and are home to the GTA's largest manufacturing employer. In addition, green space, trails and recreation are part of the park's features. The interplay of modern industry with natural beauty has always been characteristic of Downsview, and this space embodies it.










 

 

 

 

From there, a visit to George Jackson House, a living museum, is in order. Built in 1830, this building is reminiscent of a time before Canada was even a nation; when settlers occupied vast tracts of farmland. During a recent renovation, old artefacts and photos were discovered in the main building's attic from this time.


Downsview United Church is the last stop. Built in 1870, this Church is one of Downsview's oldest structures. Its impressive steeple and classic architecture stands the test of time in function and beauty. The Church is still in use and will be displaying the Downsview episode of the TV show "Structures" which attendees can watch to learn more about the area. Volunteers will be discussing the history of the Church.

Route:

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: MOTH Gardens in the Downsview Memorial Parkette at Keele St & Wilson St

team.bio: Maria Augimeri is the City of Toronto Councillor for York Centre - Ward 9. Councillor Augimeri was first elected in 1982 as a School Trustee and was subsequently elected to the City of North York Council in 1985. She has continued to represent the area of Downsview as a City Councillor, acting as an advocate for her residents and championing key local issues. She is passionate about the revitalization of Downsview and hopes to share her stories about the municipal work being undertaken in this neighbourhood.

accessible-parking: Parking at Keele and Wilson plaza (where Metro is) beside Downsview Memorial Parkette.

title: The Death and Life of the Tillicum-Burnside Action Plan?
shortdescription: This walk is designed around a series of quotes from Jane Jacobs’ seminal book on city planning, The Death and Life of Great American Cities. Employing a unique question-based method, it uses the ideas of Jacobs to encourage participants to observe and engage with their urban environment, build on their own knowledge about the city, and think explicitly about their how their values influence their understanding of the city. The route was inspired by the Tillicum - Burnside Action Plan published by Saanich in 2005.
longdescription:
This walk is designed around a series of quotes from Jane Jacobs’ seminal book on city planning, The Death and Life of Great American Cities.* Employing a unique question-based method, it uses the ideas of Jacobs to encourage participants to observe and engage with their urban environment, build on their own knowledge about the city, and think explicitly about their how their values influence their understanding of the city. The route was inspired by the Tillicum - Burnside Action Plan published by Saanich in 2005. For a full description of the walk, with pictures of the locations we'll visit, see Vincent's blog post about it.

A few overarching questions will guide our discussions on this walk:

1. Do you know what the Tillicum-Burnside Action Plan suggests for each of the places that we visit today? What kind of improvements have you noticed in this area over the past few years? How do you think such changes should be implemented?

2. What is a neighbourhood? Do you think of the area we're walking through today as one neighbourhood or many? Are there other neighbourhoods adjacent to our walk? What are their boundaries? What are the benefits and drawbacks of thinking about and planning a city in terms of neighbourhoods?

3. How should local decisions be made? How much power should local residents have? How much power should organizations like the GTCA or higher levels of government have? How can a neighbourhood make its voice heard?

At each of the following sites, we'll consider the following ideas and more specific questions:

1. Qu'appelle Park

"The more successfully a city mingles everyday diversity of uses and users in its everyday streets, the more successfully, casually (and economically) its people thereby enliven and support well-located parks that can thus give back grace and delight to their neighborhoods instead of vacuity” (111).

  • Does this park succeed according to Jacobs’ criteria? How could it be improved?

2. Commerce vs. Homes on Arterials - Burnside from Davin to Orillia

“To generate exuberant diversity in a city’s streets and districts four conditions are indispensable: 1. The district... must serve more than one primary function… 2. Most blocks must be short... 3. The district must mingle buildings that vary in age and condition... 4. There must be a sufficiently dense concentration of people.” (150-151).

  • How well does the stretch of Burnside Road between Davin and Orillia meet Jacobs' criteria for a  diverse neighbourhood? How could it be improved?

3. Public Sector Infrastructure - Tillicum School

"Schools, like parks, are apt to be volatile creatures of their neighborhoods (as well as being creatures of larger policy). In bad neighborhoods, schools are brought to runiation, physically and socially; while successful neighborhoods improve their schools by fighting for them" (113).

  • What role does Tillicum Community School play in this neighbourhood? How does its physical and social presence enhance our neighbourhood? How could it be improved?

4. Transportation Infrastructure - Burnside and Tillicum

"Lack of wide ranges of concentrated diversity can put people into automobiles for almost all their needs. The spaces required for roads and for parking spread everything out still farther, and lead to still greater uses of automobiles" (230).

  • In what ways could the highway infrastructure at this intersection be improved? How could other forms of transportation be encouraged?

5. Density, Parking Lots & Major Land Owners - Tillicum Mall, Saanich Centennial Library & Pearkes Arena

"Massive single uses in cities have a quality in common with each other. They form borders, and borders in cities usually make destructive neighbors" (257).

  • Does this parking lot create a "border vacuum"? What should be done about it? If new buildings were placed adjacent to the street, with underground parking, how would that enhance the public realm?

6. Successful Mixed Uses? Low Density Commercial & Religious Institutions

"On successful city streets, people must appear at different times... I have already explained this necessity in social terms while discussing street safety and neighborhood parks. Now I shall point out its economic effects. Most consumer enterprises are just as dependent as parks on people going to and fro throughout the day... If consumer enterprises lie idle for much of the day they may disappear" (152-153).

  • Is there sufficient density and diversity in this corridor to support storefronts like those in this block? How might we increase the economic viability of commercial enterprises in this area?

7. Commercial Aesthetics & Function - Fairways Complex

"The aim should be to get that project... rewoven back into the fabric [of the city] – and in the process of doing so, strengthen the surrounding fabric too" (392).

  • Is the Fairways complex working well now? What strategies might be used to make it more functional and aesthetically pleasing?

8. Finish - Gorgeous Coffee

Gorgeous Coffee offers the "bohemian life of [a] coffee house" (245). Moreover, it is a great neighbourhood place to discuss the issues raised during our walk in more depth.

  • Will you join me there after the walk for coffee and more discussion?

* Jane Jacobs, The Death and Life of Great American Cities, New York: Vintage Books, December 1992 [1961]. All the quotes in this outline are from this edition.

team.bio: Vincent is a Masters Student in the History Department at the University of Victoria. He is studying urban history, with a local focus on urban renewal in the Capital Region during the 1950s and 1960s.  He has also developed and led several local walking tours, including a previous Jane's Walk in Vic West and a successful series of scholarly walking tours during the fall of 2012. He plans to continue walking for a long time to come.

title: Jane's Walk: Phoenix
shortdescription: This year's "Jane's Walk: Phoenix", hosted by Will Novak, will explore the history and urban characteristics of Adams Street, which is currently being reviewed by the City of Phoenix for an "activation project."
longdescription:
In the first weekend of May each year, people around the nation host "Jane's Walks" in honor of Jane Jacobs, who prevented highways from carving up Manhattan and Toronto – and is arguably America's most famed urbanist.

This year's "Jane's Walk: Phoenix" – hosted by Will Novak, board president of the Phoenix Historic Neighborhoods Coalition – will explore the history and urban characteristics of Adams Street, which is currently being reviewed by the City of Phoenix and its consultants for an "activation project."

Meet on the patio of the Marriott Renaissance's Icon restaurant. There will be opportunities during the walk to enjoy a drink refreshment and converse with other Jane's Walkers about our downtown.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Icon Restaurant Patio, Marriott Renaissance, 50 E. Adams St.

team.bio: Will Novak is a former film production freelancer in Phoenix, Arizona. Unfortunately most of the work in that industry dried up due to the economic crisis and Arizona's film tax credit expiring. For about two years Will worked as a tour guide in Massachusetts and Arizona, and is now following his passion to improve his great love, the City of Phoenix. Will, currently serving as board president of the Phoenix Historic Neighborhoods Coalition, believes Phoenix is the most interesting city in America in the 21st Century and is poised to become the world's greatest Desert City.

accessible-transit: Metro Light Rail: 3rd St. & Washington (or) Washington & Central
accessible-parking: Street parking and various adjacent parking garages

title: Priceville Heritage Walk
shortdescription: The Walking Village combines two of our favourite subjects - history and nature in this two hour walk in the Village of Priceville.
longdescription:
Please join the Walking Village for a
Priceville Heritage Walk with guide David Turner.
Sunday May 05, 2013 - 2pm - meet at Lisa's Country Cottage General Store (approx 2 hour walk)
This is a Free event in support of Jane's Walk 2013 - which celebrates walking everywhere!

Our tour will take us primarily around the north side of town, visiting buildings with historic plaques; and then we will stroll down to the river.

David Turner, our guide, will speak about the historic buildings, for example original general store and commercial hotel, and also some natural history, especially as it would have been applied by the early settlers.

Rain or Shine ~ Wear your Walking Shoes

title: Walk T.O. Public Art & the City Tour
shortdescription: See the city's most exciting public art installations and debate the role of art in the city. This tour explores art from City Hall, through the Financial District, to St. Lawrence Market on Walk T.O.'s Art & the City Tour.
longdescription:
Join Toronto walking tour company, Walk T.O., on their Art & the City Tour.

In the 1960s Torontonians decided that art belonged in public spaces and buildings, and in the 1980s, the City decided that big business should foot the bill. As a result, the Financial District boasts some of the most expensive – and masterful – modern art in Canada. Gaze up at Canada’s biggest indoor mural, explore a secret garden, and learn about the city’s history through its architectural wonders. Don’t forget your camera or sketchpad! 

• Start at the controversial sculpture that kicked off the public art debate in Toronto in the 1960s   • Sketch or photograph water and rainforest plants in an art-filled garden   • Find a secret message inscribed on Old City Hall by its 19th Century architect   • Compare stunning skyscraper architecture through the decades   • Photograph Santiago Calatrava’s canopy of trees

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: In front of the main wooden doors of City Hall, Bay & Queen Streets, Toronto

team.bio: Your guide will be Sonny Bean, a Toronto artist and activist. Spot Sonny's cropped-cut & Walk T.O. hoodie.

accessible-info: We walk underground and use escalators, however there are elevators available for wheelchairs and strollers
accessible-find: Your guide will be Sonny Bean, a Toronto artist and activist. Spot Sonny's cropped-cut & Walk T.O. hoodie.

title: Wander through Wildwood: Discover Radburn in Winnipeg
longdescription: Wildwood Park is unique, planned by Hubert Bird in the mid-40s to replicate the Radburn concept in New Jersey. See how the original 5 house designs have changed in the past 65 years. Explore the natural wonders of this green space in the city.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Wildwood Community Centre - at intersection of Okenwald St. and North Drive

accessible-info: Weather dependent - suitable footwear, rainwear & umbrellas if necessary. Mostly on pavement and sidewalks - could handle wheelchairs.
accessible-parking: Parking on North Drive near the Community Club (not to be confused with the Wildewood Golf & Curling Club, which also has a North Drive address)

title: What if there was an alternative to riding your bicycle on McPhillips?
longdescription:
Riding a bicycle along McPhillips Avenue in Winnipeg’s northwest is not exactly fun. In fact, for many people, having to share a high volume, 6 lane roadway with cars, buses and trucks is a pretty frightening experience. Yet if you live, work or play in the northwest of the city, there aren’t a lot of alternatives to McPhillips for cyclists. Not surprisingly, this area has a pretty dismal rate of cycling, even by Winnipeg standards.

But what if there were an alternative to McPhillips for pedestrians and cyclists?

Lying just 400 metres to the west is Manitoba Hydro right of way with the potential to turn a stressful soul sucking commute into a leisurely, reinvigorating ride through the park (quite literally).

Join me as I take you on a tour of what might be the city’s best opportunity to get more people out of their cars and onto their bikes. We’ll start up at the Safeway at the corner of Jefferson and McPhillips, and wind our way south to Pascoe Park in the Weston neighbourhood. Along the way, we’ll contrast the traffic of McPhillips with the tranquility of community parks; witness the decline in neighbourhood connectivity that evolved as the city developed outwards; see how community gardens have transformed desolate spaces into hubs of activity, and discuss how a designing our neighbourhoods solely around cars has left us with a built environment that actively discourages walking and cycling.

The tour will include a mix or riding and walking, so you will need your bike for this tour.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Canada Safeway Parking Lot, Corner of Jefferson & McPhillips

accessible-info: The tour will include both a walking and cycling element, so a bicycle is required.  Short sections along McPhillips and Pipestone will be walked to avoid heavy traffic areas.

title: Crouching Tiger Hidden Station: How We Fuel Our City
shortdescription:
Fuel is so embedded into the fabric of the city that we hardly even notice it anymore. Gas stations blend into the background, and cars are commonly accepted as king of the road. 

But how often do we stop to think about where that gasoline comes from, or how it has shaped the geography of the city? What impacts does this fuel have on our environment?

Our Horizon will lead a one hour walk through some of downtown's gas stations to connect the dots between fuel consumption and climate change. Finishing off at City Hall, we will introduce our idea to turn the city into the focal point for action on climate change.
longdescription:
Fuel is so embedded into the fabric of the city that we hardly even notice it anymore. Gas stations blend into the background, and cars are commonly accepted as king of the road. 

But how often do we stop to think about where that gasoline comes from, or how it has shaped the geography of the city? What impacts does this fuel have on our environment?

Our Horizon will lead a one hour walk through some of downtown's gas stations to connect the dots between fuel consumption and climate change. Finishing off at City Hall, we will introduce our idea to turn the city into the focal point for action on climate change.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Esso Gas Station, the north east corner of Church and Dundas

team.bio: Penny is the Chief of Communications of Our Horizon, a national not-for-profit organization addressing climate change in a globally-unprecedented way. Our Horizon wants to put warning labels on gas pump nozzles just like those on cigarette packages. It is only once we've been made to face the reality of climate change that we will be able to take meaningful steps forward to address our generation's greatest challenge.

accessible-transit: Five minute walk from Dundas Subway Station, also on the Dundas streetcar route.

title: Compartiendo Inseguridad
shortdescription: El Centro Histórico de Córdoba se caracteriza por tener una morfología de calles laberínticas, donde la posibilidad de ver y ser vistos en algunas zonas, se ve reducida afectando a la sensación de seguridad...
longdescription:
El Aula propone un paseo para la detección de espacios inseguros, así como la realización por parte de los participantes de un análisis y diagnóstico de los mismos. De esta forma, se pretende una implicación activa de los asistentes durante todo el recorrido, finalizando con la formulación de propuestas destinadas a mejorar las zonas que abordemos durante el paseo.

Partiendo de esta intención, nuestra propuesta consiste en realizar un itinerario por el Centro Histórico, abordando en grupo algunos espacios que consideramos inseguros a ciertas horas del día, comenzando en el Convento de Santa Ana (Vimcorsa) y finalizando en la Plaza de la Corredera.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Convento de Santa Ana (Vimcorsa)

team.bio: Enlace biografía Aula Eileen Gray

title: An Alternative to the Broadway Subway
shortdescription: A bike tour of the 1st Avenue - CPR Right-of-way - 16th Avenue route for an alternative to the Broadway Subway route currently under discussion.
longdescription:
A bike tour of the 1st Avenue - CPR Right-of-way - 16th Avenue route for an alternative to the Broadway Subway route currently under discussion.

This route could accomodate a ground level Light Rail Transit system at a lower cost and a more rapid construction program than a Broadway Subway.

The bike tour will include discussions of the pros and cons of this alternative concept.

markers.description: Skytrain Millennium Line—VCC-Clark Station; Entry Plaza

team.bio: Adam Fitch is a professional land use planner with interests in urban design, development planning, transportation and transit planning.

accessible-transit: Skytrain Millennium Line to VCC-Clark Station, 84 Bus
accessible-parking: Pay parking available at VCC

title: Dorset Park Discovery Walk
shortdescription: Want a sneak peak of the city's newest Community Hub before its official opening? Interested in learning about one of Toronto's 13 priority neighbourhoods? Join local residents & leaders as we discover Dorset Park together!
longdescription:
Join fellow walkers and Dorset Park Discovery Walk  leaders at the entrance to the Dorset Park Community Hub (1911 Kennedy Rd) at 10:15am. 

The Hub will be both the start and finish of the walk (see map and route description below) - which will begin at 10:30am and is expected to last about 1 hour.    With a community fair to follow in nearby Thomson Park, our Jane's Walk will finish with ample time to make it to the fair for its noon start!

Getting there: The Hub is situated on the west side of Kennedy Rd, just north of the intersection at Ellesmere Rd.  There is parking on site (first come first serve), the Hub is walking distance from the TTC's Ellesmere RT station, and is further accessible via the 43 Bus from Kennedy Station or the 95 Bus from York Mills Station. 

Hub - Dundalk - Glamorgan - Antrim - Kennedy - Hub Circuit

The theme of this walk is focused on connecting the past to the present and future of the north half of the Dorset Park neighbourhood.  Weaving through side streets, walkways and a school and park nestled underneath the 401 - organizers will highlight local issues, challenge walkers to think about urban planning in the inner suburbs, and  connect the dots to a vision and ongoing campaigns for a more walkable and accessible future for all. 

Meeting place: The Hub - Introductions, brief discussion of the theme, and key questions for everyone to think about on their walk!

First stop:  Lights, signs & safety!

Second stop:  Glamorgan Community Garden

Third stop:  Walkway to Glamorgan School/Park

Fourth stop:  Antrim & Kennedy developments

Finish: Inside tour of the newly built Dorset Park Community Hub!

title: Savannah in the City
shortdescription: Tour High Park's endangered Black Oak Savannah to learn about its unique plants and intriguing animals. We will discuss threats to the Savannah and how people are attempting to save it from extinction.
longdescription:
Come learn  about the Black Oak Savannah, one of the most endangered ecosystems in the Province of Ontario. 

Toronto's High Park has 44 hectares of continentally significant Black Oak Savannah. What does Oak Savannah look like? Think widely spaced trees, tall prairies grasses, low shrubs and a  rich variety of wildflowers. Oak Savannah is also a fire-dependent ecosystem... come find out what that means! 

On this hike you will see:

  • Areas that were burned this April to ensure plant diversity  and openness
  • Huge oak trees
  • Migrant and resident birds
  • Native species of plants 
  • Invasive species of plants
  • Stewardship intiatives to restore High Park's Black Oak Savannah

Jon has worked at the Nature Centre for 6 years leading Family Nature Walks, naturalist clubs for kids, special events, teaching school programs and summer camps. Jon has also taught at Toronto Botanical Garden and Allan Gardens.

In the spirit of  Jane's Walk, we welcome contributions from the audience. We hope that this chorus of individual voices singing the praises of Central RPL will reinforce the importance and significance of this distinctive modernist public building in the downtown cultural and architectural landscape of Regina. We will conclude with a 5pm tour of teh exterior of the Masonic Temple next door with one of the Masons.

Gene Domagala is a very active member of his community.  Not only is he a local historian who regularly leads walks through various neighbourhoods of the Beach but he volunteers a tremendous amount of time to many worthy causes in his community.  He sits on a variety of boards in the community, is a regular contributor to Beach Metro News and has helped with countless initiatives around the Beach.  He was the first recipient of the Beach Citizen of the Year in 2001.  
Councillor Mary-Margaret McMahon is an activist, a realist and a champion of community and collectivism. A catalyst of change, she is a natural connector and fights hard for what she believes in.  Councillor McMahon is committed to nurturing the integrity of Ward 32 and this vibrant city through a sustainable partnership between community and councillors. She believes in uniting the city to face challenges together, where good things come from combined engagement and efforts. She’s loyal to citizens, good ideas and effective execution.   She also happens to have an affinity for all things spooky!
Local thespians will spookily entertain walkers along the way.  They are volunteer performers from Bard in the Park, a non-profit theatre company formed seven years ago by Anne Butler.  Bard in the Park is proud to be an annual part of summertime in the Beach.

title: Burlington Bicycle Destinations
shortdescription:
This Jane's Ride looks at two commuting destinations:  Central High School and the Burlington GO Station.  

We look at the good and the bad for bicycle infrastructure for people to get to these destinations.
longdescription:
Welcome to the second annual City of Burlington Sustainable Development Committee (SDC) Jane's Ride.  The Ride starts at 1:00 PM on Saturday, May 4 at the plaza in front of Burlington City Hall.
 
SDC focuses upon transportation cycling to work, shopping and everywhere else we go.  This ride goes ahead rain or shine because my boss expects me to arrive at work even when it is raining.  No special clothing or equipment is required.  We are just ordinary people wearing ordinary clothing going about Burlington.
 
The theme for this year's Janes Ride will be Destinations.  We will focus upon two particular destinations:  Central High School and the Burlington GO station. 
 
These two destinations should have high cycle mode share amongst people arriving there.  When I went to high school in Burlington, cycling was the dominant transportation mode share at Central High School and to a lesser extent at Central Elementary School next door.  This is no longer the case.  This Janes's Ride will look at how to turn this around. 
 
We will look at both good and bad practices.  The good includes the Baldwin Street permeable neighbourhood connector,which provides for what is known as "separation without segregation."  Then we will see how this Baldwin Street connector becomes a mere unusable stub at the hydro corridor.  That's bad! 
 
We will then go north to Richmond Road and see the "rat running" cut-through car traffic on the notorious "Richmond Road Racetrack."  We will see how the roadway design encourages dangerous driving which has the effect of terrorizing children off the road and preventing them from cycling to school.
 
Then off to the Burlington GO station.  Good includes the secure bike parking at the Station.  Bad is the lack of connection to the north to the Hydro Bicycle Path.
 
See you there!

Nous désirons parler de l'histoire du quartier Limoilou, amener des discussions sur l'écologie urbaine et sur les enjeux liés au transport actif.


Nous évoquerons la fondation du quartier formé au départ par 4 villages, nous parlerons de son évolution en regardant l'architecture propre à ce coin de la ville, quelques lieux célèbres seront pointés du doigt.  Nous profiterons aussi de la marche pour soulever quelques enjeux liés à l'environnement et à l'écologie urbaine ainsi qu'aux transports actifs.

Seguiremos por la calle Jesús y María hasta las calle Alta de Santa Ana para llegar a la Plaza de Jerónimo Páez, allí hablaremos de nuestro pasado romano y nuestro futuro, los/as niños/as, que por supuesto serán protagonistas durante todo el paseo, experimentando mediante le juego cada plaza, como no puede ser de otra forma... Continuaremos por la calle San Fernando hasta llegar a la Plaza del Potro, ¡que historia! y finalmente investigaremos un poquito más hasta llegar a la Plaza de las Cañas y a la Plaza de la Corredera, como fin o inicio de futuros paseos en familia.

title: Pie-Traspié
shortdescription: “Pie-Traspié”, se ha articulado en torno a inmuebles de gran importancia para el desarrollo de la participación ciudadana en el Distrito Sur de Córdoba. Algunos enclaves suponen un buen ejemplo de uso de lo público, propician “el pie”, entendido como el discurrir por las calles dinamizando el barrio. Otros son “traspiés”, zancadillas de un urbanismo que no cuenta con la ciudadanía. Son edificios vacíos de presente, que forman parte de la estética del descuido político y que castigan el paisaje urbano. “Pie-Traspié” invita a la reflexión sobre los equipamientos públicos y su proyección social en la ciudad.
longdescription:
La Culpable propone la ejecución de una actividad sociocultural consistente en un Paseo de Jane Jacobs en donde se analicen algunos edificios públicos del barrio, en uso o no, destacando aspectos históricos, funcionales y urbanísticos, su impacto social, económico y cultural y su proyección a corto medio plazo.

El PASEO DE JANE, “Pie-Traspié”, se ha articulado en torno a ocho elementos arquitectónicos de gran importancia para el desarrollo de la participación ciudadana en el Distrito Sur:

  1. Colegio Rey Heredia.
  2. Centro Cívico Arrabal del Sur. C/Santo Domingo de Guzmán.
  3. Local municipal en antiguo cine Séneca. C/Fray Pedro de Córdoba.
  4. Polideportivo Municipal. Avda. Cádiz.
  5. La Normal. C/Priego de Córdoba.
  6. Mercado de Abastos. Plaza del Mediodía.
  7. Local en alquiler (Piedra). Barrio del Guadalquivir.
  8. Antigua sede UGT. C/ Marbella.

Este itinerario irá conducido por personas del barrio, de tal modo que cada asociación vecinal que desee participar irá presentando a sus convecinos/as los edificios del itinerario que se localizan en su ámbito territorial.

title: Patios desnudos
shortdescription: Un paseo por los patios desconocidos de Córdoba, patios decadentes, olvidados, patios en busca de oportunidad. Conocer y difundir nuestro patrimonio es la mejor manera de preservarlo.
longdescription:
Un paseo por los patios desconocidos de Córdoba, patios decadentes, olvidados, patios en busca de oportunidad. Conocer y difundir nuestro patrimonio es la mejor manera de preservarlo. Visitaremos 2 patios desnudos y algún lugar de interés.

Córdoba, una ciudad orgullosa de su historia, vive paradójicamente de espaldas a un patrimonio histórico de valor incalculable, que ignora o desprecia.

Complacida en su belleza, y adormecida en el recuerdo de lo que una vez fue, vive una larga decadencia desde su último momento de esplendor, el periodo fugaz que va desde  la reconquista hasta el descubrimiento de América, en que los centros de poder se trasladan definitivamente hacia Sevilla y Cádiz. Esta lenta agonía ha permitido que la fisonomía de su extenso casco histórico haya pervivido inalterada, hasta finales del siglo pasado, aunque progresivamente empobrecida y finalmente oculta bajo el manto uniformador de la miseria más digna. Así, poco a poco, grandes casas señoriales, acaban convirtiéndose en humildes casas de vecinos, en las que vienen a hacinarse a mediados del siglo XX, los hijos del campo y la hambruna llegados a la remota metrópolis en busca de una vida mejor.

Estas grandes casas, caídas en desgracia junto con el resto de la ciudad, ocupan un codiciado suelo, sobre el que se abalanzan las promotoras, en sucesivos embates a finales del siglo pasado y principios de este.

Hoy, tras el estallido de la última burbuja inmobiliaria, la forzosa retirada de las grúas deja atrás un paisaje desolador, irremediablemente alterado, en el que inmuebles anodinos ocupan el lugar de los valiosos originales, conformando un decorado de pueblo andaluz para consumo del turista de parque temático.

Afortunadamente, la riqueza patrimonial de la ciudad se ha mostrado superior a la avidez carroñera de los últimos asaltantes, y la supervivencia de valiosos inmuebles aún permite entender y mostrar la hermosa ciudad que heredamos.

Es nuestro deber conocer y difundir este patrimonio. Sólo desde el conocimiento aprenderemos a apreciarlo. Sólo desde la difusión garantizaremos su pervivencia. Aprovechando el altavoz que supone el festival de Patios, queremos abrir las puertas de algunos de estos supervivientes, hermanos de esos otros que, con mejor fotuna, lucen todo su esplendor en esos días.

Son inmuebles vacíos, y en venta, sí, pero más allá de los legítimos intereses mercantiles de sus propietarios, esta iniciativa pretende alertar sobre su valor y su peligro cierto de desaparición, alentando además un debate de fondo que permita la preservación, revalorización y proyección de nuestro patrimonio histórico, que indudablemente está llamado a convertirse en el motor de la actividad de la ciudad.

title: Future City: Kalasatama
shortdescription: A glimpse into the future, as we walk around the unbuilt Kalasatama area discussing architecture, environment and the unfinished city.
longdescription:
The walk  into the yet unbuilt Helsinki starts from the yet-unopened Culture Sauna in Merihaka. Architect Tuomas Toivonen will tell us about the sauna and the thinking behind it.  We also study also the plans to the terrace houses across the bay.

Then we stroll along the shores to the Kalasatama area, where we familiarise ourselves with the new plans for the area, for example the towers around the metro station.

Kalasatama is a place where the old meets the new, in the event center of Suvilahti and the food center of Tukkutori. So appropriately the walk ends in Teurastamo, where we will hear about the plans for the new urban hub of Helsinki.

 The Teurastamo restaurant and food centre.

Jarmo Elukka Eskelinen has made his living by working in the city: as an architect, party organiser, media producer and smart city service developer. He is the CEO of Forum Virium Helsinki innovation company (which is the Jane's walk host organisation in Helsinki). Originally trained as an architect, Jarmo is an expert in digital content, smart cities and user driven design, currently devoted to open data. 
Jarmo cycles more than walks, and as a former DJ still buys far more music than he has time to listen to.

title: Greenbelt Walks the Don
shortdescription: Find out how we can expand the Greenbelt to protect one of Toronto’s most beloved rivers, and enjoy a sampling of delicious local food from a Greenbelt farmer!
longdescription:
The Toronto City Council is considering extending the Greenbelt along the Don River. Find out how this initiative will better protect the Don, one of Toronto’s most beloved rivers, and how you can bring the world’s largest Greenbelt into your city. Want to learn more about Growing the Greenbelt and new Urban River Valley designations? Keen to hear about what’s happening in the Don River Valley first-hand? Join us for ‘Greenbelt Walks the Don’. See some beautiful nature at the height of Spring, and enjoy a sampling of delicious local food from a Greenbelt farmer! Sturdy, comfortable (and waterproof!) footwear recommended.

We will be giving away free samples of Greenbelt grown salad mix from the lovely folks at Rolling Hills Organics - www.rollinghillsorganics.com!

Please note that this Walk begins at Crothers' Woods and continues to the Evergreen Brickworks Farmers' Market. The walk duration is 45 minutes; however, the walk does not loop back. Walking steadily back to the parking lot requires approximately  35 minutes. 

As always, all Jane's Walks are free and none require registration. However, if you'd like to let us know that you're coming (especially so we can ensure we have enough delicious salad samples) please click here to register on Eventbrite!

 

About The Don River Valley

The Don River is one of Toronto’s largest and most significant watercourses. Historically, the river was a prime location for pre- and post-colonial settlement as it provided food, fresh water, transportation, and later a convenient place for industry and waste disposal. Today, though the river is heavily urbanized, it remains an important part of the City of Toronto’s identity; both as a beautiful, natural oasis in the heart of the city, and a rich cultural resource in the history and sensibility of place.

 Despite it’s significance however, the Don River Valley, like many other urban watercourses and natural corridors, is struggling.  Although the headwaters of the Don are protected from further encroachment of development by the Greenbelt, the lower reaches of the river remain unprotected and vulnerable to unwise land-use. Through new Urban River Valley designations, Greenbelt protection can be extended to public lands along this fragile, incomparable, natural corridor in the city. Join us on this walk to learn more about the how and why!

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Loblaw’s Parking lot, 11 Redway Rd (the closest intersection is Millwood & Laird).

team.name-first: Shelley Petrie, Program Director, Friends of the Greenbelt Foundation & TRCA Staff
team.bio:
The walk will be lead by Shelley Petrie, Program Director for the Friends of the Greenbelt Foundation, and TRCA staff.

About the Greenbelt
For fresh air, clean water, healthy local food, and a thriving economy with good jobs, Ontario’s Greenbelt is the solution. At more than 1.8 million acres, it’s the world’s largest permanently protected greenbelt, keeping our farmlands, forests, and wetlands safe and sustainable. The Friends of the Greenbelt Foundation works to help keep farmers successful, strengthen local economies, and protect and grow natural features. To learn more, visit greenbelt.ca. Become a Friend of the Greenbelt at greenbelt.ca/friend!
Become a fan on Facebook and Twitter:

accessible-transit: Take the Bloor-Danforth Subway to Donlands Station and catch the #56 Leaside Bus - Northbound to Eglington Station. Get off at Redway Road and walk 400m west to the Loblaw's parking lot.
accessible-parking: Large parking lot, a lot of spaces close to the trailhead.

title: The Early Bird Gets the Walk
shortdescription: While the sun is still climbing, join us on a dog-friendly stroll to check out the newest additions to Toronto's transforming waterfront including the Underpass Park, Sherborne Commons Park, and more!
longdescription:
Join us on the first Jane's Walk of the day!  This is a dog -friendly stroll starting at the corner of Queen Street East and River Street in Toronto while the sun is still rising.  We will be checking out some of the newest additions to Toronto's waterfront urban landscape including Underpass Park,  Sherbourne Commons Park, Ripley's Aquarium and more. 

 

The walk ends at the lovely Spadina Music Garden and leaves us plenty of time to  enjoy the other Jane's Walks throughout the day.

Well behaved dogs on leash are most welcome!

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: South West corner of Queen St East and River St

team.bio: Nicolas Bello has lived in Toronto most of his life.  He is an enthusiastic volunteer who dedicates much of his time towards making the City an even better place to live for everyone.  He is an official Greeter with Toronto's Greeter Program and also helps new Canadians improve their English skills with Woodgreen's conversation circle program.

accessible-transit: Take Queen Streetcar to River St.
accessible-parking: There is limited on-street parking available nearby.
accessible-find: I will be with my yellow dog Woody and I'll be wearing a lanyard with an ID badge.

title: Un paseo sobre ruedas y... mucho más. Una nueva perspectiva del Casco Histórico.
shortdescription: ¿Has paseado alguna vez la Judería sin utilizar tus pies para caminar?  ¿Has disfrutado del Patio de los Naranjos utilizando tan sólo el sentido del oído y del olfato? ¿Has leído alguna vez un texto en un idioma desconocido? Si no es así, “Un paseo sobre ruedas y... mucho más” te va a dar a conocer diferentes maneras de caminar, ver y sentir.  Descubriremos cómo la ACCESIBILIDAD posibilita el uso y disfrute de la ciudad a todas las personas, y en especial a las que caminan, ven, oyen y piensan de manera diferente a la mayoría de la población.
longdescription:
Queremos ofreceros un recorrido por el Casco Histórico de Córdoba lleno de nuevas experiencias. ¿Has paseado alguna vez la Judería sin utilizar tus pies para caminar?  ¿Has disfrutado del Patio de los Naranjos utilizando tan sólo el sentido del oído y del olfato? ¿Has leído alguna vez un texto en un idioma desconocido? Si no es así, “Un paseo sobre ruedas y... mucho más” te va a dar a conocer diferentes maneras de caminar, ver y sentir. Descubriremos cómo la ACCESIBILIDAD posibilita el uso y disfrute de la ciudad a todas las personas, y en especial a las que caminan, ven, oyen y piensan de manera diferente a la mayoría de la población.

Os esperamos el viernes día 3 de mayo a las 6 de la tarde en la Torre de la Calahorra. Este será nuestro punto de partida, desde allí nos dirigiremos hacia la Mezquita atravesando el Puente Romano y las zonas de reciente urbanización. Haremos una parada en el Patio de los Naranjos, desde donde continuaremos nuestro itinerario por la Calleja del Pañuelo y Plaza Abades, hasta concluir por la Calle Cardenal González en la Ribera.

Te pedimos que por favor nos avises de tu intención de pasear con nosotros, para que podamos disponer del materia adecuado. Para ello, no tienes más que enviar un mail a la siguiente dirección: beatrizalcantara@turismoinclusivo.es.

Esperamos que este Paseo de Jane cambie tu forma de ver la ciudad, y contribuya a hacer una sociedad más solidaria. ¡Anímate!

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Torre de la Calahorra

team.name-first: Beatriz Alcántara, Javier García, Fran Reina y Márcos Vázquez
team.bio: Si has comprendido el sentido del Paseo y quieres saber  más sobre ACCESIBILIDAD e INCLUSIÓN, te recomendamos visitar los blogs  Turismo Inclusivo y Minusválidos de Córdoba. Además, te invitamos a conocer el mundo asociativo a través de la web de  FEPAMIC.

title: El convento de San Pablo. Un espacio urbano en continua transformación desde finales del siglo XIII.
shortdescription: Un paseo entre lo publico y lo privado para conocer el espacio urbano que está entre el jardín de Orive y las traseras de los edificios de la calle Capitulares. Allí se conserva parte del antiguo convento dominico de San Pablo de 1.241, junto al cual, esta previsto abrir la puerta oeste al jardín de Orive.
longdescription:
El propósito de este paseo es conocer un poco más lo que fue el convento dominico de San Pablo, hoy regentado por monjes claretianos, a través de los restos del edificio y de los patios que quedan entre el jardín de Orive y las traseras de los edificios de la calle Capitulares, en parte públicos y en parte privados.


Comenzaremos en la calle San Pablo, en la cancela de la puerta lateral de la Iglesia de San Pablo.


Visitaremos la iglesia y saldremos por la puerta del compás de la calle Capitulares, donde intentaremos reconocer la traza de la desaparecida plaza del Salvador.


A continuación entraremos en uno de los inmuebles de la calle Capitulares que tienen ventanas al antiguo claustro principal del convento, y que solamente es visible en su totalidad desde estas viviendas.


Por último, a través del callejón de Galápago, acabaremos el paseo en el patio público de acceso a la delegación de cultura, e identificaremos el lugar por donde está proyectado abrir el la puerta oeste al Jardín de Orive.


Os dejo una imagen con el trazado aproximado del recorrido.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Calle San Pablo. Entrada lateral a la Iglesia de San Pablo

accessible-info: Hay escaleras en el compás de la Iglesia de San Pablo

title: Idea Gardening In the Mabelle Park
shortdescription:
Tour the Mabelle Park - a once neglected thoroughfare that now serves as a
creative hub for the Mabelle neighbourhood. Find out more about our future
plans for park transformation and engage with MABELLEartists in the creation
of an on-the-spot performance piece based on questions, ideas and challenges
generated by Jane's Walk attendees.
longdescription:
Join MABELLEartists, community members and friends as we share thoughts and 
reflections as well as future plans for the Mabelle Park.  We’ll serve home made treats prepared by the Mabelle Ladies Cooking Circle and 
celebrate signs of spring in the Mabelle Park. 
 
Bring your questions, project thoughts and public space problems for a high 
speed and co-creative "idea gardening session" with our highly-trained and professional "idea cultivators". Together we might plant new connections, generate schemes
and generally get our hands dirty (metaphorically of course!) 
 
We'll begin our tour at the northwest exit of the Islington Subway Station.  Follow the signs to the "car park".  Mabelle artists and community members will be there to meet you - and we'll make sure we are visible!
 
Those with strollers might find the stairs difficult, but we'll help!  Cyclists welcome 
(as long as you can carry your bike up a long flight of stairs).  We'd rather not have dogs on the walk, but do love our furry friends and are easily won-over by very 
well-trained and friendly pups.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Northwest exit of the Islington Subway Station, follow the signs to the "car park". Mabelle artists and community members will be there to meet you.

team.bio: MABELLEarts brings together people of all ages, backgrounds and abilities to make art, tell stories and creatively transform the place that is Mabelle – a high-density Toronto Community Housing complex in Central Etobicoke.  For us, community arts is a collaborative process of creating culture with the hands, voices and dreams of everyday people. Together we talk, work, play, plant, tell, build, remember, think, sew, eat, celebrate, draw, sing and mourn, transforming indoor and outdoor, physical and conceptual, personal and collective spaces in and around Mabelle.

accessible-info: Accessibility: long flights of stairs, steep downhill sidewalks and broken ground (not accessible). For an accessible tour of the Mabelle Park please contact leah@mabellearts.ca to arrange it.
accessible-transit: TTC: Islington
accessible-find: Mabelle artists and community members will be there to meet you - and we'll make sure we are visible!

title: Yesterday's Papers
shortdescription: Toronto has long been one of the most competitive newspaper markets in North America. Primarily focusing on the period from the 1870s to the 1970s, this walk will feature the colourful characters, behind-the-scenes drama, and lost architecture of Toronto's newspaper business.
longdescription:
Toronto has long enjoyed one of the most competitive newspaper markets in North America. With no fewer than three major competing dailies at any time since the 1870s, Toronto readers are accustomed to a broad range of editorial viewpoints. Our papers have been run by a cast of characters including philanthropists, labour and social activists, political parties, comic strip enthusiasts, lousy businessmen, and Fathers of Confederation. The behind-the-scenes stories were often as dramatic as those that were printed in the pages of publications bearing banners like Empire, Globe, Mail, News, Star, Sun, Telegram, and World.


This walk will look at the sites where the news was produced, and how those sites were used as public gathering places, especially during election campaigns. We’ll reflect on the architecture lost when the cluster of newspaper offices around King and Bay gave way to financial towers. We’ll explore the circumstances under which some of today’s major dailies were born, and how nearly-forgotten papers died.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Southeast corner of King Street East and Leader Lane, in the parking lot across from the King Edward Hotel.

team.bio: Jamie Bradburn is a staff writer for Torontoist (and co-writer of the “Historicist” local history column) and “Ghost City” columnist for The Grid. He has long had an interest in the history of the local media scene, and has written several lengthy articles about the subject. He has never polished off a bottle of hooch while facing a writing deadline.

accessible-transit: Subway: King station, then walk two blocks east. Streetcar: 504 King, get off at Church, Victoria, or Yonge.
accessible-parking: There are pay parking lots nearby.

title: Transformaciones urbanas en el entorno del Alcázar y las Caballerizas Reales de Córdoba
shortdescription: En el paseo se visitarán los escenarios donde han tenido lugar importantes transformaciones urbanas a lo largo de la historia de la ciudad, desde su origen hasta el siglo XX.
longdescription: Este sector de la ciudad ha sido a lo largo de la historia el centro del poder político y religioso de Córdoba, vinculado a la importancia jugada por el río Guadalquivir. En el mismo encontramos una compleja superposición de recintos amurallados que finalizan con la construcción del barrio  de San Basilio a finales del siglo XIV. Dos edificios de primer orden,  Alcázar y Caballerizas Reales, dotan al lugar de un enorme potencial para la ciudad. En el siglo XX a pesar de su rico pasado patrimonial es objeto de una gran fractura, siendo atravesado por la carretera nacional que conectaba el sur de España con Madrid. Este paseo por el pasado nos llevará a reflexionar sobre las oportunidades que ofrece para el futuro desarrollo de la ciudad.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Entrada del Alcázar de los Reyes Cristianos

title: Saints, Sinners, and Success: Christ Church and Elbow Park
shortdescription: Commemorate the centennial of Christ Church with a walking tour in Elbow Park. Two chances to participate: Walk with Blane on Saturday or with Harry on Sunday.
longdescription:
During Calgary’s great boom prior to the First World War, speculators and developers transformed grazing lands and homestead farms into Elbow Park, and streetcars linked the new district to the city core and industrial areas. Chief among those speculators and developers was Frederick C. Lowes, a driving force behind Elbow Park and its Anglican church, which is now celebrating its centennial. Join Christ Church for a walking tour of the district and its rich history.

http://www.christchurchcalgary.org/ to listing of centennial activities

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: In front of Christ Church, 3602 8 St. S.W

team.bio: Blane Hogue is the Executive Director of Lougheed House, a National Historic Site located in the Beltline district of Calgary  operated by Lougheed House Conservation Society.

title: Connecting Ideas:Urban Agriculture, Local Economies
shortdescription: This walk will explore the connection between grassroots sustainability initiatives and those of government and business in Kitchener-Waterloo. How do we live sustainably and support local initiatives in our community?
longdescription:
This walk will explore the connection between grassroots sustainability initiatives and those of government and business in Kitchener-Waterloo. How do we live sustainably and support local initiatives in our community? How can we incorporate agriculture into our backyards, and advocacy into our lives? 

On this walk we will explore Little City Farm, hear from SmartGrowth Waterloo, visit urban chickens, and hear about the importance of supporting local farms.

El paseo de las sensaciones ya está aquí!

Tal vez no te hayas planteado la posibilidad de ir a un paseo guiado equipado con cualquiera de tus objetos de uso temporal o permanente que te hacen la vida más fácil

¿Te atreves a salir a la calle en grupo y recorrer pasos y pasos de ciudad con tu maleta o con el carrito de bebé sin tener que dejar a tus hijos con los abuelos? ¿y si te traes tus gafas, o tu carrito de la compra? ¿tal vez un paraguas? ¿y por qué no un bastón si para caminar así lo necesitas? ¿y un andador o una silla de ruedas?, aquí valen todas esas ayudas que nos permiten movernos por la ciudad y realizar todas las tareas que emprendemos de manera autónoma.

Con ellas descubriremos cómo llegar desde Costa Sol hasta la Mezquita atravesando La Cruz Roja y San Basilio e intentando hacer un Itinerario lo más breve posible y donde TOD@S podamos “caminar” y leer la ciudad, con los pies, con los ojos, con los oídos, con el tacto.

¡Por lo que os invito a un paseo lleno de sensaciones y sorpresas!

title: Hinge Park and Habitat Island at Vancouver's Olympic Village
shortdescription: Southeast False Creek Olympic Village is one of Canada’s leading sustainable communities, and Vancouver’s first comprehensive sustainable neighbourhood development.
longdescription:
Located on a 32 hectare, previously industrialized waterfront site in Vancouver, The Village on False Creek, Vancouver’s premier sustainable neighbourhood, exemplifies a new green infrastructure based approach to public realm through the introduction of restored natural environments into a highly urban community.

Because of the density of the community, a quality public realm becomes a critical component.  Strong sustainable principles were followed throughout the planning and design.  The public realm, which is comprised of Hinge Park, Habitat Island, a 650 meter long continuous waterfront park, and neighborhood streets, provide multiple and varied recreational opportunities while acting as kidneys for the neighborhood, cleansing stormwater runoff before it reaches the ocean.

Join us for the walk to learn about why Habitat Island and Hinge Park exisit, and how they are increasing the health of the water in False Creek.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Olympic Village Square

team.bio:
Margot Long is a landscape architect and principal at PWL Partnership Landscape Architects Inc., who is passionate about sustainable community development and creating great public realm projects in urban environments.

Roxy is PWL's official 'designer mutt.' She loves landscapes and is especially into place making.

title: Downtown Victoria Places and Passages
shortdescription: A discovery walk through urban plazas and connecting walkways in downtown Victoria, BC.
longdescription: We will explore a number of Victoria downtown plazas and walkways, observing how space is used, how spaces are connected, and the potential for innovative and positive changes in our shared spaces downtown. We will talk about what makes a successful plaza, or an uninviting one. What makes a great urban connecting walkway? The walk will amble through a variety of contrasting places downtown and conclude at a coffee shop where the conversation can continue for those who are interested. We will be joined by local graphic recorder Tanya Gadsby who will capture ideas and places along the way.

title: "Jugend-style" walk in the heart of Helsinki
shortdescription: If you want to see Helsinki from "Jugend" perspective and just have a nice walk around the city admiring it's beauty, this tour is perfect for you!
longdescription:
Often referred to as the pearl of the Baltic, Helsinki is one of the finest centers of Jugend architecture in Europe. The city is home to around 600 Art Nouveau buildings, the largest concentration of the architectural style in the region.

Jugend gems can be spotted throughout the city, with some districts built almost entirely in the Jugend style. Adjacent to the downtown area, the neighbouring districts of Kruununhaka and Katajanokka make for easy exploration on foot.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Senate Square, in front of a Statue of Alexander II

team.bio:
Jaana Konstantinova is an enthusiastic young girl, who loves Helsinki, it's architecture and history. Walking tours have been her hobby since she was a kid. She has been guiding some groups in Finnish, English and Russian languages during past years. 
Jaana will wear a hat ( the same you can see on the picture ) and will hold "Jane's Walk"-sign in her hand, so you will recognize her easily.

title: "Jugend-style" walk in the heart of Helsinki
shortdescription: If you can't make it on Saturday,you can join us on Sunday! And together we can have a nice walk around the city admiring it's beauty!
longdescription:
Often referred to as the pearl of the Baltic, Helsinki is one of the finest centers of Jugend architecture in Europe. The city is home to around 600 Art Nouveau buildings, the largest concentration of the architectural style in the region.

Jugend gems can be spotted throughout the city, with some districts built almost entirely in the Jugend style. Adjacent to the downtown area, the neighbouring districts of Kruununhaka and Katajanokka make for easy exploration on foot.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Senate Square, in front of a Statue of Alexander II

team.bio:
Jaana Konstantinova is an enthusiastic young girl, who loves Helsinki, it's architecture and history. Walking tours have been her hobby since she was a kid. She has been guiding some groups in Finnish, English and Russian languages during past years. 
Jaana will wear a hat ( the same you can see on the picture ) and will hold "Jane's Walk"-sign in her hand, so you will recognize her easily.

title: Walking through the Old Town history
shortdescription: We will walk and speak loud about how life in this part of the city has changed since the sixteenth century. Please join us and share talks about history, architecture and real estate speculation. This is an open call and everyone can contribute with their knowledge or questions about the areas to be visited.
longdescription:
We will walk and speak loud about how life in this part of the city has changed since the sixteenth century. Please join us and share talks about history, architecture and real estate speculation. This is an open call and everyone can contribute with their knowledge or questions about the areas to be visited.

Also we are going to stop in some iconic coffee shops, pubs and gastronomical societies of the zone.

The plan is to start at 10:00 a.m. with a hot chocolate at Chocolatería el Puerto (Puerto kalea 19), and also it would be fantastic that we could eat together at 14:30 pm (still to confirm the place)! The walk will end at La Casa del Vacío  (Iñigo kalea 15), where from 16:00 pm the artists asociation ZukZeuk presents cultural activities.

title: Urban Design in Historic Newmarket
shortdescription: Lessons learned from the past
longdescription:
This walk is approxamatly 2.5 km and will begin where Newmarket began, at the foot of Main Street. We will then walk up Main Street, into the historic residential area and through some public open spaces. We will conclude the walk right where we started, at the foot of Main Street at Water Street, which happens to be right next to Cachet Restaurant & Bar (great patio).

Stops will touch on:

- Historic urban layout and design

- Adaptive re-use of historic buildings

- New development considerations

This area of the Town is full of historic buildings and sites, so we will talk about a few of these as well.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: The foot of Main Street, at Water Street.  Next to the waterfall.

team.bio: As a resident of historic Newmarket as well as an urban planner / urban designer with a private consulting firm, Adrian is looking forward to highlighting the area from an urban design perspective to residents and visitors alike.  Adrian is particularly interested in Traditional Neighbourhood Design, pedestrian focused development and applying urban design practices which build off of lessons we’ve learned from the past.  Adrian is an active and founding member of the Ontario Chapter of the Congress for the New Urbanism.

accessible-parking: Parking is available at the public lot at Water Street and Doug Duncan Drive.

title: Summerhill Summerdale
shortdescription: Discover a 1920s English Garden Suburb that still enables residents to bird-watch, visit the oldest continuously occupied house in Toronto, and explore the natural beauty of Toronto's ravine system!
longdescription: Leave from the former North Toronto Station (now Summerhill LCBO); visit Woodlawn, the oldest continuously occupied house in Toronto, designed by John Howard in 1834; travel through Summerhill Neighbourhood and Summerhill Gardens, developed in the 1920s as an English Garden Suburb; explore the Rosehill developments that grew up following the completion of the Yonge Subway; visit Rosehill Reservoir, the City's first reservoir; birdwatch through David Balfour Ravine; and return to the North Toronto Station through Chestnut Park, one of Rosedale's Oldest and Swankiest Neighbourhoods.

markers.title: Meeting Place

team.bio:
John van Nostrand is an Architect and Planner who lives in Summerhill Gardens.
 
Michael Vaughan is a lawyer who lives in the historic Woodlawn House and whose grandfather developed Summerhill Gardens.

accessible-parking: Lots around the Sumerhill LCBO

title: Recycle Kingdom Walk
shortdescription: The East Calcutta Wetlands take in all the solid and liquid waste of the city and generates fish, rice and vegetables and sends it back. Join us to explore how that process works and where does all the waste we generate go.
longdescription:
The East Calcutta Wetlands take in all the solid and liquid waste of the city and generates fish, rice and vegetables and sends it back. Join us to explore how that process works and where does all the waste we generate go. 

The East Kolkata Wetlands (EKW) comprise a large number of water bodies located in the districts of 24 Parganas North & South. It is situated between 22°25' to 22°40' N and 88°20' to 88°35' E and adjacent to the eastern part of Kolkata bordering the Salt Lake township on the one hand and the upcoming new township at Rajarhat on the other. The multifunctional wetland ecosystem consists of an area of 12,500 hectares. It comprises 254 sewage fed fisheries, small agricultural plots and solid waste farms. Besides, there are some built up areas also. The EKW nurtures the world’s largest wastewater fed aqua culture system. The goods and services provided by this wetland include, in addition to fisheries, a very cheap, efficient and eco-friendly system of solid waste and sewer treatment system for the city of Kolkata, habitat for waterfowl and home for a large flora and fauna. However, because of increasing pressure of urbanization, change in the quality and quantity of the solid waste and sewer, as also human neglect, this site, presently a Ramsar site, is under threat from various directions.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Paroma Police Station

team.bio: Bonani Kakkar, India President, People United for Better Living in Calcutta (PUBLIC), an NGO working on urban environment and active citizenship. Former project and education officer for the World Wildlife Fund India. Responsible for starting and guiding about 100 nature clubs in eastern India. Has promoted the idea and practice of "good citizenship" in several PUBLIC-affiliated schools to the extent that young girls now take ideas and complaints directly to Calcutta's police chief and city managers. Holds an M.A. in public health, University of California, Los Angeles, USA.

title: Meet Me Downtown: A Walk & Talk About Inclusion
shortdescription: What makes for a vibrant, dynamic, safe & healthy neighbourhood and community? Exploring this theme for a 3rd year, this group is taking a deeper look at inclusion and how it contributes to vibrancy, energy & a healthy community.
longdescription:
This walk will explore numerous places, spaces & organizations in Downtown Kitchener that work at making sure EVERYONE is included in the civic life our community. You will learn what is offered by different organizations and what inclusion looks like to them on a daily basis. 

You will also hear different perspective on why inclusion is important to the health & well being of our entire community. 

Steps include an education centre, a community centre, your public library, a theatre and several community agencies.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Kitchener City Hall - 200 King Street West

team.name-first: Abdul Rahimi, Juanita Metzger, Santiago Grande, Sue Weare
team.bio: The Walk Leaders are all members of the Kitchener Safe & Healthy Community Advisory Committee. Each of them is active in any number of diverse community initiatives - cultural celebrations, settlement for newcomers, placemaking, crime prevention through social development, community engagement, neighbourhood building, student inclusion at school, LGBTQ community, civic participation..... and likely a whole lot more!

title: Jane's Walk Woonsocket
shortdescription: NeighborWorks Blackstone River Valley will be hosting a Jane's Walk. Downtown Woonsocket offers many different services that are overlooked by local citizens. I hope to utilize the principles of Jane's Walk to explore these services and share them with community members. I believe it is a great opportunity for Woonsocket residents to meet the owner's of the Main Street businesses and in time form a relationship in which every party involved benefits. Jane's Walk is also a fun and exciting way to get people to stay healthy and active throughout the warmer months.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Market Square Woonsocket, RI 02895

team.name-first: Shane Culliton and Antonio A. Rodriguez
team.bio:
Shane Culliton
 
Shane Culliton joined the NWBRV team in 2012 as a consultant working on the organization's Commercial Corridors economic development project. He seeks to combine his background in both the Social Sciences and Business to better the Blackstone Valley and has spent the last decade contributing to teams within corporate, small business, non-profit, and civic organizations. Shane has an MBA from Webster University and a Bachelor’s Degree in International Affairs from Northern Arizona University. He has been a resident of Woonsocket since 2007 and has quickly developed an appreciation of the area for both its aesthetic and historical significance. 

Antonio A. Rodriguez

Antonio A. Rodriguez joined NWBRV as a NeighborWorks AmeriCorps VISTA after graduating with a Bachelor's of Science in Political Science from the University of Rhode Island. He hopes to pursue a double masters in College Student Personal and Public Policy/Administration after his service as an AmeriCorp VISTA. New to Woonsocket, he hopes to bring fresh and fun ideas to the community and looks forward to serving as the organization's Community Improvement Coordinator during his service year.

title: Walk the Green Line
shortdescription: Walk the western half of the Green Line--a 5km hydro corridor through midtown Toronto--and imagine the electricity infrastructure as a continuous linear park. The walk ends with a community event and free BBQ: greenlinetoronto.ca
longdescription:
Discover the area surrounding the Green Line,  a unique place in Toronto; a truly mixed-use neighbourhood with a rich and colourful past that emerged from the receding glacial Lake Iroquois about 12,000 years ago. The walk will unearth the geologic, farming, and industrial history of this layered community, highlighting the infrastructural nature that frames its very character. This community grew on the peripheral of city regulation, when strict planning, building codes, and land-use controls were far more relaxed – when polluting industries, worker housing, local cottage businesses, and city infrastructure functioned cheek by jowl. Unlike the rest of downtown Toronto, this community does not hide its infrastructure: rail lines and electrical fields weave through the neighbourhood and create strange but fantastic spaces!

 In the past, the area was a centre of market farming, then manufacturing and worker housing. Today, much of the heavy industry has disappeared and the industrial spaces have been repurposed as spaces for artists, businesses, autobody shops, furniture galleries, and musical bands. Unlike other areas of the city that have made a full transition from industrial to creative, the area proudly retains pockets from each section of its urban history.

We will follow the park spaces along the "Green Line" from south of Earlscourt Park to Garrison Creek Park. The walk ends in Geary Ave Parkette (north of Dupont at Ossington) with a free BBQ, an exhibit of the Green Line Ideas Competition entries and community activities from 1-5pm. For more info: greenlinetoronto.ca

team.bio:
Hon Lu - bio coming soon!
Netami Stuart is a landscape architect and certified arborist with the City of Toronto’s Parks, Forestry & Recreation division. She is on the editorial board for Ground Magazine, the Ontario Association of Landscape Architect’s quarterly publication and is a member of the Advisory Board of Jane's Walk.  Netami has been involved in researching, designing and advocating for linear parks and paths in Toronto for ten years as a member of the Community Bicycle Network and Friends of the West Toronto Railpath.  She is an avid urban cyclist.
