title: Rethinking Car Culture in Downtown Kitchener
shortdescription: Explore some of the core themes of downtown transportation issues, while we tour Community CarShare stations and other infrastructure that helps us get around sustainably.
longdescription:
What role does transportation play in our lives?  How can we use transportation to improve affordable housing, attract talent for employers, move sound municipal policy forward, and reduce our carbon footprint?

We will address these themes and more in a series of conversations anchored by Community CarShare stations throughout the downtown.  The route will consist of a 4km loop.  Share your stories, concerns, and hopes about mobility in our community.  With fellow residents, we can explore the past and present, and imagine a bold and vibrant future of affordable, sustainable, and neighbourly transportation systems.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Kitchener Farmer's Market Piazza (300 King Street East)

team.bio:
Jason Hammond is President of Community CarShare, a non-profit co-op serving Kitchener-Waterloo since 1998.  With dozens of cars serving hundreds of members in a growing number of cities, the carsharing service empowers drivers to shift their focus away from the automobile.  While increasing their use of transit, carpooling, and active modes such as cycling, members retain access to cars when needed.
Jason also serves on the Climate Action Waterloo Region Transportation Task Force, and the GO Transit Customer Service Advisory Committee.  Twice a candidate for Regional Council, he maintains a focus on how urban mobility affects climate change, affordability, and neighbourhood vibrancy.

accessible-info: The route consists of municipal sidewalks and facilities.
accessible-transit: Route 7 stop at King and Cedar.  Many other routes within a few blocks.
accessible-parking: Free parking at Market Garage (enter from Cedar between King and Duke, using central stairs/elevator to access piazza).
accessible-find: Look for the Community CarShare banner on the piazza (front courtyard) of the Kitchener Farmer's Market.

title: Uptown Waterloo: Development Old and New
shortdescription: Walk by some of the oldest and newest developments in Uptown Waterloo, and think about what makes a vibrant, livable city.  Is it preserving heritage?  Is it active street frontage? Is it public space?
longdescription:
Walk by some of the oldest and newest developments in Uptown Waterloo, and think about what makes a vibrant, livable city.  Is it preserving heritage?  Is it active street frontage? Is it public space?   

We'll visit St. Louis School, the Red Condos,  @lex live-work residences, and lots of spaces and places in between.

title: This River I Step In Is Not The River I Stand In
shortdescription: Come explore the changing dynamics of the neighbourhoods of Riverside and Leslieville! This Jane's Walk will take us along Queen Street East over the Queen Street Bridge into the heart of Toronto's east side. We will explore how some of the areas and buildings have changed use over time, providing historical context of how the neighbourhood developed, its current state, and its future potential.
longdescription: Come explore the changing dynamics of Riverside and Leslieville. This walk will take us along Queen Street East over the Queen Street Bridge into the heart of Toronto's east side. We will explore how some of the areas and buildings have changed use over time, providing historical context of how the neighbourhood developed, its current state, and its future potential.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Queen St. and River St.

team.bio: Adrian Lightstone is an economist with HDR, a global engineering/architecture firm. Adrian has been a contributor to Spacing Magazine, The Globe and Mail, and Toronto Star on transportation related issues. This is Adrian's second year as a Jane's Walk leader.

accessible-parking: Limited

title: Meet Me at the Four Corners
shortdescription: Meet Me at the Four Corners walk will stop at alleyways, decaying buildings and vibrant ones, look at graffiti, public art, and mixed use and historic buildings. People who live and work downtown will give short talks about the city they see every day. Walkers are welcome to speak up and share their stories.
longdescription: With the desctruction by fire of the landmark Quinte Hotel this winter and at least two empty buildings in the core of the city, some think downtown Belleville is at a critical point in its redevelopment. This walk will stop at alleyways, decaying buildings and vibrant ones, look at graffiti, public art, and mixed use and historic buildings. People who live and work downtown will take the time to come out of their shops and homes to give short talks about the city they see every day and the history behind some of Belleville's most notable places. Walkers are welcome to speak up and share their stories.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Century Place (At corner of Bridge and Front Streets)

team.bio:
Orland French is a writer and publisher who appreciates the heritage buildings of  downtown Belleville. He feels the downtown area has a great opportunity to develop and capitalize on its history and heritage. Orland was president of the Hastings County Historical Society for 10 years and is currently past-president. He and his wife Sylvia live in Old East Hill and frequently shop and dine downtown. Their company, Wallbridge House Publishing, produces history and heritage books for clients. Before his publishing career, Orland was a parliamentary reporter for The Ottawa Citizen, political columnist for The Globe and Mail and journalism teacher at Loyalist College and the University of Regina.
www.wallbridgehouse.com

title: False Creek South
shortdescription: A short walk around a planned neighbourhood.  Conceived in the 1970's.  Built on the ideas of Jane Jacobs and many others.
longdescription:
A short walk around a planned neighbourhood.  What's so great about it?  Do people live aboard those boats?  Can we look inside the courtyards?

Conceived in the 1970's.  Built on the ideas of Jane Jacobs and many others.  Clusters of housing (non-profit, strata and co-op) and a school in a park setting.  Mixed income.  Family friendly. Very walkable. 

40 years ago this was considered an experiment.  A lot of people thought it would fail.  Townhouses built on leased (ex-industrial) land close to the heart of the city.  People living onboard their boats.  Low, middle and high incomes in the same neighbourhood!  Homes sited and designed on quality-of-life principles of the  rather than pure economics.

Was it a success?

Does it have a future?

Is this a heritage site in the making?

title: Riding the Rails in Red Deer
shortdescription: This tour will visit several significant existing and former railway sites in the central part of the city.
longdescription:
Red Deer's three railroads had a major impact on the development of Red Deer as the distribution, transportation and communications centre for central Alberta. The tour will visit several significant existing railway sites in the central part of the city, including the historic CPR railway station, the CPR river bridge, the ACR pillar and the railway park fountain, as well as former sites including the location of the home of Rev. Leonard Gaetz, the CNR river bridge, the CNR station, CNR and CP rail yards and facilities, the ACR wooden trestle at Kin Kanyon and the links between the railways. This is a long walk so please wear good walking shoes.

Joining us? Please email environmentalservices@reddeer.ca by May 3rd so we have an estimate of numbers.

title: A stroll Through Queen's Park
shortdescription: Starting at city hall and ending in Queen's Park, this walk with be a conversation of the sights, sounds and stories of this beautiful neighbourhood.
longdescription:
I’m not a native of New Westminster, but it has easily become my adopted home.  Years ago I moved to Metro Van for work, arriving from a small town in Manitoba.  I was drawn to New Westminster because it is centrally located and relatively small.  This compact nature makes the City’s neighbourhoods comfortably walkable, with amenities and services close at hand.  Its size also allows New Westminster to have a strong identity. The houses and streets of each neighbourhood quickly appealed to me for their sense of establishment and perceived longevity.   There is something comfortable about arriving somewhere new and strolling through a community that has a strong sense of place.  For me, it makes the city easier to connect with.

By luck I’ve always lived in close proximity to the Queen’s Park neighbourhood.  I’ve regularly walked through it on my way to work; travelling from Uptown to Downtown.  In evenings and on weekends I’ve explored the streets that travel across Queen’s Park; taking note of their names, numbers and even the pavement beneath my feet.  I’ve learned there are stories attached to many of these characteristics, and these stories connect us to the very fabric of New Westminster – stories of parks lost, community celebrations held, and people who have influenced the city from half a world away. I’d like to share some of these stories with anyone who will listen, but especially those like me who have chosen to make New Westminster their home.  I’d like this walk to be a conversation, to hear your stories and learn how you’ve connected with New Westminster, continuing the legacy of many who have decided to make this place their home for well over 150 years.

title: Vancouver in Toronto
shortdescription: This bicycle-only "walk" is inspired by conversations we've had with ex-pat Vancouverites who yearn for the outdoor adventure we find on our front doorstep back out West. Now that we call Toronto home, it's worth discovering how simple it can be to access the natural wonders this city has to offer. To celebrate Toronto's ravine system and it's natural wonder, you are invited to ride your bike along the full distance of the Humber River Trail.
longdescription:
NOTE: A bicycle needed if you are to join this walk. 

Relocated West Coasters often struggle to reconcile the "nature-within-reach" benefits of home with the "creativity-and-opportunity-everywhere" benefits of Toronto.  This walk is intended as a gift to ex-pat Vancouverites who might be struggling to access natural wonders. Of course, all interested parties are welcome to join. This TTC/bike/meander will introduce you to the Humber River Trail, from its trail head in the northwest corner of the city, down to the lake and then returning to Union Station, which is where this adventure will begin. 

The plan is to meet at the NW corner of Bay and Front, take our bikes on the subway and then the bus, and ride back south, completing a loop that should take a little under four hours. Specific details can be read below.

Bring your bike, helmet, water bottle, snacks and anything else you think you might like to bring along.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Union Station at 10:45 am OR Finch Ave W and Humberline Drive by 12:30 pm

team.bio:
Zahra Ebrahim is as active as they come. Her enthusiasm is infectious, and she brings her playful spirit to eveything she loves to do. When Zahra relocated her design practice to Toronto from Vancouver, she refused to be put off by this city's concrete facade, and to this day, continues to find new reasons that Toronto is a city worth celebrating. She doesn't know how to be lazy, but sometimes she'll sit still for a short while. 
Eric Rosenberg is a nature-inspired city-guy who runs his own education studio. Committed to his urban life, he continues to find meaning in the cycles of the seasons that help him make sense of the world. Taking notice that winter is  good time for stillness, whereas spring is more appropriate for getting new things off the ground. It leads to good flow, which Eric likes because he can be a bit more lazy. You can take a look at his 12 Season Calendar here.

(416) 456-4700 and/or (416) 995-9632 if you have any questions or need to get in touch.

title: Activate the GreenLine in Hollygrove!

longdescription:
Be part of the community-driven redevelopment of the Hollygrove GreenLine. Come see how this neighborhood corridor is being transformed into to a green park and community space. Learn about the innovative partnerships between public agencies, small community organizations, universities, cultural institutions and others that are working together to bring this project to life. 

Hear firsthand accounts of neighborhood history. Learn how the built landscape has changed over time.  Witness rebuilding in action. Share visions of how the GreenLine fits into its future. Wear your walking shoes and your Jane Jacobs glasses to explore stormwater management and urban farming in the heart of Hollygrove!

Before the walk be sure to make groceries at Hollygrove Farm and Market, and they'll keep them fresh for you during the event. A post-GreenLine walk grocery pick-up has been arranged!

longdescription: What is the relationship between University of Toronto and the City? How has this relationship changed over the years, and what can we learn about the University's vision for the future by reading its buildings and footprint in the downtown area? Our walk will explore the shape and form of the University at its edges, bringing together and juxtaposing the official tour narrative with new development projects in order to create a psychogeography of institutional and municipal dynamics.

longdescription:
Let's enjoy the city lights on our evening walk which will take you on a two hour walk through downtown Toronto, highlighting many places in the city with German connections - historical facts, modern presence, quirky connections and advice on where to find excellent German food and drink.

This walk is inspired by the mobile website  "German Walk Toronto", which was developed by the German Consulate General. It was originally outlined by Shawn Micallef, author of "Stroll" and Toronto Star columnist. Together they have set out to highlight the many contributions and cooperations - past and present - that link Germany and Germans to Canada's largest city.

Please note that this walk will be guided in German only.

title: University Campus 101 - Secret Spots, History Galore & Ghosts
shortdescription: Tour the University of Alberta Campus with Historian Ellen Schoeck
longdescription: This tour will begin and end at the Student's Union Building (SUB) on campus.  We'll start off with some nuggets of early UofA history, including the then revolutionary 1906 University Act, which founded the UofA, at the time the only Canadian University open equally to women and men by provincial law.  We'll then stroll through the heart of the original campus, where you will stories about Pembina, Athabasca and Assiniboia Halls, the original residences, and learn what the Cree inscription about the doors of Pembina means.  From there we will walk towards Saskatchewan Drive to view the four remaining Ring Houses, including the home of the first UofA President, Henry Marshall Tory.  We will loop back through the newest campus building to have a rest stop inside Triffo Hall, another of the first buildings, now renovated to LEED gold standard.  Next stops will be the Arts Building, Rutherford Libary, Saint Joseph's College, the first SUB, and across the street to end at today's SUB.

longdescription:
Often overlooked when we think of great neighbourhoods, Academy is one of the more eclectic and exciting areas of the city. Adjacent to Lakehead University, it is home to students, professors, older adults, newcomers, a place of worship for the Greek Orthodox community, and one of the best vegetarian restaurants/grocery stores in town.

Come join Elisa Coates and Rebecca Johnson as they take you on a tour of the place they love to call home!

title: Downtown Kitchener - Celebrating Our Past, Innovating Toward Our Future
shortdescription: Highlighting the transformation of Downtown Kitchener over the past two decades, this walk will start at the Governor-General's award winning Kitchener City Hall and will take you on a transformational journey highlighting what has been accomplished and what the future plans for the ongoing renewal of the heart of our city are.
longdescription:
September of this year will mark 20 years since the official opening of the Governor-General’s award winning Kitchener City Hall.  Many attribute that event as the beginning of the renewal of Downtown Kitchener.


A little more than 10 years later, Kitchener introduced it’s $110 million Economic Development Investment Fund (EDIF).  The fund was designed to guide the city’s next steps both in terms of downtown revitalization and it’s economic development strategy, leveraging the city investment with dollars from the private sector and other orders of government.

Our walk today will start in the City Hall Civic Square and will focus on the transformation that has taken place over almost 20 years and which will continue with the construction of the LRT multi-modal hub at King and Victoria, where our walk will end.  In between our walk will take us to the international flavours of Downtown’s east-end and home to The Kitchener Market all the way to the developing Innovation District in Kitchener’s west-end around the Lang Tannery building – home to Communitech, Google & Desire 2 Learn. 

Many new restaurants and retailers have come to downtown Kitchener.  How did  this happen?  Who can we expect in the near future?  Residential development is a key element of the downtown’s transformation as well.Wilfrid Laurier University and University of Waterloo have been a big part of the downtown’s renewal, and now Conestoga College is partnering with them and the private sector for the new Kitchener Digital studio.  What does it all mean?  And what will happen to the Civic Centre block where the expanded Kitchener Public Library is going and in the area of the LRT multi-modal hub.

So, if you are passionate about Downtown Kitchener, it’s importance as the heart of our City and want to be in the know about where it’s been and where it’s going to ensure Awesome Keeps Happening Here, then join us for what promises to be an exciting walk on Downtown Kitchener’s urban transformation.

team.name-first: Councillor Berry Vrbanovic, Rod Regier, Cory Bluhm & Hilary Abel
team.bio:
Councillor Vrbanovic has been on Council since 1994, and is Chair of the City's Planning & Strategic Initiatives Committee.  As a suburban Councilor who is passionate about the Downtown as the heart of our city, he has been on successive councils that have led the renewal of Downtown Kitchener.  Before that, he worked at the City of Kitchener at the time of the move in to the new City Hall.
 
 
Rod Regier is the City’s Executive Director of Economic Development .  Over the past few years, together with his team, Rod has led the implementation of the EDIF.  He has been the architect of the city’s cluster economic development strategy, focusing on things like digital media, technology and manufacturing. Cory Bluhm is the City’s Manager of Downtown Development.  Cory and his team have brought us the King Street reconstruction, Downtown Live arts and culture and most recently the Awesome Happens Here branding.  Want to know about something in Downtown Kitchener, Cory has your answers.
 
Hilary Abel is the City’s Downtown Marketing & Program Co-ordinator.  A member of  Cory’s team, she is about as passionate as one can get for all things Downtown Kitchener.  Talented on social media, Hilary works tirelessly to make downtown cool, funky and well, simply Awesome!

title: Farmington Historical Jane's Walk
shortdescription: Join us for a walk around downtown Farmington, led by local historian Brian Golden.
longdescription:
Join Farmington resident Brian Golden for a history-themed "Jane's Walk" through downtown Farmington at noon on May 4. 

Walks are taking place all around the country May 4 and 5, in memory of urban activist Jane Jacobs, who believed in urban design that fosters community. According to the Jane's Walk website, "There are only two rules: walks should be taken and given for free, and they should be walking conversations." 

The Farmington walk is also a chance for community members to get in some steps for the F2H Fit city-wide health initiative. Residents in Farmington and Farmington Hills have been challenged this year to "eat well, exercise regularly and have more birthdays". (Read more: F2H Fit Aims to Help Residents Drop 500,000 Pounds) 

Anyone interested in learning more about local history, sharing their own knowledge and talking about the future of downtown Farmington is welcome to attend the May 4 walk, which will start from the information booth at the Farmington Farmers and Artisans Market located on Orchard Street, just east of Farmington Road and behind Fitness 19. 

To learn more, contact Brian Golden, 248-701-8112.

title: Radical Jack & Other Historical Characters of Lambton North Side
shortdescription: All sorts of wondrous characters have a history here from Lord Durham (who brought responsible government to Canada) to George Lyon (the only person to have ever have won a gold medal in golf at the Olympics) to Robert de la Salle (who claimed the entire Mississipi river basin for France). Come learn about their stories and more on this rich social and historical exploration of the Lambton North Side!
longdescription:
Come meander along a 4,000 year old Aboriginal trail, walk in the footsteps of the great explorer Robert de la Salle, learn about the first school to have a dentist, among other stories! 

Historical maps and photographs will be passed around to provide context for some of the stories including the 1904 tale of George Lyons, the only person to have ever won a gold medal in golf at the Olympics.

team.bio:
Madeleine McDowell is a historian and storyteller who has lived here all her life. She recently helped to preserve the Lambton house and is passionate about helping people to understand - not just know, but understand - how the legacy of the past resonates in the present. To learn more about the Lambton House please visit . 
 
Joan Carrington is a local artist and historian whose family has lived in the neighbourhood for three generations. She loves to paint and is thrilled to be co-leading her first Jane's Walk this year!

city: San Francisco Bay Area and Oakland
title: Retracing San Francisco's Freeway Revolt
shortdescription: Jane Jacobs helped stop two planned-for urban expressways, one in Manhattan, the other in Toronto. San Francisco also had its own decades-long parallel struggle dubbed the "Freeway Revolt". This Jane's Walk will retrace the Embarcadero Freeway route to see some results of that Revolt.
longdescription:
As an activist, Jane Jacobs helped stop two planned-for urban expressways, one in Manhattan, the other in Toronto.

San Francisco also had its own decades-long parallel struggle eventually dubbed the "Freeway Revolt".

This Jane's Walk  will retrace the route of the former Embarcadero Freeway, along what today is Herb Caen Way.

During this walk a history of planned freeways criss-crossing San Francisco will be presented, along with the struggles to stop them from being built, or to tear down existing expressways.

As we walk the route, we will highlight the positive results and unintended consequences of bringing down the Embarcadero Freeway.

With the walk leader being from Toronto, comparisons between both cities will be made on the intersection of Expressways, Public Transit, Neighbourhoods, and Waterfronts plus the politics driving them all.

This Jane's Walk winds up in Chinatown ending in front of  the Central T Subway Station currently under construction.

This subway station is an important piece of a giant transit jigsaw puzzle that helps us to understand San Francisco's municipal politics.

( Photo Credit : Russell Mondy )

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Cupid's Span in Rincon Park. We'll meet at the footpath right in front of the Giant Arrow where it enters the ground.

team.bio:
Beginning with the first Jane's Walks in 2007, HiMY SYeD has lead walks all over his hometown of Toronto, Canada.
Including one Jane's Walk  titled "Retracing Stop Spadina", which retraces the route of  the unfinished Spadina Expressway.
"Spadina" would have cut many Toronto Neighbourhoods in half, including Jane Jacobs' adopted Annex neighbourhood.
HiMY is in the Bay Area completing a Documentary Film about Public Transit and Municipal Government in Toronto. It will include comparisons filmed around the San Francisco Bay Area.

title: A Slice of the West End
longdescription:
Join me for a mostly historical walking tour of the West End that will cover parts of Ellice Avenue, Sherbrook Street and St. Matthews Avenue.

Some of the buildings I will speak about include: Mac’s Block (former Ellice Café and Theatre); the first HMCS Chippawa; Sherbrook Pool; the first St. Matthews Anglican Church (West End Cultural Centre) and the present St. Matthews Church. Along the way we will pass home ice of the Winnipeg Falcons, where Standard Aero got its humble start and Guy Maddin’s quirky childhood home made famous in his film My Winnipeg.

The walk includes a peek inside some of these buildings. We start inside the former West End Library (now Daniel McIntyre / St. Matthews Community Association building) where refreshments will be served. We'll also see inside St. Matthews Church which is being converted into West End Commons. The tour ends inside Winnipeg Central Mosque.

title: Made in Kitchener: personal stories from our industrial past
shortdescription: Exploring Kitchener's industrial past through a digital storytelling walking tour of the downtown.
longdescription:
Made in Kitchener is an art project designed to both celebrate Kitchener's past and probe its future through personal storytelling.

Building on a series of audio interviews with local people who worked in the city's manufacturing industries – John Forsyth, Smiles and Chuckles, BF Goodrich and others – conducted in the early 2000s as part of the Industrial Artifacts project, we have uncovered the personal narratives of these workers and used them to engage the present-day "knowledge" workers in a larger and continuous community narrative.

Bring, or share, a smart phone with a QR scanning app. Meet at the Gaukel Street entrance to Victorial Park at 1 p.m. We’ll provide you with a tour guide and a guidebook for the tour. Prepare to walk, and prepare to engage with the past in an innovative way.

Project originally initiated to celebrate the City of Kitchener's 100th anniversary of cityhood in 2012. Made in Kitchener was made possible through a partnership: Dwight Storring, digital media artist and director of Latitudes and Longitudes digital storytelling project, Latitudes Storytelling Festival, and the City of Kitchener’s arts and culture unit.

markers.description: Gaukel Street entrance to Victoria Park

team.bio: Lori-Ann Livingston founded Latitudes Storytelling Festival, a volunteer-driven arts-based organization, in 2006. She is a writer, mother and sometime guest blogger, not necessarily in that order.

title: Home Town Path - kotikaupunkipolku
shortdescription:
A dive through the different layers of built environment and the nature in the Oulunkylä area.
Sukellus Oulunkylän alueen rakennettuun ympäristöön ja luontoon.
longdescription:
Oulunkylä and Veräjänmäki home town path - Oulunkylän ja Veräjämäen kotikaupunkipolku

This path guides you through the history and presence, nature and culture, architecture and people of the area. How have the different forces formed the neighborhood? What is the secret which has preserved the old villas in this area?

Oulunkylän ja Veräjänmäen kotikaupunkipolku esittelee alueen historiaa ja nykyisyyttä, luontoa ja kulttuuria, arkkitehtuuria sekä merkittäviä henkilöhahmoja. Polun varrella tutustutaan siihen, miten eri voimat ovat muokanneet kaupunkia. Miten huvilakaupunki on voinut säilyä pääradan varressa, kasvun puristuksessa?  Samalla tutustutaan alueen merkkihahmoihin Leninistä Schaumanniin.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: The Oulunkylä square - Oulunkylän tori

team.bio:
Pauli Saloranta is a city walk professional, who has developed the home town path concept from year 2004. Currently  51 paths have been realised in projects led or assisted by him, with the total length of 299 km. Along these paths you can find 1503 important points of interest in Helsini, Espoo, Vantaa, Tuusula and Riihimäki. The paths are published in the Internet, and over 100 000 flyers have distributed through different channels.
Pauli Saloranta on kehittänyt  kotiseutupolkujen ideaa ja toteuttanut sitä käytännössä vuodesta 2004 alkaen. Hänen vetämissäänja avustamissaan hankkeissa on koottu jo 51 kotikaupunkipolkua ja kolme kotiseutupolkua sekä yhdet fillaripolut yhteispituudeltaan 299 km. Polut koostuvat 1503merkittävästä eri alojen kohteesta Helsingissä, Espoossa, Vantaalla, Tuusulassa, Järvenpäässä ja Riihimäellä.
Kotikaupunkipolkuja on julkaistu verkossa ja niistä on painettu yli 100 000 esitettä, joita jaettu eri kanavien kautta.

city: San Francisco Bay Area and Oakland
title: Dark Age Ahead – The Wizard of O'Farrell Jane’s Walk
shortdescription: This Jane's Walk ties in ideas discussed in Jane Jacobs' final book published before she died, Dark Age Ahead, as seen through the lens of downtown San Francisco Neighbourhoods.
longdescription:
Jane Jacobs in Dark Age Ahead, identified five pillars of our culture that we depend on but which are in serious decline:

  • Community and Family
  • Higher Education
  • The Effective Practice of Science
  • Taxation and Government
  • Self-policing by Learned Professions

The decay of these pillars, Jacobs contended, was behind such ills as environmental crisis, racism and the growing gulf between rich and poor; their continued degradation could lead us into a new Dark Age, a period of cultural collapse in which all that keeps a society alive and vibrant is forgotten.

This walk will tie in ideas discussed in Jane’s last book she published before she died, Dark Age Ahead as seen through the lens of downtown San Francisco Neighbourhoods.

Please join this walk.

And maybe, just maybe you might meet The Wizard of O'Farrell Street !

title: Long Short Jane's Walk with a Doc to Yoga
shortdescription: When is a walk more than a walk?  Come with us and find out!  Walkability means good health and fitness (Walk with a Doc), good urban planning and good conversations (Jane's Walk), and road safety for everyone (The Long Short Walk).  Kicking off the United Nations Global Road Safety Week (May 6-12), this 2 mile walk takes us from Capitol Hill's Stanton Park to Constitution Gardens (near the Vietnam Memorial) on the National Mall and ends with free yoga at Yoga on the Mall.  Join us for conversations about community, traffic safety, health, public health, fitness, yoga, and more!  www.mylongshortwalk.org
longdescription: When is a walk more than a walk?  Come with us and find out!  Walkability means good health and fitness (Walk with a Doc), good urban planning and good conversations (Jane's Walk), and road safety for everyone (The Long Short Walk).  Kicking off the United Nations Global Road Safety Week (May 6-12), this 2 mile walk takes us from Capitol Hill's Stanton Park to Constitution Gardens (near the Vietnam Memorial) on the National Mall and ends with free yoga at Yoga on the Mall.  Join us for conversations about community, traffic safety, health, public health, fitness, yoga, and more!  www.mylongshortwalk.org

title: JANE'S WALK OF ST. GEORGE
shortdescription:
Sunday, May 5, 2013
2:30pm until 4:00pm
Free

36 Main Street South, St. George, Ontario N0E 1N0 (Brant County)
 
Starting from the St. George Museum & Archives - at the corner of Main Street South and High Street, St. George.
 
Lead by Cliff Jones and David Simpson.
Presented by the South Dumfries Historical Society.

The Jane`s Walk of St. George will follow in the footsteps... so to speak... of the three previous walks we have hosted. 

We will explore the history of St. George by highlighting the buildings we pass – and we will also explore the present and future of the village as we try to see things through Jane Jacob`s eyes.
 
She studied and theorized about communities that work - that are walkable and liveable –  where young and old fit in and participate in the daily life of the neighbourhood.

If you grew up in St. George, please join us and add in details we might have missed (or correct me when I get something wrong) –  and bring your ideas about what makes St. George a great village - and what could make it better!
 
The Jane's Walk of St. George is one of 100s of walks taking place around the world in honour of the memory and lifework of Jane Jacobs.
 
Visit the new, improved SDHS website at www.southdumfrieshistory.ca
 
Hope to see you on Sunday,
 
David Simpson

p.s.  St. George will be celebrating its Bicentennial in 2014!

title: Historic Workers Housing of Somerville, MA
shortdescription: Leisurely stroll to explore some of the mid 19th and early 20th century housing and industrial buildings that established Union Square, Somerville, MA as a place to both live and work.
longdescription:
Somerville Historic Preservation Commission and Union Square Main Streets invite to explore Union Square, Somerville, Massachusetts with us.  We’ll take a leisurely stroll to visit some of the workers housing built in the mid to late 1800s that forged the fabric of Union Square and established the neighborhood as a place to both live and work.  We’ll look at the elements that typify this kind of housing in Somerville, talk about the businesses these former residents once worked for, and discuss how this pedestrian-orientation of urban planning is returning to cities like Somerville.

The tour kicks off with a short award presentation from Walk Boston,  advocates for improved walking conditions in cities and towns across Massachusetts. The group is recognizing Union Square Main Streets and The Neighborhood Restaurant with a Walker’s Choice Award.

From our gathering point on the Union Square Plaza the group will explore these areas:

  • Emerson and Newton Street
  • Lake Street and Olive Square
  • Quincy Street
  • Summer Street

The tour concludes at Bloc 11 cafe where participants are invited to linger for refreshments and conversation.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Meet on the Union Square Plaza, Somerville, MA. In front of Precinct.

team.bio: Union Square Main Streets creates a vibrant neighborhood by enhancing the Union Square business district and surrounding neighborhoods through active community collaboration.  By highlighting the artistic and ethnic strengths of the neighborhood we seek to drive commercial and economic development.  We celebrate food — local and international, our own eclectic creative sensibilities, and the dense, unique fabric of our New England square that blossomed before there was such as thing as smart growth.

title: Where Sissieretta Walked (Morning)
shortdescription: Concluding a stunning three part celebration of the life and music of Sissieretta Jones—Rhode Island's internationally renowned Black Diva who lived on the East Side—this guided walking tour will illuminate where she lived, worshiped, schooled and socialized on College Hill.
longdescription: Sissieretta Jones, the internationally acclaimed soprano who was the first African American woman to perform at Carnegie Hall and called Providence home for most of her life, will be the focus of this walk, conducted by local historian Ray Rickman. The walk will begin at the Old Brick School House at 24 Meeting Street on Providence’s College Hill, where Sissieretta Jones herself attended school as a young girl in the 1870s, and will wind through the neighborhood to visit sites and buildings that were central to Sissieretta’s life in Providence in the early 20th century.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: 24 Meeting St.

team.bio: Ray Rickman is president of the Rickman Group, a consulting firm that raises funds and conducts management training for non-profits and small businesses.  He is a former State Representative from College Hill in Providence, and served as Deputy Secretary of State from 2000 to 2002.  Ray is considered a leader in the promotion of African-American history, and regularly conducts general and African-American tours of College Hill.

title: Long Short Jane's Walk with a Doc to Yoga
shortdescription:
When is a walk more than a walk?  Come with us and find out!  Walkability is about health and fitness (Walk with a Doc and Every Body Walk!), urban planning and conversations (Jane's Walk) and road safety for everyone (Long Short Walk for Road Safety).  This walk, on the day before UN Global Road Safety Week, will take us from historic Capitol Hill (Stanton Park, 4th & Massachusetts NE - meet at the statue!) to Constitution Gardens (Constitution Avenue and 17th Street, NW, along the northern edge of the National Mall) for free Yoga on the Mall!  All are welcome - bikes, dogs, strollers, everyone!  And remember, many of us are yoga novices.  Come walk and talk about community, health, public health, transportation, gardens, cycling, kids, yoga, and more. 
www.mylongshortwalk    
www.janeswalk.net
www.everybodywalk.org

title: Central-Cocoanut Neighborhood Scavenger Hunt
shortdescription: Neighborkids will lead an exploration of the Central-Cocoanut neighborhood of Newtown in Sarasota, Florida.
longdescription: In keeping with the local tradition of "neighborhood scavenger hunting," neighborkids will lead an exploration of Central-Cocoanut.  We will begin at Mary Dean Park on 15th & Central and neighborkids will set the route from there.  Everyone is encouraged to bring along cameras, notebooks, binoculars, magnifying glasses, bug boxes, tape measures, dog treats, sidewalk chalk, baggies, and whatever else seems potentially helpful for exploration.  We will end with snacks at Sarasota Community Studio.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Mary Dean Park:  15th Street & Central Avenue

team.bio:
Central-Cocoanut is home of the Neighborhood Scavenger Hunters - neighbors on a quest to explore all the great things in our home neighborhood, and to discover how we might increase our sense of connection and belonging in this particular patch of Sarasota, Florida that we call home.
While a few of us are grown-ups, most of us are kids. That's because our neighborhood scavenger hunting is all about following neighborkids' lead, since kids are naturally inclined to make friends, tell stories, and be curious, playful and exuberant - the very qualities that make for gifted neighborhood changemakers, community leaders, and social innovators.
Summertime is "scavenger hunting season" in our neighborhood. That means that each week, we set out on foot, scooter or bike, with our toys in tow, and explore another block in our neighborhood. We meet people who live or work here, find all sorts of fun ways and places to play, and keep an eye out for fellow neighborkids. We snap pics as we go and afterward we write up stories of our adventures, both to remember our discoveries and to share them with everybody else in our neighborhood and community. We hope this will help us all to better tune in and recognize all that's going on around here these days, so that we can make the most of opportunities as they arise and also respond to upsetting stuff as it happens.
Community development professionals call neighborhood scavenger hunting an innovative approach to ASSET-MAPPING. We say it’s something we do together as neighbors because it's fun, and we love it here, and we are explorers and inventors at heart. It is not a formal service program. It is not an "out-of-school time initiative." It is about being neighbors together, with intention and awareness. 
In 2013, neighbors established Sarasota Community Studio as a creative space in Central-Cocoanut where neighbors come together to invent powerful approaches to community change by following the lead of neighborkids.  For more details, please visit www.sarasotacommunitystudio.org

accessible-find: Curious and joyful neighborkids who look like they are getting ready for a real-deal adventure

title: Mount Pleasant History and Urbanism
shortdescription: Join us for a trip down memory lane and learn about the urban design principles that shaped historical Mount Pleasant, Vancouver's original suburb.
longdescription:
Join us for a trip down memory lane with a Heritage Walk in Mount Pleasant, Vancouver's original suburb. Find out about the urban design principles that shaped the evolution of this historic neighbourhood.

In addition to visiting landmark buildings such as the 101 year-old Quebec Manor, the Lee Building, the tour will touch Belvedere Court, Ashnola Apartments, Crosbie Block, Wenonah Apartments and the Royal Bank's building. Other points of interest are apartment blocks on Quebec Street, a few rowhouses, Brewery Creek and Watson Street.

The tour will conclude at a local coffee shop - please feel free to join us after the walk!

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Quebec Manor, 101 East 7th, Vancouver, BC

team.name-first: Lewis N. Villegas, Robert McNutt and RAMP
team.bio:
Urban Design Specialist Lewis N. Villegas is a resident of Mount Pleasant. He has studied the history and evolution of the neighbourhood over the years, and has explored how urban design principles apply to Mount Pleasant. Lewis Villegas is a guest speaker and lecturer appearing at a number of events such as the City Shaping Growth and Land Use Workshop in North Vancouver earlier this year.
Robert McNutt has lived and worked in Mount Pleasant for 19 years. He is an avid antique collector and has done significant original research on Vancouver's Heritage.
 This walk is done in coordination with Residents Association Mount Pleasant (RAMP). RAMP can be contacted at info@rampvancouver.com (website at www.rampvancouver.com).

accessible-transit: 99B-Line bus or 9 Trolley bus to Main & Broadway, and walk one block west to Quebec and two blocks north to East 7th Avenue. Alternately, take the Skytrain to Main Street Station and take the #3 Main Street Trolley bus to 8th, and walk one block west to Quebec and one block north to 7th. The #19 and #8 Trolleys stop at 8th and Kingsway.

title: Byvandring på Filipstad og i nabobydelene
shortdescription:
Vi utforsker byutviklingsområdet på Filipstad og ser på hvordan den nye bydelen kan integreres med eksisterende by. Møt opp lørdag 4. mai kl.12:00 på hjørnet av Løkkeveien og Huifeldtsgate, utenfor Galleri Vepsebolet (Løkkeveien 11). Turen avsluttes kl 14.00 på en kafe i nabolaget.

Vandringen er gratis. Meld deg helst på til epost audun.engh@gmail.com , eller møt evt. bare opp.

Vandringen ledes av medlemmer av fagtamet for Filipstad-plansmia, bl.a. Kjell-Høy-Pettersen, Niels Torp Arkitekter, en av arkitektene som arbeidet sammen med representanter fra frivillige organsiasjoner under plansmia i 2012, og produserte en alternativ byplan. Audun Engh som organiserte medvirkningsprosessen under plansmia deltar også.
longdescription:
Som i fjor arrangeres "Jane's Walk"! Det blir byvandring på Filipstad og i nabobydelene Ruseløkka-Skillebekk.


PROGRAM: Etter en kort introduksjon starter med å studere gateløpene fra byen som bør videreføres på Filipstad, særlig Huitfeldtsgate og Parkveien. Vi går Munkedamveien til Tinkern, og kommer gjennom denne parken ned mot Frognerstranda og Color Lines fergeterminal. Vi diskuteter hvordan det kan forhindres at terminalen blir en barriere mot sjøen. PBE og Havnevesenet vil utvide nåværende terminal. Plansmia har foreslått en sammenhengende park fra Tinkern til Filipstad, med fergeterminal flyttet ut på tuppen av Filipstad, og plassert under et parklokk. Deretter tar vi for oss utbyggingsområdet på Filipstad, og sammenligner forslagene fra Plan- og bygningsetaten, Havnevesenet og Plansmia når det gjelder gatenettverk og bebyggelse. Vi får en innføring i de ulike forslagene til tunnelløsninger for E18, som Vegvesenet nå skal utrede.

Det arrangeres Jane's Walk årlig i mange land, inspirert av forfatteren og byaktivisten Jane Jacobs, som organiserte motstand mot riving og ødeleggende byfornyelse i New York på 60-tallet. Hun har siden inspirert både aktivister og fagfolk over hele verden. Les mer on Jane`s Walk her: http://www.janeswalk.net/index.php/about/

Det er forøvrig uavklart om Plansmias forslag til byplan vil bli fremmet til politisk behandling senere i vår på en måte som gir de folkevalgte reelle valgmuligheter når reguleringsplan skal vedtas. Plansmias forslag støttes av bl.a. et enstemmig Bydelsutvalg på Frogner, Oslo Byes Vel, Kontakturvalget for Velforeninger i Oslo og Norges Naturvernforbund - Oslo.

Filipstad et er stort utbyggingsprosjekt, og siste mulighet til å relisere de mange gode intersjonene i Fjordbyplanene, som levedne bydeler, park i sjøkanten og god tilknytning til omkringliggende eldre bydeler.

Du kan lese mer om planene for Filipstad:
Plansmias forslag:
http://www.allgronn.org/plansmie-filipstad.html
PBE og Havnevesenets forslag:
http://www.prosjekt-fjordbyen.oslo.kommune.no/delomrader/article18808-5743.html

city: San Francisco Bay Area and Oakland
title: The Jane Jacobs Oakland Wiki Walk
shortdescription: This Jane's Walk through Downtown Oakland is based upon Oakland Wiki's crowd-sourced pages.
longdescription:
We will walk through several streets that are the sites of Oakland’s history from its founding up to the present.

Knowledge gleaned from the pages of Oakland Wiki will be presented at stops throughout this two hour walk :

  • Legacy of Horace W. Carpentier - Oakland's first mayor on the city today
  • What ever happened to Harrison Railroad Park ?
  • History of Chinatown and Old Historic District
  • Oakland Police Department - The Good. The Bad. And some stuff in-between.
  • Oakland's Oldest News Stand
  • The Great Wall of Oakland
  • How Art Murmur became First Fridays

And much, much more!

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Lake Merritt BART Station - street level main entrance facing the park.

team.bio:
Beginning with the first Jane's Walks in 2007, HiMY SYeD has lead walks all over his hometown of Toronto, Canada.
Currently visiting the San Francisco Bay Area, HiMY has been editing pages on Oakland Wiki and learning about Oakland and The East Bay.

title: Ambient Electronic Music Walk Along The Waterfront
shortdescription: Enjoy the sweet sounds of music on this self-guided Jane's Walk while taking in the sights of the Toronto's Waterfront.
longdescription:
This Jane's Walk is designed around my new album, Major Over Minor, but it can be enjoyed while listening to any of your favorite artists! 

Show up ANY TIME between 5 pm - 7 pm  at the foot of Front Street and Portland Street (at the entrance to the yellow bridge.) You will be given a map and instructions, then you plug in your headphones and enjoy!

After the walk, we all meet at The Old York Pub (167 Niagara Street) where you will be treated to a complimentary beverage while hanging out and celebrating the release of my new album Major Over Minor which will be capped off by a live music performance by myself and Chris Gartner.

For more information on - and to listen to - my album, check out my website!

Kids, dogs, friends and family are all welcome. 
And it's FREE.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Foot of Front Street and Portland Street

team.bio: Morgan Doctor is a local music and drummer who moved from her native LA to Toronto in 1999 and has since been a highly sought after session player as well as private drum teacher, having played over a thousand dates all over the US, Canada and Europe and have played with such artists as: Andy Kim (30 million records sold), The Cliks (Warner/Tommyboy), Ron Sexsmith, Lights, Alex Lifeson and The Tea Party. Some artists Morgan has been billed alongside—on tour throughout the U.S. and Canada—include Cyndi Lauper, B-52’s, Tegan and Sara, The Cult, The New York Dolls, Indigo Girls, the Gossip, Dresden Dolls, Debbie Harry, The Stars, Feist and plenty others.

title: Harbord Village East (Reprise Walk for Door's Open)
shortdescription: Explore Harbord Village East in this two-part series on Jane's Walk and Doors Open!
longdescription:
Harbord Village, enclosed by Bloor, Spadina, College, Bathurst, is a neighbourhood of late 19C and early 20C homes (about one quarter of which are members of Harbord Village Heritage Conservation District.) It is bounded by a diversity of retail, dining and entertainment venues and is close to the University of Toronto, Queens Park, Kensington Market, Little Italy and Chinatown.

The 2:00pm walk explores the eastern half of Harbord Village, south to College then north-east to finish at Trinity-St Paul's United Church at Bloor St W and Robert St at 4:00pm.

This is a Doors Open Toronto Jane's Walk, with a first leg of the tour on May 4th or 5th!

title: Story Planet Presents: The Youth Walk-and-Write Tour of Bloordale Village
shortdescription: Grab your notebooks and join us this interactive walk inspired by the rapidly changing neighbourhood of Bloordale!
longdescription:
Bloordale Village is often considered a “rapidly changing neighborhood” but how do these changes affect your day-to-day experiences?  Art galleries, cafés and bike stores are speckled between fruit markets, cheap hole-in the-wall restaurants, Bloor C.I. and an abandoned elementary school.  

Grab your notepads and become inspired with a walk through Bloordale Village. What captures your eye?    How do you think your community is being “transformed?” What would you change about your community? What would you want to keep the same? 

This tour is interactive and bring your best stories about Bloordale Village to swap.  We’ll have time for writing, and you’ll walk away with a poem or flash short story, and who knows, maybe inspiration for a larger piece.

markers.title: Meeting Place
markers.description: Story Planet's Intergalactic Travel Authority 1165 Bloor Street West

team.bio:
Imagine being a kid with big ideas, but with no way to share them with the world. Or, being a teenager who is struggling in school with writing assignments, feeling like their future is a waste of time. Whether they are English language learners or struggling with self-expression, our schools and communities are overflowing with kids like these.
Based in Toronto, Story Planet is a non-profit that offers free workshops to support children and youth (ages 6-18) in becoming creative and effective communicators.  By combining creative writing projects with art, we approach writing and reading with excitement.  For many kids who struggle with writing, having a visually creative side to the work enables them to launch their imaginations and get their words flowing. Once writing is fun, it is far less daunting. Often a few small successes are all a child needs to boost their confidence and understand the importance of strong communication skills. From there, the future looks brighter.
Story Planet is inspired and mentored by our friends at 826, a national writing centre for children founded by author, Dave Eggers and educator, Ninive Calegari.

accessible-parking: Plenty of street parking available.
